title: Fits in your hand, works with Fire Phone, loud volume, can accept & make calls through phone text: I was very surprised at how powerful this little pod speaker actually is - it really does have a significant amount of volume and can be used in your car if you don't have a blue-tooth enabled system (for example my Mother's 10 year old Suburban out at the ranch) or at the barn when working horses in the round pen or dressage arena. It works via a standard blue-tooth connection or using the NFC option if your smart phone is equipped. There is also a microphone built in and the speaker does in fact, work very well with phone calls - we placed and received two calls using this as a speaker phone and the calls were a tad "tinny", but if you need to speak to someone hands free while cooking a meal or grooming a horse and you don't want a traditional headset, this is an excellent option.

I tested this speaker both inside and outside and it kept the signal from my Amazon Fire Phone almost 60 foot away outside in a direct line of sight with no degradation playing music. Inside the house, it managed to retain a strong signal through a closed door for about 30 feet before it lost the connection and that was far better performance than a no name blue tooth speaker we bought at Hastings in December. Sound quality is pretty good with both classical and country music. Pop can be a bit hollow at upper volume levels and hard rock has reasonable bass sound, but the vocals tend to become somewhat shrill to my ears. This is not a big deal in the least - just turn down the volume and know that at this price range you're buying the idea of portability rather than some super hi tech music snob gizmo.

Connecting this TechMatte Sound Pod to my Amazon Fire phone was super easy & took literally 10 seconds via NFC. It also connected just as easily to a Samsung Galaxy S2 and a Samsung Galaxy Note 1st Generation. My one complaint is that the on/off switch is directly over the charging outlet, so you have to disconnect the charging cable to turn it on or off and then reconnect the cord if you need it to charge or want to power it via the outlet while in use. A minor irritant that is at most worth a half star deduction. Overall, this is a very nice portable speaker that does exactly what it claims to do and fits in the palm of your hand. I did receive a sample speaker to test and review.

title: Excellent product. I had a little difficulty setting it ...
text: Excellent product.  I had a little difficulty setting it up initially because of a conflict in my wifi system, but customer service talked me through it nicely.  Great sound.  I will be buying more units to cover different rooms.

title: Great battery life...little bit of a learning curve! text: I bought the Samsung Chromebook with the idea in mind that it was even smaller than my laptop and would work great to read books on the go without having to drag along my kindle as well as my phone as well as...blah blah blah. Sometimes I honestly feel like all of my various devices turn me into a walking satellite receiver. The first thing I took note of when using the chromebook for the first time was how easy it was to set it up and make it personal. There is a handy one screen guide to walk you through the process. It is all pretty straight forward and if you are a user of google chrome, you pretty much have it in the bag already.

I set up the chromebook and downloaded the apps I would need to use offline and found the process simple and satisfying. Typing on the chromebook is pretty much the same as on any other keyboard with the noted exception that the keys have somewhat large spaces between them which can cause my typing to be a little awkward since I am used to my laptop where the keys are all close together.

The screen has beautiful even illumination and the apps download very quickly. It was a bit of a change to go from windows to the google operating system and took me a few days to organize things to where I could easily access them and remember where I put them.

As for battery life, this thing rocks! I have used this thing for seven hours before and still had it estimate that I had over an hour left. Mostly I use the chromebook for business applications and perusing the web for my job so I have not had to much experience playing movies on it or listening to music. I don't do much with multimedia.

So far it was a great purchase and I have been thrilled with it after a month of use. If you are looking for a lightweight, portable device to fill your basic needs, this is an excellent choice.

title: Syncs all Google stuff correctly, long battery, weighs nothing text: These Chromebooks are a weird hybrid of tablet and real laptop. They don't do everything can full laptop does, but they do more than a simple tablet. Oddly enough, there is a place for these. This is the second one we've had in the last few years.

This one is very light and easy to grab and use in the armchair or while on the road in the passenger seat. The screen is vibrant and the colors are true when watching a movie or looking at your photos. The beauty of a Chromebook is having super easy access to everything stored in your existing Google cloud account - photos, books, passwords, contacts, email, etc. This syncs exactly like your phone and tablets do so you can switch between machines and still keep current.

I've been pleased with the battery life on the Acer. It can go with light use and sleep mode a couple of days before needing to be charged. It has no trouble connecting to and staying connected to our WiFi even outside on the patio. I've connected my Bluetooth headphones and watched a movie with it and it works fine. I like this and find I'm grabbing it more often than I thought I would.

title: Five Stars
text: We love them.

title: Solid ergonomics text: I have tried quite a few wireless keyboard and mouse combos, and it seems usually I have to compromise on either ergonomics, build quality, wireless capability, or budget.
This set really impressed me. It supports two Bluetooth connections as well as using the wireless dongle for a straight USB connection, and you can easily swap between them. I prefer the dongle because bluetooth won't wake up my computer when it goes to sleep (since BT also goes to sleep), and I can easily plug the dongle into something like a mini PC without having to get ANOTHER wired keyboard to pair it first.
Yet, it has a palm rest and split keys for ergonomic typing, plus the mouse is the taller bulb shape that fits in your hand better and feels like a substantial work tool. I'm used to only expensive wired ones feeling this good.
I have to admit, I'm out of practice typing ergonomically so I still sometimes try to hit the B key with my right hand, but that's on me. The B is on the left side here, which it should be, but I'm quickly getting used to it. This review is being typed out on it and so far I'm really liking it with my standing desk setup!

I'm not blaming Dr Cool yet since it did help drop the immense heat down a tad.  Go buy something else, or try my next route...buy another router and use this solely as a modem.  My mechanical engineer best friend said that fixed his issues.

title: Compact in size, good grip and good pictures text: This is our first super zoom camera, up form our usual point and shot. We were not ready for the SLR and the weight of of lenses. So for amateur photographers, what do we think after playing with the camera for a couple of months:

Pro
1. Love the handle of the body, very compact, good rubber grip and relatively light given the lense;
2. There is a zoom on the left side of the lense: love it since we noticed the zoom function is a lot smoother than when using the usual zoom button;
3. Quality of pictures were very sharp even when using the zoom to its max. Especially with a blue sly backdrop, we were amazed with the contrast of the subject matter.
4. Video was less impressive, could be quite grainy when using the zoom to the max:
5. The screen dispaly has a feature where it can extend such that when you are taking a picture/video of a subject high up, it permits your head to stay level without over craning your neck! A plus. Or if you want to take a picture over a crowd!
6. Certainly a great camera for the price and we looked at the Sony at the time and it couldn't compete with the design and features. Great step up for someone who had a point and shot!

Con: just one for us, we found the view of the subject matter on the display and what was actually taken was a little off and we had to comepensate for it when we were taking apicture. The actual picture was lower by a centimeter from what you view on the display. Not good.

title: Extreme Speed Memory Card Requires Compatible SDXC Device text: To use this SANDISK EXTREME UHS-I SDXC memory card the way it's intended (for advanced photography), you need an SDXC device (camera or camcorder). You also need an SDXC device that's compatible with this new, latest SDXC format. I was disappointed to learn that my older Panasonic Lumix DMC-LX2 camera, which is compatible with many SDXC memory cards, is NOT able to recognize and use this memory card.

A word of warning: If your SDXC or other device is incompatible with this SDXC card, the device may suggest that you format the card. Do not do this! Formatting will ruin the card as an SDXC card. SDXC devices are backward compatible (and can accept SDXC, SD, or SDHC memory cards), but SDXC cards should be used only in SDXC devices. (To learn more about the do's and don'ts of SDXC memory cards, you can Google "SD Association Using SDXC memory cards".) If you have a Panasonic camera, you can find a list of cameras that are compatible with SDXC on the Panasonic web site. Presumably other camera manufacturers' web sites have similar lists.

Although this card doesn't work in my camera, it can be accessed with a USB reader or adapter that is SDXC-compatible; or through a WinXP, WinVista, or Win7 PC card reader slot, if the PC has the exFAT file system update (KB955704) that can be downloaded from the Microsoft Download Center. My fairly recent Win7 PC (ASUS Essentio Series) is not compatible with the above file system update, but already had a driver that enabled it to access the SDXC card without formatting.

title: It's pretty good - text: 3.5 STARS. I rounded up because it is more good then bad:
Bought as a Christmas gift for the boyfriend. We are long distance and we FaceTime a lot. Well, actually, I FaceTime with the underside of his kitchen cabinets, the blanket on his bed, the ceilings in all his rooms, or the top of his nightstand. He talks away, oblivious until I say something. It's funny mostly but sometimes in a relationship you need all the connection you can get, even if it's their face on your device while they smile or laugh or talk you through a bad moment. So, I got him this for Christmas so that he could hands-free me and I could still see his pretty face. He finally put it together and started using it the other day... with an asterisk. *THE INCLUDED SCREW/BOLT IS GARBAGE. It was machined badly. Really badly. So it only screws maybe halfway into the arm/neck or whatever it is called, which sits in the weighted base. Thankfully he really doesn't need the screw/bolt because the arm/neck (like a metal dowel, I suppose, that inserts into the base maybe half an inch. The screw/bolt is inserted from under the base and - if it fits correctly) recesses into the base when it's tightened. As this one had threads that weren't smooth about halfway down on the screw/bolt, it left the screw/bolt jutted out. The base won't sit on the nightstand or other flat surface with this issue unless he just doesn't use the screw/bolt. I'd post a photo for clarification but the stand isn't available and getting him to send photos isn't always something I remember when we do talk.

The screw/bolt is I'm sure metric and it does use an Allen wrench (included) to screw in; the threading is very tight, so finding a true replacement screw/bolt is probably gonna require going to a specialty nuts/bolts/hardware store. That's annoying enough to take off 1.5 stars for me.

title: Great, Small Camera
text: I am very happy with my order of the Digital Camera, 36.0 MP Compact Mini Camera. This arrived in great condition and was well-packaged. I really like this camera because it's small and very easy to use. It makes very nice photos. This is a great camera for anyone that has not used a digital camera before. The menu is easy to navigate. The box also includes batteries, an adapter, a nylon handle, bag, memory card and user manual. I was prepared to go buy a separate memory card but was very happy to discover one is already in place. The batteries do not take long to charge. It's great that 2 are included so one can be charged ahead of an event for backup. I like to take this camera along when I take my dogs out for walks. I tend to leave my cell phone behind so I can relax. I am now taking many more photos of my pets and inspiring photos from nature. It's very nice and relaxing to be able to use a small camera and avoid the extra stress of messing with an interrupting phone. I find this is a good value for the camera and inclusions. It would make an excellent gift for elders or as a first camera for young photographers. I hope that you find my experience helpful as you kindly click the button below.

Anyway, it was fun playing and the price is amazing, so I recommend this radio.

title: Good Speaker
text: This is a great speaker. It is really easy to pair with your device via Bluetooth. The sound quality is really good. The lights are pretty mesmerizing. The water proof and dust proof capabilities make me happy, given that I use it in the kitchen next to my sink and outside while I am doing yard work. It performs really well for our uses. When the battery gets low, it verbally tells you the battery is getting low. So, no watching for some random light or waiting until it dies. It does have audio input jacks, as well.

title: Easy plug and play on PS4 and has helped with some issues of a almost full original hard drive
text: great product. I just plugged it into my ps4 and my system detected it, asked me  if I wanted to use extended storage and it was set up. Transferred 450gb of data to it in 40 minutes. No sound from it to worry about and makes my system run faster as far as menus go, now that the external hard drive has freed up space for the basic programs to use from the original hard drive. Do not think you will get faster load times I have not really noticed any difference. I had issues with lagging when trying to go to the power off menu or other main menus on the ps4 due to a almost full original 500gb hd this has solved those issues for me. Don't know if others will find the same results but I'm thoroughly pleased.

title: Tiny Treasure text: I love movies. One of the things I have missed most during the pandemic is seeing new releases on the weekend. Well, with this projector you can have the theater experience at home. It's tiny, but it works as well as something twice the price. The picture quality is crystal clear. You'll see every minute detail on the screen. It doesn't take much to set it up. It's pretty much ready to go out of the box. This is a small investment in your happiness. Treat yourself!

Thanks so much for taking the time to read this review. I hope the information that I've provided helps make your decision a little easier.

text: UPDATED: Earlier Review: "Right out of the box to test use with my Android and Camera. The portion that attaches to the bottom of camera has a nice little 'knob' for screwing in quite tightly (as does the mount for screwing the camera on). These little knobs could be easily missed. In other words,  all fit on 'Tight' in all ways and the legs are very flexible. Will be interested to see all this will come down out in the field, but inside, for common use so far, great. Only thing, I'm afraid I could lose the removable part (detachable base),  as it is very small (Make a mental note)." title: Very Good Dummy Cameras with Excellent Motion Activated Floodlights text: I have been working with security camera products for over 20 years - over that time I have installed systems for businesses, corporations and individuals - from enormous multimillion dollar systems to single camera nursery monitors. I’ve consulted on large projects and written about security vulnerabilities within networks for trade publications.

This is a field I know well. Over the years the technology has improved and become less and less expensive to produce. It is now practical to install security systems that would have only previously been used in commercial settings in residential. When I’m discussing systems with people who are not familiar with the breadth of this technology, especially those on a tight budget, I always recommend making use of quality dummy cameras in addition to the real cameras.

To the casual observer, these dummy cameras look real - someone who is familiar with security cameras will easily pick it out as a dummy but for the vast majority of people this will not be the case.

What really makes these dummy cameras stand out from others is the solar powered nighttime red light and bright 800 lumen motion activated floodlights.

Any security camera configuration works best when each of the components works with the others to optimize performance. By setting these cameras as an initial trigger the lights will provide illumination for the real security camera so it doesn’t have to rely on infra red. By this product providing ample light the images the other security cameras in range capture will be far more crisp and clear.

These lights are easy to install and adjust so that the solar panel can absorb maximum sunlight. There are multiple adjustment points so the lights can be directed where most needed.

As with any solar powered product, there are some good tips to know:

* When placing each light make sure the panel is unobstructed from foliage so it can absorb the maximum energy from the daylight
* Every few months clean the solar panels with a moistened towel to remove any dirt or mildew - the panels tend to develop a film that diminishes their ability to absorb energy over time
* The rechargeable batteries that power these, and all solar lights, can typically be replaced without replacing the entire light. I have not opened this unit to see what batteries it uses as my set has worked flawlessly for the last couple of months. When the batteries no longer hold the solar charge I will attempt replacement.

So far I have loved these dummy cameras with motion activated floodlights. I highly recommend the set. title: Good GPS Unit with Outstanding Support Behind It text: This is my third (and final) write-up on the Magellan RoadMate 2220-LM. I decided to rewrite my review again after making more discoveries regarding this unit, enough that my previous attempts at writing a review were no longer satisfactory. In a nutshell, this is actually a very decent GPS navigator with a generous feature set and a few minor quirks. One of this navigator's greatest strengths is the level of support they receive when a problem is reported.

Up to this point I have used a TomTom Start as my primary navigator and my wife uses a Garmin Nuvi. Both of these units have their strengths and weaknesses, but both navigate well and do a good job of selecting routes. I have always been curious about Magellan GPS navigators so I was pleased to get the opportunity to do a side-by-side comparison with the Garmin and the TomTom.

Right off the bat, the Magellan maps look a lot more simplistic and basic compared to the Garmin and TomTom maps. Where Garmin and TomTom have opted for more colorful and polished-looking road maps, Magellan uses much more simple graphics when it comes to the maps. At first I looked at the Magellan's maps with disappointment, but as I have used them I realized that there is an advantage with their approach. Because the maps show the roads as more basic, single-color and narrow pathways, the maps are actually less cluttered, making them easier to read.

I ran into a serious issue with the Magellan when I was trying it out during the first few days. Navigation was reasonable but the position showed me at roughly 10 yards behind my actual location, regardless of the direction of travel. Unable to find a calibration option, I contacted technical support. I got very immediate assistance and was walked through a procedure that was supposed to reset the unit, and what it did was more of a hard reboot. After several emails back and forth my issue was resolved and the navigator now tracks accurately. I am very pleased with Magellan's support - highly professional and very eager to make things right.

So, with the accuracy issue out of the way I mounted the Magellan next to the TomTom and the Garmin and went for a drive along a known route I frequently take. All three navigators tracked the same, though I observed something interesting regarding the Magellan. The Magellan marks position with a blue triangular icon and the others use a cartoony icon that can be selected from a palette of choices. With the Magellan, actual position is the top point of the triangle, but with Garmin and TomTom the position is the center of the icon. Even more interesting is that, because of the roads being represented as more narrow at all zoom levels, the Magellan is more likely to show slight inaccuracy while the others show the same location and appear more accurate due to the wider road representation.

There are a number of features that the Garmin and TomTom have that the Magellan does NOT have, though these are more personal preference options more than functionality options. Magellan has one voice - period. If you do not like the Magellan voice the only option you have is to mute it. Also, there is no option for changing the icon that represents the current location, it will always be a blue triangle. Garmin and TomTom also have content communities for upgrades where Magellan does not.

Of the three navigators, the Magellan has the very best mounting bracket and suction cup. Attaching it to the window is quick and easy and removing it is almost just as easy. Like any other mounting cup, it does not do so well when the window is very cold, so if mounted on a cold windshield it can suddenly let go and fall.

For my particular car, the Magellan's car charger is all but useless, due to the size of the plug and the placement of the 12V outlet. That said, because the Magellan has a standard mini-USB plug it can be used with a typical USB cable and a 12V-to-USB adapter. This is the configuration I use and it has worked out well. I did notice that the Magellan does not necessarily charge completely when it is plugged in and operating simultaneously.

Magellan's navigator offers four routing options: Shortest Distance, Fastest Route, Most Use of Freeways and finally Least Use of Freeways. These vary in usefulness, the first two being by far the most helpful to most people. When using Shortest or Fastest I have found the routing to be very sensible most of the time, though the routes usually differ just a little bit from what my TomTom offers up. I have not mapped out a route by hand to see which is more accurate but I believe them to be roughly equivalent.

I decided to try "Least Use of Freeways" for a 45-mile one-way trip. The route offered up was reasonable but because of the traffic at that time of day I knew better than to take that specific route so I took another way. The Magellan then continuously told me to make a U-turn until I was probably 5 miles from the turn I skipped, after which it finally calculated a new route - way out of my way and making little sense. It recommended turns going farther from my destination, continuously trying to steer me back to whatever route it had chosen. I finally got on the freeway for a three-mile stretch, and it recommended I take the very first exit (west-bound) followed by a U-turn, when what I needed was the east-bound exit maybe 0.1 mile further down the interstate. After the exit, it tracked just fine. To make matters worse, every route after that seemed to have some quirky turns in it regardless of the method I chose for routing. I finally reset the unit using the suggestions that technical support had made earlier, after which the navigator has been just fine. Bottom-line: the Least Use of Freeways routing is not very good.

Probably the biggest weakness of this navigator is the software used to interface with the unit. Content Manager, which can be downloaded directly from Magellan's website, is a rather unintelligent application that provides basic connectivity to the GPS unit, with a poor interface and the inability to recognize that an update was made already without requiring a relaunch of the software. It continuously tells me that there is a map update when it says I have the current version. Magellan could have done a much nicer job with the software.

The actual interface on the navigator itself is very well thought-out and designed. It is very much icon-driven and it shows a little more polish and refinement than that of Garmin or TomTom. Hiding in this interface is a good amount of functionality - access to POI databases, traffic camera alerts, "phantom" alerts, navigation by landmark instead of by street name and many, many more features. Magellan got something important right with their interface - it is very uncluttered and clean, making it a lot less distracting while driving.

One feature of which I was completely unaware revealed itself on my commute home one afternoon. My unit did not come with traffic alerts. When I reached the portion of my commute that requires access to the interstate, traffic came to an abrupt stop. Without prompting, an icon popped up on the Magellan screen, offering three alternative routes. I had no clue the Magellan would do that since I did not get traffic alerts, but the feature is very much welcome, regardless.

The Magellan 2220-LM GPS navigator is a nice unit with a good feature set. It is different than Garmin and TomTom navigators and some of those differences really set it apart in good ways. Support is outstanding. The software used to interface with it is acceptable though could be better. I think this is a fine unit that will serve the owner well. If you're looking for a good, basic navigation system at a reasonable cost, this is a unit that is worth a look.

While the air vents typically have screens that help collect this the ports do not - this is where plugs are so important.

I utilize port plugs on all of my devices - computers, switches, cameras, TVs, any port not in use has a plug to prevent both dust and moisture intrusion.

title: Case Fits iPad 2, Bluetooth Keyboard Works With iPad 2 text: This polyurethane Targus Versavu Keyboard Case is beautiful, with imitation-leather exterior and suede-like "soft touch" interior. A hard shell (also with imitation-leather exterior) holds the iPad firmly in place, yet the iPad can be easily removed. The shell is attached at the circular hole shown in the product photos; the hole allows the Apple logo to show through. The shell rotates (with the iPad inserted) a full 360 degrees, so that the stand and keyboard can be used when the iPad is oriented either horizontally or vertically.

The lightweight keyboard is about the same size as the keyboard on my Toshiba netbook. The flat, non-contoured keys are reasonably comfortable to use. The keyboard is surrounded by a raised edge, to prevent scratches or damage to the iPad screen. The keyboard must be charged independently (using the included USB cable, attached to your computer). The keyboard will give a low-charge warning at 15% power, and shut down at 10% power.

This case (with cutouts for buttons, switches, rear camera, and charger plug) fits my iPad 2 perfectly, and the Bluetooth keyboard connects with my iPad 2. I didn't expect it to work, because the iPad 2 is equipped with Bluetooth 2.1 + EDR technology, while the iPad 3 is equipped with Bluetooth 4.0 technology, and the product description says that the case requires an iPad 3. The case does NOT have an automatic iPad Wake/Sleep switch that operates when you open the cover; however, the keyboard puts itself to sleep after 10 minutes of inactivity.

I like this case and all of its features, but it's not the "perfect" iPad 2 case. It adds weight and bulk, and apparently--judging from other reviewers' statements--the manufacturer recommends against using the case for anything but display (no carrying the case around in a backpack, tote, or bag). Because the keyboard works well, I rate it at 3.5 stars, rounded up to 4 stars.

It holds it and protects it nicely. The projector itself is very nice looking and of great quality. For the price point, it's definitely worth it! title: Player is great, software is garbage text: I had an iPod 2GB Nano and wanted to get something with larger capacity. I did some research and finally bought the Walkman. I was around for the very first Sony Walkman casette tape player, so the idea of getting a Sony MP3 player was appealing.
After using it for over a month, I find it a great little device. The battery life is amazing. I charged it over two weeks ago and have used it on multiple three hour car rides. I also had it hooked up to a speaker in my office and left it on for several hours and it stil has battery life.
It took me some time to get used to the navigation, but now I am fine with the difference between the Walkman and the iPod. The sound quality is good and although the volume could be better, it is acceptable for my use.
The major problem I have with the unit is the software. Sony included one of those mini disc's which loaded a couple of software programs on my computer. The main program is one which allows you to drag and drop files from your computer to the player; however, it doesn't work. I dragged a few tunes to see how it worked and then started dragging all the music. The software kept accepting the tunes, but after it "loaded" for about 2 hours, I discovered it had only loaded the first set of tunes. The rest, and the two hour wait, was for nothing. The software also has a "delete" function, which also doesn't work. It tells you that it delets items from the player, but they are still there.
So, I junked that software and decided to use the Windows Media Player. This is ok, except that the Media Player has a very odd way to create playlists. There are some round about ways to create the play list and I have finaly learned how to do it, but it took way too long compared to iTunes. The other odd thing is that when you create a play list it has to be from tunes on your computer, not on the device. Then when you sync the device to load the playlist, it may or may not put duplicate versions of the music on the device. Sometimes it finds the songs on the device and sometimes it does not. So, I ended up with multiple copies of some songs. The device software is also pathetic. It doesn't allow you to create playlists on the device, and as others have noted, there is no way to delete items from the device without using the software.
I finally just had the computer recognize the device as an external drive and was able to load songs and delete them with no probme.
Despite the isues, I still like the device better than my Nano. For one thing it has an FM receiver, which works great. Now that I have come to terms with the crappy software, it works great. So, if you are looking for an alternative to the iPod, this is a good option. Just stay away from the software provided by Sony and you will be fine.

title: Cuts Wind Noise on Cameras with External Mic Jacks text: It took my husband and me a while to figure out that not all of our cameras have places to plug in external mics. Before ordering, check your camera body and locate the mic jack. Many point and shoots just use built-in mics. Most DSLRs should be fine. Just use the supplied cord with the little camera picture on it. The other cord is for phones and tablets. Yes, it does work with those.

The only problem my husband had was looking through the viewfinder with his ever-present baseball cap on. The cap's bill bumped into the mic's fuzzy cover. Things were fine when he turned the cap around. (more 'tude anyway.)

I don't know what "sheerness" or "warmth" mean in regard to this product, but my husband and I like the way it improves our outdoor videos. It's easy to attach to cameras with top shoes and external mic connections. Love it!

title: Works with some Android boxes text: I received this as a free review sample eleven months ago and am only now getting around to using it. When you need one of these, you NEED one. I wanted to connect my [[ASIN:B00M933WUQ Keedox MXIII Amlogic Android 4.4.2 M82 S802 Quad Core Smart 4K TV Box]] to a monitor I have.

The monitor's HDMI ports were fully populated, but the VGA port was open. The MXIII did not have a VGA out, but did have HDMI. This adapter did the trick - it was truly plug and play.

A great feature (in my opinion) is the ability to split video and audio. I ran the 3.5mm audio jack to a better speaker than the one integrated into my monitor. I did use a third party cable that I deemed better than the three foot one that ships with this dongle.

Bottom line: this is a great product. Not everyone will need it, but if you have the same situation as the one I described this is an effective solution.

title: Super Compact and Functional text: I work as IT support for a private college and I got a reviewer package of these to outfit my department's laptops. they are perfectly functional and most importantly, they are small and look great. I laughed at these when people first started getting them, but after having to Zoom and Skype into a couple of meetings and having the camera on before I was ready, I figured this was a good foolproof privacy option and they are. Now I can open the camera only when I know I want it to be in use. No highjacking my camera for extortion picks (although they would be pretty disappointed.) And built up lots of extra points with my faculty and staff by offering them for their use.

All in all, good looking and functional at a decent price. Adhesion looks good. I would recommend.

title: Very cool 4k recorder if you know what you're doing text: I've been doing a lot of live event streaming and usually have OBS software running to also record. Having this device however means I don't need to record in the software and/or use it as a backup, as this will offload the recording directly to my SSD drive I have plugged into it!
I have an Atmos Ninja recorder I sometimes use as well, however it is picky about the source (if there's a splitter or adapter in the middle, it doesn't like it), whereas this seems to accept almost anything I throw at it so far. I like that. Also, the fact that it can bump all the way to 4K is pretty sweet too, as I can even use the original Sony A7S (which only recorded 1080 internally) as a full 4K recorder now! Cons are that it doesn't really have a display to tell you what's going on so you need to rely on the little LED colors to figure it out. Plugging a field monitor into the HDMI out helps, as you can see the output as well as the "rec" label on-screen.
NOTE: DO NOT use the output of this box as your stream or other devices in a chain, as the output is NOT a clean copy of the original! Imagine that this box is using your monitor/TV/output as its own screen, with its own overlays and all. One other reviewer mentioned that it appeared cropped on the output versus what his camera showed. That is acceptable with using this with a field monitor to keep tabs on what it is doing, however, if you wanted to go straight from this box to an OBS stream or projector for a wall at an event, you're going to see the overlays. It does NOT support clean HDMI out.
I intend to use it with an HDMI splitter as a backup stream, or with my A7S mark i as a 4K recorder, and for that it is perfect.

title: It's a mouse, it works. text: When purchasing a bluetooth mouse, or any bluetooth device, an important factor is how well it connects and how well it STAYS connected. After all this time, the industry still can’t make up its mind about how bluetooth works:
- Microsoft with their mouse and Sony with their controller that pair without the need of a code (which Android’s bluetooth stack doesn’t support).
- Mice and keyboards that will not reconnect after it wakes from sleep mode.
- To this day, bluetooth devices still can’t wake a computer from suspend state.
So when I get a simple bluetooth mouse for a good price, and it actually works as expected, I was happy.

For my review, I’m comparing the Bornd mouse to the [[ASIN:B006428K7I Motorola 89519N Bluetooth Mouse]] which I got in a set that included the [[ASIN:B004L9MBH6 Motorola Wireless Keyboard for Motorola ATRIX and XOOM (Motorola Retail Packaging)]].

With the Motorola mouse, its frequency somehow conflicts with the Motorola keyboard, resulting in sticky keys, as in “I’m having a good daaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay”. Conversely, the keyboard interferes with the mouse where the computer would actually lose connection with the mouse for a few seconds after typing, or lose connection completely.

What I liked about the Bornd:
- Pairing was simple using the button at the bottom of the mouse.
- Operating distance is about 5 feet, but this may be because of my computer’s bluetooth antenna
- Takes a single AA battery which lasts over a month of moderate use (2 hours per day)
- Mouse movement is good. No need to adjust mouse speed in the control panel.
- Accuracy is good. Editing images using Pixlr.com, I’m able to select precisely the parts of the image I need.

What gave me trouble with the Bornd:
- When you first put your hand on this mouse, you will not feel that it is very well built. The plastic is completely smooth and the mouse wheel seems to rattle when you shake it. I got used to it after a few minutes, though.
- The mouse reconnects with the computer most of the time, but sometimes it was necessary to turn the mouse off and on again after the computer reboots or if the computer was out of range for an extended period of time.
- Lately, I’ve been experiencing double-clicks when I click on the left mouse button once. I’m usually able to fix this by getting angry and slamming the mouse down a couple of times. This may indicate a build quality issue with this mouse.

In my specific case, the Bournd did not interfere with my Motorola keyboard at all and it seems the sticky key occurs only when the batteries on the keyboard runs low.

title: You never know when you’ll need one...

title: Good Resolution, Wide Range, Easy Setup, Very Slow Response
text: There is no operating or setup manual with this camera; only a website listed in a very thin brochure.  You go to the website to set up the camera and download a manual, if you need one.  Setup is pretty easy.  I set it up on my computer and then later on my Android smartphone using the free app from Google Play Store.  5 stars for the easy setup procedure once you realize you need to go to the website.  The camera started functioning right away on both the computer and the phone.  The picture resolution was quite good and it does have a decent wide angle.  I didn't test the face recognition feature, as it didn't seem like it would be useful to me.  The main problem I encountered with the camera is the delay between the time the action occurs and the video result; it takes almost 5 seconds for the video to appear.  That's a real problem if you need live action; it's not quite live with the 5 second delay.  The Android phone version was very easy to set up and use.  It could be a nice camera if they can do something about the slow response time.  Also they need to put a little more information into the printed brochure that comes with the camera.  Note that my unit heated up quite a bit after being plugged in for a while.  Not too hot to hold, but warmer than I expected.

title: good volume, use friendly, comes with remote, works on charge or with power cord text: I bought it for use with my tv. We have a smart tc with terrible speakers. Well, more like the sound is terrible with some apps, like Netflix or Amazon Prime- where the volume is sometimes not able to go up enough to really hear it, and I have sound sensitive ears. So I bought this thinking that it could lend a boost to the sound. I was able to get it to work with the cable, and the DVD player (the two areas that really don't need help), but could not get it to function with the tv itself. I tried all options, and I am either missing something or it just doesn't work with the tv. So while that issue *may* be on my end alone, I will just rate it on the actual sound.

The sound it produces is definitely a boost over what I am used to with the tv speakers. It doesn't have a dynamic sound, but it isn't flat either. Not directional, more in the front sound. Clean though. I think it would be better for use with a phone, tablet, or even lap top- where you just need some clean volume. It is long, but it is sleek. It can be controlled from the unit, or with the remote. The remote is uncomplicated and makes sense it its layout.

So while it ultimately isn't working (right now) for MY purpose (I aim to figure it out), it is a nice speaker, at a decent price point (I wouldn't got higher), and the options it provides is nice. Normally I go into mega detail on items like this, but there are already plenty of reviews that go over the specs nicely. So in short,

-Long charge
-Easy blue tooth connectivity
-Comes with connectors
-comes with remote for volume, power, and switching between outputs
-easy to follow short instruction pamphlet
-TF card option
-USB
-AC adapter
-built in microphone (which I haven't used, and have no intention of using)
--slim, sleek design
--has great volume capacity, not super dynamic- but different ears will pick up different sounds. I am attuned to nuances, so I can tell that this speaker doesn't go there.. BUT I still recommend it, overall.

I figure out anything else, or if I get it working for my needs, I will be back to update. I hope my little bit helped, even if it was just reinforcing the more detailed reviews. Take care, and enjoy your day :)

EDIT!!! Perfection!! OK, so I took one more try at trying to get the sound to work with Netflix & Prime. I was watching Captain America last night, and could barely hear it despite the volume turned way up. I realized that the last time I had tried to use this speaker for that, I may have had the tv volume down and of course it wouldn't pick up on sound. For cable, you want volume on tv down as it is running through cable box and you the sound to only come through this speaker. For roku, etc, you would just plug it into the headphone slot, and hence want the volume up. The addition of the speaker totally amplifies the sound AND it did a great job with the sound nuances of the movie. It didn't just add volume, it enhanced the overall sound. SO this really impressed me and I knew I had to come back to update my review. I already liked the speaker at 4 stars, but now I am really happy to have this in my life. It makes ALL the difference in our program watching as we typically use Netflix and Prime daily and it is frustrating that the volume is greatly reduced. Now it is better than ever. The sound is large and fills the room, and I can hear various other tones and bass within the movie- so I guess it depends on the source not just the speaker..

title: Excellent Internal USB Hub for Tower Systems text: One of the issues with some tower cases is the placement of USB ports. Some of the newer cases have USB ports on the front but often these are USB 2.0. Even when there are 3.0 ports on the front of the case it seems there need to be one or two more. AVANTEK's 5.25" drive bay USB add-on hub adds three USB ports as well as a 2.4A charging port.

The hub has two internal plugs. One is for power and one is for the USB bus. Be sure that your case and motherboard can support USB 3.0 and has the proper plugs.

Once installed, the three ports are immediately available to the operating system and they work like the other USB ports on the system. The USB speeds are best realized with something like a USB 3.0 storage device like an external hard drive, though USB 1.1 devices like mice and keyboards work just fine on this hub too.

What makes this hub interesting is actually the 2.4A charging port. This is very convenient for charging a cell phone, a tablet or similar device. My chosen device for testing chargers is a Magellan Roadmate GPS navigator, which is an ornery device that will not charge when powered on unless using the car charger that came with it. I selected a high-speed USB cable and plugged in my navigator and it charged up quickly when powered off. However, the navigator slowly drained faster than it charged when powered on. This was expected though it was worth a shot.

I am especially encouraged at how solid this device is - the ports are securely soldered to the PC board and the board itself is mounted on several posts to the frame which makes it much less likely to flex and ultimately break. I applied some direct pressure to the PC board (not a realistic scenario in use but a good test before installation) and the board really did not flex much at all.

I can't find any real issues with this hub. It's a solidly built device, it mounts easily and once connected provides 3 USB ports and a charging port on the front of a computer tower case. It is reasonably priced too which makes it a very good buy.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

title: 70 LBS Down and counting!
text: I credit Fitbit with my loss of 70 lbs over a period of approximately 9 months, a loss I've kept off for going on a year.  Using it regularly made me realize how little exercise I was getting, and made me focus on increasing my efforts.  I'm not one for group exercise, but competing daily against myself--my previous Fitbit results-- stirred my competitive juices, and I tried to better my numbers every day.  Now I'm at the point where I feel restless if I haven't walked my five miles a day, and I try to shake up my routine a bit by finding new and different forms of exercise--like skydiving!  When I think of all the money I wasted over the years on exercise equipment, weight loss plans and so forth, I'm grateful for the simplicity and effectiveness of Fitbit.  Not to say that it would work for everyone--motivation is key--but at this price, it's well worth a try.

title: top load, front display, comes w/ remote (INC batteries!), HDMI, USB power, inc Earbuds text: Compact, super lightweight, easy set up. There is an HDMI cord, and a USB power cord. Depending on how you plan to power up, you can use the USB side, or you will need to supply your own wall adapter, or your own USB-C adapter.
I wanted a DVD player for our spare room tv. I was looking at plain DVD players, and wanted something on the small side as well as something I could use with another tv or computer. This came up as an option, and I decided to take my chance on it (initially thought it pricey for a mini DVD player--but if it worked, then it would have been a good purchase).

It meets all my needs. I wanted it to have a display, and a remote. It has both. It is super easy to set up-- just plug in the two cords --HDMI from DVD player to TV/monitor and power cord (plug mini USB into DVD player, then plug USB into a USB port or wall adapter). DONE! There is a small front display to show track time. There is a power button, volume dial, pause/play, forward, reverse. So remote can be used or can make adjustments directly on unit. Headphone port. Comes with ear buds! Top load. Included a sturdy remote that comes with batteries!

Picture quality and response is spot on. No issues with sounds. No issues at all!

Everything works. I tried everything on it. I tried it on two tvs and a monitor (it is that easy to use). I kept a DVD going for a few hours (season 1 the office) and no issues.

I have tried both a store bought DVD and a rewritable. Both worked fine.

I noticed a slight pause when I was messing around with the cords (working on cord management when putting in the main spot I plan to keep it). So I am not sure how it would be for "active" use. I dont plan to move around with it.

So far, I am quite pleased with this unit. Meets all my needs. If I learn anything else, or experience anything else worth sharing, I will be back to do so.

title: No Bluetooth capability so without a computer you can't upload any music to it! text: I have their regular bone conducting headset that you can use via Bluetooth to listen to music with your phone. So I thought this was an upgrade that lets you do that as well as upload 8GB worth of music so you don't have to have your phone with you at all times in order to listen to music, but I was wrong.

This one will NOT connect to your phone via Bluetooth and I was rather upset about that since I wanted to use it that way as well. This leaves you basically with an MP3 player that is in your headset, which is nice, however since this headsets don't have a display, you can't really control the songs except press next song or previous song. It is not like you can connect it to your phone and control a playlist that way for example. That is a crappy non existent feature in my eyes. You are stuck with whatever playlist is on your MP3 player forever and ever until you change what songs you have on there, and let's face it, who does that? Who wants to constantly connect their MP3 player to their computer to upload new songs so the playlist changes? I listen to music at work nonstop so this would be an issue fast. In addition work no longer allows to use my work laptop to download files from, which includes my own music, so that leaves me with no means to do it since I stopped keeping a personal computer.

They need to figure out a way to connect it via Bluetooth to your phone and use an app that allows you to control this headset, make playlists and select them and so forth.

In regards to music quality, it is similar to the other one from this brand I have. The quality is what I expect from a bone conducting headset. You get pretty good music all considering you have surrounding noise interfering. The issue I had with their other headset, it died on me after about 2 months or so. Since right now I am struggling on getting music on this and am stuck with their demo stuff only, I can't give it more than just 2 stars. It is fairly comfortable but they need to figure out a better way to control it since there is no display like other MP3 players have. They have another one that is Bluetooth enabled so they have the technology already. Combine the 2 and make and app and fix it! Until then I can' recommend it as it is right now.

title: Clever design for a headrest mounted case text: The review sample that I received had a sturdy elastic band that did not break on me. I do not doubt the earlier reviewer who claimed that theirs did, but my experience was different.

When I claimed in the title that this is a clever design I am comparing this one to other headrest mounted tablet holders. I have tested literally dozens of other models and all required that either you remove your tablet from any case you may be using, or you endure less than optimum grips of the mount will accommodate a case. This one is a case plus headrest mount.

There are some trade-offs in this one's design. First, you can only mount your tablet in landscape mode. Since that is the mode I always use this is perfect for me. If you need a mount that will accommodate portrait mode, or you need to switch between the two, this is NOT the mount for you.

Some physical details that I do like include the heavily padded case when you are using outside of vehicle back seats. While the holder into which you insert your iPad is not the hard plastic, snap in design that affords optimum protection, it does dampen and absorb some shock. The covers are thick and provide a great deal of protection. In fact, that feature is better than ninety-five percent of every case I have ever tried. The organizer is handy, and all of the cutouts and accesses are perfectly aligned to an iPad's camera and various buttons and ports.

If you need a case that will function as both a case and headrest mount this one is worth considering - as long as you understand the limitations that I have cited.

title: responsive buttons, VOX oe Push to Talk HDX, durable feeling unti text: For testing, we have been using these around our property. As expected, it is a half-duplex system. We each tend to use the physical push to talk button rather than the VOX option -- same principle, just that the unit detects voice/change in atmosphere/adjusts signals to allow talk. Still person at a time to speak.

I'm not a fan of reading directions or deciphering technology through instructions. I tend to just poke at something and figure it out. This took me a mix. I figured some stuff out then needed to look at instructions to figure out other functions. Overall, it isn't hard to figure out how to use it, but give it a few practice runs before you really need it. If you are already familiar with products like this, then it doesn't seem to have anything wildly unique. If you need more info than what is in the box (and in the product page), there is a user manual and guide on this product page under Product Information. Look to the far right and you will see Technical Specifications. There are two html pdf links.

It recommends to keep on charger when not in use.

Possibly a good set of walkie-talkies for hunting with pals. Too early to tell. Outside of that, the main use is at the house- either within our two story house or when one of us is outside and one is inside. It is a convenience item for that reason. I think it will become a part of our camping or hiking items. Just a redundancy in ability to communicate as needed.

The units look and feel durable. They have the heft of a cordless phone and the buttons are responsive.

Can have more units added on.

Nothing stands out as far as concerns go. It works!

4 stars because we haven't put it through its paces entirely. Will update as we learn, experience more.

title: First tech gadget to drag my husband from 1997 into 2014! GREAT tablet! text: Wow! I got the Fire 8.9" tablet for my husband as an early Christmas present while he's recovering from major surgery. (I used a gift card for another store, so thanks Mom!) This is his first ever tablet - dragging the man into this century is like pulling an ox out of quicksand with a rubber band. I needed a tablet that would be: easy to use, back itself up, was big enough for his giant hands, light weight to use while in recovery, have access to all our photos in the cloud while he was in and out of the hospital and bed rest, and easy access to movies and the books already on his ancient Kindle Keyboard. As expected, the first hour with his new Fire HDX was full of complaining and cursing and shoutiness. (This also happened with our new car, the Kuerig coffee maker, yogurt, blue underwear, and every new toothbrush in the past 18 years. )

Two days on....The man is carrying his new Fire everywhere he goes. He's doing email on it, SKYPEing with a buddy, Twitter, reading the news, watching movies, shooting video and pictures of the dogs and throwing them to the TV via the mirroring with the Fire TV stick. (That is a neat trick). In short, my beloved Neanderthal has finally arrived in 2014 and I am delighted! To be honest, I love my 7" Fire HDX, but after seeing and using his new 8.9" in person, I am jealous and sort of want the bigger version myself now.

title: Superb Display for Multimedia, Gaming…and Developers text: Not all monitors are created equal.

There is a huge assortment of monitors on the market from which to choose, and each one brings strengths and weaknesses to the table. Which monitor is a best-fit often is driven by cost, brightness, resolution, speed, power consumption… This particular flat-screen LED monitor by LG excels in most of these areas and a whole lot more. The catch is the price - $999 as I write this – but it’s worth every penny of this.

The monitor arrived in a huge box (which should be fairly obvious) and when we opened the packaging we could not help but notice that it was very well packaged to minimize possible damage to the contents. Everything was packed in tightly so that nothing was able to shift in the box, which shows that LG put some thought in the packaging. This was a plus before we even plugged it in.

I have a teenage son who is an online gamer so I selected his laptop computer as the testing ground for this monitor. This particular system is a Core i7-based system (reporting 8 cores, not just 4) with two video cards and running Windows 7, making it an ideal testbed for this monitor. We plugged everything in, connected the monitor to the computer through the HDMI interface and rebooted. The resolution is absolutely stunning – it came up at 3440x1440 without any manual intervention and we did not need to load up any special drivers. After using it at that resolution for a while we decided to scale it back to a lower resolution, to make images and text bigger.

The image quality is fantastic. There are no dead pixels at all and everything is very bright, clear and visible. The main complaint my son has had with other monitors is the lack of brightness and the inability to see certain things due to the inability to brighten the image. With this monitor, all complaints have stopped.

When gaming, my son has exclaimed about how much extra space he has in the virtual realm in which he plays and has seen a slight increase in the game speed. That is, his complaints regarding video lag have all but gone away.

Set at the highest resolution there is a real advantage for software developers, particularly when wanting to see more “stuff” on one screen. When opening an IDE for development, opening multiple files in a side-by-side arrangement on a screen this size becomes very comfortable. It’s easy to see most files at line width and still have room for two or three more files in a row across. This is so much nicer than having two monitors that may or may not allow for moving open windows between them (depending on the system configuration).

One very nice feature of this monitor is the built-in USB ports that allow one to connect devices behind the monitor, clearing up desk clutter in the process. That can be used as a USB hub of sorts, which frees up ports on the connected system. One surprise we got, though, was that as a connected USB device itself it steals the sound away from the main speakers and pipes them through its own (which are of good, but not great, quality). It was a little disconcerting when we tried to connect headphones to the system and the sound was still audible without the phones on. Once we figured this out it became a non-issue.

So, I have one and only one issue with this monitor – it is actually too big to fit on my own desk. As a result, my son uses it all the time now as his desk can handle it.

LG has designed and built a truly amazing monitor. It’s bright, has amazing resolution and is wide enough to replace two monitors and then some. It is expensive but it is unlikely that you’ll find a better monitor for less unless you really need something smaller.

title: Classy, well-made, durable, efficient....everything to make it work! text: There is no mistaking the Tamrac Expedition 5 photobag is of superb quality. Just by looking at the straps is one indication. The bag is not lightweight; it is very well-padded, keeps your equipment safe, and it is spacious inside, and if you do not have enough photo equipment to fill it, consider room for more stuff. Therefore, I use it for more than a photobag, and including for the padded lap top pocket that provides easy access. I have adjusted the Velcro adhesives for the many compartments, and what I like is the strength and durability of the Velcro adhesives.

The Tamrac is geared to handle the outdoors, as the rain flap covers the zippers to keep out moisture. It would be nice if it had a full rain cover, but it does not. Fortunately, with material will be safe during a nice wet hike.

The design of the straps is called Strap Accessory System, which means you can attach accessories to the strap with hooks/straps for secure and easy access. The straps are thickly-padded as is the backside.

I like the large clear mesh inside pockets that can hold a lot of odd stuff. Two large pockets hold enough small things without getting cluttered. Also, for easy access are the two side wing pockets, great for holding the smaller things.

This is considered a mid-size bag, great just to store your equipment, and keep it ready for longer shooting locations. The external dimensions are 12 ¾ wide 10 deep x 16 high. It weighs just over 4 pounds. And just like most quality bags, there are straps to securely hold a tripod. The zippers are dual sided.

Again, this an attractive, durable, well-made photo backpack. You will be sporting style when using this backpack. ....Rizzo

title: More Trouble to Wear, But Much More Sensitive Than Lumo Lift text: The UPRIGHT SMART WEARABLE POSTURE TRAINER is an "anti-slouch" posture trainer that really works! I discarded my [[ASIN:B00N9P8GMW Lumo Lift]] after a week or so, because my sitting posture is pretty good, and I rarely slouched badly enough to trigger the Lumo Lift. In contrast, the Upright buzzes me whenever I start to relax my posture even partway to a full slouch.

The Upright needs to be pasted to your back with gentle adhesive pads (60 included), rather than pinned to your clothing (like the Lumo Lift), but the greater sensitivity makes the extra effort worthwhile. Packets of one-time-use adhesive pads are available from the Upright web site for about $15.

You can wear the Upright between your shoulder blades if you're going to be standing, walking, and sitting; or at the small of your back if you're an Upright novice or generally sitting. As long as it's turned on, the Upright works even without the accompanying app (Android or iOS) that tracks your training progress. The Upright app uses Bluetooth to connect with the wearable Upright.

The app walks you through the simple setup, which mostly involves (1) finding the proper spot for placement on your back, and (2) calibrating the device so that it can detect a slouch. Once it's calibrated, the device will gently buzz you whenever you sink into a slouch--which inevitably happens as your muscles tire from holding a single position--so that you can straighten up. (There is no sound. The product page video that demonstrates the buzz is kind of amusing.)

When you create an account (free), the app collects information about your height, weight, and age, and then generates a daily posture training program that is personalized for you. The training program begins with your wearing the device for a few minutes, and then for longer and longer sessions. At the end of a session, the app gives you a score, based on how long you held your upright posture. (Mine was only 86%, because I intentionally slouched to test the buzz.)

The Upright arrives fully charged. The app tells you how much charge is remaining in your Upright. When you're charging the device in the supplied charging dock, a solid red light tells you that it's properly connected and charging.

Two of the outlets have extra space for large plugs.  Seems like a lot of the things I need to plug in these days have the larger plugs, so for me that's almost a necessity on a power strip.  Wish they had made 3 or 4 with wider space, but it would have made the power strip larger.  The 3 USB charging ports are a good feature, something you are seeing on more and more power strips these days and it is very convenient for me.  Would have been better with one or two more, as I maxed out the 3 already.  The cord is a little on the short side, but worked okay for me.  An overall nice power strip and I like the white color too.  I replaced a larger, old, cumbersome power station with this and gained back some desk space.  Very satisfied with this.

title: Great way to add volume knob to a setup (I used it to mod my custom radio) text: This is useful for so many things. If you want a big easy to use knob for your gaming setup or live audio production rig, this is a really great way to avoid having to hunt for buttons or click volume controls with your mouse. I like that the LED glows under the knob, but I sort of wish it stayed on all the time so I could find it quickly in the dark (it lights up during use, but then seems to turn off the light after a few seconds of non use).
Personally, I wanted to use this to add a volume knob to my aftermarket car radio. For some reason, new head units all rely on buttons and touch screens, but I want a good old fashioned volume knob. Thankfully this is compatible pretty universally as a USB input device (no drivers, so even Android can recognize it!) so I can pop off the knob and drill a hole in my double din adapter to mount the knob behind my dash. Plug it in, and it changes the volume as needed. Awesome! It isn't designed to work this way, you're supposed to just connect it to a desktop I think, but the fact that it worked the way I wanted means this makes it also a great modder/hacker/tinkerer's tool.

title: Good head unit, excellent customer support! text: [[VIDEOID:5f99a990ea71fc33e4d54b09c37038e2]] EDIT January 2023: I originally complained that Bluetooth used to only reconnect to the last phone used. This is an issue with all of their Android powered head units apparently, as the S8 did the same. However, I'm happy to say that customer support came though with a modified firmware that FIXED the problem! It will try to connect to the last device, but if not found will move on to connect to other previously-paired phones, as expected. I am now very happy with the unit for the asking price. Definitely would recommend!

Originally review follows:
Before I go into what I don't like, let me tell you what this product is:
This is a buttonless edition of their popular A6 PF head unit. I can't tell if it is identical to the button version internally, but if you like the look of a smooth bezel-less design, this is the head unit to try!
I have tried and owned a few of their devices and largely love what you can get for the money. That's not even counting that their customer support has been EXTREMELY responsive! However there is one major user experience problem I just can't get past which makes it hard to recommend this to my friends.
If you are the only driver of your car, you'll likely never know or care about this, but all of Atoto's Android powered units (S8 included) will only pair automatically with the last phone used. That means if you share the car with other family members, and they drove the car last, your phone won't auto-connect next time you drive. It will be stuck looking for THAT phone (the last one) in perpetuity. You had to manually go into the settings for BT1 and find the list of paired phones, then click on yours, and THEN it will connect. Only to repeat this process the next time someone else drives and wants their phone to connect. It's silly, honestly. Their F7 doesn't do this, but the S8 also did. Most name-brand head units will move on to the next device in their paired list if the last one isn't found, I don't see why this device can't do that. They claimed it has something to do with security and specifically with Android units (which would be why the F7, based on linux does not have this limitation?). It does not make any sense to me and is a complete user experience failure, to the point that my wife has told me she might want us to go back to our old OEM head unit- at least that one would auto-connect to whoever is driving the car, regardless of who drove it last!
See attached video for demonstration.

title: Good for Google Users Like Me text: Electronics are a fact of life and most families have multiple electronic devices to get through their day. My family of four has four cell phones, about six different pcs, laptops, and tablets, and three printers. Now, we also have our first ever Chromebook thanks to this Amazon product.

Chromebooks, I quickly learned, differ from the usual windows or apple laptop in several important ways and chief among them is the limit on the number of things you can download. If you have specific games and other things you want to download, they may not work. I already knew this going in but I can tell from reading other reviews that some people were not aware that it worked this way and they now have a device with limited usefulness.

Once you accept the Acer Chromebook for what it is, you will find that it does serve as a handy device. It’s excellent for browsing the internet, creating google docs, using google apps, and pretty much doing all things google. I am already a google chrome user when I go online and I already use many apps from the google play, so what this Chromebook offers is compatible with my needs.

Looking at other specifics of this Acer Chromebook, it is about the same size as my old laptop, at least in terms of the screen size. The image is good, although I have seen other laptops/tablets with more pixels and sharper images. Still, it should be sufficient for most needs, and it has a good deal to offer for the price. I have noticed that the charge doesn’t hold as long as the manufacturer claims and the bottom of the Chromebook does feel hot a little sooner than with others. But the Acer Chromebook is still functional and it performs well enough for my needs.

Electronics are a fact of life and as much as we try to limit their use, they are here to stay. Since we have to have them and use them, it makes sense to get the electronics that best suit our needs for a fair price and this Acer Chromebook does exactly that. It does have its limits and it cannot do everything that a windows or apple laptop can do, but as long as you know the limitations before you purchase, you should be fine.

text: This is a horrible product and a pathetic attempt at a more affordable item by a company that has the reputation of being better than this monstrosity. There is no bass (despite a knob that claims to be such). The clarity sounds like a rock band sinking under mud all while trapped in a well. The wattage depicted is a total lie. title: Portable LED Light Works With Any Powered USB Outlet text: This SE FL89021UL 120 LUMENS USB LIGHT provides good spot lighting when you plug it into any powered USB outlet. It works with my desktop computer, and with my laptop (from the battery, or when the laptop is plugged in and charging). It also works with the USB outlets on my router, and with the USB outlets on my Belkin AC outlet surge protectors.

The flexible neck bends easily into any position. (I don’t know how durable this device is over time--whether the wires inside the neck are fragile or sturdy.) There is no on-off switch, and no dial or button to adjust the brightness. The light just comes on when you plug it in. Because the lights are LED lights, they should last a long time; they also shouldn’t drain a laptop battery too fast.

title: Impressive acoustics, precise verbiage- great work option.. text: These live up to the brand and quality of Nautica.. hands down they did not disappoint! Ordered in navy- I love these were Nautica’s signature color- very sleek and sharp looking. A switch to the latest iPhone had us in need of a wireless option.. and these stepped up to the task.

Impressive sound quality- we needed no nonsense and dependable option to conduct corporate business from home. What better endorsement then to report-headphones surpassed expectations in functionality and no tech failures.. along with a crispness and clarity in verbiage. Nothing muffled or distorted by poor sound.. word recognition was precise- which is a huge plus with business dealings in finite numbers/details! There’s no room for error which is a lot of pressure for any headset and yet, these stepped up!!

Love the ease one can switch from music to phone- buttons are easily accessible and no nonsense to use.. the kind you memorize after x1-2 uses. Loving the ability to hang around the neck.. Trust me you wont misplace as they’re holding till needed! A perfect feature for exercising.. Magnetic heads come together to secure a complete circle around the neck. Simple overnite charge provides plenty of battery life for the entire next day.. such a nice piece!!

Not just ideal for chit-chatting purposes.. these deliver surprisingly deep bass! Crystal clear sound allows for exceptional acoustics- you can actually hear the precise notes being played.. I’m impressed and for $40- I have nothing but praises for price, quality and aesthetics.. a total trifecta! Hoping this info helps your decision- stay safe everyone.

title: This is HUGE and better than I expected
text: I have a kiddie inflatable bounce house with a similar blower system, so I was expecting this to be LOUD. Like, too loud for our usual outdoor sound system. But I'm pleasantly surprised to say the volume isn't all that bad... especially since you'll be sitting far enough away to see it that the sound becomes less and less of an issue. That being said, I think I didn't realize in my head just how HUGE this is! I have a large garage I wanted to test it out in first (big enough for a basketball hoop inside), and THIS WAS TALLER THAN THE GARAGE. It must be used outside, and they're not kidding about tying it down either! If there's wind, this thing will act like a sail and blow away. But when used correctly in the right setup, this is really an incredible screen. Much more fun that my old foldable or pull-down projector screen. You'll need a bright enough projector to present from far enough away, so I suggest using a real brand name high lumen one, the cheap made-in-china projectors tend to be optimistic about their brightness lumen rating, resulting in a picture that gets pretty dim when you're this far away. My trusty Viewsonic does a decent job, but I'd even try to get something rated for more light output if you can. The more the better. Great product, I recommend it!

title: Positives & Negatives text: I bought my pair of Bluez 2S directly from AfterShokz company, and not via Amazon. Just like with so many things there are aspects to like and aspects to not like.

I will start with the negatives. If you are in a noisy environment, such as working out in an exercise room, the volume just is not loud enough or satisfactory at all. You need earplugs in the ears to get the satisfactory volume. Yes, earplugs. Of course, that defeats the whole purpose of buying headphones that do not go inside or cover your ears.

You can test this out by simply putting a finger in each ear and then you'll hear the remarkable level of volume change.

Because of the lack of loudness one can achieve in a noisy environment, I cannot recommend these (unless you want to buy earplugs and wear them at the same time).

The only other negative for me personally is the lack of a way to go back to a previous song, or repeat the currently playing song. (You can skip forward to the next song, but you cannot go back.)

The positives: These are comfortable to wear and very lightweight. The Bluez 2S offers the ability for decent call quality when using them to make calls. Microphones seem good (I have only tried this indoors, and not outdoors, so I cannot comment further on this particular subject.)

The Bluez 2S are very easy to operate.

In a quiet environment, volume is fine, and music quality is acceptable for this price point. (Of course you will not get the level of music quality or bass you'd get with a more expensive name brand headphones that go directly over the ear.)

So, for specific purposes such as cell phone calls where you want to keep both ears free, these are quite good indeed, offering good voice quality for both parties. (Pairing with my iPhone 5 and 6S went flawlessly.)

title: Perfect Fit for 2017 Kindle Fire HD 8 text: EDIT (August 19, 2017): The seller replaced my original screen protector at no charge, and I was able to install the replacement with almost no visible dust particles. It's essential that you wash AND dust the tablet screen before placing the screen protector. This is a thick glass screen protector that provides maximum scratch protection without interfering with touch screen sensitivity. And it's clear that the seller gives excellent customer service. Rating raised from 3 stars to 5 stars.

This KINDLE FIRE HD 8 TEMPERED GLASS SCREEN PROTECTOR was a perfect fit for my 2017 Kindle Fire HD 8 (with Alexa), and it was very easy to apply. It is a stiff glass sheet with gentle adhesive backing.

Unfortunately, I caught a single dust mote between the screen protector and the tablet screen--and this caused a pea-sized (⅜”) air bubble that was highly noticeable. The air bubble was impossible to remove, because the offending dust particle was trapped in the adhesive. (This happened even though I started with a perfectly clean screen. Removing and replacing the screen protector only resulted in even more trapped dust particles.)

I’ve installed enough screen protectors to know that this was just bad luck, but for me the screen protector was a total loss. I think that I’ll try a wet-application film next time, instead of another glass screen protector.
