title: Lowepro SlingShot 202 AW text: The fit and finish of this bag are top notch. I've been camping and backpacking for decades and I have to say the quality of this bag and the workmanship are among the best I've seen. The nylon material is heavy duty and durable. The bag and shoulder strap are well padded for comfort and protection of your gear. The pack includes a built in micro-fiber cloth and two memory card slots in the main compartment. There's even a tuck-away all-weather cover in the bottom of the bag for inclement weather situations. The dividers in the main compartment are infinitely adjustable and all can be removed/repositioned. The pack includes a pull-out tripod holder/foot pocket and strapping system on the side of the bag. There's also a separate compartment at the top of the pack for personal items large enough for wallet, keys, an emergency poncho, etc. Also included are two smaller pockets on the back of the pack suitable for lens pens, notepad, pens, what have you.

This bag is huge. Easily as big as most hiking day-packs. There's room for everything and the kitchen sink. Currently I have my old Canon AE-1 with 80-200 mm lens attached. My 55 mm auxiliary lens. A half dozen assorted filters. Cable release. 1:1 reverse adapter AND my Kodak Z-650 point and shoot all in the main compartment.

Ease of use is incredible. The shoulder strap and waist belt are widely adjustable for people of almost all sizes. The zippers work flawlessly and fast never catching or hanging. The velcro throughout the pack is quite heavy duty and looks like it will hold up to years of abuse. All you need do is slide the pack from your back to the front of your body and the camera access section is right there. You never have to take the bag off to get at your rig.

Those are the pros.

Here are just a couple cons:
The micro-fiber cloth is not removable. I'm not sure what you could do if it became soiled or stained and needed cleaning. The strap for the tripod is not fixed to the pack and could easily be lost. The all-weather cover fits very tight to the bag (in and of itself this is a good thing, but...) it won't fit over any but the smallest mono-pod or tripod. My [[ASIN:B00005T3TI Ambico 54 Inch Tripod with Quick Release (V-0555)]] just barely fits on the pack.

I have no doubt this bag would last years for anyone from amateur to most demanding professional.

title: I owe Sennheiser and apology text: ----- Updated with an apology to Sennheiser ------

It turned out that the muddy sound I was getting from these headphones were from my laptop, not from the headphones. I have since gotten a new iPod Touch as well as used them on a high end stereo system. The Bluetooth is friggin awesome. With my iPod on a dock I can use these throughout my entire apartment including lobby with no drops or distortion.

I apologize to Sennheiser for mistakenly blaming the headphones. Here is the original review, unchanged. Please note that any notes about the bluetooth quality is in error. I have also raised my review to the full five stars it deserves, 9 months later and I love these headphones.

----------------------------------------------------

I was very happy to receive a reviewer pair of these head phones. They promise a great audio experience and for the most part they truly deliver. I have recently moved into a very quiet apartment complex and was looking forward to being able to continue cranking my music while not disturbing my neighbors.

I was impressed unboxing the headphones. These headphones are nicely engineered and I listened to them hardwired while charging the batteries, I was very happy with the sound quality. The fit and comfort were nice, but a little warm and confining when compared to ear buds. But, I lost a little love when using the bluetooth option. The bluetooth set up was easy enough, but it was a little muddy when connected to my laptop. Also the range was about 15 feet, and only line of sight so I could not leave the room without skips and dropouts.

The only other word of critique I have for them is that their noise canceling is a little too effective. I find myself missing phone calls when just 10 feet from the ringing phone. These are very nice headphones when listening with the included headphone cable, but don't live up to their bluetooth promise for me. I don't know if I would be very impressed for the price. They are nice, but perhaps not $300 nice.

It captures wildlife and people with motion detection.  The pictures are very clear.  It has a nice far range and it is really nice to see everything on the large 12 inch LCD monitor. title: Doesn't focus on what you want text: I have a hard time with this camera. Maybe I'm just not camera savvy enough, but I seriously just wanted a simple point and shoot that would produce good quality photos. This camera comes with a ridiculous amount of fancy settings which I'm sure a lot of people enjoy.

A big reason we got it was to replace our DSLR which I never really learned how to use and I wanted something simpler. I try to take photos of birds in the back yard and this camera is completely hopeless with that. It will not focus on anything you want it to focus on, especially if there's any movement. It'll focus right next to the bird or behind the bird or under the bird or wherever. So you have to try to zoom in to the bird so the camera focuses on it, then zoom out again and hope that it stays focused on your bird (or whatever).

If you're looking to take photos of wildlife or anything of that sort, I'd find something else. We've switched back to the DSLR for wildlife photos so this camera will sit around to be used once a year with family or something. Hopefully it takes good landscape photos but I haven't seen a setting for that yet.

title: A future proofed 8k bidirectional HDMI switch that works with my HDMI extender... text: THE GOOD:
---------------
* 8K, but backwards compatible.
* HDMI 2.1, but backwards compatible as well.
* Bidirectional, but when using as a splitter, only one TV can display at a time. Two TVs cannot display simultaneously.
* Power supply unnecessary for 4k and below source. Which is great because does anybody really have 8k sources? Regardless, you can simply plug the USB into a port on your TV for peace of mind.
* This thing is a bit future proof.
* Works with my HDMI extender. My Nintendo Switch and Chromecast is across the room from the entertainment console. I connect the Nintendo and the Chromecast into this switch, then I HDMI out to the HDMI extender. Works great!

THE BAD:
------------
* As mentioned above, when using as a splitter, two TVs cannot display the source simultaneously.
* Antiquated micro-usb power port. For the price, I was expecting USB-C for the power source, instead of micro-usb. They future proof this thing with 8k, but they give you micro-usb. LOL!
* This seems to be a white label product, meaning the exact same product is sold under different names on Amazon.

Overall, I'll give this guy 4-Stars. I just hate micro-usb in 2022. LOL!

title: Strong enough for a man, but doesn't understand women. text: Pros:

1. The 102 is small enough for everyday toting - great size for everyday working folk who always keep their camera close at hand.
2. Enough space in the main compartment for a DSLR with medium telephoto/standard zoom lens attached, plus an off camera flash and one more lens.
3. Easy zippers allow quick access to the camera, and support straps keep it secure.
4. Comes with an all weather cover neatly tucked away in a pocket and a built in microfiber cloth.
5. Two external compartments and a pocket for small accessories. Handy memory card pockets in main compartment.
6. Includes a tripod holder and strap
7. Nicely padded with customizable dividers

Cons:

1. The 102 is a lot smaller than it looks on-line. A Nikon SB900 flash can't stand upright as illustrated, but has to be pivoted over the DSLR compartment.
2. The upper compartment can't hold a change of clothes, or anything other than small accessories, keys, a wallet and a couple of calling cards. It can hold filters, a small lens or a point and shoot camera.
3. Can only hold compact tripods or monopods, and even then, it becomes unwieldy.
4. If you sling the strap over one shoulder, the bag isn't balanced and keeps slipping off your shoulder, especially if you're doing anything with your other hand.
5. If you sling it over your head and across your back as illustrated, it's stable, but not comfortable for the female anatomy, and certainly not aesthetically pleasing for frontal views.
6. If you use the additional support strap, it doesn't fit around your waist as it should, but across your chest, hence even more problems for female photographers with curves.
7. No place for water bottle, no cell phone pouch on strap

I bought this to use for everyday toting of my DSLR. Size wise it works for this purpose, but is not comfortable to walk around with. It's not big enough for travel or comfortable enough for nature shoots, or weddings, or suitable for anywhere you'll need extra gear, water or clothes. Definitely not for a theme park or hiking expedition.
I would recommend this to male urban or street photographers (or non-zaftig female photographers).

Amanda Richards
July 22, 2013

title: Cover for the IPad - Great text: I really love this product. Although made for IPad 2 and 3, I am using it for an IPad 4. The openings for the buttons do not line up. To me, it is not a distraction as the purchased the item for the protection and multi-position offered by the cover.

The product offers solid protection for the IPad. The swivel and different positions available make the item a joy to use. The cover does not add any great weight to the IPad.

title: Incredibly beautiful picture. text: I never thought the day would come when I would state that I love a t.v. But at the age of 69, that day has come.
I knew from the start that I wanted a Vizio and no other. I have been in enough stores to see the difference in Vizio's picture when compared to other brands. I also did my research and decided that the 4K Ultra HD was the way I would go. Let me tell you, when it was hooked up and turned on, I was left breathless... The clarity and color just blew me away.
I purchased a 4K blu-ray dvd player and then a 4K blu-ray dvd (which they really need to produce a greater variety of, by the way) and turned them on. Stunning, is the first word that came to mind!
Now I have signed up for Netflix Streaming and will get the Ultra HD as well as 4K movies.
Yes, I was around when the tiny black & white t.v.'s first came into being with the rabbit ear antennas and very limited channels and fuzzy pictures so I think I qualify to say that this is the most amazing picture I have ever seen.
I love Vizio and I know I made the most perfect choice in buying this.

title: Got it Working Under Linux text: I am a little different when it comes to computer users. I use Windows for email and photo editing, but just about everything else I do on Linux. I selected this drive for use on my Linux laptop and so far I am happy with it. It's very fast and it works very well.

Linux recognizes the drive straight away. Note that Windows sees it too but it's not readily usable. I took the time to repartition and rebuild the drive with a different file system in order to optimize it for use under Linux, but that was the plan from the beginning. Once rebuilt I plugged it into the USB-C port and away we went.

This drive is FAST. I have been able to copy large ISO images (9GB) in short order and it doesn't miss a beat. So far it has been reliable too, so this has become my new backup drive.

This drive might be designed around Mac users but it does work under Linux (and I presume Windows as well) with some coaxing. It's fast and seems to be reliable.

title: good price, nice bundle size, works exactly as I need them too text: You know you are an adult when you get excited to add a big bag of zip ties to your home tool box. I have an assortment of zip ties in various sizes for various tasks. If you didn't know, it is better to go a little larger than what you think you need as the length indicated is entire length and not just working length. I just so happened to have had a need for the smaller size (6" or less) zip ties to secure some corners on a multi tier wire crate. I ratcheted them tight and trimmed off the excess. In all, I used about two dozen immediately. With a pack of 500 I should be set for awhile. Always better to have too many of these than not enough. I'll be using them for sure to secure snow netting. Not on the posts (need 10-12" ties for that), but to hold together the overlap going from one roll or piece to the next. Since a section of netting always gets blown apart at some point during the winter, I just head out with a handful of zip ties and put it back together again. So yeh, 500 seems like a lot, but when you have them you need a bunch of them.

The 6 inch size is also great for wire management in general, and just about any small sized securing needs.

No complaints. Happy to have them!

title: Nice choice for audiobooks text: Sometimes, I like to listen to my audio book in bed while my husband watches TV. In order to avoid disturbing him, I use a fancy pair of noise cancellation earphones that vost several pretty pennies. They work well, but can feel heavy after an hour or two.

This set is a decent substitute that I won't feel bad about breaking/dropping etc. They are extremely light and don't have noise cancellation, but that's fine. The fit is decent and the ear covers are soft and don't feel hot. The sound quality is better than expected - audiobooks are clear and clean. I listened to a bit of country and classical music with these and the music sounds right, but not quite as pure as with my Bose headphones - of course, that's not a fair comparison. Still, these are a good option for basic stuff.

title: Great addition for your digital camera text: If you can get only one add-on for your digital camera, let it be this one.
I took my Kodak digital camera decked out with this 128MB CompactFlash card on a 6-week road trip. I used the "middle" quality setting for the pictures, and managed to take over 130 photos (the equivalent of 5-6 24-shot rolls of film), filling not anywhere close to half the card (at that setting, the card will store over 300 photos)!
I'm not a digital photography technoid by any stretch of the imagination -- I just like capturing memories of the places I go and the things I see. Having the extra memory afforded by this little card meant that I could relax and not worry about running out of space for all my photos.
Transferring the photos to my laptop was a piece of cake, and took very little time -- partially a function of the card.
I highly recommend this as the *first* accessory/upgrade you purchase for your camera!

title: Versatile tablet stand with unique cable management... text: The arm and the base of this stand is mostly metal. All the white things you see are plastic. It's a little unique than most because the holes are for cable management. So if you're someone who likes to keep their phone or tablet plugged in at all times, then you'll appreciate the built in cable system. The arm and base weighs about 2.2 lbs. The holder is 3.6 ounces and all plastic. The 360 rotation at the neck requires loosening and tightening of the wingnut. I'm a stickler for higher quality holders. Maybe there is an engineering purpose to make the holder all plastic, but I've seen higher quality holders that is made of both plastic and metal, especially the extension spring part. I've seen metal rods for this part, and that's what I would have preferred. Overall, I give this stand a 4-Stars!

Now if you don't care for the cable management holes, you might want to check out another tablet stand that is all metal at the base and arms, but it also has an all plastic holder. But where it has an advantage is that it can hold tablets/ipads up to 12.9 inches. This Bracwiser version only holds up to 11 inches. This other tablet is more heavy duty at 3 lbs and the 360 rotation does not require loosening or tightening of a nut. Both are vine items for me, so I have no dog in this fight. You can check that out here: https://www.amazon.com/review/R1JCXQ06T6Z7W9/ref=cm_cr_srp_d_rdp_perm?ie=UTF8

title: Excellent Value; Does Not Strobe text: I do a lot with photography and I always keep my eyes open for good lighting solutions that will help me get the lighting effects I want or need for given situations. I saw this one at a reasonable price and decided to take a chance on it. So far I am very pleased with it. It meets the biggest requirement I have for lighting - it does not strobe.

So many LED lights have an issue with strobing, especially when they’re low-cost. This light is not expensive when compared to a lot of others, so even though it is marketed as a video light I was only cautiously optimistic. To determine this for sure, I set my camera to use the electronic shutter only, sped up the shutter speed as high as I could and pointed directly at the light when it was powered on. Strobing lights always show banding in pictures with higher shutter speeds when using the electronic shutter; this one did not (though the display on the camera sure did but that’s a different problem). This test proved to me that this LED light does not strobe, at least not slow enough for my camera sensor to see it at high shutter speeds.

This is a fairly large LED panel, designed for video use of course but I also can work just fine for photography or even general lighting in the right setting. It comes with a clamp mount and a pole so it can be attached to a desk or shelf, then the mounting head allows for angling the light as needed so it can light a surface at just the right angle desired. The mount is sturdy and there should be no issues with stability when it is set up properly.

The light is super-easy to adjust. There are two dials on the back for tweaking the brightness and the temperature range, and there is a remote included that does the same. The temperature can be adjusted from a warm 2800K to a blistering white 8000K and everywhere in between so you can get the lighting just right.

Power is via an AC adapter and there is no battery. So, this is not a travel light by any means, If you need a light to use in the field, unless you have a power generator with you then this light isn’t it. For a static setting in a studio or room, this light is very good.

One design decision that would have been nice would have been a detachable mount so it could be used with a standard tripod instead of a clamp mount. That’s not a big deal, especially at the price point, but it would have made this light so much more versatile. I have other lights that I can mount on a tripod, so I am not too concerned.

This is a very good video light, especially when considering the price point. It has excellent temperature range, it has a solid mount for stability, and it does not strobe. If you’re looking for a solid video LED light that won’t cost a fortune, this one is better than could be reasonably expected at the asking price. It’s an easy one to recommend.

title: Super large but beautiful backpack; well-made; holds my 17” Dell Inspiron text: When I first opened the box, I said "wow, this is a big bag." It is definitely tall and much larger than I expected. However, it is beautiful, well made, and feels good on.

This fits my 17" thick Dell Inspiron laptop with ease. I feel it is also very protected in the bag.

FEATURES I LIKE:
- Padded and adjustable shoulder straps
- Full size folder pocket on the back of the bag (where shoulder straps are)
- Cinch straps for the top part of the bag (see photo) so that it folds over
- Handle above folder pocket on back
- Double handle on top of bag
- Two side pockets with mesh webbing to hold tiny incidentals like chapstick, cell phone, keys, bus pass,
etc.
- Small half height zippered folder pocket in front
- Large full size folder pocket with Velcro flap closure in front
- Another full size folder pocket behind the above pocket with center Velcro closure
- Central compartment with soft, padded, interior full sized folder pocket for laptop with tiny Velcro closure
- Interior small zippered pocket and two pen / pencil sleeves and two other sleeves on either side
- Zippered closure of central compartment
- Ingenious zippered expansion of two water bottle pockets on either side of the bag; can be zipped  and then snapped closed when not needed
- Nice leather (or leather-like) Zinz label on front

In summary, this is an exquisite bag with interesting compartments. There is no room for a regular-sized purse inside this bag due to the design. However, this can be used as a purse and laptop carrier all in one. I have no idea how much this will cost since no price is listed at this time. The zippers flow easily except for the very top size zipper that opens to the water bottle pocket. That one sticks on me a bit.  I doubt if this will be listed for less than $25.

title: Price came down. Have bought it. Awesome TV! text: This looks like a good little TV, but the price increased greatly since before Christmas. I would buy it at the pre-Christmas price of $250.00, but at this price I think I will consider a TCL with more feedback and a two year warranty. Pity. I would have preferred the lower price and then I could have gotten a 3 year Square Trade warranty to buffer my purchase. I will keep an eye on this for the next few days before I make my final decision. I am giving it 3 stars for the massive, sudden hike in price.

Update: Thanks to David Miller for the reminder, this review was due for an update. The price did come down, as it tends to when one makes an issue of it on Amazon - especially when there is an intention to purchase stated in the complaint. I have used this tactic several times now and it has paid off every time so far (3 times now, I think). And I am very glad I complained and then followed through on my intention to purchase this item. I bought it on Jan. 17th, 12 days after posting my initial complaint about the huge price hike.

This is a wonderful TV with great, easy to use features. The most important to me were that it has a truly great picture that is easily tweaked to my preferred specs. Also, it boasts 3 HDMI ports, one of which is conveniently located on the side, along with a USB port. It also has RCA inputs and component inputs, as well as an S-video input. All in all, I can hook just about anything up to this little gem of a TV! Overall, I am not as enamored of the sound quality from the unit as some of the other reviewers seem to be, but it really is better than what most other TVs give off, so that's just fine too.

The controls and functions are very user-friendly and it takes no time at all to be cruising along smoothly, switching from one input to another.

I have been shopping for a second TV for the upstairs bedroom and I have yet to find one that compares to this one for price, quality and features. I may very well be buying a second one very soon... as soon as the price comes down some more... ;)

UPDATE: January 25, 2017. Five years later. Still working perfectly. Very happy with this purchase.

title: Excellent Articulating Arm for Steady Base text: I built a custom computer desk last year and used another table top as my keyboard platform until now as I hadn’t found an articulating arm I thought was worth trying until I saw this.

I installed this earlier this week and have been so impressed. I was able to squeeze my full sized keyboard within the flexible fingers on each side with my wrist rest at the base. While tight, it is very secure which is exactly what I wanted.

The arm is highly adjustable to different usage scenarios which is very important. For those of us who are always thinking outside the box it is nice to know there are options with a product.

One of my concerns with using an articulating arm for my keyboard was whether it would bounce or jiggle as I typed. This has not been the case at all. It is easy to tighten the adjustments of certain bolts to hold those joints in place while still having other move which allows me to articulate the arm out of my way.

I have worked with several Mount-It! products and not only are the products themselves high quality but the customer service is amazing.

This is an outstanding product by a dependable customer focused manufacturer.

I definitely recommend this.

title: Good Budget Shelf Speakers

title: Serious (and odd) design flaw makes it uncomfortable to hold in your hand - not a good case for reading text: I looked at a lot of cases before selecting this one, and I am sad to say I am very disappointed in this purchase. I have an Omoton case for my Kindle PaperWhite. I really like the design of the shell--the way Kindle fits into on it, so I was trying to find something similar, where the entire unit is enclosed all the way around. This was the only case I found which appeared to fit this way, so I ordered it. Build quality is fine, and the Kindle does fit snugly in the case, providing the fit I was looking for. Unfortunately, there is a serious (and odd) design flaw in this case: a small lip that protrudes outwards and runs all the way around the edge of the unit.

This lip serves no purpose, and I do not understand why it was built into the design. I don't know why the lip did not register as a potential problem when I was making the decision to buy the unit--I suppose I thought it would be too small to matter. I was wrong. It matters. It is not an issue when you are not holding it: for example, using the tablet to watch movies and it is supported by the folded case on a flat surface (although this feels somewhat precarious/barely balanced). The issue is when you are holding the case in your hand and trying to read with your Kindle: the lip digs into your palm or fingers and after a few minutes becomes uncomfortable. You end up shifting the kindle to your other hand every couple of minutes. This is uncool, and makes what would otherwise be a great case almost unusable as a hand-held device. I thought about returning it, but given the hassle involved, I decided not to bother for a $12 unit.

I cannot recommend this case. If you plan on reading with this case (i,.e. holding it in your hand for any length of time), it will be uncomfortable (sure is for me anyway).

title: Compared to two other brands of cables, this is incredibly slow with two new cell phones in the car. text: Slower than the 5 year old name brand cables from my ancient Blackberry and slower than the Amazon basics cables from last year. This cable works and it does charge my cell phone in the car, but when used with the same car charger as the other two cables mentioned above, my phone charges much more slowly. I noticed the same problem when using this cable plugged directly into the USB outlet in my truck vs using the other two cables. I am charging a two month old LG V10 phone in the truck normally. This morning I switched things up and tried with a brand new (2 days) Sony Xperia X phone - exact same issue - very slow charging.

My LG typically gains a 10% bump in the truck in the time it takes me to drive from Starbucks to the horse barn every morning - this is while it plays my audio book via blue tooth at the same time. Yesterday with this StarTech cable my LG gained went from 83% on the battery to 86% under the exact same conditions. Bottom line for me is that this cable does work, but at a glacially slow pace and at best it's an emergency back up and nothing more.

title: love the speaker... it works great in a noisy environment text: love the speaker... it's got great range and long battery life. As long as I can hear the music and the speakers last throughout the 6 hours it takes to milk I'm a happy camper. Anyway, the speaker performed even better than I'd hoped since I could hear the sound as well in the back of the parlor as well as the front (normally with the rectangular speakers I've tried either the back or front of the parlor has better sound quality - not sure why that is though) - and it lasted all the way through milking with battery life to spare (and that was listening to it at max volume.

I did knock the speaker down one star because of the charger cord. The minute I took it out of the box I just knew I was going to end up losing it and sure enough I did! Fortunately my son's Playstation controller's cord is a match and I was able to recharge it using that. My only other complaint is not with the device itself but with the plastic casing it came in... why???? Heavy duty cardboard casing would work just as well, be economically and environmentally friendly... not to mention less frustrating for consumers to open.

title: Acer gets 5 stars....Amazon gets a zillion. text: I did a little homework and this machine, especially at the price looked excellent. I noticed in reading Amazon reviews that a small percentage of buyers had received machines with faulty screens. So I went to BestBuy to see what they had, and found nothing appealing in any where near this price. So I ordered one. It arrived on Wednesday (days matter in this little story). Knowing there was a slight risk, I opened everything very carefully, saved everything in case I'd want to return it. Sure enough I got one with a faulty screen. However I'd also calculated the odds: very slim chance of getting two in a row. Thursday we started what I thought was likely to be a tricky, time consuming effort: filling forms, emails, getting to UPS, etc etc. It went like this: one click to get to the trade request on the Amazon order, five minutes to complete it ....Including a stunning question: did I want to drop the first one at UPS, or have them pick it up at my door? UPS would have the prepaid return label with them.
Then they shipped the replacement to me Thursday. SAME DAY! Monday the new one arrived, the man had the return label in his hand.He took one look at my shipping ready packaged box, slapped the label on, and left while I watched still in disbelief. This is way beyond 5 stars for Amazon.

And true to the odds, this machine I'm using for this is flawless. I love it. It's everything it is advertised to be, and more. The slowness some mentioned was easily remedied for my use by clearing the "Start Up", using Blackle as a homepage, and one click to change the "Next Window" screen. I don't play complex games, just puzzles, solitaire and the like so no need for speed there. Pictures, movies and TV are all beautiful, and quick to load.

The Windows 10 Home is surprisingly user friendly...and I'm 72. The machine runs cool, easy to upgrade, and most of all: affordable. So don't be afraid to take a chance if you're waffling. Thank you Amazon! Very much.

title: It's Small, but it Makes a Big Difference text: When listening to your favorite tunes, videos, etc., sound enhancement makes a noticeable difference. Cell phones and other electronic devices are often quite lacking in sound quality, mainly because the sounds are directed to a tiny speaker. An enhancement can make music and other noises come to life and the Xboom Mini Portable Capsule Speaker is ready to serve in this regard.

This speaker is small, stylish, and versatile and I have used it with several different electronic devices. It is very compact in size, operates on a rechargeable battery, and can be collapsed to a size so small that it fits into tight quarters with ease. Just plug it into a cell phone, tablet, or other device, flip the switch, adjust the volume, and listen to your favorite music like never before.

I was skeptical when I first used this device because it just didn’t seem capable of much. It looks cool, but it’s just so small. How much sound could possibly release itself from such a tiny speaker, I wondered. But a few uses demonstrate that this little speaker is capable of many great things. It doesn’t produces deafening decibels, no. But the volume is much louder than that of a typical cell phone or tablet. And the bass enhancement makes it sound like a true stereo speaker. I was pleasantly surprised when I used it and I couldn’t believe something so seemingly miniscule and insignificant would be capable of so much.

The battery in this little guy is good for about 12 hours of use, according to the manufacturer. Truth is, I have never had to worry about this because, if you use the USB cord and plug into a computer, you don’t need to charge it first. My kids like to use it in their cell phones and they are always careful to maintain the charge. Twelve hours is a long time and the reason I know it’s a long time is because, in a few months of use, it has never exhausted its charge. The kiddos can use it on a lengthy road trip and it maintains its juice.

Many smaller electronics need better sound and the Xboom Mini Portable Capsule Speaker is a very good device for improving your next audio experience. Multiple units can be plugged together for even greater satisfaction but even if you have only one, you will find this little gadget is more than able to deliver very good sound quality. It’s one of my favorite electronic enhancers and one I and my kids will continue to use.

title: Excellent Cables at a Great Price text: I have a good tangle of cables in my home office for a variety of devices that require a micro-USB cable. Most of these cables are very nondescript and I have no idea who made them, though there are a couple of them that have manufacturer names printed on the plugs on the end. Most are plain black and are mostly indistinguishable from one another. These cables from Magic-T are absolutely the most easily identifiable cables on the desk and it has made it very easy to assign cables to every device on the desk. But, there is more to these cables than just pretty colors.

The most obvious advantage of this cable set is the colors. Each of these cables is a different color and none of them are black or gray - there’s blue, pink, orange and green. And, even more important than the color is the fact that they are insulated in nylon weave, not plastic coating, which in my experience holds up a bit better under stress and the result is a more reliable cable.

The plugs on both ends are metal shielding with a plastic base, sufficient to give these strength for the connections. The cables have been inserted in the bases and attached within, not attached to the plug base, but those connections are very tight and seem to be solid so I am not concerned about them pulling loose.

Each cable is about six and a half feet in length which is much more convenient for me than the regular 3' cables.

These cables are capable of high-speed charging so if you have a device and a charger that are both capable of high-speed charging then these cables will work well for you. I used one for my tablet and a high-speed USB charger and the tablet did charge faster than when using a lower-grade cable.

I want to mention the pricing. As I write this, the price on this set of four cables is about $9. That’s about $2.25 per cable, and the cables are of good quality. The price can change of course, but at the current price this is an absolute bargain.

There’s something else I need to mention. The manufacturer offers a 12-month warranty on these cables, and to me that’s just amazing. For a cable that costs less than $2.50 per individual cable the manufacturer thinks enough of their product to back it with a 12-month warranty. I doubt I would ever need to use the warranty for one of these, but it’s reassuring to know the manufacturer believes in their products.

It is hard to find fault with these cables. They are made well, they are easily identifiable and they are very inexpensive. This is a fine set at a great price.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

title: Poor support text: Lenovo warranty service is non functional. When trying to resolve and issue I was presented with an option to purchase a solution. We have a Lenovo G580 laptop with wireless network connection issues. We have been dealing with this issue from time of purchase, about 4 months. The laptop will loose connection and will not be able to connect without shutting off the laptop and then powering back up. When I called for support I was given the latest drivers to update the laptop, this looked like it fixed the problem but not for long. The laptop still had problems with losing connection. When I called again the hardware department stated that the issue was due to the software on the system. This has happened from time of purchase, so I asked if this would still be covered. The answer was no because they did not feel it was a hardware issue and the only way to continue was to purchase a $179 warranty support package or a $89 single case package. With a guaranteed solution to be provided after the purchase.

I was not going to go forward with this option because I do not want to pay for something that should be covered. If Lenovo knows the solution and charges customers more to fix a problem that is from the factory then this will be the last time I purchase and Lenovo or IBM equipment.

I instead purchased a $14 usb wireless adapter from the local electronics store. After installing this device and using it, instead of the onboard device, I have not had any connection issues. The system is working without any issues. If this is a software issue then it is a "hardware" driver software issue that is only supported by Lenovo.

I feel that this is just a way for Lenovo to make extra money from the customers who purchase their products.

title: Useful for various laptops when away from outlets! text: This is a fantastic tool for people who need to work in remote locations with multiple kinds of computer. Not only does it work in the car for road warriors that need to meet a deadline or watch a lot of videos, but it makes it easy to power up off other DC sources without an additional inverter.
In my case, I do a lot of live streaming events and need to power a laptop for hours, usually too far away from a plug to be charged. So I carry around a portable power bank that offers 12v DC car outlets, and this is PERFECT for use with that!

Something to note: While my Lenovo and HP laptops were easy to identify the correct plug right away (yellow square and blue tip), my Acer was a little bit more difficult. Each plug tells you what voltage it is (printed on the plastic), and I found one that fit but was .5 volt lower than it needed to be. Usually if it is within range of the specifications it would work, but in this case it would power the laptop but not charge it. Only when I opened the booklet and saw there was a listing of different specific numbered tips with compatible models did I notice there was a better match, and upon switching to that one I'm happy to say my Acer was charging fine after that. I took a picture of the booklet for reference and am uploading it here.

Also interesting to note, I own both a MS Surface and older magsafe Macbook Pro, neither of which have tips included in this set. Strange as those are popular laptops. However those aren't ones that I use for live streaming, somehow all of the ones I DO have the included plugs here. But I feel like it is important to point out that certain popular models are omitted in case you are looking for support. If you have any of the laptops in the list shown, it's a great product!

title: Im ordering a replacement. Will stick with Momentum text: Ive had a momentum camera for 4years and have really liked everything about it. I am not tech savvy, but the picture quality-day and night is great, notifications, use on app easy, sd card, everything has been great. I have even reviewed footage to see where I set something down lol.
I have been looking for a few days to see if theres anything better or cheaper since I dropped my camera last week.
I am floored and appalled by what is out there.
Yes some cameras say they have clearer video. But no night vision. And some record only when motion detected, but only 6-12 seconds, what use is that? And many have a privacy policy that you absolutely have to agree to, or camera doesnt work. And those policies state that the company can access your personal information, files and data. As in social media, contacts, pictures, passwords, etc. and is authorized to use any of that and video clips to use how they want.
Some cameras dont turn off no matter what, and people found out they were being recorded without permission.
I don't like the idea of a surveillance camera in my home, but, I have been robbed too many times. So I would rather do passwords, get dressed etc in a different room.
And I have ordered another momentum camera. I did have trouble setting up the 1st camera, but I thought it was me. After reading a few reviews, I hope the 2nd one is as good as my other one has been for years.
I will do an update if anything changes.

title: Good Replacement for Fitbit Alta text: Apparently Fitbit doesn't make bands for their old Alta units anymore, so had to get these through a third party. I am quite pleased; in heaviness and thickness these are the same as the old Fitbit bands, and instead of having that annoying "button" closure, these bands have a proper buckle. In fact, they are a little difficult to get off because the little retainer strap that keeps the end of the notched part of the strap from sticking out has a little protrusion on it that clicks into the notches, so when taking the band on and off you have to figure out how to lift the little protrusion from the slot to get the band to come out of the retainer. However, this gives you a little measure of extra safety when the Fitbit is buckled on, so I feel it's a fair tradeoff.

These come in a variety of colors; you can go wild with metallics, or bright pinks and blues, or just do as I did and give your wrist a tiny fillip with purple or blue if you don't want to resort to sober black and grey.

title: Not great
text: I received my Fire on Dec 31st 2011 as a B-day gift.  I was thrilled! Sadly, my elation was short-lived. Less than five months later I had blown pixels in the display and had to have a replacement.  Before you assume I'm a careless person with my 'toys' - I'm not, just the opposite in fact. I received my replacement Fire, reloaded all the stuff I needed and went on my merry way, sure that I would use it until I wanted to upgrade - NOT SO!  About three months later, I was again on the phone with a service rep explaining that the charging port was loose and the unit no longer charged. So, I am on my THIRD Fire.  A few days into my third Fire, literally, I had to call and get a new charger, as the one they sent only charged for about 30 seconds at a time and that was it.  My complaint is that Amazon is selling poor quality electronics and I was nothing more than their guinea pig and I don't appreciate it at all!  I will NEVER buy another Kindle of any kind.  To be fair, Amazon's customer service, for the most part, throughout this ordeal has been acceptable to good, but my gift was not Amazon's customer service!  I have no reason to believe that Amazon's latest and greatest are better tested or higher quality than their last series.  Not happy!

title: Works, but for geeks only text: I had the same issues with the review sample that I received that rpv's May 10, 2014 described. The camera and accessories are first rate; the documentation is not.

What I like is this is a full solution with various mounts, a waterproof case and all of the cables you need. All you have to do is add an SD card, and you can insert one up to 32GB. To be honest, all you need is a 4GB card since the camera itself will operate for an hour fully charged. For the extreme sports type videos this was designed to capture, an hour is a long time, so the operating time is certainly not a limitation.

Video quality is respectable and after you spend some time experimenting to fill in the gaps in the documentation you will fall in love with the camera. I attempted to use mine mounted to a microphone stand to capture practice sessions with me and a pianist. It can be done, but the results were less than spectacular. However, strapping this to a handlebar or helmet and dirt biking, skydiving or similar activities would result in some priceless shots.

For the right audience this is a great camera. All you need is a 4GB SD card, some technical savvy, and the patience to experiment. If the documentation were better I would give this a solid five stars for what it is and does.

title: Step up your cell phone content production! text: [[VIDEOID:b24da4d426cb291b56dc311a2d09dc8e]] If you've got a USB-C port and no 3.5mm input, THIS is the mic adapter you need! The phone receiver is so clean looking, it plugs directly into the port and is self powered by your phone, so no additional batteries or charging needed. It just sits there, like a chin bump. The transmitter needs 2 AAA batteries (4 if you want to use both transmitters).
Note: On some devices like the OnePlus phones, the built in camera app doesn't recognize external microphones, so you'll need to download something like Open Camera (excellent free app I recommend anyway for more camera control). Pixel and Samsung phones I tried this with did not require that.
ALSO- when this is plugged in, it registers itself as a "headset" to the phone, so it will not play back audio until you unplug it. I was able to monitor the audio via the headphone jack going in, but then I could not hear it recorded until I unplugged the receiver. This is simply how it works on Android and not the fault of the unit, however it would be nice if a future version could route outgoing sound over the included headphone jack (I was a bit disappointed it did not do this, however the product was so good I still want to give it 5 stars).

title: Mine had a problem, will be returning it text: This card is exactly what I wanted, small with low power requirements. I used it in a home theater computer and it played every HD movie I tested smoothly and cleanly. The problem is there is something funny with it's temperatures. At first it was fine, running 42 to 53 degrees but then on the 3rd day I turned it off to install a network card and burned myself on the video card's heat sink. When I had the computer back up and running I checked the video card's temperature and it was idling at 103 degrees, Celsius. I let it run for a few more minutes while I installed Evga's precision software to verify that temp and it agreed with hwmonitor. I shut it down. A couple hours later I brought it up again, this time it was idling at 63 degrees and didn't vary much from that temp for the next several hours. The next day it was up in the eighties and then again nineties. Today it stayed around 71.

I really don't have a good idea what is wrong with it and I'm not going to spend anymore time worrying about it for a brand new card. It's going back.

title: If you want a great clear sound these headphones are in my opinion some ...

title: Good if you want to use these for swimming, I guess. text: These bone conduction headphones are waterproof (IP68) and come with 16GB of storage so that they would work while swimming (bluetooth will not work well under water and really doesn't have the distance to cover a pool). They can be fairly loud and can be heard even with (especially with) earplugs.

The advantages of an open-ear, bone conduction headphone is that you can hear everything going on around you while still being able to listen to your music or audiobook. Put earplugs in your ear and you can retreat into a more private listening experience.

The disadvantage is that the sound quality is just not going to be as good as headphones that cover your ears. That is especially true for this pair of headphones.

The sound quality from these headphones is not good. The lows are barely audible most of the time and when you turn up the volume to try and hear more of the lower tones (including human voices), the higher tones are already too loud. This is alleviated by putting in earplugs. The plugs will block most of the higher tones as those come out of the speakers themselves while the low tones come in through the vibrations.

Another issue I have is that the buttons are horrible. They are made of a single piece of rubber on the outside and the buttons themselves are recessed pretty far in. This means that I have to push quite far before actually hitting the button and there is just no tactile response to know that I've actually pressed it. This makes everyday use of these headphones a chore.

The last problem I have with it is the custom charging cable. I really do not like devices that do this. Not only do you have to remember to bring the cable with you if you need to charge in your car or elsewhere, if it breaks, you're pretty much screwed.

For the price they are charging (more than Aftershokz Titanium), this really isn't worth it.

title: Ethernet is a no go on firestick text: This is basically a USB host cable that delivers power, and a mini USB hub with Ethernet built in. I wish I could review them separately because the USB host part works perfectly! I tried it on several devices (including my Moto G5 Plus smartphone) and it gives everything a USB port to plug a peripheral into. I wanted this for my Amazon FireStick 4k, which was successfully given a USB port which can be used for things like game controllers and wireless keyboard/mouse combos, etc.
The USB hub + Ethernet works alright- the USB ports, at least, work fine. I'm able to plug in a keyboard and wireless controller adapter dongle, and everything works fine and is recognized by the Firestick. You can even plug in a USB storage stick to play local content. But I REALLY wanted the Ethernet port to get a stronger connection by the TV for streaming. I know there are other USB host / ethernet combos that work with the FireStick, it is capable of working with the right hardware. I thought this would be one of them since it claims to be "for Streaming TV Stick" in the description, however the Ethernet port does NOT work. I'll have to try to source my own and see if I can use it with the USB host this offers. The Ethernet port did show up on my Windows desktop when I tried the hub there, so maybe it just isn't compatible with Android/non desktops? I don't know. If that's the feature you want, this might not work for you.

title: Alexa - "I can't do that from Fire TV" Garbage Product
text: Maybe it's just me as an older guy, but I really wasn't expecting this. Unlike ANY remote I've ever used. NO control over TV volume, mute, 'back', numbers for channel, etc. Nope, this thing (streaming) is NOT intuitive to use, freezes, pixelates, is slow to change channels, and is a pain to use. "Alexa" has more of "I cannot do that for_____ reason" than it has use. Alexa listens to me about as well as an old deaf dog! Useless 80% of the time. If I'd have known all this I would have probably gone with an antenna and free, over-the-air TV viewing. I hate this thing and "help" is a matter of luck with no humans involved. I have to have my 16 y.o. grandson help with some things. Get ready to carry a bunch of remotes and such (Fire control, TV remote and cordless phone if you carry that around). I really, really don't like this POS!

title: Immediately recognized by both my Galaxy Note 3 and Windows XP laptop text: Long story short, my review sample was immediately recognized by my Samsung Galaxy Note 3 phone when I plugged the dongle into one of the ports on my [[ASIN:B00KMKKJWW Unitek USB 3.0 hub 4 port Bus-Powered OTG hub]]. It was also immediately recognized and functional on my ThinkPad T61 running XP.

As great as it is, you need to pay attention to details when unpacking it. Specifically, the cardboard insert in the retail packaging has a web site for the manual. That is important because this thing will make no sense to you without it, unless you have used one of these before. The manual you will want to download is for model KP-810-10.

Basically, the dongle is cleverly stored in the body of the keyboard, and the key is to find the small power switch, which is on the upper left side. After that you are literally up and running. While this makes a wonderful remote for a PC doing presentations, it's even handier connected to any android phone or device that recognizes an OTG connection. That is where this thing excels. However, for Windows PCs this is also optimum because it has Windows keys.

If you need a remote for a Windows PC, or want a convenient way to interact with your OTG-capable phone or tablet this may well become your best friend. I can actually get real work done using this and my Note 3 phone. That is why I gave it five solid stars.

title: Great except one nagging thing text: So far. after a few months this cooling pad works great. Quiet fan. Enough motion to cool my laptop. Thick enough not to bend when I pick it up with computer by one hand. My Cooler Master was two thin and eventually squashed fan to the point of not working.

Pretty lights are hidden though, but I didn't buy it for that.

My only gripe is the way the configured the extra USB connector. Not on the pad. One side plugs in to the laptop and it has a universal connector opposite the plug in on the same wire. Kind of funky and it always has me guessing which one to plug in to my laptop. Hint. It is a tad smaller, which I have to look at both and size them up every time. I'm thinking of putting a dot o nail polish on the insert end so I can more easily tell at a glance. It is a constant nagging chore. I only took one star off but maybe I should have taken 2 stars off for the inconvenience.,

If you don't need the fan or your eyesight is better than mine, then no problem. Otherwise be forewarned. This is a constant pain.

I went back and took another star off after writing this.

I'd just as soon not have the replacement USB port.

title: Great for exercise without the cord text: Pros:
1. Wireless BT works great. 35 plus feet. I've tested using in another room from my phone about 30 feet with the door closed. Did not drop the signal.
2. Noise isolation is very good. Can't hear my kids yelling and the dog barking.
3. Quality of sound is very good. Bass is good.
5. Charge lasts at least 4 hours from my testing. They will last longer but I have not tested beyond that. They recharge in about an hour or so. Standard USB connector for charging is good. So I can use other cables if need be.
4. Fit works very well after getting used to putting them on. They do not fall off during jogging or other high motion exercises.
6. BT connects automatically after first setup. My other BT headphones do not and it's an extra painful step that these allow me to skip.

Cons:
1. Fit gets to be uncomfortable after longer uses. This is acceptable, as these need to be secure in your ear so they don't fall out while moving around or exercising. I would not recommend if you will be using for longer periods of time, as comfort will probably be an issue. Not as much a Con on the product but the type of headphone.
2. Profile could be a bit smaller. They sick out a bit far but not any more than other BT headphones I've seen. I would have liked to wear these under my motorcycle helmet but they stick out too far.

title: Worst Tripod I've Ever (Tried)! Poor Engineering! text: I really wanted to use this. I absolutely hate this tripod. I own several. Upon extending the legs to set it up, it broke and I cannot fix it. There are these little thin, plastic tabs inside each piece of tubing that extends. The washer came off, the plastic tabs went flying, I placed them back, and the leg was stuck. I tried to retrieve them to try placing it again, and they were lost in the larger section of tubing. I carefully and methodically removed the larger washer to find the tabs, and they were so far up inside I couldn't retrieve them, so I replaced the plastic tabs from the larger piece, carefully placed it back... and low and behold those disappeared inside as well.

This is the worst engineered product I have ever encountered in my life. I cannot fathom paying anything for this. It's worthless garbage to me now. It cannot be used. I feel sorry for all the people that spent precious time of their life designing, manufacturing, selling and shipping this piece of trash. An entire tripod leg will no longer fix into place, because of these thin plastic tabs. Maybe this could have been saved by threading the adjustment washers differently, or even a piece of tape holding the plastic tabs. I cannot say for sure. What I can say is, this would be a waste of money. It's much too easy to unscrew the washers, then those tabs come out. They cannot be placed back. Once they are inside the tube, they are gone.

If I can somehow manage to fix this, I will update. Until then, don't waste your money. I would not even recommend this to someone I don't like.

Thanks for reading my review. I hope you have found it helpful.

title: Decent dashcam for the price, a pain to configure, not the image quality I expected text: For the price this is hard to beat. It has lots of great features, including a Wifi app, but resolution/quality even on the highest settings are slightly disappointing. I have everything configured to provide the sharpest possible image (highest resolution and bit rate, etc.), and if a car is more than 30' away, zooming in on a screenshot of a license plate is iffy at best, even if the footage was taken in bright daylight (screencaps taken in VLC). Something seems off to me. Yes, I removed the protective films, and yes, my window is reasonably clean (normal conditions). I have attached two photos: one of the unit in a fantastic little case I found for it (see below), and a screencap showing the problem I described. The van in front of me is semi-readable, and was about 25 feet away. The car 15-20 feet further away on the left is unreadable, as is the plate close to me on the left. And yes, I have the CPL filter installed on the lens.

Configuring this was a bit of a hassle. The Wi-Fi app is not intuitive, and some quick googling led me to discover you have to temporarily disable your cellular data the first time you use it to get the camera to connect. Once configured, the camera itself acts as the network your phone connects to. This means your phone cannot be connected to any other Wi-Fi network while you are connected to the camera. I have no idea why they don't just allow you to use Bluetooth for this--it would be simpler to set up, that's for sure. Honestly, having integrated security video will be a factor in the next car I purchase. This is all way too much work.

Many PCs will not play the default file format this records in as they lack the correct video codec (H.265) or enough processing power. I think there must be a way to change the format it records in, but I was unable to find the configuration setting to change in either the app or the camera itself. To get this to play files on your PC, I suggest using VLC Player. It is free, and if you are running the latest version (check for updates in the application), it will run them just fine if your PC has the juice for HD at this level. If you experience dropped frames or choppy video when playing back on your computer, this is probably because your computer is not equipped with a GPU to support this high resolution of video (many aren't; if you don't have a dedicated video card in your PC, you may experience this). My office desktop does not have a dedicated video card and the video is a bit choppy if other things are running--expected.

If you are interested, the case is the "Mchoi Hard EVA Travel Case for Garmin inReach Mini GPS", (ASIN: B08F9QV1BQ), which is very sturdy and cost me $13.49 in Feb 2021. I looked for EVER for a case for this, and this was the best fit I found.

title: Sturdy and high quality text: This is a great light. It is super bright and feels very sturdy. It has 3 brightness settings, and since it is a diving light, the angle is very large (unlike a regular flashlight which has a concentrated beam). If you turn the light on the brightest setting and just have it face up, it can light an entire room. Which is really nice in that regard.

The light also has a red, blue, and a red-blue flashing setting, which is useful for signaling danger/attention. It's made of stainless steel and aluminum and feels very sturdy. It weighs 1 lb 3 oz.

It took me a while to figure out how to charge the battery: the charging port is on the battery structure (i.e., you have to unscrew the back, take out the batteries, and the charging port is on the bottom of the battery structure).

Overall a great light that I would recommend.

title: Not Worth the Cost of Returning text: This is advertized as a 'hard case.' It is NOT a hard case it is simply formed vinyl with minimal rigidity. You can easily compress the sides with one finger.

The description also claims this has a 'padded inner pocket.' The elasticized strip that divides the case in two is no thicker than a heavy-weight T-Shirt. It offers your GPS no real protection at all.

The walls, sides, faces of the case have no padding whatsoever. I was forced to improvise padding with a divider taken from one of my camera gear bags.

The case does not seal. The zippers come ¾'s of the way up the side and then there's an extra piece of vinyl stitched to both sides of the case. Forming something like a collar. The flap that velcro's over the top does not hold the collar section tightly closed. You can easily slip a finger into the case with it 'closed'. This means dirt and moisture, etc. have an easy path to your GPS. Additionally, I've had this for less than four hours and the velcro patch the flap attaches to is already pulling free of the case!

My [[ASIN:B005HSDL8S 5" Garmin nüvi 50LM]] barely fits in the Zeikos IR-CA101 Large Hard Case side to side but there is a lot, too much really, front to back room. Along with the improvised padding I was forced to add to the inner side of the case where to protect my GPS I've also wrapped my 12v car power cable in a piece of towel to keep it from thumping around. I would NOT recommend putting a window or other mounting device in this case with a GPS unit.

If it wouldn't cost me half of what I paid for it to ship it back I'd return it in a heartbeat. As far as I'm concerned this product is NOT as described. It's not a hard case. It's not padded. It offers almost no protection AND it's already falling apart just hours after arriving.

Do yourself a huge favor and don't buy this, it's overpriced junk.

title: Created and fit rocksolid.. Love the extra neck support! text: How great is this.. sure! It’s a phone cord- and that falls along the same lines of reviewing a pair of underpants… But hey, just like underpants- we all need them, appreciate when made of good quality and love it when they’ve got a good trustability factor- A factor that they’re going to do their job.. and do it well!! Yep- totally the same😝!!

• Ordered 3ft. red cord- And I’m loving the integrity of the nylon braid.. In our house, we are hard on charge cords! Love love love the red.. and here’s a HACK: assign each one of your kids a color of a cord- that way, no one is taking the other persons bc, “they know it’s theres!” or accidentally, leaving behind at a friends- bc, a colored cord is so obvious to locate and easy to see!! You’re welcome..

• Love the neck support.. in fact, I look specifically for this when ordering a replacement cord! With the ergonomically cut, bendable rubber protection, it offers extra support and keeps the cord from the ever dreaded breakage these are prone too.

•Comes in a perfect box. So, Keep it!! Then, if traveling you have extra protection and safety for the cord itself- I included a photo, showing the slide box mechanism. It’s perfect for storing again and again..!! Box reminds me of a match box- it’s perfect.

•Connecting into device is a smooth fit. It connects without issue- and does so, firmly. I haven’t received the obnoxious “cord not supported by this devise” message.. Hallelujah!

•Charging speed is an important factor- I don’t know that I notice a large difference in length of time to charge from 0-100... but, where I do think this has high speed factor- is in quick “boosts” -When needing to get the phone a solid 25-35% amount of power and in a hurry.. this gives good, quick burst of power, quite fast!

Overall, getting a replacement cord should be about quality. listed at a higher price point- I feel longevity should be a must.. As of now, all my picky requirements have been met and then some. If, looking for a dependable replacement option- this is a great option.
Hope this info helps.. feel free to let me know!

title: Additional things to consider text: UPDATE 9/5/21 Still Five Stars. Operating flawlessly. No weird startup/freeze issues. I upgraded my cpu to i9 9900k and GPU to 3080 FTW3. Im likely bottlenecked at the CPU level, but ill take care of this later.

UPDATE 10/19/2021 4 to 5 stars after using for 2 years:

CPU had random starting issues for a long time. as I initially wrote.. I never updated my bios since there wasnt any major updates. Then one day it stopped working. F7 error. I was perplexed. So I updated my bios directly through the motherboard. A bit of a hassle, took about an hour or two to get it figured out and reset. Its has been working flawlessly for 2 months now. OS actually starts and loads a bit faster without any weird startup issues. In any case, really enjoy this motherboard. So definitely recommend getting it. Just update it and make sure you have backup BIOS on the other 2 slots since the working one can get corrupted for whatever reason.

Without adding to what others have said, I will say this is the great sounding motherboard. Assuming you dont use the internal DAC and just use the SPIDF output cable to an external DAC you will get very good results. Dont bother wasting money on external sound cards. That being said, the internal DAC is passable[for non-serious listening], but thats besides the point. This motherboard isnt made for audio. However, its apparent they use quality parts on the motherboard.

There are some negatives to this motherboard, and I dont know if its just because I bought mine from AMZN warehouse, which is supposed to be LIKE NEW, or because its how it is generally, but it gets a bit temperamental sometimes, and wont start right away. The bios boots, resets, multiples times before it gets to windows. Sometimes it doesnt boot right away. Ive checked against my other parts as well and they are fine. However, this only happens very rarely. Ive had this two months or so and maybe 4 times?

The other negative is the cheap I/O shield. They need to do something about this one. It may have something to do with the fact that it makes it easier to adjust to different cases. However, it is really cheap...

title: Impressive text: I have put together many, many computers using cases of all shapes, sizes and costs. Dollar for dollar this case is hands down the best value I've ever seen. As others have noted the materials are a bit flimsy but this is a computer case, not the frame for a tank. As long as it isn't abused it should last and give good service for years. And I like that is fairly light weight, many cases that are "sturdy" are also on the heavy side. By the time you have them loaded with a good power supply and several hard drives they begin to feel like a tank when you need to move them.

The cutouts and gaps to make routing cables easy are nice, they not only improve the appearance but also help air flow freely through the case. I was a little worried about sharp edges but have not found any, which is good because knowing me if there was even one I would have cut myself on it.

I read several reviews which mention the hard drive rails being difficult and backwards so I wasn't sure what to expect. At first I was a little confused about how the hard drives are meant to be installed but once I understood it, it makes perfect sense and is no problem to work with. If you have right angled power and data cable ends you can mount the drives facing left or right which might make things easier if you have several drives installed.

Another thing that both surprised and pleased me was when I was installing the power supply I noticed there were two extra holes which makes it possible to mount the ps either right side up or upside down. I am not a huge fan of bottom mount for power supplies and as others have said, it can cause problems if the leads for motherboard power are not long enough. Mine just barely reached to the cpu power connector after running it up the rear of the case, resting as it is on the motherboard and running under the video card. I have extensions on order though I'm sure I could get by for the life of the ps as it is now.

I like the long, thin blue light on the front for power on though the green light for hard drive activity is a bit hard to see. Most of all though, I love the paint. No more of that ugly, dingy looking gray metal with thoughts of how I want to paint it black. I am not an expert on such things but I believe the paint is baked on giving it a very nice texture and appearance.

This is a case I would not have been disappointed by if I had paid 60 dollars. Getting it from amazon for 36 with free prime shipping is one of the best deals I've ever found.

Three cheers to NZXT !!!

title: Couldn't get it to run at CL16 at 3600 MHz text: When I installed this RAM (by itself) in my PC, I could not get it to run at 3600 MHz at CL16 (even with XMP enabled). It was getting speeds of CL18-22-22-42. I've attached a screenshot of CPU-Z showing the timings. I tinkered with the RAM, my BIOS, etc. for several hours and could not get it to run at CL16, which is unfortunate. The best I could get was CL18. When I installed this RAM alongside my existing CL16, RAM, it reduced the speed of my memory for 1066 MHz.

I would not recommend this RAM.

title: Allowed me to add a 2009 TV to a 2008 laptop via HDMI text: This device connects to the VGA port and from there connects to a monitor or TV HDMI port, It WILL NOT work in the other direction, and it requires a source of 5V 1A power (any standard phone charger will work.)

It comes with a USB charging cable and a 3.5mm cable for transmitting sound. Apparently it will not send sound interlaced with the HDMI signal through the HDMI cable (that you will need to supply.) For me this is not an issue because I am using it on a legacy laptop to send video only to a legacy TV, which I am using as extended video under Windows 7. Yes, it's using some ancient gear. But that is why I rated it five stars.

Limitations: even if your TV or monitor is capable of higher resolutions this is not going to provide more than 720p from an old laptop or PC to an old monitor or TV. I know the specs say that this will go higher, but I could not get it there. Yet, going straight VGA from my T400 to my Sanyo TV it went into higher resolution as an extended screen. I am OK with the limitation because I am only using the TV as a second screen with MS Office,

On an old Windows 7 system it's truly plug and play. I had it up and running without the scant instructions in mere minutes. For me it is a perfect solution.

title: Great case for my first serious build (i bought it ... text: Great case for my first serious build (i bought it a while ago). It's still in use, and I would really recommend it for a first timer or a pro

Pros:
-active cooling is awesome. watching the fins come up when i open a game is pretty sweet.
-great looking in a room. It's kind of a monster, so this is subjective, but it definitely lets people know there is serious power inside.
-SO MUCH STORAGE. seriously I ran out of SATA ports before i ran out of drive space.
-excellent cooling. my roommate has a similar build as mine in a phanteks case that gets uncomfortably warm.
-lots of room for modding or decoration. for the DIY inclined i would strongly recommend it
-the GPU holder is a great addition

CONS:
-didn't fit my motherboard. did not have the correct standoff holes for an MSI 970-A KRAIT edition, which i believe is a standard ATX motherboard. The right side of the motherboard is to this day completely unsupported. this makes changing RAM a pretty scary endeavor.
-a PSU basement would be nice
-the front dust filter sucks. it is removable, but i would much rather see something more like the PSU filter than the flimsy grate thing that sits behind the door.
-the fins on the top don't line up too well. again, at this price point I don't expect the mercedes of cases, but I would gladly pay more to see satisfyingly perfect alignment in the plastic bits.
-it looks great from far away, but once you start building in it, you notice that a lot of the parts are a bit cheap

title: Perfect in every way but one. text: Have had this TV for about 3 years now, and it was one of the best deals I've ever found. The picture quality if wonderful, especially the HD channels on my cable. Every time I'm in a store with HDTVs on display, none of them seem to compare to the great picture I get on my Soyo.

However, I've just purchased a PS3, mainly for the Blu-ray player, and realized I wasn't getting full resolution because the TV resolution goes to 1080i only, but full Blu-ray needs 1080p. I had bookmarked a review from 2006 saying there was really no reason to buy 1080p at that time, and I took that advise. That's no longer the case.

If you don't care about Blu-ray (the TV does an amazing job with regular DVDs), then this is probably still a great deal.

As another reviewer mentioned, this model had an update somewhere along the way. Mine is the older model with just one HDMI input, so perhaps they've updated to provide 1080p resolution.

title: Good for what they are, but there are better ones text: I love the concept of bone conducting headphones, and if you haven't tried a set before you really should! The sensation is a little unsettling at first but when you get used to it, you are rewarded with the ability to hear deep bass in your sounds without covering your ears completely the way ear buds and over-the-ear headphones require. They're not for everyone admittedly, but I love that I can feel/hear the sound and still be aware of my surroundings and able to respond if someone calls my name.
Good bone conducting headphones are easily 2x-3x the price of these, so keep that in mind. This is not going to be an alternative to a big name brand set. However, they aren't terrible either, and I kind of like them for the novelty of it at the price point.
If audio quality is your primary goal, understand that for the same money you can get a very decent pair of traditional headphones that will outshine this. But where's the fun in that?
4 stars for the novelty of it, but I give the sound quality and cost value only 3 stars.

title: Amazing for those with vision trouble! text: I had decided I did not "need" a Kindle, having tons of other gadgets for all sorts of things. Then I began to lose the vision in one eye and realized over a period of weeks that I could not read normally (or at all some days). Magazines, books, the newspaper.... heck even email was difficult to impossible some days. All my friends have Kindles, so I borrowed one for a day and fell in love. We immediately ordered the Special Offers Wi-Fi Keyboard version. I've had it about 45 days now and my quality of life has seriously improved! I can enlarge the font and change the style of the font depending on my needs at that moment and on really bad days, when my eyes are tired or refusing to focus, the voice function is amazing. The very idea that it reads aloud to me is tremendous and once you adjust to the sometimes robotic pronounciation of some words, it works like a charm. So far, all the books I've purchased have allowed the voice option.

I signed up for Audible.com about two weeks after getting the Kindle and the quality of the audio books on my Kindle is excellent. No robotic voice here - you get the narration exactly as read by the real person - it's an MP3 file I think. Additionally, getting the local newspaper every morning on my Kindle has returned to me my morning tradition of the local editorials & coffee. I do love the number of free books available as well - some are garbage, but most are pretty decent and some have been excellent books. (Loads of Sc-Fi for free too, what's not to love?) I have used the sample option for a ton of books and it's helped me decide to spend the money purchasing a novel, or not. In case you are worried about the Special Offers... they are the screensavers while the Kindle is in sleep mode and NEVER show up in your actual books. I've used a couple of them already now that I think about it.

One last thing - the Kindle in a case, fits into almost all of my handbags and has saved my sanity sitting in doctor's office waiting rooms and at the car repair shop, and I can now sit out under a tree on a pretty day with my horses again while I read a great book. This version of the Kindle will also play my own music while I'm reading. Bottom line is that the Kindle has helped me get a valuable part of my life back and this in turn has allowed me to be more rational while facing possible permanent loss of vision in one eye. Very worthwhile purchase!
