title: Excellent Quality Tiny Ear Buds text: I’ve tested a few similar sets of ear buds with mixed results but I was really impressed with this set.

I read the instruction manual - removed the tiny stickers on each ear bud and plugged in the case. It achieved a full charge in just over an hour.

I removed the ear buds from the case, the right one first and then the left and they paired with each other immediately. I went to my Bluetooth settings in my iPhone and found Haylou-GT1_R and my phone paired with the set with no issue.

I was surprised at the sound quality these tiny ear buds deliver. They can definitely be turned up as loud as you’d want to listen. The bass, midtones and treble is on par for ear buds - even those that are much larger.

I did figure out that the initial way I had them in my ears was upside down when I went to test the calling features. The microphone needs to be pointed towards your mouth for best audio reception and sound quality improves a bit in this position.

Call quality was excellent for both hearing the other person and them hearing you.

In my testing the earbuds had no problem receiving within the 33’ stated range (actually making it to around 40’) and even received clearly through multiple walls - 2 rooms away with the doors closed and many obstacles in between.

The only issue I struggled with was tapping the ear bud to stop / start the music and answer / end calls / activate voice assistant and skip tracks. There is no button, you just tap an area of the exterior of the ear bud but you have to tap a very exact area which isn’t necessary easy to locate as it is not differentiated from the rest. It would have been helpful if the manufacturer put a different texture in that area so you could feel it with your finger to locate it.

While the manufacturers claims these last for 12 hours I found it was closer to 8 under normal use - still excellent. And the case will charge them without it having to be plugged back in which is always a nice feature.

These earbuds excelled in all of my tests showing that they are a high quality, dependable product.

This is a set I wouldn’t hesitate to recommend.

⭐️As with all Drew’s Reviews, if I discover something new about this product - good or bad - I will UPDATE my review. I believe in creating detailed, complete reviews because, like you, I depend on them when I am shopping. If you found my review HELPFUL - please click ⬇️ below!⭐️

title: For the price I haven't found any better text: The cord is a great length, long enough to be comfortable, but not so long I get tangled in them. The mic work great, no issues with sound quality
The sound is good, especially for the price. You can crank it up with no distortion, and the bass is pretty good for ear buds.
I use my ipod to listen to books, mainly at night while falling asleep. These are super comfortable,I don't end up ripping one out so i can sleep on my side. No sore ears.
My only complaint is there is no volume control,the pause and start works great but make sure you have the volume where you want it. This may be because I only use apple products, Im not sure. Its not a deal breaker for me, especially for the price.

title: Like other things Netgear, it kind of works for a while and then it dies text: I had a Netgear MR814 that worked half-decently for around four years and then for some reason totally stopped transmitting internet wirelessly. Bought this new one through Amazon for $40 and it worked OK for a few months before it stopped transmitting internet as well. So I bought a Linksys instead and there's a stark difference. No more restarting my router every other day to get it to work, and NO MORE NETGEAR FOR ME! There's a reason I guess why their routers are less expensive. Do yourself a favor and pay the extra ten dollars for another brand like Linksys.

If you do buy this one note that when I followed the instructions on the included setup CD it didn't work. When I just did the setup manually it worked fine. If you know anything at all about wireless routers then I suggest you set it up manually without the CD.

title: Worth every penny!!! text: This LG soundbar is simply fantastic. It was easy to hook up physically and the app works great. I don’t know how often we’ll actually use the app, but I like having it as a backup option (our kids manage to lose remotes all the time!). Once we had the soundbar and sub hooked up, the technical portion of setting the sound set up and configurations took a while for my partner to get right. I thought the sound was amazing and beautiful, practically right out of the box. But my picky husband fussed around with the settings for a better part of an hour getting it just right. I’m kinda glad he did though because the sound quality went from “now this is nice” to mind blowingly “excellent!!!” We watch a lot of Disney and nature shows, and now it sounded like we’re right there. As if we’re sitting in a real movie theater or in the middle of the rainforest! The sound really is that impressively good.

The only thing I didn’t love is the bar itself is a bit bigger than our old one (which is nearly 10 years old); so check the measurements if space is tight. I am sure I’ll get used to it in time. But the sub is quite small, so I can really hid this one! I think that is really nice. Overall, LG this set it looks modern and looks great in person. It works amazing well and we couldn’t be happier with it. I usually try not to comment on price, since what affordability is subjective. But I think this LG bar is worth it’s weight in gold.

title: USPS LLV Comparison: OontZ Angle 3 Plus vs Anker SoundCore text: First off, I am not an audiophile. This is a review from a simple person who wanted music at work.

I am a Rural Carrier for the United Stated Postal Service. I deliver mail in an LLV truck and these vehicles are basically mobile tin cans. Every panel rattles, making for quite an unpleasant environment, audio wise. I tried playing music directly off my phone, but alas my speakerphone is only so loud and is constantly drowned out by the LLV.

So, I researched Bluetooth speakers and, based on the reviews and popularity, recently purchased two:
-[[ASIN:B016XTADG2 Anker SoundCore Bluetooth Speaker with 24-Hour Playtime, 66-Foot Bluetooth Range & Built-in Mic, Dual-Driver Portable Wireless Speaker with Low Harmonic Distortion and Superior Sound - Black]]
-[[ASIN:B01LZV6TYQ OontZ Angle 3 PLUS Splashproof Bluetooth Speaker - Designed & Engineered by Cambridge SoundWorks for Richer Bass, HD Sound, and 30-Hour Playtime, 10W+ Power, Water Resistant, Portable Wireless Speaker]]

The Anker SoundCore is being returned while I am keeping the OontZ Angle 3 Plus and here is why.

I tested both speakers in my home at first. My very first impression, out of the box:
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - was nice to touch and just felt solid and very well built.
Anker SoundCore - just felt like a simple lightweight brick. It really didn't give the impression of longevity or durability.

The set-up guides were quite different from each other.
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - Extremely easy to read, follow and understand (remember, I am not a music nut lol. This was my first time ever using a Bluetooth speaker and was in completely uncharted territory.) It was all in English, and only English and the diagrams were detailed and made the entire set-up process seamless and carefree.
Anker SoundCore - This guide was very hard to follow. It is printed in darn near every language, in tiny print and the diagrams were quite small as well. I ultimately did get the speaker paired with my phone and figured out what buttons did what, but it took nearly 15 minutes to do so.

Bluetooth Pairing
With both speakers and my phone lined up on a table (well within the proximity specified in each set-up guide), both speakers paired, however:
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - MUCH faster in pairing (mere seconds!).
Anker SoundCore - took nearly two minutes to complete the pairing process.

Pause/Play Button
Since I dismount to deliver packages to a customer's door routinely on my route, I really need to have a simply way to pause my music. I really like how both speakers offer this function on directly on the units, saving me from having to handle my phone.
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - I barely press the Play/Pause button and the speaker immediately reacts. There is NO hesitation.
Anker SoundCore - I press the Play/Pause button and there is a delay of about 5 seconds.. just long enough to make me think I didn't press hard enough and reach to do it again only for the speaker to finally react.

Volume/Overall Playback Quality
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - Wow. Just wow. It is truly unbelievable to hear such full sound, and bass(!), coming from such a small unit. I found myself perfectly pleased with the output without ever reaching max volume on the speaker itself. So I am looking forward to how well it will work in my LLV during my first road test. As for now, I am thoroughly impressed!
Anker SoundCore - I maxed out the volume on my phone and the speaker and was just not impressed. If I could guess, I'd say the max output this speaker achieved was only about 25% more than my speakerphone alone (while the OontZ Angle 3 Plus blew it out of the water with close to double, if not more, output than my speakerphone alone).
I also noted some kind of distortion or interference type background sound with the Anker SoundCore at mid volume and above.

Speakerphone/Mic
I was able to answer an incoming phone call on both units as described in each set-up guide. The quality of in-call sound on each speaker differed:
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - My husband's (the caller) voice was crisp and clear, as if he was sitting talking right next to me. There was no distortion or feedback out of the speaker. Husband reported nothing but a clear voice on his phone.
Anker SoundCore - Husband's voice was clear, but echoed horribly. No matter what volume level I used. There was no distortion (I was expecting this given the distortion with the music playback) bu the continuous echoing is a major issue for me. Husband reported a slight "faded" type of echo on his phone.

Road Test (in my LLV)
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - The sound is amazing in the truck! Thinking I would need it, I maxed the volume on both the speaker and my phone then pressed play on my music. Well, I certainly don't need max volume. I reduced the volume on both the speaker and my phone and found a very happy medium output. This speaker performs perfectly in the loud, rattling setting of a USPS LLV.. even while bouncing down rural dirt two tracks and washboard gravel roads. I am extremely pleased with this tiny speaker.
Anker Soundcore - Even with maxed volume settings, I could not get this speaker to perform anywhere near as well as the OontZ Angle 3 Plus. It had volume and was loud enough to hear over the vehicle's own noise, however the distortion/interference mentioned earlier was still present and in the truck during the road test it had what I would describe as an echoing effect on the music, specifically the singers' voices. It just wasn't clear. (I hope that makes sense.)

Battery Life/Listen While Charging
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - So far, the battery life is impressive. After receiving it, I charged it overnight (as recommended). I then had it connected to my phone for about an hour of home testing. Turned it off and I next used it at work on a Saturday.. had it powered on and connected to my phone and actively playing music for about 5.5 hours. I then used it again on Monday (much longer and busier days in the USPS, FYI).. had it on, connected and active continuously for nearly 9 hours. I have yet to see the low battery light come on. I plan to see just how many days of work I can get out of a single charge.
Anker Soundcore - I have no information for this section on this speaker since I am returning it.

Exterior/Cleaning
At first, I had the OontZ Angle 3 Plus setting on the dashboard of the LLV. This didn't last more than two stops. Despite having the four rubber "feet", the speaker still slid around causing more of a distraction than I would like. I ended up setting it on top of my personal bag, in a bin by my feet with the speaker facing up. This move really helped my piece of mind, knowing it will not go anywhere. This speaker has a soft rubber exterior. It is quite nice and feels luxurious, however... this exterior attracts all dust particles within 50 feet! USPS LLVs are *not* known for being the cleanest and even though I moved the speaker from the dust-ridden dashboard to a bin, it was still slathered with dust and dirt by the end of my route. I figured it was a fair trade, sacrificing the appearance for the gain of having decent music. But.. I got home and went to clean it. I will tell you, my expectations of this working were very low. I didn't think the dust would come off that supple rubber. But with a wet paper towel and a few slow wipes, it did. So, it can be cleaned up!

Case
I did purchase the case for this speaker ([[ASIN:B01NBDY6VP [Official] OontZ Angle 3 Plus Bluetooth Portable Speaker Carry Case, Neoprene with Aluminum Carabiner, reinforced zipper, by Cambridge SoundWorks [NOT FOR OontZ Angle 3]]]). I was mainly wanting a safe way to transport and store the speaker, but after reading the other reviews I was hoping I would be able to keep it clean in the case and still enjoy my music on my route. I received the case and used it yesterday. The case is extremely nice and I appreciate the interior mesh pocket. I have no need for it now, but I'm sure it will come in handy if I ever take this speaker on vacation and need to take the charging cables along. As for playback while in the case? Yeah, it was terribly muffled. It didn't work for me as it apparently has for others. Yet, the case itself is exactly what I was wanting for taking it to and from work. It is not as thickly padded as I would have expected, however it does protect the speaker.

Overall, for my specific purpose and intended use for a Bluetooth speaker, the Anker SoundCore simply won't cut it. However, it is still a nice speaker and will perhaps fit your needs perfectly. After all, most people don't drive LLVs and have the same high demands that go along with that. For me, the OontZ Angle 3 Plus is what I'll be bopping down the road to, mailbox to mailbox.

Happy hunting! Hope this review helps you out!

title: Bright, easy to clean, and a good value text: At a little under $10 per cushion and the crate, this is a pretty good option for a small group seating arrangement in a classroom or in a therapy space. As a play therapist, I am always looking for things that can do multiple things or that I can use in multiple ways because with all the stuff I accumulate, I need to make the most out of my space.

These have multiple colors which is great for having a kid pick their favorite color to sit on and talk about it. The foam works well with my foamnasium sets and these have become little “roofs” and stepping stones in imaginative play. These clean up easy and can be sanitized quickly with some wipes on both sides which makes it easier to keep kiddos safe in the office.

The only thing I don’t love about these is that there Is the same material on both sides. It is a slippery vinyl which can slide around really easily on my floors. If a kiddo wants to use this as a stepping stone or as a part of an obstacle course, I have to break out some rug tape or find another way to keep it from sliding out on them.

title: Fantastic Radio text: To mention right off the bat, I am not even an amateur radio operator, just someone who enjoys radio. I find radio to be far more romantic and compelling than modern methods of broadcasting. Staying up late in the night and turning the dial with the soft glow of the tuner, the sound of static and mystery that can sometimes accompany radio broadcasts offers something truly genuine that you can't get anywhere else today. That feeling is priceless and not duplicable (If that was even a word).

Anyway, this radio is good quality and contains the capability needed to reach further than most others. If you enjoy radio as I do, a clock radio, ghetto blaster or home stereo won't cut it. If you know what I am talking about, then this radio is for you. I've stayed up many nights listening to Coast to Coast AM on the internet, but it lacked the feeling something like this radio will bring you. I was unable to pick up a station on my home stereo to listen to CTC and was forced to use the internet. The internet provided a clear, stereo sounding broadcast and was very clear.

The CC Radio has been spoken about on the program for many years. I finally picked one up and am very pleased with it's performance. I can now pick up the radio broadcast of Coast to Coast AM and with all the nuances I expect of a a late night radio broadcast. When interesting speakers talk about compelling topics, a crystal clear internet broadcast does not move you inside. However, using the CC Radio, the slight static, the slight fading in and out and all other fantastic experiences you can only receive using a real radio, it has the ability to make you feel and even send chills up your spine. There is just something a good solid radio can do for you that nothing else can and the CC Radio delivers on that 100%.

You will not be disappointed and I really need to get my license.

title: These won me over text: Prior to receiving this review sample I was happy with in-ear type phones, but always grabbed headphones when I wanted to listen to music without disturbing others, These phones changed that. For one thing they are super comfortable. For another the sound is incredible. In fact I have been testing various phones - mainly from this brand, but also some Sennheiser models - and this is head and shoulders above the pack.

I'll be honest and disclose that comfort edges out sound when phones sound good enough. I will normally not quibble over a few hundred Hz one way or the other as long as I can wear the phones without noticing them. These are not only unobtrusive, but downright comfortable, which is a major reason why these have now replaced my trusty [[ASIN:B00ENZRS76 Brainwavz HM9 Hi-Fi Noise Isolating Headphones]].

Soundwise the specs do not begin to describe the richness, especially bass. In fact, when I read the 20 Hz to 20 MHz range I thought that the sound would be somewhat generic for phones in this range. I own a pair of IEMs (in-ear monitors) that go as low as 18 Hz at the same 95dB at 1mW sensitivity, yet these sound much deeper than those. I love the balance of sound across the frequency spectrum as though it's on a smooth continuum. Every one of my test albums I played through these phones sounded so good that I decided that it's time to hang up the headphones and go with these.

Part of the reason why I love these from a comfort perspective is the over the ear memory wire. I prefer that style, but not everyone does. They are definitely stiff and take on a shape that will be uniquely yours over time (and a very short time at that!) Also, while this ships with a [[ASIN:B00HPPL1M4 Brainwavz Hard Earphone Case]] the phones will not fit after you have contoured them to your ear. The case is useful for carrying around the array of adapters and tips that are included. In fact, the final reason I love these phones is the included triple-flange style silicon tips, which block out the rest of the world and allow me to focus solely on music.

If you love music and want to hear every note faithfully reproduced in their natural frequencies these phones are it. I can honestly say that I have not used a better set of phones from any brand in this price range, including some Sennheiser models that have a street price of fifty to seventy-five dollars more than these, so the value is definitely there.

title: Effortless performance text: Just a phenomenal cpu. This is probably the best upgrade Ive done, coming from an i7 7700k. I had 30 days to use and figure out if I wanted to stay with this or go with the latest AMD cpu.

Work- I used to have trouble running programs that were either too complex or inefficiently coded that it led to stutters, hitches, delays or freezes. One program that always caused massive trouble for me over the years was the Think or Swim trading platform. I originally upgraded to the i7 7700k and it could not handle more than 2-3 chart at a time running the time and sales and L2. Run some side charts and you could forget about trading, especially at the open when calculations need to be run at an extremely rapid pace. I even added a total of 32gb ddr4 3400 ram and it still wouldnt run properly. Arguably, the program is encoded really inefficiently requiring much more from the CPU than necessary. Ive tried many different trading programs and this one caused the most trouble. After stepping up to the i9 9900k I can now run this inefficiently encoded program on my main chart screen, with two different tickers having 4 different time frames each with its own L2 and time and sales, PLUS 15 side charts without a hitch! Also im running my browser with at least 5 tabs open and video/audio running. Absolutely amazing. I never thought I could get it to work like this.

Gaming- even if the cpu doesnt run at 100 pct it affects the quality of the experience of the gameplay, especially for demanding games, or just poorly coded, inefficient ones. RPGs fall into these categories. I.e., Kingdom Come Deliverance. Video and streaming is flawless as well.

Vs AMD- Performance isnt always about raw numbers, if there are too many peaks and valleys, it affects the quality of the experience. I havent personally compared it directly to the newest AMD cpu, but having looked at the side by side comparisons, AMD cpu seems to put out better numbers for work-related applications, but clearly on the gaming side, intel is superior. From my observation, the quality of the experience with Intel was greater because the frame rate was consistent with much less, if any micro stuttering, which you can see with the AMD chips. As a result, Intel's presentation was more effortless and smooth. With the AMD setup, you can see some graying/discoloring/hazy effects in demanding scenes. It seems like AMD is an overcharged chip that experiences these dips because of that, causing a deterioration in the experience. AMD is perfectly fine for work I presume, but not for me when it comes to gaming. Intel performs like a more refined, polished product. This is just based on my personal observation of their performance in these two different areas.

Overclocking- its perfectly fine using it the way it is. No need to overclock, but of course you can overclock it. I run mine 16 hours a day without any problems. Top recommendation at the asking price these days.

title: TERRIBLE picture quality and mediocre design text: I purchased this player as a replacement because I clumsily killed my Toshiba SD-P1900 9" player. I figured, even with a half-inch loss of screen size, I'd still be in the game, right? Panasonic's a great brand name, right? WRONG.

This particular Panasonic model not only has lousy picture quality and no remote, but there are no fast forward or fast rewind functions other than skipping all the way ahead or all the way back to the beginnings of scenes. I'm a film buff, so I like to be able to back up two or three seconds to check out that explosion in fps detail, or to move forward or backward at 2X or 4X or 8X, etc. Plus, if you extend the adjustable screen forward as shown in most illustrations, you cannot see or reach the control buttons without moving it out of your way.

I'm no video product engineer, but I hope my impression of the VERY inadequate picture quality and overall poor design of this player makes you think twice. Go for the Toshiba instead!

title: Fairly sturdy, but difficult to mount
text: The trays seem to hold everything in place, but mounting these can be a chore depending on what you are mounting them on.  My desk is extremely dense / hardwood and ideally i would use a drill to drive in the screws. However it is not possible to fit a drill bit between the gaps.  So I drilled pilot holes and screwed in by hand.  The screws are made of a fairly soft metal, and several stripped out even after drilling a bigger pilot hole. It would be nice if they used some sort of mounting bracket that you could mount with a drill, then snap these into place.  As it is, they probably work OK for softer desks, but maybe not the best choice for a really dense wood.

title: Adds 8 Ethernet Ports (for Wired Connections to Additional Devices) to Your Network text: Be sure to watch the manufacturer’s video (bottom of product page), if you’re not quite sure what this NETGEAR 8-PORT GIGABIT ETHERNET UNMANAGED SWITCH (GS308) is supposed to do. For me, it adds 8 Ethernet ports to supplement the 5 Ethernet ports on my Netgear Nighthawk router.

The ports are used for connecting additional devices to your network with Ethernet cables. These are wired connections, so your devices have to be close enough to the switch to be reached with Ethernet cables. The switch is easy to set up (see photos of installation guide).

I’m a firm believer in Netgear hardware. My Netgear routers have always been rock-solid, so I’m expecting no problems with this switch.

I’d recommend always registering your Netgear products, so that you will get emails if there are important firmware updates available, or if any other significant issues come up regarding your products. The company is very good about sending these notifications.

title: Great reception
text: The reception this antenna gave our weather alert radio was exceptional.  Even when we moved the radio to different places in the house, the reception and clarity was never affected.  We never had to adjust it or point it around to get great reception.  Wherever we set it with the radio, it performed exceptionally throughout hurricane Irma.

title: WD GET YOUR ACT TOGETHER text: I originally bought a WD 2tb NVME to use as my main OS, but it would not migrate/clone properly even with their own software. I downloaded a 3rd party migration/cloning software and that didnt work either. I tried nearly everything I could for 1.5 days! I even tried backing up/restoring manually and then repairing. Nothing worked. It was a complete waste of time. I didnt even learn anything in the process other than learning that I should go with a company that has a readily available comprehensive solution that doesn't needlessly waste your valuable time. 1.5 days down the drain.

So I ended up migrating my Samsung 1tb NVME to a new Samsung 2tb NVME and it couldnt have been any easier. < 15 minutes, very quick! I previously, migrated from a corsair SSD to Samsung 1tb NVME (when i couldnt get another SSD to migrate properly), and that was flawless as well. Why didnt I initially go with the Samsung 2tb instead of WD? Press had positive news about it. I am not a fanboy so I like to try different solutions. That was a mistake. What's apparent to me after this experience is that Samsung is better than all their competitors at providing a comprehensive package of the best hardware and software. The experience is FLAWLESS. I havent had any issues with any of their storage solutions to date.

Why did I bother writing this review? Because I wasted 1.5 days. Something has to come out of it. Maybe itll help someone or maybe WD will get their act together and work on their cloning/migration software because the hardware seems to be fantastic.

Disclosure, I bought and paid for everything myself and I still own HDs/SSDs/MicroSds by WD (only old HDs), Sandisk (microsds, ssds), Seagate (HD), Samsung (SSDs, Micro SDs and NVMEs).

title: Made Well and Works Well text: USB-C cables are the one cable type I usually have trouble putting my hands on in my house, and I need them for charging my tablet as well as my video lights. I selected this one because I like cables with braided insulation and so far this one has worked out well for me.

This is a 6' cable which is just about right for my needs. It is long enough to reach my devices when I have it plugged into my USB brick on my desk without requiring rearrangement of everything on my desk just to make it fit. Longer would be handy but unnecessary, but shorter would make it a lot less useful for me.

I have not used it for data transfer, just charging up devices, and so far it has worked out well in that capacity. The connection is snug and I have not noticed any particular difference in charging speeds between this cable and the OEM cables that came with my devices.

I am especially pleased with the build quality. The cable is stiff (as to be expected) and it should hold up for a long time against kinks and twists. The junctions where the cable goes into the plastic casings for the connectors are tight and allow no play which is a big plus for me as these are the spots where I have had cables fail most often. Overall, I am not unhappy with the build quality.

This is a decent third-party USB-C cable that works very well for me. It is made well and it does a fine job charging my devices. It isn’t too expensive either, making it easy to recommend.

title: Good FOV with very little distortion text: A lot of these cheap webcams use very small sensors and rely on super wide optics to see the room. They also tend to overstate their resolving power, claiming to send a 1080 sized image that looks more like an upscaled 480. I'm happy to say this is a degree better than those!
The sensor is still small, as expected, but the optics aren't super wide to the point that edges distort. In fact, it seems pretty rectilinear (straight lines stay relatively straight in the background). The resolution seems decent as well. I'm not sure if it's actually resolved a full HD image like it claims, but it is definitely more resolution than a lot of the cheaper webcams I've tried. It looks pretty good and I'd argue that any live web call, skype, zoom, etc, will look perfectly fine with this camera and play at whatever resolution that protocol is capable of clearly.
The thing that sorta disappointed me, however, was the "ring light" built in. I mean, I have a REAL ring light so I get what that should do, but this sorta does... nothing. It doesn't create soft shadows or a circular catch light in my eyes- in fact, it's very hard to discern the difference between capture with the light on versus off. In a dark room, it can add a bit of illumination to the subject to make you a little easier to see, but it really isn't all that bright and under normal lighting conditions in my office, it makes zero difference at all. It also seems to get kind of warm as long as it is plugged in, even if not currently active, so I'm going to be in the habit of disconnecting it when not using, and only plugging it in when I need to make a video call at my desk.
For what it is, it is definitely a better webcam than most of the cheap ones, but it definitely is not perfect!

title: Outstanding Durable Cat5e Cable text: I have used and tested more Ethernet cables than I can remember and there is no question, all Ethernet cables are not created equally. While I had no experience with the ZOSI brand prior to testing their Ethernet cables, after thoroughly testing them I have been thoroughly impressed.

Typically any device requiring an Ethernet cable will come with one in the packaging - it will work (usually). A good comparison is those cables are much like an old car - it should get you there, whereas this cable is like a high end sports car - it will get you there lightning fast, without fail.

This Cat5e is designed to be thin, but don’t let that fool you into thinking that it lacks capacity - within the ample PVC covering contains 4 pairs of twisted 100% bare copper wires for fast transfer speeds. The connector bases are reinforced at each end of the wire which really help hold all of the wires in place even if you have to bend and twist it to fit it within the plug.

One area where this cable could use improvement is the plug hood lacks a protective rubber boot guard that protects the clip on the plug - this becomes very important when snaking the cable through walls and tight spaces. Due to not having this feature it is critical to wrap the boot and plug with a small piece of electrical tape to make sure not to unintentionally snag anything as the cable is being snaked.

I love the grey PVC shielding on this cable - not only is it waterproof, durable and will help the cable withstand damage but it can be run along a wall and then painted to match the wall color.

I used this 65 foot cable to run between a PoE switch and an external security camera, this cable supplies power and transmits data to and from that security cameras - after thoroughly testing this cable over the last 3 months I’ve been nothing but impressed by this product.

This has proven to be an outstanding, dependable Ethernet Cable - this is really a top of the line cable that you’ll love.

This is a purchase that you’ll never regret. I’ve been utilizing two ZOSI cables for a3 months now and I’ve had nothing but outstanding results from them.

This is definitely a brand and product I recommend.

text: I was looking for a simple sort of cd clock radio to keep on a nightstand. I went to a local electronics store and first tried a litte Sony machine, was set to buy it, and then the salesman showed me this Phillips unit.  The sound was overwhelmingly better on the Phillips unit.  I admit I'm not an audiophile, but I just want something that sounds good when I played CDs at bedtime.  I quickly dismissed the little Sony and went for this unit.  Since having it about a week now, I really like the sound from the CD player.  I did try my iPhone 4 on it to see if it would connect, and it did and it played music like a champ.  Strong and clear.  I have a rubber bumper on my iPhone and had to remove it to make the phone fit properly but that's no big deal.  In fact what I'm thinking of doing is reprogramming my older iPhone (first generation) with nothing but music on it and leaving that plugged in the Phillips unit.  I keep my iPhone 4 in a different charger in a different room so it doesn't disrupt my sleep AND so I won't forget it when I'm leaving the house.  So far I'm a happy camper with this little Philips unit.  The only con is the brightness of the backlit display which is rather bright.  I placed the unit in a different part of the room where the remote still works but the brightness of the display doesn't affect my sleep.  I like a dark room!

title: Decent Basic Player; Minor Odd Behaviors text: The last Blu-Ray player I owned bit the dust about a month after we got it and I have been quietly looking for another one to replace it. I was given the opportunity to try this one and I took it. It's not a bad player and it seems to work, but there are a couple of behaviors about it that I do not like.

It is as simple a player as it gets. It's not fancy and it doesn't do a lot of extras beyond basic player functions - pause, play, eject, skip, etc. At the end of the day it's all that's needed. It connects via HDMI which is fine, and the resolution and picture size can be tweaked in the menu system which is good. Playback is fine and I have had no issues with picture quality.

There are two things about this player that bother me, both of which are annoyances but neither are deal breakers. First, when the unit is powered on it asks for the user to set the language and voice prompting. That's fine the first time. But, this player does it every time it is powered on again and that gets irritating. Second, when a disc is put in and playback starts, there's a very brief hesitation in the sound within the first 10 seconds of playback. This hesitation is just enough to notice, and then it's gone, almost like it skips a quarter-second of sound or something. It doesn't happen again until an eject operation and a disc is inserted again. I have observed this with multiple discs.

There is no HDMI cable in the box. Keep that in mind when you buy - you'll need to either have a cable already or you'll have to buy one separately.

This is not a bad player and so far it is working better than our previous Blu-Ray player. It sticks to the basics and it gets them right. There are a couple of minor odd behaviors that bug me a little but at the asking price I can overlook those.

title: Low battery and camera shuts off with NO WARNING text: Problem #1: Camera eats up normal AAA Energizer batteries quickly. Maybe get 5 pictures and then it quits. Change to AAA Lithium Entergizer Batteries. Now, you are OK. The sensor on the camera trips just after a few underwater photos.

Size, and functionality seems comfortably nice. Not too technical to get started using this camera. Found this camera a great first step for beginners who want to document their scuba dives, take photos on surface, on the boat, on the shore, etc. But, hold on... when you want to go scuba diving:

Problem #2: Does not have an underwater setting for diffused lighting. Only Flowers and Landscapes. What dah? Is this not for underwater use? Hello! All of my underwater photos could have improved by 100 percent if there was a setting for underwater lighting. The sunny days at the shore, boat photos, trees and countryside photos, ok. These were nice, the detail in the landscape photos were good. You can even use the camera without its plastic shell. The protective casing makes this an excellent choice as a first step scuba camera. But, how are the photos underwater? This is a $100 camera, so please do not expect high quality photos from your squid, lobster, or grouper ... posing for you underwater, even at 25 feet. This makes a great first step camera, getting your feet wet with underwater photography.

Problem #3: strap holder is on right side only (for right hand use.) Better if there was a strap holder on both sides, for those who need on left hand side (underwater.) Why? My first hand experience is that you want to use this point and shoot camera using either your right hand or your left hand. Not both. This camera is a quick shot camera, not "oh, wait a minute, pose, look this way, now smile, ok, cheese ..." This camera sits on your right hand or left hand while diving. Now, if you see that nice fish, and want to take a picture, you try with one hand. If the strap is on the wrong side, it blocks your ability to use the left hand to hold the camera. So, this camera is ONLY FOR RIGHT HANDED folks. But, do not let go of the camera underwater, you may loose it. Right? Not really. Nice thing about this basic camera is that it float to surface (rather than sink into the bottom.) Wow, did that save me a few times. Dropped off my wrist. Then floated for a few feet, and I got it back. If it sunk down 300 Feet, I could have kissed this baby --- good bye.

I have taken about 50 surface images, and 50 underwater images, using this Intova. All 50 surface photos, with reasonable sunlight, were excellent considering this camera. Of the 50 photos underwater images, about 10 were acceptable, the other 40 were blurry and not acceptable. Yeah, I had to spend another 15 minutes per each of the 10 photos to convert the poor colors into something more exciting, adding RED, adding CONTRAST, adding BRIGHTNESS using a photo editor. But, I did get 10 acceptable underwater photos. And that was great. Really Great. These photos were generally above 25 feet.

Scuba divers need to know the difficulty of taking photos underwater while attempting to swim around reefs, wrecks, squid, lobster and other photographers. Buy this camera as a first step. Just correct that battery issue, take lots of pictures, and learn the responsibility of underwater photography is the PERSON BEHIND THE CAMERA. For $100, not bad, eh?

title: They're Okay text: I have a terrible time with my eyes when I'm at the computer for too long. The white background on most websites makes my eyes hurt. When I got new glasses I ordered a pair of blue light blocking computer glasses as well as regular progressives for my nearsighted eyes, but I rarely use the computer glasses when I use my laptop. So I thought this screen might help. There were two, so my husband could have one too.

Maybe it takes longer for some people, but I don't see any difference. I still get a headache when I use the laptop too long, so maybe it's not the blue light that bothers me.

Alas, I've never had any luck with these screen protectors anyway. With this one, I followed the directions to the letter to get all the dust off the screen and the bubbles from between the protector and the screen. The "squeegee" card to press the bubbles out worked really well, but there are still two bubbles in the middle of the screen that are there because there is a speck of dust there. When the screen is bright, the little speck of dust that was invisible when I was using the sticky thing to get all the dust off is now very visible. If you have better luck with putting on protective screens, you may like this one. It does not impede the touch screen function in any way.

title: Fine Two-Pack of Cables text: If you own an iPhone, iPad or one of the newer iPods you are familiar with the need for lightning cables. These are basically special USB cables that are reversible and are specific to Apple electronics. The problem with these cables is that they can be expensive, especially if you go with Apple-branded cables. There are some good third-party cables available, and they represent a good value when compared to Apple cables. I get offered a LOT of lightning cables for review and I have noticed an unpleasant trend: most vendors hawking their cables to not mention MFI certification at all, anywhere, and this is important. This particular cable is clearly marked in the description as certified, so it is worth some consideration on that basis alone when compared to many of the others available.

These come in a two-pack, and they are a little more than 3’ in length. These have hard plastic plugs on the end and the length is insulated with a vinyl sheath for protection. So far these have shown no signs of fatigue at the plugs and they work very well. I have been able to charge my phone as well as connect it to iTunes. I attempted to pull the shielding away from the plug and was unable to do so, so I see no risk of exposing the wires inside the casing.

I mentioned the certification above, and I will restate that this is a very important feature. Because these cables are certified, they are guaranteed compatible and will work. If you use a cable that is not certified you might get messages on your phone or tablet that the cable is unrecognized and it might not work as desired. I have worked with non-certified cables and sometimes they work while others do not work at all. I have never had a certified cable fail me.

If you are looking for a less expensive alternative to Apple-branded cables, make sure you select a product that has been certified to work. This two pack of cables is a good choice; so far, they have given me no trouble at all and they have worked well for me. They are definitely compatible and are made well too. And, getting two of them instead of just one in the package means you can have one in the office and one at home.

Disclosure: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at minimal or no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

title: More like a 4-in-1 text: The hi-res touchscreen is the main reason to buy this computer. Everything looks very sharp. It comes in a thin aluminum case you can flip into tent mode or with the keyboard against the ground or into a big tablet. It's way more than fast enough for home and work. The SSD is great. The Intel graphics are OK and you can play some good games with decent framerates (I have Epic and Steam installed). There's a sliding camera shutter. The battery lasts about 6-8 hours with normal usage and the whole machine is very quiet and non-intrusive. Has thunderbolt 4 and 2 USB 3.2s.

The trackpad is huge but hard to press down on sometimes. The sound should get louder. The keyboard is good but the keys are silver and can be hard to see sometimes even though they light up. The screen is somewhat reflective so I set the Windows background to gray. Overall though it's a great big screen laptop.

title: Reliable, no-frills tablet for folks on a budget text: I received this as a review sample and have been using it for a little less than a week. At the time of this review this tablet is shipping with Android 4.4.4. Before I dive into what I like and why I rated it so highly I want to set expectations.

This DOES NOT come with bluetooth, and the screen and cameras are not especially spectacular. The screen is readable (easily so) and has nice, vivid colors. However compared to even my Note 3 phone it falls short. As the cameras, for some reason tablet makers seem to skimp on those as though they are an afterthought.

Since there is no bluetooth you are stuck with the internal speaker or using phones. The internal speaker is not what I would call optimum for listening to music, but the included phones are surprisingly decent. I also connected one of my bluetooth speakers that accepts 3.5mm input and the sound was excellent, so while this does not have bluetooth, you can still stream music to it.

Another thing it does not have is bloatware that every other tablet (and phone) seems to be plagued with. That is one of the reasons why I rated this so highly. But the real reason why I gave this tablet five stars is price. At the time of this review it is selling for sixty bucks, which is not a bad deal for an entry level tablet - especially if you want to browse the web, stream music or wile away the day on facebook.

It is a complete package that includes a stylus, soft bag, charger and cable, and OTG adapter. The latter allows you to connect USB peripherals to the micro USB charging port. I tested it with a keyboard, then a mouse and it recognized both. The USB charging port is another thing I like - it;s a micro USB type, which is a major improvement over some entry level tablets that I have tested that use a non-standard barrel connector.

You can add a 32GB SD card using a TF adapter. I tested it with an old SanDisk Ultra 32GB MicroSDHC Class 10 UHS Memory Card that was immediately recognized. The application manager allows you to move some apps to the SD card, so as you add your favorites some will be eligible for running off an external card (depending on the app, of course.) Browsing the web, using Google's location feature and maps, and Youtube all performed with no lag or issues. In fact I would put the performance head-to-head against my Verizon Ellipsis 7 4G LTE Tablet, Black 7-Inch 8GB tablet. Do note, though, that if you have all services turned on and are constantly using this tablet you are going to get about 2.5 to 3 hours of use time if you are not connected to a charger. For some folks that may be a deal breaker, so take that into account.

Basically this is a stripped down, but very functional tablet for folks on a budget. If you can live without bluetooth and will be using it near a power source it's a decent tool (or toy, depending on your outlook) at an affordable price, It is a perfect first tablet for someone who also has an Android phone, and is definitely useful for folks addicted to the web.

title: Excellent for drawing or scratch paper! text: This board is another knock off the classic Boogie Board, a great tool for drawing temporary things- a doodle, a scratch pad for math homework, a note on the fridge, etc. It is an analog touch-sensitive surface that "reveals" a more reflective back layer when the opaque top layer is pressed. Basically, think of it like a touch-sensitive etch-a-sketch. When done, you can erase the entire thing using the button.
It is NOT a digital tablet, it is very much analog, but it does have a battery used to zap the screen clear when done (resets the liquid crystal to opaque).
My kids love these. The original boogie board has a bit higher contrast, but this is a good value.

title: Exactly what I expected--maybe a little better, even. text: I spent a long time hmmming and hawing over this purchase. I really wanted the OEM Panasonic case for my LX7, but at $65 here on Amazon, it was just too expensive. I compared the aftermarket cases for this camera and examined photographs closely. This was the winner for apparent quality and design. And it lived up to expectations.

I was worried that it would block some of the screen or controls in the back, but this is not an issue at all. This case fits almost perfectly (screw mount is slightly out of alignment with the hole on the bottom of the camera--but it works), and is of as high-quality materials as one can imagine, given that this is *not* a leather case. The prospective purchaser should be aware that the vast majority of the cases on Amazon for the LX7 are not real leather. You can tell a case is real leather on here if it costs a fortune. The real leather cases on Amazon are all >$50, and some are $100+.

For $15, this case represents an excellent value, as it fits pretty well, is well-made (sturdier than I expected!), and looks very nice. (I have the white LX7 and I bought the light brown case--the color of a well-worn baseball glove). One thing: as expected, the strap is made of vinyl, and looks it. I will likely be upgrading to a proper, padded camera strap though, so this is of little import, at least to me.

If you are on the fence, take my advice and go for it. This is a good value, and a decent case--especially for this price. I did, and I have no regrets.

Note: you will have to remove the case to access the battery/SD card compartment and the ports, as is the norm with all cases of this type for this camera (I was unable to find one that did not require this).

---

UPDATE: After several months of hard use, this case has held up remarkably well. No evidence of wear. I get compliments on it, as well. Note: Do not attach the camera to a tripod with the bottom of the case on. The knob on the case is threaded to allow you to do this, but getting it off the tripod mount afterwards is a nightmare. Just take it out of the case--trust me.

My favorite to this day is how intelligent the lighting is on the buttons; lift them slightly and the lights turn on, but remain off when lying still for a while.

I haven't used the voice features after the initial night, so I can't comment on that. Everything still works great, and overall I find the button configuration pretty intuitive. I still confuse the Exit and Last buttons sometimes, so maybe some tweaking could be used between those two (if there hasn't been yet). But the main issue I have is how the power buttons don't work properly. When turning on both box and TV, the TV will turn on but the X1 box won't. It's been like that with two TVs. And when powering them off the TV will turn off but the box won't. I have to manually turn it off, which is a step more than I'd like but I've adjusted.

title: Good Hardware, Not-So-Good Setup text: I work a lot with smart watches but this is the first health monitor/GPS watch I have used. I was excited to have the
opportunity to work with it, and I was hopeful that it would be a good unit. Epson is a brand I know well from their printers, so out of the gate I had some expectations. This watch has proven to be a mixed bag.

I will start with what I believe are the strongest features. This watch has a much better-than-average charger. Many watches I have used have a magnetic charger that is either poorly constructed or will not stay on the device it'’s charging. This one, however, is a clamp-based charger that does a good job of holding the watch even under its own weight without letting it slip or shift. I would have liked to see other manufacturers adopt this kind of charging clamp.

The battery lasts for a very long time. I charged it up completely and after taking it from the charger I deliberately left it on the shelf to drain. It's rated for 20 hours, and I assume that is for active use. Letting it sit idle, it lasted two weeks for me. It of course drains much faster when it is actively being used so once I started using it I had to charge it again. This is a handy data point if you're traveling - if you're going for a weekend, it holds enough charge to get through in most cases, and if you are an infrequent user it will retain a charge for a while.

The display is very clear and easy to read. I have had no issues at all with the display and I am very pleased with how easy on the eyes it is.

One of the issues I have with most wrist-wear of any kind is getting it to fit properly. I have large hands and wrists, and I found this watch to be a bit snug on even the loosest setting. This is par for the course for me. I was hopeful it would fit a bit better, but it wasn't to be.

The aggravation started when I set up the software and paired the watch to my phone. The Bluetooth pairing did not go smoothly and I tried several times to get it straight. I finally switched over to setting it up through the watch instead of through the phone, and I was able to get it working and connected. While this is an acceptable work-around for someone with patience, it is an aggravation for someone who prefers things to just work the way they're supposed to.

I will say I am not especially impressed with the software app. I think it is a little too overly complex and counter-intuitive, but it does work and it has a lot of features. It does a good job of tracking progress.

So, aside from setup and fit, how does it work? It seems to work well. I am very familiar with sport GPS units so I assumed this one would work about the same, and it does. It acquires the satellites and uses those to report position back to the phone app so you can track yourself. This is useful when you want to see where you went and how far. The speed of acquisition of the satellites seems to be roughly the same as with my hand-held units. The heart rate monitor seems to be good and in measuring manually for comparison it appears to be accurate. The step feature is a good quick measurement and is sufficient to replace a dedicated pedometer.

Overall this is a decent health watch, but there's some room for improvement. It looks great, it works well and it's easy to read. It is hampered by less-than-idea setup and software, and it would be nice if it fit a little better.

title: Took some time to get used to, but they are great! text: I'm going to swallow my pride and admit that it took me a REALLY long time to figure out how to get a good fit/seal with these headphones. Honestly, 30 minutes of fiddling with them, and I was ready to give up and send them back - they were uncomfortable and offered no better sound than my $10 pair of bud headphones. BUT...if you happen to have the same problem, hang in there! These headphones really are incredible!

What I didn't realize at first was these come with one of the optional "wing" skins already on. I had been trying to put another pair of the wings on over it, and it was awful. But lo and behold, when I took the one skin off and put the correct wing size on...then figured out the right bud size for me...then figured out exactly how to twist them in, allow the wing to hook under the groove in my ear, and press slightly to get a good seal in my ear canal...WOW, these have amazing sound!

They have been very easy to pair with any device, I love the charging dock, and I've been able to run them a long time before re-charging. I might be most impressed by the range, though. I do use these when working out, but more often I use them while doing housework, and I can go several rooms apart - putting laundry away, even going outside to dump the garbage - and the sound stays constant. And once I figured out the fit/seal in my ears, they have been comfortable to wear.

title: GPS Carrying Case text: They call this an "AmazonBasics" carrying case and I think the moniker fits well. Nothing fancy here, but a very well made expandable case for holding your portable GPS.

I have two GPS units and both screens are marred from throwing the units into a backpack or drawer and the display getting scratched. This protective case is very easy to use as it expands to contain the GPS... no snaps, velcro, or buttons to get in the way. The case has enough compression to hold both my GPS units in securely.

The case has a front pocket to slip a couple of bucks into or a card or a note. Nice looking, well made, and quite usefull.

title: Easy to set up; working well so far. text: We had an Asus router that was working extremely well over the past couple of years, but for some reason it just went completely kaputt. Finally, it was time to set this one up.
The installation was a breeze, and I love that there's an app to allow me to monitor it instead of having to use a web browser. However, the initial web page needs some updating!
I'm pretty tech-savvy, but IT stuff always gets me hot and bothered. This one was one of the better experiences.

So far so good, but I will update if I need to change my rating.

title: Fun Assortment!
text: Stickers such as these have been very popular with my eighteen year old daughter. She uses them to cover her notebooks, folders, and letters to her friends. (She's away at college and sends a lot of letters!). These are a good quality sticker. They are sturdy enough as far as stickers go. The colors are vibrant. It's a fun assortment!

title: LOOKS LIKE NEW! text: I got mine from Omega Distribution USA, and I have to say, I'm IMPRESSED! This thing looks and acts like brand new. I've bought good condition "refurbished" handsets before, but this is something special. I don't know where they found a V20 in such condition, with a battery that seems to be holding its original charge like this. In fact, it even seems to come with the original Nougat firmware- usually a phone that has been used recently would have been upgraded to Oreo already.
Only problem is that I was looking for a version that would work with T-mobile, and while this handset is unlocked from Verizon, it doesn't work as well as an actual T-mobile branded would be (that's the H918 model). So sadly, I have to return this gem of a phone and get the one with the correct bands and software for my needs. Its a shame, I wish I could keep it. But if you're looking for a Verizon model to use with Verizon service, this is EXACTLY what you want for a great price!
As for the V20 as a phone- if you know what it is already, you don't need me to tell you. It's one of the last great super phones ever made. Built like a tank, this phone is easy to repair yourself if need be (no glue or heat gun needed to open it up and, say, slap on some thermal paste to keep the CPU cool under a load)- I've seen walkthroughs to replace cracked screens, camera backs, vibrating motors, etc, that require nothing more than a small screwdriver. If the battery starts to go or you need more power than a stock one offers, you can easily replace them and get BIGGER capacity ones. IR blaster, second screen display (which is really neat!) HDMI out via USB-c, pretty much everything and the kitchen sink is thrown in here. They don't make them like this anymore, folks. This was the last of the greats. That's why people still have and use them in 2019!

title: Mine does not work correctly, going to return this.
text: I would give this one star, except for the cheap price.  The number one problem with mine is that the heart rate monitor does not accurately measure heart rate, or even close.  After 15-20 minutes of running, the readings fluctuated wildly.  At first it was 120, then 131, then a few seconds later 85!  I tried looser and tighter band settings, and also tried rotating the watch to position the sensor on different areas of my wrist (to detect pulse better), and it still never worked correctly.  I'm not sure if mine is just defective, or this product is poorly designed.  There are also a few other minor issues, such as the dull screen (see photo - very hard to read when outdoors) and also my device has randomly shut off a few times.  Overall, I would not recommend this product for anyone.  It's too bad, though, because the design is nice (as is the price) and the bluetooth connectivity and software work well.

title: What is the purpose of this device?
text: My AT&T/Direct TV salesman talked me into buying this worthless overpriced junk to somehow enable voice commands for my DirectTV remote (they are about the only tv service that has a remote without it).  Didn't work.  3 IT people in the family worked on it for over 2 hours just to get it connected to the Internet.  The only instructions I found on the Internet about using it to voice control my remote basically required "hacking" and reprogramming the Echo.  So gave up on that and cancelled by Direct TV service to go back to my old service that had voice commands and a wonderful search engine built right into the remote.  We did get it to stream music - and it sounded like a scratchy LP. So I have to buy expensive speakers for that? I'm out of table space for all of this and hate ugly cords running everywhere.  I'll just stick a CD in my DVD player or computer and listen to the music I want to listen to.  Siri on my iPhone has a better search engine.  It seems like every device you want to connect to (and I really don't want to connect it to anything - I simply don't care) costs more money for special equipment that will work with the Echo.  Spent HOURS of research on the internet trying figure out it's vague instructions.  The only time I need a smart anything is when I'm in my car and need directions - Siri does that quite well most of the time and I don't need to buy anything else.  In my home I have two computers, my iPhone and television.  All are pretty smart and keep me well informed on news and weather.  I have enough noise in my life - I don't need a device that just adds scratchy noise.  As far as music streaming Sirius is a huge waste of money so I stopped that service and decided my hundreds of CD's and/or an MP3 player can play all the music I want to hear.  I don't need any more complications in my life and I'm sick of trying to get devices to talk to each other - and the echo is the worst example of this.

title: The perfect cleaner for your unsightly, smudgy phone screen, to make it shiny new again. text: Try them. You will love them. Guaranteed.

I've been using iCloths for several years now. They are the perfect phone screen cleaner, hands down!! I've tried other products from dry cloths, to alcohol rubs, to my t-shirt, nothing else comes close to clearning so thoroughly. One cloth is plenty!!

They may see a little too dry to work when you are first using them. Don't worry. They are the perfect moistness.

A trick. One side of the cloth is more rough than the other. Use the rough side to clear the phone screen. It works much better than the smoother side.

I fold the cloth in half so there are two of these rough sides. I use one side to do the initial cleaning and the other side to do the final - perfection clean.

Then, I fold the cloth inside out to clean off my finger tips before discarding the cloth.

A suggestion - could you make a biodegradable wrapper?

The price varies between 10 and 17 cents. Obviously, it's better when you get them for the lower price by buying a larger quantity.

title: It works- sorta text: I got this specifically to use with my Amazon Fire Stick 4k. I have a wireless media remote keyboard that I used to use with an HTPC that needs a USB dongle, and wanted to also take advantage of the wired Ethernet jack I had previously installed by my TV (wired is always more reliable for streaming in our experience). This device seemed perfect! It connects to the power socket of the Fire stick and offers a USB hub with ethernet jack.
The problem is, the ethernet jack doesn't seem to be recognized by the Firestick at all! I know what it is supposed to do when it recognizes a network jack, but the option to use the wired internet simply doesn't show up- it doesn't know or acknowledge it is there!
On the upside, at least the USB sockets work, so I was able to use my media remote keyboard. In fact, this device comes in two parts- one is a USB host plug that allows a single USB connection while passing power, and a standard USB hub + ethernet that attaches to that. In all honestly, if I just want to use the USB media remote, I don't need the hub... I can plug it directly into the host port without the hub attached. Its a shame because I really want ethernet. So it only half works.

title: A lightweight, sturdy mono-pod for hikers, birders, bikers, and other camera buffs needing portable support
text: For times when handheld isn't steady enough and a tripod is awkward, this compact, lightweight, but sturdy mono-pod is a great addition to an amateur or semi-pro's gear bag. It adjusts down to 17 inches for storage, carrying, and tabletop use. It has four snug-fitting but easy to twist adjustment wheels (not clips). Fully extended, it's five feet long. A screw-on rubber tip is on the foot when delivered. An alternative substantial screw on metal tip for use in loose ground is also included. If you need greater stability, you can purchase accessory "feet" from Amazon. A handy wrist strap is attached to the mono-pod (removable, if it gets in your way). If you prefer, the unit comes in a beautiful sturdy black nylon zipper pouch with an adjustable shoulder strap. The camera mount has two screw sizes (one screw with two different ends). My Canon DSLR wouldn't fit the way it came, but I just unscrewed the top, turned the screw around, and put it back together. Perfect.

title: Good for IOT or guest WIFI networks, but wouldn't reconnect to my main router after a reboot. text: The Wavlink N300 Wi-Fi Range Extender is a quick and easy way to extend your 2.4gHz network to reach the remote corners of your house. It is easy to set up if you're familiar with normal router setup procedures (connect to its wifi or via ethernet cable, then access the router configuration through a browser). It will normally create a wifi SSID that's different from your original wifi, but you can just force it to use the same name.

For my phones and computers, I use my 5G wifi network but the older 2.4 Ghz is great for home automation products such as switches, doorbells, and cameras. Keeping those devices separate from your main network will keep your main network running smoothly and free up a lot of IP addresses on that network.

This device is very stable once it is set up. My IOT devices have been able to communicate at a good speed and have not lost connections yet.

Unfortunately, this extender did not automatically connect with my main router again when I rebooted it. In fact, I was forced to reset the device and set it up all over again in order for it to work. I can't say for sure that the problem is caused by this device or by my main router. It's just my personal experience. Perhaps test this functionality while you're still in your return period for the product.

title: Fantastic battery life. text: These are my first wireless ear buds. I've got a couple of $100+ IEMs, the Sony WH-1000X M3, and Audio-Technica over-the-ear headphones. I think I've got a good sense of under-$500 sound quality, and these Technics are slightly overpriced in my opinion, but they still sound fanstastic.
I have smaller ear canals than normal (as told by my audiologist), so I always opt for a size down when trying on tips. I followed the instructions to insert these Technics buds into my ear holes with the smaller tips, and they fit great. They don't come out with vigorous head-shaking, and haven't come out during my work commutes. I walk about half an hour a day, and so far so good.

The ear buds pair easily, and they always connect to my phone when I take them out of the case. I tried the noise-canceling, but found it to be sub-par compared to my Sony headphones. Sony actually sucks out the volume outside; these Technics add a white noise filter, which to me obstructs the audio I'm listening to. There's an app you can download to your phone which turns off the white-noise filter, so I did that, and turned of equalizer settings. On my phone I use Poweramp v3, AntennaPod, and Amazon Prime HD. They all sound great, but, because the Technics don't slide all the way into my ear, some of the bass gets lost. Higher volumes help, but then you run into ear damage.

Overall, I'm pleased with my first set of wireless ear buds. While they won't take over my Shure IEMs, they're super convenient to have during my work commutes.

title: Looks much better than Metra version. text: I had a Metra kit in my older Solara, and it worked alright but always felt a little cheap on the materials and paint quality, even the little cover in the middle didn't fit right. But after I lost it to an accident I decided to start over with a new kit, and I have to admit I'm glad I did. The quality of this one is much better!
It still doesn't fit my Atoto radio face exactly thanks to that being a full double din 7" display (instead of most double dins assuming a 6.8" hole). This will fit a standard 6.8" face radio with the plate just fine, but a 7" like my Atoto unit doesn't like the plate in the middle. That's not the fault of this kit, most double din kits won't fit a full 7" radio face. I was able to get around that by using a dremel to edge out some tabs and make it fit better, and now it looks better than the Metra ever did.

title: The Hum Is Gone text: It works. The annoying hum is gone. I can't believe that it works since other hum eliminators I bought failed.

I have a 2017 model High Def TV that has RCA audio output jacks. (The built-in speakers on the TV leave a lot to be desired, of course.)

I am going direct from the TV RCA jacks into the RCA input of an expensive speaker. The hum was bad.

I tried all the suggested tricks, including using shielded RCA cables, plugging the TV and external speaker electrical cords into the same outlet, or a different outlet, plugging the electrical cords into a line conditioner, and buying cheaper-than-this-product hum eliminators. Nothing worked.

I then spent $100 for this Sescom IL-STEREO-19...and I found success. The hum is gone. (The only reason I deducted a star is because it's expensive at $100. It's a passive box.)

title: Powered from your Kindle 3, super super light text: I love reading my kindle as is, dont like the extra weight of a cover. So I ended up purchasing a LED attached light, super, but the batteries ran out real quick and I could feel the weight of the light on the kindle, not terrible, but I did not love. Finally, I splashed out on this light and it is pretty much all love: super super light that I really don't feel its extra weight, powered from the kindle, great light coverage for the kindle 3, easy to attach, and does not feel obtrusive even though it makes the left buttons defunct: i didnt notice as I can equally use the right buttons.
Although it has an on-off switch, the light will only come on if the kindle is not in sleep mode, hence if you fall asleep and the kindle goes into sleep mode, it automatically switches itself off!

I noticed that the light actually adds to the hold of the kindle: gives it more grip.

If you like me, love to read the kindle without a cover, without the added weight, and conscious of the green impact of replacement batteries, this is the kindle light for you!

8/25 edit: just bought the RooCase super bubble case for kindle3: love it, it has enough wiggle room to fit both the kindle and attached SimpleLight together. Super price a d great color choices too.

title: much fuller than expected text: Needed a Living Room sub for our 5.1 system. had to be somewhat small but pack a good punch.

we get good deep sound (*way better than the cheaper sub we had earlier), it is pretty harmonious with our Axiom and BIC fronts.

title: Fantastic tool for the serious photographer!
text: I started shooting with my first DLSR and lenses about two years ago; one of the major inconveniences was lugging around a heavy shoulder bag containing my DSLR body, lenses, batteries and accessories, so I was thrilled at the prospect of a rolling camera bag. Usually when I travel, I'm lugging around a small wheeled overnight bag plus a bulky camera bag and tripod, but with the Convertible Rolling Camera Bag, I'm able to combine my camera and lenses and overnight bag into a single bag. The clever Velcro interior can be rearranged in any number of configurations; there is room for two camera bodies and numerous lenses, along with a built-in laptop pouch, memory cards, and ample side pockets. It also comes with a rain cover. You can use the bag as a roller bag (preferable) or as a backpack. The wheels handle smoothly and the collapsible handle is sturdy; I feel like this bag will stand up to a lot of abuse and still perform well. I look forward to stepping up my photography game (and saving my back!) with this great new addition from AmazonBasics!

title: Inexpensive solution for upgrading some older vehicles text: I received this as a free review sample. Since Vince McLaren's exceptionally helpful review of August 21, 2016 covers what I also discovered, take the time to read his (and mark it helpful because he did an excellent job.)

It took me a few weeks to get around to writing this review because I needed to order an adapter for the 1998 Ford Explorer it was destined for, and also to have it professionally installed. The adapter I purchased is [[ASIN:B01ES32D7C Fits Ford Explorer 1998-2001 Double DIN Stereo Harness Radio Install Dash Kit]]. There are other kits by different brands for most vehicles. One of those will allow you to install (or have professionally installed) in older vehicles where this system will add some modern touches.

The reasons why I subtracted a star are the touchscreen is not as sensitive as I had hoped (not unusable, but frustrating sometimes), and the instructions are not that great. A professional will have no problem installing this unit, and there is a comprehensive wiring diagram in the product photos on this page. If you are planning to do the install yourself, refer to that photo to get an idea of the complexity of the job.

For me, the bluetooth capability and radio make this is great bargain in my opinion. I have a back-up camera that attaches to a license plate holder that adds that feature (you will need to provide your own camera, but they are inexpensive.) While this will display videos, you will need to load them via the TF card slot because this has no DVD (or CD) slot for that kind of media. Frankly, streaming music via bluetooth obviates the need for a CD (in my opinion), and I do not foresee myself ever needing to use any video player in the driver/front passenger compartment of a vehicle. If those are important to you, this is not the in-dash solution for you.

My overall impression is this is a good - and very inexpensive - solution for upgrading in-dash entertainment and hands free solutions in older vehicles. Before you plunk down your money, though, make sure that this will fit your vehicle, and that there is an adapter kit available for installing it in your vehicle's make, model and year.

title: Quality, Beauty, and Practicality in design
text: I have had my new tablet and cover for almost a year now. This cover is solid, sturdy, and well constructed.  It has held up to my frequent use and still looks like new. I have not grown tired of the lovely pattern I chose mainly because I l selected a pattern and color I love. Oriental style and the color teal are very pleasing to me. The texture of the cover feels good in my hands and the surface is easy to clean. The softness of the material on the inside also feels good to touch. I really like how the front cover flap design has two grooves on the inside for hands free interaction with the tablet. By setting the tablet on a flat surface and folding the tablet into a triangle the touch screen can be tilted in two different upright positions. I also like how the flap folds back 180 degrees to allow for handheld use of the tablet. This design is much improved over the previous tablet cover I had for an older model Samsung tablet.

title: All Metal and Very Quiet text: Sometimes I like to have a little air moving across my desk when I am working at the computer. Even when it is hot, a little bit of a draft can make it seem cooler. Large desk fans and box fans can create too much air flow, but a small desk fan like a USB fan is often just the ticket for getting the air flow without blowing papers everywhere. I have worked with other BTOOP products and they have all been very good, so I had high expectations for this fan. The only real issue I have had with this fan is that my son has absconded with it and claimed it for himself.

The most obvious advantage of this fan is that it does not require batteries or direct AC power. It plugs into a USB port on a computer, power bank or even a charging block and that is all it needs to run for hours.

What has struck me as most interesting about this fan is that it is all metal, not cheap plastic anywhere. Even the blades of the fan are metal. It’s a refreshing change from all of the plastic junk that is prevalent everywhere. I have a huge air mover in my bedroom and even that fan is mostly plastic.

Considering that this is a metal fan and not a plastic one, the current asking price (under $15, subject to change) is surprising. I would have expected it to cost a lot more.

This fan operates quietly but still is able to move substantial air, enough to cool down a work space.

There are a couple of small improvements in design that would make this fan even better, in my opinion. It is not the easiest to adjust the tilt and having a wing nut to loosen/tighten the screws for tilt would be a big help to that end. That is an easy modification that can be made at home without really any effort. The other improvement would be a variable fan speed setting but this is not a deal-breaker. The price of the fan is compensation enough for these two minor quibbles.

Overall, this is a nice little fan and I like it. I especially appreciate the fact that is it all metal and it works so quietly.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.
