title: Upgraded from a 500w white 80+ PSU and this is way worse. text: Update: I've had this for a long time now because I forgot to return it. I've gotten bored and installed it again 2 separate times. Both times it still just shuts off my whole computer as soon as I load a game. My old 500w PSU is still working fine.

I was running some overclocking on a Vega 56 and Ryzen 5 2600 on a different 500w CPU and everything was fine. I decided to get this PSU as an "upgrade" for more headroom and a bit of future-proofing. Not only can this PSU not handle even the minimal overclocking I was doing on my Vega and Ryzen, and not only can it not handle just one of the two, for some reason it causes my computer to shut down with absolutely no overclocking. This seems to be a very bad PSU and I will be returning it. I took a gamble on this brand and I wish I wouldn't have.

title: Another non-standard use text: I decided to take a chance and use this a bit differently than designed.

I have a Foscam WiFi security camera in a steel pole barn. Even with a high gain antenna on the camera and a fiberglass door, my connection was pretty bad. Choppy video and lost connections were common. I needed to get the antenna outside.

Although this antenna isn't outdoor rated, it is pretty easy to make watertight. Some tape over the mounting screw holes on the back and a little self vulcanizing rubber electrical tape around the antenna joint and no water is going to get in. You could use something like RTV silicone too. Keep the moisture out and you now made it outdoor capable. It was pretty close the way it comes and I'm sure it would probably be fine for a long time, but sealing it completely is pretty easy. The magnet mount works great on the steel siding. The camera I have, like most, comes with a standard SMA connector vs.the SMA-RP (reversed pin), but you can get an adapter here on Amazon. [[ASIN:B005H488Y4 SMA Male to SMA-RP Female Adapter]]

Added a 20 foot cable with standard SMA male and female connectors and now I have a great outdoor antenna for an indoor camera in a steel building that is great for blocking radio signals. It works very well and the results exceeded my expectations.

I've bought another antenna for the same setup on another camera. Although it isn't exactly what they intended it for, it works extremely well.

title: Will not reformat itself.

title: Pricey, but fits and feels great. text: We have had a couple of MBPs before getting this one, and those two have sustained minor injuries over the last 10+ years. But since this MBP will be used between two people this time, we decided to get some sort of protection for it besides the padded sleeve. This one was far more expensive than others, but I love the colors and that I could see a majority of MBP. It snaps-fit into the MBP. They're a bit stiff and the snap sounds like it damages the computer, but obviously it's supposed to protect it I guess that's normal.

The kit comes with two filters that fit over the MBP as well, in case you're worried about having full coverage. Though I"m not sure if there are any films to remove from them; they come with tabs that you have to remove--like from phone screen protectors--but they remove nothing when I remove them. I lifted them up and out and just the tabs took off. Weird.

It's very pricey for what it is, but it looks sleek and doesn't add much bulk. I like the blue accents in the inside, though they're barely noticeable when on the computer.
The bump at the bottom where you rest your thumb when using the track pad takes some getting used to. I've been used to the groove of the MBP for years, which has been improved with each subsequent model, but this one tries to make it easier to find the notch but at the same time throws me off because I'm not used to it.

It's a nice case; maybe a bit pricey, but I love the colors. Just wish the Thule logo was more subdued.

title: Decent price for name brand, but USB2 speed text: I love and trust Lexar products for my work jobs (professional grade memory cards and other solid state storage), so I had high expectations for this product. I love the build quality of this material, it's a solid feeling metallic body instead of cheap plastic, and it gives the impression of a product that will hold up to the test of time.
The price is also impressive for a name brand product with this kind of build quality. However, I had almost forgotten how slow USB2.0 can be. I'm so used to USB3 storage speeds of easily over 150MB/s, that the benchmarks on this one seem almost painfully slow at around the 20MB/s mark. But, that's par for the course with the older standard, so I can't really fault the product for it. This is a great value but you could easily get a much faster storage stick for a bit more money. I could see this being useful for someone who wants to distribute a hard-copy of something by hand and would like to order a bulk supply of durable and fast-enough but still affordable media. Otherwise, I think I'd recommend one that is USB 3 compatible at least since you can always be backwards compatible with 2.0 if necessary, but have the increased speed when available.

title: Love the colors text: Well, these are certainly interesting!
I often lose my little Roku remote, with it sliding off the bed, then being hard to find under the bed, under cat stuff, etc.

These are silicone covers. If you or your child has ever bought a game controller cover, these are like this.

These are not super easy to get on to the remotes. There are so many button cutouts, it gets caught every step of the way. As a chubby woman, it brought back flashbacks of trying to put on pantyhose too soon after a shower, or on a humid summer day...good luck! 😄

But, I persisted and slowly got it on correctly. It has a textured back to help keep your grip. It does kind of cause the volume button to feel recessed a bit, but that is not a deal breaker. It also includes a wrist strap, but there is no designated punchout for it, so it seems useless to me. The strap is also too small to go over your wrist, so just a pointless addition.

I love the colors though, and it will definitely help me find it on the floor, or amid blankets. The silicone might even help stop my cat from ceremoniously shoving it off his spot by my pillow, but we'll see about thay one.

Overall, I'm pretty happy with these. The only negative side is having to peel it off again if a battery change is needed, but that isn't oftem enough to be a concern.

title: Excellent desktop computer text: I have typically bought and loved Dell Inspiron desktop computers for use with school and business purposes and have been very satisfied over the years.

When we were told that we needed Windows 10, I tried to download it to my old Inspiron but was not successful because my Dell equipment was really too old for a successful install; I really love the Inspiron and Windows 7.

In February 2020, I bought a new desktop and had a really stressful experience. There was something wrong with the configuration, and the tech support people could not get the computer to perform properly. After many hours online with tech support, the situation started to seem hopeless. The pandemic began to become worrisome both here and in India (tech support), and I returned the desktop for a fully refund.

Last week I started again trying to find a desktop with Windows 10. I didn't want to spend a small fortune for a computer that I use primarily for shopping, email, browsing, and, rarely, online banking transactions. I found this Acer after reading good reviews. Since my current desktop is an I3 and has basically the same specs, I chose this computer rather than the I5.

One of my siblings told me that Acer has a long history of excellent quality and that I would be pleased. He was right! This desktop is great.

PROS:
Comes with Windows 10 pre-installed. Plug it in. It's ready to go.
Norton Security is pre-loaded with a 30-day trial period.
The computer is extremely user friendly. I had no struggles with glitches with any of the programs.
Bloatware is easy to recognize and easy to remove (a Windows 10 feature).

CONS:
There really are no cons except that the "feel" of the plastic components is not as hefty as some of the desktops that I have used in the past (other companies). The plastic casing of the tower, the keyboard, and the mouse are beautifully designed but not quite as heavy as prior desktops that I have owned. That isn't necessarily a "con," and I like the keyboard, mouse, and computer case. Very attractively designed.

MY RATING:
5 STARS

The price, the ease of use, the beautiful performance -- a great buy!

title: Some good, some bad. text: First with the bad: the adhesion is terrible. Either the glue is too strong or too weak. Peeling the sticker paper off the organizers was a pain, and sticking them to the wall didn't last long. Many of the little cable hooks have come loose on their own. Thankfully the kit comes with several and I haven't used a bunch of them, so I have extras.

The Velcro straps are fine, though a bit too strong. Of course, it's not name-brand Velcro, so it does an adequate job for its manufacture.

The other parts are fine but not used with adhesion for my purposes. The only real issue I have with this kit is the adhesion used, so if that's your primary need then I'd consider an alternative.

title: Decent for TV, not great for PC text: I was looking for a simple keyboard/mouse combo to use with a Windows 10 htpc attached to a projector. Pairing was simple enough- unfortunately, I needed to dig up a real USB mouse in order to pair, but that's true of all Bluetooth input devices. Unlike a unit that uses a USB dongle, you need some other form of input to initiate the process first. On my fire stick, I was able to pair it using the remote pretty easily as well. Once paired, you are able to use it like a directly connected keyboard or mouse by just powering it on in the future.
The lights are cool looking (and very nice when using in the dark with a home theater setup), and the keyboard is nice and large, easy to type on. However, the mouse was little bit too jumpy for my taste. It was difficult to nail icons with accuracy due to how erratically it moved. On Windows, I'm sure I could have turned down the mouse speed to make it better, but on my fire stick there isn't that kind of control available. I definitely would not use this as a keyboard/mouse replacement for a desktop experience due to the mouse experience, however it is ok for a presentation control or htpc that doesn't require a lot of pointing or clicking.
The only thing is that I KNOW there are smaller keyboard-only devices on the market if you aren't going to need the mouse that much, and ones that can use a USB dongle to avoid the pairing process. And if you want to use this with something like a firestick or Roku, one could argue the mouse part (which takes up a significant amount of real estate on the bar) is superfluous and doesn't have such precision control even if you DO want it (using Silk browser, for example). I sort of feel like you can get better options in all those scenarios, but it is OK at what it does. So 4 stars at best.

title: More Bass text: I'm serious about my music. I want to hear every single note as it was intended. These earbuds are for people like me who care deeply about sound quality. The bass is amplified to make your favorite songs sound their best. You also get quick charging and long playtime. You can use the app to customize the sound. I HIGHLY recommend this product.

Thanks so much for taking the time to read this review. I hope the information that I've provided makes your decision a little easier.

title: Great Totally Wireless
text: I purchased a three camera set with base. Very easy install. I am not impressed with motion detection. Most people are out of view at front door and all i get are tops of heads. But for wide angle outside it does pickup larger / hotter vehicles. Quality of videos is excellent. Love being able to define by camera and not as group for email / notifications. I will recommend for friends.

title: Great value, great reception and clarity. Tiny too! text: We paired this with three mobile devices: the iPhone (success), the blackberry touch (success) and the older version of HTC (failed).

Synching to the iPhone was the easiest of the three, where it just picked up the signal and away we go. The blackberry took a few attempts, but it worked. Our android HTC may be old, so I wouldn't want to rule out android phones I general.

The quality of the sound was fantastic (relative to the Bose Bluetooth headset). It is tiny, but didn't seem to affect the reception of the voice. The hearing aspect was crystal clear. It is so tiny and light, you forget you have it on your ear! It has effectively three buttons: on-off; to end a call, and to mute the call. Volume is adjusted through your handset device. Upon switching on the device, it tells you how many hours of talk time, and there is 6 hours for a fully charged headset. In terms of range, we could walk around our apartment from the phone without loosing the quality of the call.. (Just a little reminder for those new to this device that u don't have to walk with your phone). It took less than one hour to fully charge. It also comes with various ear pieces to fit your ear-hole, and if you prefer an over the ear piece, there are two such frames. I only wished they came with a little case, like the Bose, to hold the headset.

I also LOVE the wood color, and they look great on my wooden colored book shelves. The only problem? They are about 20-30% bigger than the bookshelf speakers I wanted to replace! I used to have black shelf speakers from Sony, then traded those in for wooden panel ones that didn't sound as good, and now these are the best of both worlds, but they are bigger than any of the previous options! They actually could not clear one of the shelves I was using because it is too tall. I guess that's what you get for having better sound (larger speaker usually produces better response), but I have to rearrange my shelf heights to permanently place it.

title: Best USB hub I've tried so far text: Love this hub. Lots of performance, lots of flexibility. You don't need external power for this hub, unless you want it; in which case you need to provide your own power source (there is a USB-C port on the side that you can plug the power source into). If you are going to be using this hub for everyday devices (flash drives, mouse/keyboard, etc.), you don't need external power anyway.

Having 7 (!) expansion USB 3.2 ports sitting on your desk is a game changer. Much easier than plugging directly into your computer. The high transfer speed is SO nice. Most (newer) PCs only have 1 or 2 USB 3.2 ports, so getting 7 with this hub is awesome.

It seems like a selling point for this hub is the 32 degree angle that it sits at, which at first I didn't think would be a big deal at first, but it is definitely better than a lay-flat hub (i.e., every other hub I've had). Makes it quite easy to plug in/out of.

The only thing I'd wish for is faster charging (even with external power plugged in, it's not very fast).

Bottom line: a great hub.

title: Displaylink sets this dock apart. text: [[VIDEOID:8052bc9e6eb256b6a38698f645a9fee]] So you purchase a laptop or compact PC with one or more USB Type-C ports maybe not knowing much about the technology. In truth, the Type-C port is a huge mess. There are so many functions that the port is designed for that a normal consumer would have a hard time understanding all of them. In my case, the type-c port on my computer doesn't support HDMI video output. This port came in handy with its Displaylink technology.

As a dock, the iVANKY 15 in 1 Triple Display dock is a great product that, if your laptop has USB charging capabilities, can connect all of your external devices with just one USB plug. You can connect multiple external monitors, external USB drive, your keyboard/mouse, and gain the ability to read SD and MicroSD cards, all with a single plug. In terms of charging, the PD port outputs 18W of power which is good enough for fast charging your tablet and phone, and the computer port outputs 94w, powerful enough for many laptops running a CPU up to an Intel i5. All this is packaged in a modern, metal shell and it even has a 100w power adapter included.

Already, this is a great dock, but the DisplayLink feature sets this dock apart from the rest of the pack. DisplayLink allows a computer to output video to a computer monitor (up to 4K) through a standard USB 3.1 port. This means that if you have a type-c that doesn't support video output or if it only has Type-A ports, this dock can still give you the ability to add more monitors to your setup. Just install the included drivers (the dock shows up as a computer drive when you plug it in) and this dock will extend your desktop.

While it is a little pricey, this dock has the quality and functionality to justify it.

title: Versatile for users with multiple USB devices text: I received this as a review sample and tested the claimed specifications on a few platforms. The following are my observations that, with Debbie Lee Wesselmann's excellent review, should give you a complete picture of this hub.

First, word about using this hub for charging devices. The specs on this product page at the time of this review claim that this hub will NOT charge devices. Actually, it charged my two phones and another device while I was doing other tasks. Perhaps the specs mean it is not intended to be a standalone charger. The only thing that I do NOT like is the wall wart type power supply that is approximately 3x2x2 inches. It can (and does) block adjacent plugs in my surge protector. However, I can live that that considering the functionality I get from this hub.

My favorite feature and the reason I awarded this hub five stars is the integrated electrical safeguards that protect against over voltage, over current, leakage and short circuits. This may not be a big deal for cheap peripherals like mice, but for an expensive hard drive or my Galaxy Note 3 it's a welcome feature.

If you have a computer and peripherals that are USB 3.0 compliant this hub will boost your transfer speeds significantly. For example, my new Samsung Note 3 will transfer at the 5gbps speed, but frankly I do most of my data transfers over WiFi. However, if you wanted to attach an external 3.0 hard drive to your laptop this hum will allow it to operate to it's full potential - which is lightning fast.

Set-up is easy. You literally connect the included power supply, plug it into your system's USB port and switch it on. All of platforms with which I tested it immediately recognized the hub and the things I plugged into it (which included a flash drive, mouse, two snart phones (Galaxy Note II and Note 3), and a speaker that is powered by USB.

This hub works with Windows 98 (I have an old Sony running it and this hub plugged in and worked with it), and above. I know it works with Win XP, Vista and 7 because I also tested the hub on those platforms. I do not have access to a Windows 8 system so am taking the manufacturer's word that it works on that too. If your experience is different please leave a comment.

One final feature that makes this a five star hub in my opinion is the fact that this will simultaneously support maximum data transfer of up to four high speed devices (three of which can be USB 3.0) plugged into it. Of course the host system needs to be USB 3.0 too, but the hub will sling data as fast as the host can accept it. Not all hubs will operate in this mode, and I suspect that the external power supply has something to do with that level of performance.

title: Great NAS for the $$ .. but issues, dead after 2 years text: Really all you could want out of a BASIC NAS
Upgraded to 16gb RAM .. Running RAID 6 .. 4 x 8TB drives now
Works great !
pretty much saturates my 1 gigabit connection
getting 104 mb/s reads and writes (125 mb/s is max for 1 gigabit)
considering an ssd cache .. but even without getting good speed, so may opt for a 5th hdd later (instead)

update 1/12/17 .. tried ssd cache and really found no speed improvement, so ditched and added a 5th HDD and also switched to RAID 6 .. which is more reliable .. Still working great getting 110 reads/writes now

update 10/18/17 .. still working great. Had some reboot issues but switched memory and where I had plugged in and seems to have stabilized for now. Great buy when stable.

update 2/8/18 .. I off and on was having issues with this unit (dropping drives randomly)
Tech support right away said I needed to send in for RMA (which I finally did)
I had upgraded RAM, but luckily saved original otherwise they would not repair.
They will only repair original setup. 2 weeks later got my unit back and now it's been stable (20 days no issues) Looks like they replaced a faulty mobo.
Tech support for me was great, they have been very helpful.
I still really like this unit for the price, but my Synology seemed like a better built product. Hopefully, after this repair it remains stable (so far so good)

4/15/2019 - The Unit has now dropped drives again, and is out of Warranty so will not RMA
Basically 2 years of service with an RMA after 1 year, and dead after the second year.
Will not buy QNAP again

title: Mostly excellent, but does disconnect once in a while. text: Having recently dug my music collection (odd how we go back into hobbies after years of stagnation), I took time to curate my setup (and by setup I mean my Note8 with a USB DAC) for optimal listening. Until recently, but "best" headphones were my Shure Aonic 4, which are excellent for the price range. The cable it comes with is okay, but preferably replaceable. It comes with an inline mic and makes a lot of feedback-noise when moved. I know cables are a mixed bag when it comes to audio equipment, so I shied away for years. But rather than place the emphasis on audio-quality improvement when looking at cables, I realized I'd rather get a cable if it looks and feels good. This one fit the ticket.

This is the only cable I have that's meant to be swapped with MMCX in-ear headphones. They pair well with the Aonic 4. First, I'll get the problems I have out of the way.

Since this cable is meant to connect with around-the-ear IEMs, there's a plastic wrap near each MMCX adapter. It makes wearing around the ears easier, but putting them on initially takes a few tries. They are easy to tangle, even if I use the "roadie wrap." Putting them on while on the go proved to be suboptimal; I have to be sitting or standing to put them on.

Sometimes I get some feedback noise, but rarely. Definitely not the same as the stock cable that comes with the Aonic 4.

The biggest problem I have is that the end connection disconnects nearly every time I use the cable. Having a modular cable is awesome, but the connection from the cable to the audio jack doesn't lock. I expected there to be a click, indicating it's on and snug, but no such thing. Since I use this cable while on the go, it's connected to my phone, which rests in my pocket. At least once the cable end will come loose. It's easy to press back in (just a little nudge will do), but it is rather annoying.

Now for the good.

The cable feels awesome. I get now why people prefer to upgrade certain cables. I care very little for how much the audio quality is "improved" (there's too much immeasurable subjectivity in that area), but having a cable that doesn't tangle easily and is very light makes enough of a difference to justify the upgrade. The cable is soft to the touch, though I don't doubt its ruggedness in the long term. The MMCX connectors snap satisfactorily into the Shure IEMs; at least those haven't come loose. The metal ends and Y-splitter are very nice and definitely attribute the cable with a premium look.

This cable has sold me on the reasons to upgrade headphone cables.

title: Adds a super speedy nvme drive to my workstation! Can't figure out how to boot though text: I have an older HP workstation that predates M.2 SSD drives, and I REALLY wanted to add some high speed goodness to it for improving boot times. This adapter was super simple! Just assemble it using the screws and bracket (which are self explanatory if you've ever installed a card before), and then CAREFULLY mount the SSD to it. This actually took me a bit to figure out, I'm used to having a screw that holds down the SSD, this is more like a holding mount that it fits into which screws in on the back. But once I got it figured out, it installed fine and allowed me to initialize and format my SSD in Windows 10.
Speed was good, about what it should be on a MB mounted nvme, but the only issue I'm having is figuring out how to boot Windows from it. It doesn't show up as a recognized boot device in my Bios, which isn't really the fault of the device and more an issue with my computer in particular. I'm still hoping I can figure that part out to make this work the way I wanted, but to be fair, this adapter is just claiming to add an NVME drive to my computer, which it DOES do.

title: Enterprise/LTE/4G version works with Verizon text: Do not buy this if you're looking for the fastest tablet. That's not what it is, though it's by no means slow. It will take a lot more abuse than the fastest tablets available for the same price. You can stand outside in the rain or snow and use the touchscreen when it's wet. You can drop it in the mud, pick it up, wipe it off, and keep using it. I wouldn't take it scuba diving though. I will take it off-roading. This one has enough storage to preload maps for off-road hiking/biking/riding/driving for when there's no signal at all.

I've seen several questions about whether this works with Verizon, and several people answer that it doesn't. Those people are wrong. The Enterprise/LTE/4G/WiFi version does work with Verizon. It should work with others. Find this model number (SM-T577UZKGN14) on the Samsung site to check. Samsung knows. Those other people don't.

This is the third tablet I've used my Verizon SIM card in. The first was a tablet I bought through Verizon. The second was a TabActive2, and now I'm using the same SIM card in this TabActive3. This does not apply to the WiFi-only version. Don't confuse the two.

I pulled the SIM card out of the TabActive2, inserted it in the TabActive3, restarted the device as requested, and a few minutes later the line was active on the new device. I ignored Verizon's emailed instructions, because they don't appear to apply to swapping a current SIM card into a new device. I even restored a Google backup from the 2 to the 3 and saved a lot of time installing apps.

So, why this tablet? It's rugged. It's Samsung. I really like having an 8" tablet. It works with Verizon.

Why 4G/LTE? It's not 5G. I drive a truck through at least 5 states on a regular basis, and in some areas the signal constantly switches between 4G and 5G and the data connection is interrupted. When I can't access online banking, credit cards, and apps relating to business with my 5G phone, I often can with a 4G tablet. I have unlimited data on a second plan for only $10/mth, since I already have a smartphone plan. No hotspot/WiFi needed.

Why upgrade? My TabActive2 only had 16GB of internal storage. The TabActive3 I bought has 128GB. The TabActive3 has DEX. The TabActive2 didn't. I didn't manage to hurt the 2, and the 3 is physically very similar. The 3 has a faster CPU, and a faster GPU.

From the beginning, everything about the TabActive2 as a usable tablet simply wasn't enough. It wasn't fast enough. It didn't have enough storage. But it was rugged. It still is. This is the first time I've upgraded when the old tablet still worked as well as it did when I bought it. It appears that the TabActive3 is just as rugged.

Con: The biggest downside to these is that there's no external charger that I can find for the replaceable battery. At least I can't find one. Maybe one exists. I have no evidence of that. It is possible to buy another compatible battery, but I can't find any way to charge said battery other than to charge it in the tablet, and it's a pain to get to, because of the lengths Samsung went to to seal the battery compartment. The battery life is substantial, partly due to the less-than-premium performance, but it would really be nice to be able to easily carry a fully-charged spare.

title: Nice but very fragile text: I got one of these for the holidays last year (12/06) and I was totally stoked. This was my first iPod--what a shame that it turned out to be such a fragile, poorly engineered device. I mean, this thing got dropped once from about 2.5 feet (it was only 2 months old) and it was TOAST (and it was in a plastic hardshell case!). I have had Laptops that survived worse. Come to think of it, I've had a lot of (far cheaper) devices that are better able to take abuse than this $400 item--including TV remotes, cell phones, Nintendo Game Boys (designed to be nearly indestructible), OTHER MP3 PLAYERS, etc. It seems that a physically appealing design does not necessarily equate to superior engineering--quite the opposite in this case. I do like it, and the replacement I got from Apple works very well. It's great looking and it does the job well. Too bad I'm so terrified of dropping it that I had to buy a big, bulky silicone case to improve its chances of survival. Let me tell ya, in its crash-test-dummy outfit, it no longer looks even the slightest bit sleek.

Have you ever dropped your keys when getting out of the car? Your cell phone? If you answered yes to either of the above, then you can probably expect to drop your iPod one day. I hope you have a (thickly) carpeted garage--or that it lands on your foot. Bottom line: If I were thinking of getting an MP3 player, iPod or another brand, it would have zero moving parts; on other words, I would buy a flash-based device instead of one with a hard drive.

I also cannot help but wonder why Nintendo does not take what they have learned about building child-proof, nearly indestructible portable gaming devices and apply this to a worthy competitor to the iPod. I would be the first in line...

I gave this product 3 stars because it does a good job of what it is touted to do: play MP3s & video/images. In fact, the user interface, including the GUI and the click wheel is one of the nicest, most intuitive designs I have ever seen on a piece of consumer electronics equipment. Too bad it's put together so cheaply. Grossly overpriced? Most definitely. I hope the iPhone turns out to be a higher quality piece.

---

UPDATE: 8/2013: still working fine... :)

title: Pretty good photo frame, super easy to use! Speakers are horrible and bad viewing angles. text: Very easy to use this- I set it up in like a minute without even reading the instructions thanks to the on screen prompts. It was very painless.

Picture quality is so so- it's decent looking but basically, you have to be standing somewhere in front of it to see full color- the image and color is distorted if you look at it from the side or any other angle. But other than that- it does look pretty good and the picture is very usable and nice looking.

Sound- it calls the speakers "loud speakers" but some videos I can BARELY hear sound, others I can hear it if everything around me is quiet and that's with the frame's volume turned up to max! Nothing "loud" about this and sadly it doesn't have bluetooth or amy sound output. I guess if you want sound, your best bet is the play music with some other device along with this.

Overall this is a fairly nice, easy-to-use frame. I loaded pictures and videos on it with ease. The speakers need major improvement. The only other complaint is the price point but these frames all seem to be higher priced than a tv which seems silly. You can get a 24 inch tv with a usb slot cheaper than this 15" screen and it'd probably have better picture. For the price, It should have much better viewing angles/ better video quality.

title: Really Great Photography Kit! text: I am very, very happy with my order of the GLOSHOOTING Photography Lighting Kit. This kit arrived in great condition and was very well packaged. Each piece had it's own box, so this was great protection for the shipping process. This includes everything I need to use with my own camera to make my own quality portraits. I work nights and often struggled with lighting to take photos at home. I really like to pose dolls from my collection to make photo stories to share with other hobbyists. This can sometimes be a long process that takes several sessions to complete. This kit does not take up too much room for me to use it over the course of several days to complete a project. It does not take much time to setup after the initial opening. Between uses, it is easy to store in it's own nylon case underneath my bed. The only minor problem I had was one bulb did not work out of the box. I found this to be a very easy issue to remedy as bulbs are the only part of this kit that will need replaced with use. I especially appreciate the thoughtfulness of all the inclusions of this set. The backdrops are light-weight and easy to store. When I set up a backdrop after storage, I find that a little bit of wrinkle spray works right away! I do use the green screen often too, and that is included as well as 2 others. This is a great set for me and my uses.

This is an ideal set for anyone that wishes to shoot photos as a hobby. It is sturdy enough to stay setup for days on end, but not so sturdy that it could take much abuse. title: Thick, sturdy fast charging cables text: Like most households today, we have so many cables. It seems like every device needs a different type of cable, be it HDMI, USB-A, USB-C, USB-mini... it's nuts! I personally can't wait for all of our devices to be switched over to the current industry standard USB-C so I can at least reduce *some* of the clutter! But until that day comes (if ever), I am trying to at least organize our cable collection to where we can grab what we need without having to sift through a sea of black cables, examining all of the ends looking for the right one.

Enter these Avyxm USB C to C 4 foot cables. I chose the red and LOVE THEM!! They are very vibrant and bright making it stupid easy to quickly grab the correct cable for our USB-C devices!! The cables are nice and thick but still with a bit of bend allowing for maneuvering around furniture legs or nightstand lamps without putting a kink in them. And one of the biggest props? These cables FAST CHARGE everything I've connected them to. Our Samsung Galaxy S8 and S10 phones, my new Fire HD8 Plus tablet and my kids' Samsung S10 plus phones. The 4 foot length is perfect for bedside nightstands although it is a little too short to reach the couch and still use the phone or tablet in a comfortable position -- so I'll be grabbing a couple of the 6 foot cables for living room use.

Bottom line... the color is fantastic, the build quality is supreme, I don't expect they'll ever kink given their thickness, I love the braiding and feel of the fabric -- overall a high quality product that I have and will continue to, highly recommend!

title: Breathtaking Display; Requires Graphics That Can Handle Native 3840 x 2160 Resolution text: After a month, this LG ELECTRONICS 4K UHD 27UD88-W LED-LIT MONITOR still takes my breath away. I’m not a gamer or a professional photographer, but I still can appreciate having crystal-clear resolution and stunning color for everything on my desktop. The extra width (27” diagonal) means the desktop itself is huge, even when the display is set to show text, apps, and other items at 200%, as I prefer. (If I use the included Split Screen 2.0 app, which makes full use of the 3840 x 2160 native resolution--using tiny icons and text, and offering multiple options for 2 or more split screens--there is an incredible amount of desktop workspace available.)

The one snag that I ran into, is that the on-board graphics in my 3-year-old ASUS computer (running Windows 10) were NOT capable of displaying the 3840 x 2160 native resolution. This meant that the monitor would not display my Windows desktop until I purchased and installed a new graphics card. My card is a NVIDIA GeForce GT 710 (in stock at Best Buy in the gaming section).

Any of the following graphics cards will work, with either a DisplayPort or HDMI connection. For Windows OS: (1) the Intel HD4600 or higher; (2) the AMD HD7000 or higher, the AMD R7 or Higher, or the AMD FireProW600 or higher; or (3) the NVIDIA GeForce GT 640 or higher, the NVIDIA Quadro K500 or higher, the NVIDIA GeForce GTX960 or higher. For Mac OS: MacBook Pro (Retina, 13-inch, early 2015); MacBook Pro (Retina, 15-inch, mid 2014); Mac Pro (late 2013); iMac (Retina 5K, 27-inch, late 2014 and after); MacBook Air (early 2015).

The monitor worked with the drivers that came with the NVIDIA card, but had a barely visible flicker. Installing the drivers that came with the LG monitor itself corrected the flicker and resulted in the beautiful display that I love.

The monitor's simple, elegant design is also worthy of comment. The stand is rock-solid, and the curved base not only looks great but takes up little space on a table or whatever you have it resting on. The flat display screen is adjustable to many, many angles. Because the stand is so well thought out, this very large, very wide monitor seems to use only a little more space than the AOC 24" widescreen monitor that it replaced.

title: Much Better than TomTom's EasyPort Mount text: I have a TomTom Start and I have disliked the EasyPort mount from the day I got it. I had been telling my wife for months that I was going to get a “proper” mount for my TomTom and that day finally came when I accidentally broke the EasyPort mount. After a little research I decided on this particular mount, and so far I have been very pleased with it.

I wanted a more “normal” windshield mount - a suction cup with a lever instead of a twist ring, and that led me to this particular mount. The design is simple - press the suction cup against the windshield and flip the lever to make the cup stick to the window. In operation this is an easy-to-use mount and it seems to hold the navigator in place without too much trouble. As expected it does not hold well when it the windshield is cold, which is an issue with every suction-based mount I have ever used - including the EasyPort.

The ring in which the TomTom attaches to the mount holds the TomTom in place well enough but I have observed that it does not hold the navigator tightly. That is, the TomTom has a tendency to turn a little in the ring. So far this has not been an issue and the TomTom has not fallen out of the ring so this really does not bother me.

The mount is adjustable and provides for a couple of places where the position can be tweaked for maximum visibility. There should be no issue with getting the position of the GPS just right so it can be seen but not in the way.

So far I am pleased with this mount and am happy to recommend it. It’s a lot easier to use than the EasyPort mount that comes with the TomTom and it’s adjustable enough to make visibility a non-issue, even while in motion. If you have a TomTom and you don’t like the EasyPort mount, this mounting system is a big improvement.

title: It works as described, but... text: The bags are good for almost any remote you might have for a tv or sound system built in the last 20+ years. While I was pretty sure the bags would be that crunchy plastic you see on Easter baskets or grocery store flowers. I hoped it would be a bit closer to something softer or maybe silicone like. The heat shrink works great and fits all my remotes well. The downside is you end up with corners of hard plastic with sharp/pointy edges after the shrink (tried multiple methods or sealing and still rough corners). And getting the air out is near impossible. You end up with a balloon around your remote and some of the buttons can't be pressed (a plus if you are just storing things). Or you put a pin hole in the plastic and the seal is tight, but maybe too tight after you get the full heat shrink smooth. One remote of mine has a frequently used button 2 in from the side and it is hard to use now.
You get a lot of bags and it might be trial and error to find the balance if you plan to use the item you shrink wrapped. Its a good product and serves the purpose I wanted it for. Just wish they could come up with a softer less crunchy plastic.
Hair dryer is all you need to shrink the plastic. I also sealed the ends with a vacuum sealer. These bags can't be vacuum sealed though, too smooth.

title: Not bad, but ANNOYING pairing and audio interface text: I've had a number of Bluetooth headphones and the overwhelming majority of them have an "audio interface" that makes sense - some bare bones, some quite pleasant. This interface is in the form of sounds the relate to each of the functions - power on/off, paring, etc. These headphones have a TERRIBLE interface. When you power them on an annoyingly loud series of tones blares in your ear. The tones rise in pitch. When you continue to hold the power button, to access the paring mode, all you hear is an extremely brief, muffled tone. Apparently, the makers thought this was enough of a signal to indicate you're in paring mode. Believe me, it is NOT obvious at all. When you power off the headphones, you hear the same annoying loud series of tones. In this case, the tones do not decrease in pitch, which one might expect.

By comparison, the audio interface of my other Bluetooth headphones are a joy - unfortunately, they do not have volume controls or skip and rewind. When powering them on, a pleasant female voice says, "Hello", and when you enter pairing mode, the same voice says, "Ready to pair." When pairing is established, the voice says, You're connected", then tells me how much charge I have - either full, medium or low. These Cootree headphones do none of that. You'll be lucky if you're able to tell if they've been turned off properly.

In terms of sound quality, they're okay - nothing exceptional. In terms of fit, they're okay as well. Again, nothing exceptional. To my knowledge, they do not have an active noise cancelling function, other than what little noise they may happen to muffle by covering your ears. I mention this only because the rating form asks about it.

title: Spacious and Well-Designed Backpack Camera Bag text: I have a growing interest in photography and I have been learning as I go. One of the things I have discovered is that a good camera bag – sufficiently large to hold the camera, lenses you need and any accessories – is absolutely essential. I have a messenger-style camera bag that works well enough but I have run out of room in it and it does not have the capacity to hold all of my extra lenses and filters. I looked to this camera bag as a solution. It definitely holds more than my old bag, it seems to be made well and there are some nice features to this bag.

This is a backpack style bag and it is about the same size as a small travel backpack, though it is an order of magnitude thicker. There are zippers and pockets everywhere. There's a lot of padding to protect the camera and multiple movable partitions.

The main compartment is large enough to hold a small laptop if all of the partitions are pulled out. There are three small partitions and two large ones and these can be arranged in any configuration to accommodate a wide array of accessories. As shipped, the partitions are arranged to allow for the camera lens and camera to sit through the middle of the pack which maximizes the padding and protection for the most valuable parts of your setup, and the smaller partitions are about right for 2-3 lens kits. I have a smaller camera – a Samsung NX300 with the 18-55mm lens – so I need less room for my camera and rearranged the configuration to permit room for several filter kits, a telephoto lens, a fisheye lens and a few smaller accessories, all in the main compartment. I have not yet purchased additional lenses but will rearrange when I do.

The main compartment also has a pocket that is suitable for either a thin book or a tablet. So, even with all of my other gear in the main compartment, I still have room for my tablet. I really can't ask for much more than that.

There is a smaller zippered compartment on the front that has room for even more accessories. In this I have loaded up a spare set of macro lenses that would not fit in the main compartment. Inside this compartment there is yet another pocket suitable for holding a tablet as well as a mesh pocket for loose items, my choice being a couple of pens. However, the most interesting item in there, attached by a tether, is a waterproof nylon cover for the whole bag. So, if you need to go out in the rain with this backpack, you can do so without fear of getting your equipment wet.

On the sides there are two small pockets, sufficient for holding a couple of small items like a filter or two or even a very small flashlight.

On the front there is one more zippered pocket that is well suited for thin items, like a map, magazine or papers.

The shoulder straps are adjustable and padded so getting the pack to fit just right is not an issue. However, there is a carrying handle loop on the top of this bag and I prefer carrying this bag using that instead (I have always preferred carrying backpacks this way).

This is a very nice camera bag. A lot of thought went into the design and it can hold a lot of equipment for its size. It has replaced my other camera bag outright.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

title: Quality Micro SD Card text: I have been working with security camera products for over 20 years - over that time I have installed systems for businesses, corporations and individuals - from enormous multimillion dollar systems to single camera nursery monitors. I’ve consulted on large projects and written about security vulnerabilities within networks for trade publications.

This is a field I know well. Over the years the technology has improved and become less and less expensive to produce. It is now practical to install security systems that would have only previously been used in commercial settings in residential.

Micro SD cards are something I install in nearly all of the security cameras I install. By installing this internal memory this will not only give the camera local storage but give a place for settings to be stored. I have found most cameras simply work better with them installed.

Not all micro SD cards are the same. While some fail quickly and are not stable for use in security cameras that is not the case with this one. I have tested this in multiple cameras, repeatedly formatting it and it continues to work perfectly.

Excellent quality micro SD card.

title: Great Party Camera text: This camera is marketed for kids, but it's a fun, simple product that is also great for parties. The images print out in black and white, which is nice because it allows you to get a ton of prints off a single roll of paper. The paper is thin like a receipt you'd get at a restaurant or retail store. It comes with three rolls, and you can take a lot of pictures with what's included with the camera. Be careful when you tear off the pictures because if not enough paper is extending out of the slot, the printing can jam. It's very easy to fix however.

The camera also includes a micro USB card which records all of your images. Be sure to charge the camera when you pull it out of the box because it doesn't come with enough energy to print right away. It takes a little while to get used to the controls, but it's pretty easy once you get the hang of it. This is a really fun product for both kids and adults.

title: Needs Better Directions
text: There should be printed directions because you have to download the app first & you don’t know which app until you connect the device. Be careful about transferring file instead of backing it up as it appears to transfer file and add a proprietary file name. Once you start a transfer the only thing you can do is disconnect the device to stop it. The directions are almost non-existent. If you’ve never used one of these devices, I suggest that you start with a different one. Intuition helps a lot but only if you have used another brand first so you have some idea what to do. The simplistic command is Back-up contacts. It gets harder after that. Very small device includes a USBC adapter.

title: Smooth text: This is the first Logitech keyboard I've gotten, and now I see why Logitech is considered to be a proficient manufacturer in keyboards and other computer-related paraphernalia.

Without installing any such programs or software, either from the website or from the included disc, I plugged in the USB receiver right out of the box, followed the easy-to-setup instructions engraved on the back of the keyboard, and away I went. I was able to type flawlessly at the office, and the keys are very smooth and quiet. Even though it's just a keyboard, I kept opening up different programs to test out the typing. Pure joy! (For a nerd like me, at least.)

I guess the only gripes I have, and I noticed it almost immediately, is that there are no lights to indicate locks for the numbers, caps, or scroll. It's a minor gripe, but a gripe nonetheless since I have to utilize the Caps Lock every so often at work.

When I used the extra buttons for various computer software, I found that the respected programs opened up right away. There was some stall, but that was the result of my slow, crunching computer.
The mouse worked just as it should.

Now, I have to admit, what I really wanted to get this keyboard for was my Wii at home. I know, it sounds nerdy.
But the keyboard I was using before was an old office wired one that was given to me. That one worked fine, but I wanted a wireless one. So, I took home this MK300 keyboard and USB receiver, plugged in the latter into the back of my Wii console, opened up the Internet Channel and found, to my delight, that the keyboard worked flawlessly.
There was some range betwixt the keyboard and receiver--about ten feet or so--but it made no matter: my sitting spot isn't too far from the console, so it's not like I'm going to be typing in a completely different room.

Since this keyboard works so well, I was hoping to use it on a Mac. I've yet to buy the MacBook Pro--which is why I'm stuck with the Wii's Internet Channel for now--and since the specifications for this certain keyboard doesn't include Apple's OS, I'm assuming that there is simply no way around hardware setups (ever tried?) and will have to resort to something else, when the time comes.

All in all, though, if you're looking for an excellent wireless (not Bluetooth) keyboard at a relatively inexpensive price tag for any PC machine or Wii, look no further. The MK300 works like a charm.

title: Beautiful tv at a good price! text: I love this tv, it is definitely a masterpiece! Very well made and fantastic quality. Deep blacks, vivid colors, natural skin tones...

Not the thinnest tv on the market but a great tv still! Easy to set up and get going. Slim feet that slide into place with no tools- only have ONE configuration. 2 USBs, 4 HDMIs, Ethernet, optical & headphone outputs, & a mini a/v input. Operating system is Google Tv which works smoothly and has lots of apps built in. Works with Google Home and Alexa.

Has some intrusive ads on the homepage. You can go into the settings/privacy/ ads to opt out of personalized ads though. You can use your remote microphone to do voice commands on the tv. It also has the nice shortcut buttons for Youtube, Netflix, Disney+, and Prime Video.

Sound has tweeters on the side. It upscales the audio to give you a surround sound effect. Acoustic auto calibration which when you go to your sitting area with the remote and start this- it sends these crazy alien laser blaster sounds out of the speakers for a couple seconds and your remote reads them so the tv can process the information and adjust your speakers accordingly. It will then adjust the speakers so it sends sound to where you're sitting to give you the best experience possible!

The cognitive processor in this puts more emphasis into the areas of the picture that you'll be focused on- definitely makes a noticeable difference!

XR TRILUMINOS PRO technology gives you better color accuracy and depth.

XR Contrast booster gives you better contrast.

Very deep blacks with very little light blooming (meaning it has very even brightness across the screen.) The screen has PLENTY of brightness, that is definitely not an issue with this tv!

Ambient optimization option which changes your screen based on the ambient lighting in the room. Controls brightness and color tones. There are settings to optimize the screen for Netflix, Imax, Cinema, Etc that are amazing!

Motion is great, it has 120 hertz which keeps up with the action very well! You can adjust the Motionflow settings to your custom settings or just set it to auto and let it do it's thing.

Comparing it to the other top Sony models:
If you're on a budget and this is on the higher end of that, you might look into the Sony X80J- it's also a 2021 model and is 4k Ultra HD. It's not quite as nice of a picture as this Full Array but it's still a great tv! Otherwise if you can swing it- this X90J Full Array is definitely a fantastic choice! If your budget can STILL swing more though, you might even look into the X90J OLED tv, it's picture pops even more than this Full Array. Whatever your choice, you'll love any of them! I have all 3 models and we absolutely love each and every one of them- the X80 and X90 line are just fantastic tvs at a really fair price point.

title: Very effective. Does change the typing height of your laptop text: I received this as a free review sample and it was sorely needed because the internal fan in my ThinkPad T61 finally died. Note: if you are looking at this as a cure know that many laptops report a fan failure then shut down. In the case of mine, I found that I could press the On/Off button briefly when that happened and it would power back up and boot Windows.

This fan array moves a lot of air, promoting excellent heat transfer. So far it has worked well and I have had no premature shutdowns (although I still have to go through the On/Off button sequence every time I power the ThinkPad up.)

Do be aware that this fan array will interfere with other USB peripherals if you power it directly from your laptop, and especially if you add even more peripherals to the ports integrated into this unit. That is because the power draw form USB ports may exceed the capacity of the laptop, especially if you are running it off an unpowered USB hub. I had that problem when I tried running this, a mouse and a speaker from my laptop. I moved this one to a powered hub and the problem was immediately resolved.

Also, this raises a laptop 1 3/8 inches higher at its lowest setting. For me it took a day to become accustomed to the raised typing height, but since it solved a genuine problem the tradeoff was worth it. Just know that you will need to adjust to that and it may slow down your productivity for a day or two.

If your laptop has a fully functioning internal fan this array will augment that and keep your laptop cool even in unairconditioned spaces on a hot day. That will definitely prolong the life of the internal electronics and the hard drive.

title: Great case! (But read below about problems with features!) text: ***The first part of this review is for the Red option***

I needed more than just a simple case for my Kindle as it pulls double duty serving as my tablet and my planner. I also needed something that would provide it with supreme protection as it accompanies me to and from work every day.

I purchased this case/portfolio in the red color in hopes that it would make it stand out at work. Many of my co-workers have Kindles as well and I didn't want mine to accidentally get picked up. The red is nice, but way too much for me. I have been considering exchanging it for the black and the following issues are what sent me over the edge and led to my returning the red case.

This case/portfolio worked nicely for my needs. However, I removed two stars for two reasons.
#1 The case stunk to high heaven. It was so bad that I thought a stink bug had gotten into my house. Though the "scent" did lessen over a few weeks, it was still very present after five weeks.
#2 The description claims that this case has the ability to put the Kindle to sleep when you close it up. Not true. After my battery died over night, I realized that the sleep/wake feature was not working in my case. I had to physically turn my Kindle off before closing the case (may not seem like much of a hassle, but it quickly becomes a time consuming annoyance).

There was one benefit to this case though. It is the first case I have had for my Kindle that does not have any issues with using the Camera App while still encased in the removable inner sleeve. This was a very nice feature, however not nice enough to get me to keep it.

**This is the review of the Black option**

So, I just returned the red case and opted to give the black version a shot. It arrived this evening and wow, what a difference!

It doesn't stink at all and the sleep/wake feature is functioning properly! I do, however, now have the ghastly on-screen message of needing to slide my Kindle up in its case to take a picture. But this does not bother me very much as I have not used my Kindle for taking pictures more than a handful of times in the month that I have owned it.

All in all, it is a nice, professional case/portfolio that offers the features for my Kindle that I was needing. It also has a fair amount of pockets inside, though do not expect to be able to store much bulk as you will run into two problems..
#1 If you add too many things to the pockets, you run the risk of the pockets bulging and possibly damaging your Kindle's screen.
#2 Also, if you add too much to the pockets, you will possibly not be able to close the case. And if you manage to close it, you may run the risk of stretching the zipper and ultimately damaging the case.

Personally, I keep a small stack (about 10) of my business cards, five gift certificates and a little cash in the pockets and the zippers still flow smoothly with no issues and nothing from the pocket side comes in contact with my screen. Overall, I would recommend this case, as long as you are willing to take a risk on getting one that has the features you are wanting/needing as it seems to be a completely random toss-up as to which case has which features.

On a side note, the included stylus/pen is a great idea, but it isn't executed very well here. The plastic tip leaves a lot to be desired - it takes more force than I care to apply to my screen for the Kindle to register the stylus' contact on the screen. I did some research and purchased [[ASIN:B00E0GV9IC The Friendly Swede Bundle of 6 Micro-Knit Hybrid Fiber Tip Universal Capacitive Stylus Pens 4.5" for Smart Phone Touch Pad + 6 x 15'' Elastic Tether Lanyards + Cleaning Cloth in Retail Packaging]]. These stylus' are VERY nice in appearance and easy to use without requiring much force on the screen at all.

title: My second review - I like it a lot more now text: My first review gave the case 3 stars, but having used it for a couple weeks now, I gotta say, I like it much more now. I'd originally found the case to be far too shiny and cheap looking, but the shine wears down and it's starting to get a bit more lived in and is actually looking kind of nice now.

The light seems fragile, and it probably is more delicate than the KK's light, but it's doing its job well, better than the KK's since the light is more even.

I love the front cover, which is super thin and stiff.and the case itself doesn't add that much bulk. The whole package is the size of a slim mass market paperback. I can't stand reading the KT caseless. It's too small and thin and it bugs me.

My only complaint is that there's nothing to keep the cover closed. I get that they were trying to make the case as thin as possible, but the cover will flip open in one's purse. I just make sure to put it in open side down now, but I'd have preferred some kind of closure.

title: Out Too Soon. Not Ready for Prime Time text: I have three of the X570 Master MBs; so I decided to try the new X570S. It has a lot of new features but some major flaws that made the build exasperating. First of all I could not get the DVD drive to be recognized. I went through all of the Windows10 fixes thinking it was an update issue, then I went to two new DVD drives from two different vendors, two full sets of cables, all to No avail!
It turned out to be that the first bank of SATA connectors of the MB were nonoperational.
Secondly, I kept getting error messages that the USB device(wireless mouse, keyboard),were drawing more current than the connector could supply. I connected this two other computers and had no issues. The computer I took it off of had no issues, either.
Aorus/Gigabyte "tech support" is vaporware. Never received any response.
I would have returned it to Amazon, but the troubleshooting took so long that the return windows closed.
Wait until a newer revision(2.X) comes out if you think you need this MB or get the x570 Master

title: Good Bargain-Priced HDX 8.9" Case, But Lacks Automatic Wake-Up Feature text: [[VIDEOID:mo2LPRAGS06QPXR]]This MARBLUE ULTRA LIGHTWEIGHT CASE for the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" tablet would be a terrific bargain-priced case, if only the magnets woke the tablet up automatically. Sadly, the magnets only hold the cover closed. Despite that shortcoming, I do like this case. My HDX rarely travels anywhere, so all I need is a simple case with a built-in stand that will protect the tablet from dust and scratches.

This MarBlue Ultra Lightweight case is made of thin leatherette. It has an interior flap pocket that holds the fairly heavy Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" securely. The case has a faux-suede lining that makes it feel just a tiny bit luxurious. The case doesn't have any padding to cushion the HDX from accidental drops, or from loose items in a backpack or bag.

The back cover of the case has cutouts for the speakers, power button, volume control, light-level sensor, and rear-facing camera. As you can see from my accompanying video slide show, these cutouts aren't placed with laser precision. However, all of the control buttons are accessible, and the off-center cutouts don't faze the rear-facing camera or the light-level sensor.

The built-in stand is solid in the "writing desk" position, and reasonably solid in the upright position. The big HDX tablet doesn't wobble in the upright position, but it can be easily knocked over because of the steep upright angle. The worst feature of the stand is the tab support. To set up the stand, you need to fold back the front cover, pull the tab on the back cover up with your fingernails, and then fumble a bit to secure the edge of the folded-back front cover beneath the tab.

Nevertheless, the price (about $20) makes this Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" case an attractive choice if all you need is a bare-bones tablet cover. Still, because the case doesn't wake my HDX automatically, I rate it at only 4 stars ("I like it" on the official Amazon scale).

title: AWESOME WATER RESISTANT SURGE PROTECTOR text: After using surge protection for audio, video and computer equipment for more than 30 years I can definitely say not all of these products are created equally.

While surge protectors will often boast of great protection, more often than not they are more multi outlet plugs rather than actual protection. This surge protector will protect up to 1500 joules - what makes it especially impressive is it is safe for outdoor use!

I have thoroughly tested this surge protector and it has passed all of my testing. This will definitely protect your important investments.

The only thing I wish was different was the outlets should be spaced a bit further apart to allow for larger power blocks. So many plugs are nonstandard and end up blocking surrounding outlets. The only thing that would make this product better would be if the outlets rotated which would make them far more adaptable to oddly sized plugs.

The 3 USB ports are definitely a nice addition as this helps avoid having to use plugs for USB powered devices. What is even better about this particular surge protector is the USB-A ports are 3.0 (which charge far faster than previous versions).

This is an outstanding surge protector that has proven itself through my extensive use and testing. While this, nor any power supply should be submerged in water, this can definitely withstand moisture and splashes of water. This has made it safe for us to use by our pool.

This is definitely a surge protector I recommend especially for any moist areas!

title: Perfect for casual listening text: I own a number of Brainwavz models, all of which compare favorably to more expensive in ear monitors (IEMs). I am going to compare the review sample of this model to two other Brainwavz IEMs: [[ASIN:B00G4UQ6U8 Brainwavz S1 In Ear Headphones]] and the [[ASIN:B009UNZ5WQ Brainwavz R1 In Ear Noise Isolating Earphones]]. What I will try to avoid is repeating the other reviews - many of which are excellent - and the product specs on this page. Here are my impressions of these phones. Bear in mind that I listen primarily to acoustic jazz, so my listening needs may be vastly different from yours.

The first thing I do with I test phones or speakers is to play Miles Davis' [[ASIN:B00136JQMI Kind Of Blue]] to get a feel for how well the various frequencies are reproduced. That album has instruments in the low, mid and high bands, and these phones seemed to have more bass than the R1 or the S1. The mids and highs on those models, though, had more clarity. I tried a few other albums that had heavier bass and these definitely did a better job of reproducing those frequencies. When I switched to some tracks with female vocalists the R1 and S1 were better phones, and both of the other phones were clearer with higher register instruments.

From a comfort perspective these phones were a little lighter than the other two IEMs against which I compared them, although I would consider it a tie among them for overall comfort. These phones and the R1 had a value-added bonus in that a [[ASIN:B00HPPL1M4 Brainwavz Hard Earphone Case]] is included.

My conclusion is these are nice low-to-mid range IEMs that can compete with much more expensive IEMs from both Brainwavz and competing brands. I am impressed with the quality, completeness of the solution and the way these sound on lower end audio gear like MP3 players, phones and tablets. For higher end audio I would probaby use the S1 model because to my ears that one sounds better. However, you cannot go wrong with this one for everyday use when you want to listen to your music without disturbing others.

title: No Batteries Needed and Cool Lights text: Navigating on a pc screen requires a mouse of some sort. They have come a long way over the years, with more features and more comfort. One that is great for those who like to add a little color to their navigation is this wireless mouse from PEIOUS.

Shaped for your hands, this mouse is comfortable to hold and click. It’s easy enough to use and you can’t feel any strain on your hands, so it earns good marks there. But the feature that is most appealing is the lights. You can change the lights to different modes and even shut them off completely, if you prefer. I like that the lights are soft- you notice them, but they are not so bright that they distract from what you are doing.

The bluetooth works okay on this mouse and one of the more unusual features is that you have to plug it in to charge. With most others I have used, you need to supply batteries, but this one charges by plugging it into a usb outlet. It’s nice not to have to buy batteries, but it also means you need to have a usb nearby for charging purposes. I consider this feature a plus, as I hate having to search for batteries when the need arises.

To conserve power with this mouse, there is a switch to shut it off. Plus, it will automatically shut off, to preserve power, if there is no movement for several minutes. This is good because, with regular use, you will need to recharge this more than you realize and saving power makes a difference.

Computers need a means for navigation and that requires a mouse of one type or another. You could go for the boring, ordinary mouse with buttons to click and nothing more, or you could have a little fun and get this wireless mouse from PEIOUS. I vote for the latter. It might only be a mouse, but the lights and the elimination of batteries make this a standout mouse and one I recommend.

title: You will need a Micro SD card. text: [[VIDEOID:c6eed282949ae4a0bf6692a543d107c8]] This FunFlix 1080 HD WiFi Projecter is very nice and the picture (once you get it up and running) is clear!

It did take some time to get it up and running as we tried to use a flash drive (which it says it accepts a flash drive into the USB port), however it didn’t identify it. We had to then shut it down and restart it and try again…. It still didn’t work. We then tried a USB adapter with a SD card, and no luck - Still not identifiable… Then finally we tried a USB adapter with a MICRO SD card and it worked! When I checked on my computer all of the data showed on the flash drive as well as the SD card, but for some reason the projector wouldn’t identify them. The instructions don’t say anything about a MICRO SD card, however I wanted to point this out as this is the only thing that worked for me.

The mirroring technique through your phone does work, however the further away your phone is from the projector, the quality fades and it starts to pixelate. Also, it will drain your phone quickly.

I plan to use this for Halloween and I am so excited! Only took off 1 star as it took some time to get this up and going. If the instructions were better, it would totally get 5 stars.

title: Nest Traveller Tripod Legs... 100% satisfaction all around
text: I started out using a Manfrotto 324RC2 light duty grip ball head (the side grip joystick) with a Fuji S5pro and Sigma 50-100mm Art lens. Not sure of the total weight, but did not notice any flexing or leg slippage once set.  Once I changed over to my Nikon D750 w/ 200-500mm...I felt a little less secure that this was the right setup. Anything smaller (video camera, Lumix fz200, spotting scope ,etc) I am 100% confident in these legs.  Not really fond of that particular tripod head but was all I had when the legs arrived. Big problem was that it would not fold back neatly because of the design of the head....  So, having recently purchased a Sirui K40x for my super heavy Bogen legs, I was so wowed by that head that I bought a smaller Sirui head k30x . I could not be more pleased with the function of either. I'd never heard of this brand or seen one, but took a chance based on the first few reviews. Really like the hook at bottom.. Never been a fan of the twist locks, but I can change. Only other CF I have is a small Monopod for traveling in a suitcase.  I have no regrets ... I got a quality product.. Light and strong. Don't think I'll ever pull the leg off for a monopod, but it's nice to know it's there if I need to splint a leg or need a walking stick. Have yet to try it on a sandy beach... that will be the ultimate test for me. Have always used heavy aluminum pods that are easy to disassemble and clean from sand and salt water.  Will update if find issues later

title: Disappointing, but it does work (kind of)
text: The first time I plugged in the Wi-Fi adapter, the TV froze.  I tried it again with the TV turned off and then it worked fine at power up and paired perfectly.  I had great hopes for this device and it seems to work fine if you have a QWERTY keyboard displayed on the screen or an actual input area for you to type in.  In some places it simply doesn't work, such as YouTube.  The search screen for YouTube does not display a keyboard, but the letters in alpha order and you have to move around and select letters instead of just being able to type in your selection.  My wife uses the TV a lot and watches almost everything from YouTube, so this isn't going to provide much of a benefit over the remote that came with the TV.  There is nothing really wrong with the keyboard; it is just that various services provided on the TV just haven't standardized on one way to do alphanumeric input and on searches.  Some of the services just aren't responsive to typing from the keyboard, which is too bad.  The keyboard is a great idea and may work for you; just be aware of the limitations and that you probably can't type in your search strings in all places on your Smart TV.

title: Easy to connect and relocate. Allows us to have full Wi-Fi at the pool and backyard text: We have a good dual band router that is really great in the house, but Wi-Fi out on the patios or by the pool is sketchy at best. I've had this extender installed for about two weeks now and it's definitely improved things.

It took several tries to find the right location to push the Wi-Fi signal where I wanted it outside, but once that was figured out, we were set. Relocating this unit is pretty simple - once it's tied into your router, just plug it in and watch the lights until you see all green. I repeated this process four times before I had the exact spot I wanted. It never failed to connect after being unplugged and moved.

It actually throws the signal significantly farther than expected. I can use my tablet sitting on the bridge over the creek, about 250 feet from the extender's location in the house - in a straight line. I'm pretty pleased with the performance so far for my simple needs. It's really close to the speeds our direct router puts out, so we're not seeing any noticeable signal degradation on tablets, cell phones or a laptop outside.

title: A solid enclosure with RGB goodness text: When I first got this M.2 NVMe and SATA SSD Enclosure, I was concerned about its build quality. The enclosure opens by squeezing the plastic at the top and sliding the drive mount out like a drawer. I felt that the plastic felt soft and didn't understand why it's not metal.

After plugging it into my computer, I understood. The drive tray is made of plastic because it is light with nice RGB lights. When plugged in, the lights will flash to different colors when data is being read and when the drive is idle, the lights pulse between different colors. It's pretty cool, actualy.

In terms of performance, it is on par with my many other enclosures. It is able to transfer at the maximum USB speed, although I don't have the diskmark app installed so I don't have any specific numbers. I just know that I'm happy with this purchase because the price is reasonable and the RGB was a nice surprise. Oh, and the enclosure comes with both type-c to type-c as well as type-c to type-A connectors cables. Other enclosures just come with a c-to-a cable.

title: Great mount for adjustments, lots of mounting options, very stable with the TV attached text: I just got finished mounting a 65" Sony television to my brick chimney with this kit. I love how much adjustment there is with this mount once it is up. It is easy to pull the set away from the wall & also turn it to the sides. The tilt angle is also adjustable but requires hand-loosening & then tightening a couple of fasteners. There are 2 height positions for the TV that are pretty easy to change &, at least with my Sony, more room for adjustments based on how the brackets attach to the TV.
The instructions for this mount are pretty good but there is a lot of measuring, math & test fitting involved in setting up the height which isn't addressed in the instructions. The kit comes with a variety of hardware options & even comes with a small, magnetic level to help position the mount, an HDMI cable & some cable organizers.
The only issue I had was concerning mounting to the brick chimney. There are a variety of holes laterally for different stud spacing but only two sets vertically. The vertical spacing was not to my liking because it pushed the mounting holes too close to the edge of the bricks. I was also a bit weary of the plastic inserts to mount to brick or concrete walls instead of the metal expanders but the screws bit hard and gave a good, tight feel when they were snugged.
Now I just need to sort out those wires.

title: Good OEM Cable Substitute text: Lightning cables are something that we all need in the house. I selected this one with the thought of having it on the main level of the house, to be available to all of us when we want to charge our phones without hunting down a cable. So far it has worked out very well for us and is one of the better cables with which I have worked.

This is a flat cable as opposed to round and I've found this has a couple of big advantages. First, it's a lot less likely get get tangled or kinked which is great. It can be tangled, of course, but it is a lot less likely. The other big plus is that flat cables seem a lot less likely to break near the connectors for some reason. As such, I expect this cable to last for a while and to be easily accessible as long as it's not tangled up with other cables.

In use it works great. It charges my phone without issue and it also works just fine as a data cable. I did not see any mention of being it MFi certified anywhere, but it seems to be just fine regardless.

So far I have no complaints with this cable. It works, and I like the design.
