title: Mind blowing wifi coverage, but had some minor hardwire issues text: Honestly, I wish I had a tried a Wifi6 mesh system sooner. This is NIGHT AND DAY difference over my previous D-link router + extender. I thought that since both my router and extender were D-link and had the ability to "communicate" with each other, it would work pretty well, but honestly even when it "worked" it was pretty laggy, and outside on the porch it would drop to single digit speed tests, if anything at all (forget about streaming for backyard movie nights!).
This system, however, is incredible. I'm now getting nearly 200mbps outside where I used to have nothing, and in most of my house I'm hitting my maximum 250mbps that I'm paying for with my internet service. Everything responds quickly and smoothly, and I love the control that the TP link system gives over what devices are connected (it alerts me when a new device connects!) and being able to set restrictions and time limits as well!
The one downside, however, is the physical ports. For starters, there are only 3 of them per unit. If you use ethernet backbone to connect them, that leaves only one on the primary node (one for the internet connection to the modem, and the other going to the second node- only one available for anything else). In my case, I have an ethernet cable going to my desktop for work (the most reliable connection), and another going into a telephony system. The 3 port limitation would have been difficult if I hardwired the satellite, but thankfully I didn't have to. The wireless mesh over 6Ghz actually works quite well so far so I managed with only the 3 ports on the primary one.
That being said, at first I had a major issue with the speed on my hardwired connection. The desktop claimed to only connect at 100mbps. Meanwhile, if I turned on wifi I was pulling 250mbps. That can't be! Many chats to customer support and we couldn't figure it out until I switched ports on the Deco and now I'm getting the full 250 over ethernet. I don't know if it was the port having trouble or just reseating the wire that did it, but I never had that on my previous D-link router, and it had more ports too in case I needed them.

In a nutshell, I got it working, and for what it is supposed to do, I'm VERY very impressed at the performance. But the hardwire hiccup and limitation in number of ports available makes this a 4 instead of 5 star review.

title: Not leather at all, but fantastic!
text: Vegan leather is just pleather, y'all. I looked it up. I did not want to like this bag. But, I got it and had to review it. So that meant, I had to use it. And use it I did. It is a joy to use!! Suprise! There is so much room inside. And all my stuff fit and was so organized. The pockets are all roomy, the middle zippered pocket is big enough for my massive day timer and various documents. My phone, kept in the phone pouch, stays up toward the top so I can reach it along with my wallet. The bag is sturdy and doesn't slump all over. The inside vinyl part makes a scratchy, plastic noise when anything touches it. That bugs me. And to describe a vinyl purse as vegan leather is disgraceful!! But it looks classy and pretty authentic. I won't tell my husband though. He'll make fun of me. #savethecows

title: Not as impressed as I thought I would be. text: This is a fun, useful tablet for the price. I love that you can make all different homepages. Love that you can pick wallpaper which you can't do with Kindle Fires which are the only other tablets I've owned. Of course, if you want a tablet
mainly for books, Kindle is the tablet you want. I also love all the apps you can get with the Samsung. What I don't like is the 8gb storage. I was under the impression if you got the 32gb extra it would integrate with the tablet rather than just be like a drive for mp3s and such. 8 gigs is barely enough for the apps you need. Also the manual tells you nothing about how to add things to the extra drive. Had to go to you tube. My tablet has connection issues from time to time.
I still really enjoy it most of the time. It can be super fast and plays things well from the cloud. Very light and attractive.

I am returning tablet. 8 gbs is just not enough. Extra storage cumbersome to use and doesn't work half of the time. Not easy like the cloud. Speakers unimpressive. I am disappointed because I thought I would like the Samsung. Also a battery hog. Will try the nexus 7.

title: awkward design, hard to get used to, finding it irritating to use text: So, I have this backpack, and it is kinda weird. You have to see my pictures as it is a different style than what is pictured in the description. I don't really care for it as it is awkward to handle.

--It is a basic looking back pack. I like the bright orange in contrast to the black. That is likely the only feature I really like.
--The bag is deep. It measures roughly 21" long, this includes the top portion being unfolded, as that is usable space if need be. @17" wide
--The access to the main compartment is a velcro closure with adjustable hook straps for added security (and to keep added length folded down). Unlike many backpacks, there is just one slit opening across the top with velcro to close. Most backpacks have a zipper closure, as well as going a bit down the sides, for ease of access. I'm not fond of how my bag is styled in that way.
--Inside the great nylon cavern of the main compartment, it splits into several more compartments and pockets, including a lightly padded pocket.
--exterior pockets included two open side pockets that would be great to stick a water bottle in or an umbrella.
--two good sized compartments on the front- one zippered, one velcro flap closure.
--one rear zip pocket, as well as what appears to be a pass through strap of material- perhaps for use on a luggage handle?
--padded shoulder straps are comfortable. Straps include d-rings for clipping keys, or whatever to.
--overall feel is good
-I cant for the life of me find the USB port that it claims to have. I don't see anywhere for headphones, etc.. so I don't know what is going on.

The part that makes me really not like it is the main opening. First, it is deep, which can be good or bad depending on your needs. But, the top folds over way to easily. So it takes some major rooting around to find stuff, and the flap wants to fold down, and if it manages to fold down, it is easily closed tight by the velcro. This is super annoying if you want to get into and out of the bag repeatedly. I'm just like STAY OPEN. If it zipped, it would be better, then at least if it folder over it would be easy enough to get it, but with the velcro closing it up, it is irritating.

The other aspect that I dont care for is the hooks on the front. Well, they are anchored on the front, but since they are used to help keep bag closed (in addition to the velcro), when they aren't hooked, they are dangling down the front. So you have those kicking around in the front, and the shoulder straps and all its extras kicking around in the back. It isn't as clean or stream lined as it could be. It feels frumpy, I am sorry to say. I was hoping to replace my every day carry bag- I like to have a little cross body purse, plus a back pack for all my additional daily needs. This might get old quick as I try to get used to the odd features.

title: Guess I got a bad one... text: I ordered this lens about 2 years ago and right out of the box the AF motor sounded like it was 'too tight'...made a high-pitched, almost abrasive sound whenever it would focus. Being the first prime lens I got for my T2i, I didn't suspect anything at first. After about 3 months, the AF stopped working entirely. I sent it off to Canon to fix under a warranty claim and they had it back to me in about 3 weeks. From that point, it worked for about another 8 months before reverting back to the same state of disrepair. I resolved to just use MF on it, however, just having this lens attached to my camera nearly instantly drains even a full-battery....must be some kind of short in it.

Regardless of the failed mechanics and weird behavior, the glass was good and I really liked the way it handled indoor light....great colors and warm tone, nice FOV. Nonetheless, this lens is basically worthless to me now and just sits in the top of my closet. Because of this experience, I am very weary to invest in more Canon lenses and have since only purchased Sigma lenses, with mixed emotions there as well. One day....I'll get a good one...hopefully.

title: OUTSTANDING SURGE PROTECTOR text: After using surge protection for audio, video and computer equipment for more than 30 years I can definitely say not all of these products are created equally.

While surge protectors will often boast of great protection, more often than not they are more multi outlet plugs rather than actual protection.

I have thoroughly tested this surge protector and it has passed all of my testing. This will definitely protect your important investments.

The only thing I wish was different was the outlets should be spaced a bit further apart to allow for larger power blocks - with that being said having 12 outlets should allow most users to have more than enough. The 4 USB-A ports are definitely a nice addition as this helps avoid having to use plugs for USB powered devices.

This is an outstanding surge protector that has proven itself through extensive use and testing.

This is definitely a surge protector I recommend.

title: Phenomenal Sound Quality, Easy Set Up - GREAT BUY! text: I paired this sound bar with our Sony XBR-65X850E 65” TV and it could not have been easier.

While my TV would allow me to connect to the sound bar via Bluetooth I opted to connect via the HDMI ARC connection to avoid any sound lag. In addition to these 2 connection options you can connect via optical cable.

I followed the instructions - plugged the HDMI cable (included) into the ARC HDMI port, plugged the sound bar and subwoofer into the surge protector and turned everything on. The TV automatically recognized the soundbar and changed my output.

The sound bar automatically connected to the subwoofer without me doing anything at all. I decided to move the subwoofer to another area of the room - I unplugged it, moved it, plugged it back in and it again reconnected without any problem.

I was able to pair the system with my iPhone without any issue and the sound is stunning. From the rich bass of the subwoofer, the vibrant midtones, to the crisp highs - every note is clear and distinct.

While I have a true 5.1 surround system most of the TV broadcasts are not going to utilize that type of system and the sound is actually richer through this sound bar with a subwoofer.

This soundbar can be easily wall mounted using the included template. Since I have my TV on an entertainment center base I’ve used the “AmazonBasics Universal Sound Bar TV Bracket - Adjustable Arm for Mounting Above or Under TV, Black” to mount the sound bar below the TV where it hangs perfectly level. Since this is a universal bracket it requires a bit of figuring out the best configuration but it comes with everything you’ll need and it works great.

The entire system is intuitive and user friendly. While many sound systems require hours to hook up and figure out how to use correctly this one is so straightforward. The remote doesn’t have a bunch of excess buttons that you’ll never need or use.

The new sound technologies Sony employs with this sound system are incredible. The “Immersive AE” function changes the directionality on the sound and is remarkable.

In my instance my TV remote was able to control it immediately with no issues.

I have always been impressed with the quality of Sony’s audio and video products - they are constantly innovating and improving on their products and in my experience they hold up far better than other brands.

I highly recommend this soundbar for anyone looking for an easy way to improve the quality of the sound from your TV - and you’ll be pleasantly surprised by the rich sound it will deliver regardless of what you play through it.

Thanks for reading my review. I enjoy writing them as I value reading other’s reviews when I’m making a buying decision. I regularly update my reviews to reflect any changes I may discover and to include helpful tips you may need if you purchase the product. I will always make every effort to answer any questions I can as it is my pleasure to help.

title: Protects Tablet text: I bought this for my Nexus 7 with LTE. The tablet usually goes out with me, and sometimes replaces the need for me to bring my notebook. Therefore, with a nearly $400 device, it will make sense to try to keep it safe. This case does the job well enough. The front cover uses magnets which activates the screen when opens, and turns the screen off when closed. This does not work for the first couple of minutes as you turn on the tablet, but this is because the OS is booting.

There is one gripe, and that the tablet doesn't do well with Qi charging pads. This is a minor annoyance as of now, but I am a proponent of Qi charging as I feel more devices should have this feature. Therefore, case manufacturers should make a better effort in making sure that their case will work well with such charging pads.

[Update - 2014-06-28]
The magnets for the case is falling out. I would have thought they would have screwed or glued the magnets in. Now, every time I open the case's cover, the magnets come along with it. Since I bought this on 2014-02-08, this is less than 5 months since it is malfunctioning. Now, I can only hope that the company will honor the warranty. In the meantime, I have no choice but to reduce my rating of this from 4 to 3.

title: Love my 10“ but they don't make them like they used to. text: Pros: screen is large enough to easily see games, read a book, etc. So ppl with vision problems this is very easy to use. Cons: The newer they are the faster they seem to fail. This is my 4th kindle 2nd 10" the first 2 were 7". My first one lasted 5yrs befor the charger port failed. The second was the same but only lasted 3yrs. My first 10" barely lasted a year. I used it until bed time, got up the next morning and nothing. It won't come on. I tried several different things but nada. I think the battery gave out and when I have time I plan on taking it apart myself to try to repair it. I'm hoping my new one is a little better. Aside from those issues the only thing I can say is since it is large it can be hard to hold so for any one with hand or arm issues that may need a holder so they can use these easier. title: Excellent set of HDMI Cables and Accessories text: Most people who have set up audio video systems have had the frustrating experience of reaching the final step only to realize they were missing a critical cable - purchase one of these sets and you’ll help avoid that situation next time.

This set comes with four 6ft HDMI Cables with 24K gold plated plugs, a 90 degree gold plated HDMI adapter and three Velcro cord keeper ties.

I’ve found 6ft HDMI cables are the perfect length most of the time for connecting the majority of entertainment systems - cable box to TV, DVD player to TV, game consoles to TV, sound bar or system to TV. Having the terminals played in 24K gold is the standard in top quality audio / video transmission.

In addition to the excellent cables, this set comes with a 90 degree gold plated HDMI adapter which comes in real handy for ports that are difficult to reach and connect into - and 3 Velcro cord binder ties.

The only thing that surprised me about this set is only 3 cord binders were included with 4 cables - ideally there should be 8 or a minimum of 4 for a complete set.

In regards to the quality of the materials and craftsmanship - this is an outstanding set that everyone will have use for at some point.

This set is an excellent value that I would definitely recommend.

title: Not A Stellar Case text: Okay, before I mention what is wrong with this case, I will mention two things that are right:

1. The leather feels so soft. For a mass produced case, they did a good job at this aspect.

2. The strap, which I am going to call a negative down below, does look cool if you are thinking of your KFHD as an ebook reader because it resembles the straps that are sometimes found in books.

Okay, done with the good. Now for the critique:

1. The spine likes to stay open. By that I mean when you open the device and then close it you have to use the strap to hold it shut because it will not do so naturally. Since the device turns on and off when you open and close it, this means that the device will waste power staying on because it thinks that the case is open. There are many ways to avoid this, but they manufacturer did not try to.

2. There are no pockets to put note cards or business cards.

3. There is no loop to hold a stylus or pen.

4. The case is open around all sides. This isn't a design flaw, but if I were the company I would offer a zippered version to protect the device from rain.

5. The strap SUCKS!!! I mean really, it takes effort to properly close this case! Why not design it not to need one like my Toshiba Thrive case, or design it with a magnetic clasp like my Kindle Touch case?

6. The rotating mechanism is pretty cool, I have seen similar for other devices, but it is pretty tight. Perhaps this will loosen up, but after 3 days I still report this to be difficult to turn.

7. The hand strap is useless. If you hold it open like that, the device is secured only to one side and can flap about. If you are going to put in a hand strap, this should provide secure and stable device placement.

8. And now for the most annoying factor: they get a point for designing a case that can sit at several angles, but then loose several million for designing it so that NONE of those angles are comfortable. They range from pointing slightly down to pointing slightly up, and all of them are best if the device is at or within 6" below eye level. If you sit it on your desk and not a long way off, it is not angled enough for a good view! Seriously? Didn't they test this before going into production?

My advice to the user is to find another case.

My advice to the manufacturer is to redesign. And while you're at it, please send me a free one of the new cases after the redesign so that I don't have to buy a new case!

One more word about the price. I know that this is a high end case with the rotating feature and all, but anything over $30 is just ridiculous! I got mine free in exchange for this review (sorry about that, but I am always fair and I have never been bribed in my reviews), but I wouldn't have paid for it if I had to do so!

title: Nice Little Projector With Built-In Speaker text: This is a nice little item for giving presentations or to use for home entertainment. The image is bright enough to use in a lighted room for things like power point presentations, but for watching a movie it is better to turn out the lights. The projector comes with a power cable, an RCA connector, an HDMI cable and a remote control. The projector hooks up easily and has a convenient dial on the side for bringing the picture into focus.

As an inexpensive projector, this item is a nice value. I give a lot of presentations, and although most of the venues where I speak have their own projectors, it's nice to bring this one along as a back-up. It fits easily in a laptop bag, and it gets the job done. The controls are easy to understand and the item works great. The built-in speaker means that you can bring this along on camping trips for outdoor movie night. It's a fun and functional projector.

title: Dynamic "Quality of Service" Feature Helps Out Home Network With Many Attached Devices text: I'm not a gamer, but I do have around 30 devices connected to a home network. These include WEMO switches, Amazon Echos, a smart TV, a playstation, Kindles, iPads, printers, and smartphones. The "dynamic Quality of Service" feature of this NIGHTHAWK X4 ULTIMATE GAMING ROUTER (R7500v2) seems to prioritize these devices, so that all of them are more responsive (faster connections) than they were with my previous router (a rock-solid NIGHTHAWK (R7000)).

When this NIGHTHAWK (R7500v2) is set up, it recognizes all of the "Internet of things" devices for what they are. In the "attached devices" list, these aren't given device names (e.g., "iPad", picked up from the device itself) but have "n/a" in the name column (and you can't assign them names even if you know them by the MAC numbers). I don't know exactly how the "Quality of Service" feature performs its magic, but now when I ask an Amazon Echo to turn on a light or a fan, the Echo performs the task immediately--instead of with a delay while it searched through the router's list of connected devices for the correct one.

The PCs and other devices that use lots of bandwidth (instead of being on standby much of the time) seem to connect faster, and they test (using OOKLA) at significantly faster Internet speeds.

My R7500v2 is broadcasting signals for both bands (2.4 GHz and 5 GHz), and my compatible devices connect with the 5 GHz network whenever I ask them to. However, I don't use the 5 GHz band for anything at present (because it's easiest to have everything that uses a printer on the same band with the printers). Thus I don't know whether the router frequently drops the 5 GHz signal, as other reviewers have stated.

I've used several high-end Linksys routers, and they have performed very well. However, I find that Netgear routers lose their Internet signal far less often, and almost never require rebooting--when Netgear routers need rebooting, the issue is almost always traceable to Comcast problems.

Another reason that I prefer Netgear routers over Linksys routers is that Netgear has no limit (or a very high limit) on the number of devices that you can list by MAC number and tell the router to "allow only these devices to connect to the network". I use this feature as an extra firewall, and find that the Linksys 25-device list is inadequate for my needs.

Finally, the Netgear "Genie" app for managing the router settings is clear and easy to understand. The initial setup for this router is easy, unless you have a nonstandard home network (e.g., my router is connected with the Comcast-supplied equipment in "Bridge" mode), and/or you interrupt the setup routine before it's run through all its steps. If you do land in setup limbo, you can start over by resetting the router to the factory settings (use a paperclip to hold down the reset button for 10-30 seconds--light will blink; unplug from wall for 30 seconds; follow Quick Start instructions again from beginning).

title: Disguises Kindle Keyboard, 1st Gen Kindle Fire, or Nexus 7 as Beautiful Book text: [[VIDEOID:mo4US5M5XC9DUY]]This case, the VERSO PROLOGUE (MARBLED BLUE), is so pretty, I'm going to use it for my Kindle Keyboard even though it doesn't fit quite as well as the case I've been using (the [[ASIN:B003DZ165W Kindle Lighted Leather Cover, Black (Fits Kindle Keyboard)]] ). Because the Verso cover is designed to fit a number of e-readers, and the Kindle Keyboard is the thinnest, the cover's "book spine" is a little wider than I'd like. But the spine itself is fun, showing a gold-stamped book title,"Verso II".

I tried this case with all of my small e-readers: the 1st Gen Kindle Fire, the Kindle Keyboard, and the Nexus 7. As you can see from the accompanying video slide show, the case works (or as the manufacturer would say, "is compatible with") all three. However, depending on the device, you may have to adjust the elastic bands so that they don't cover important keys or buttons.

The best fit is with the 1st Gen Kindle Fire. The device's power button and ports are at the center bottom, and the ambient light sensor is at the upper left corner, so the case's elastic bands interfere with nothing. The Kindle Keyboard is a good fit. The case's elastic bands come close to covering the outside keyboard keys at the lower left and right, but the bands can be pushed back for clearance; and the bands don't interfere with the Keyboard's power button on the lower edge. The Nexus 7 (which is slightly larger than the Fire, and slightly thicker than the Keyboard) is a snug fit, but the case still works. The elastic band at the top right must be pushed back to clear the Nexus 7 power and volume buttons located on the side edge at the top right. Although the case covers the Nexus 7 speaker on the back, the sound is the same whether the tablet is in or out of the case.

Once adjusted, the elastic bands stay in place, because there is a rubbery material on the underside of the elastic that grips the surface beneath it. (I have screen protector film on my Kindle Fire and Nexus 7, which seems like a good idea whenever a case holds the e-reader by elastic bands instead of a hard plastic shell.) This Verso case lacks any elastic closure, magnetic closure, or automatic wake/sleep feature. However, the case stays closed fairly well (like a book), and offers good protection if your device is placed carefully (not tossed) into a bag or tote. There is a pocket on the inside cover that is supposedly for "important papers", but it only holds a few thin items. Apparently you can use this pocket to hold your e-reader when the cover is folded back.

According to the retail literature that comes with it, the Verso Prologue Marbled Blue case is "compatible" with the Kindle Fire, Kindle Keyboard, Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 (7.0), NOOK, Kobo Wi-Fi, Kobo Vox, Sony Reader Daily Edition, Sony Reader Wi-Fi, BlackBerry Playbook, HTC Flyer, Dell Streak 7, and other 7" tablets (e.g., the Nexus 7). This case is extremely well made, using superior materials, and makes your e-reader look like a beautiful handmade book.

title: Nice earbuds but I decided swapped them out for Bose QuietComfort earbuds text: I went on the search for a set of ear buds that would stay in my ears better than my Airpod Pros but with the same level of Noise cancellation. It seemed like the Sony WF-1000XM4 and Bose Quietcomfort earbuds were the top picks in this space. After a lot of research i went with the Sony earbuds. Besides their sound and level of ANC. i liked the fact the Sony earbuds still had a lot of playback control available from the earbuds and you can use either earbud individually. I also felt like the fact that they sit in your ear canal rather than on the outside would contribute to the noise cancellation.

The earbuds felt and sound good and the accompanying app was nice but the case had a cheap, almost cardboard feel. My main issues were, although the earbuds never actually fell out of my ear, I think their top-heavy design made them feel like they were always about to fall out. The bigger issue i had, which won't apply to everyone, is how much effort went into getting them to sit correctly in my ear. Even with twisting, and pushing, I could never get the right earbud to fit securely in my ear like the left one did.

After a day of wearing the Sonys i decided to pick up a pair of Bose Quietcomfort ear buds as i already had a pair of Quietcomfort 35 over the ears that i loved, i figured I'd give Bose another shot. As soon as i opened the Bose, I immediately fell in love. Besides the unboxing and charging case feeling more premium, the earbuds went into my ear effortlessly and securely. I wore them the first day and they stayed in place all day and sounded great.

Although the Sony WF-1000XM4 is a great set of earbuds, The Bose earbuds have the same functionality, sound and ANC but are designed in a way to comfortably fit a wider array of ear shapes and at a cheaper price. The Sonys are going back and the Bose are going to be my new day-to-day earbuds.

title: Cheaply Made and Overpriced text: I selected this little organizer for keeping my collection of thumb drives organized and in one place. I have a habit of misplacing one or more of them on occasion and I was hopeful this organization system would help keep them all together. It does work well for that purpose but in my opinion this is overpriced and cheaply made.

At a glance, this is a small and lightweight case, made of plastic with aluminum framing. The inside is a foam rubber sheet with grooves cut into it that hold on to small objects, in this case thumb drives and two slots for SSD or laptop hard drives. It’s not as big as a typical briefcase, and in fact will likely fit inside most briefcases.

My complaint is that it is cheaply made, especially when considering the price ($40 as I write this). The plastic handle and the clasp are both chrome-plated plastic that is easily scratched and flaked. The clasp itself isn’t even straight on my unit and there’s enough play in the hinge that I expect it to break off completely over time. The no-slip feet on the bottom aren’t even straight, and they’re installed loosely enough that they can be turned and wiggled freely. The foam insert has the feel and consistency of packing peanuts, cheap material.

There are better solutions for SSD and thumb drive storage. This one is so cheaply made and so overpriced that I have real difficulty recommending it.

title: Not Great, but cheap text: At $13 it's a decent buy. It isn't the greatest, the instructions are poorly written and the build quality is marginal, but it does work pretty well. I'm giving it 4 stars just because it's price is so good. This thing is sold elsewhere for as much as $90.

The user interface, (button) is a bit confusing but once you play with it for awhile and figure it out, it does seem to work as described. The alignment of the camera with the little hole on mine was a bit off, but it was pretty easy to "tweak" it into alignment. The video quality isn't too bad as long as you have adequate lighting. The sound pick up is amazingly sensitive. Need to buy a micro SD to use it. It doesn't come with one.

It is an ingenious design but could have been implemented just a bit better. Still it is convincing enough and unobtrusive, The way it is made, it completely comes apart quite easily and I can see opportunities to retrofit the electronics into any number of other objects.

Overall, if you're not a little bit tech savy, you may have probelms with this, but it's a great buy for the money if you don't mind having to play with it a bit to get it to work the way you want.

title: Not bad. text: Was actually pleased by the caps when they arrived. I used to be particular about keycap quality, but in the last few years the quality and cost of keycaps have been awesome; I'm so thrilled about those new to the hobby (although it's still expensive). When GMK 9009 was originally announced, I thought it was the perfect modern edition of classic beige. Everyone should have a good classic beige set, and 9009 is it.

Right now, my workhorse keyboard is a polycarbonate 910 with Cherry MX Grays and third-party springs (I forget the weight). Typing on it is a dream every day, and the keycaps can enhance the experience. I prefer PBT on this keyboard because it has a more pleasant, thocky sound than ABS caps. There's also a bit of tactile pushback with ABS, at least from what I noticed. While I love 9009, I'm not thrilled about ABS. Sure, ABS is cool and develops a nice shine based on use, but I prefer the consistent feel of PBT; having some keycaps stripped of their coating from use while others still feel new can throw me off. All that to say that I'm glad I was able to get this 9009 set in PBT. I was very hesitant, though, because the price for this many dye-sublimated, PBT keycaps was too good to be true.

When the package arrived, I was disappointed to find that there was no shipping box. The keycaps arrived in their manufacturer box with a shipping label slapped on it. Not only can that increase the chances of theft, but the shipping label covers the rendering that shows all the keycaps included. So now I'll have to resort to the listing to see what all should be in the box. However, nothing appears damaged. The keycaps come in wonderfully secure, plastic trays, three stacked on each other. There are a lot of keycaps here, so most keyboards should be covered. Of course, not everything will be perfect; for my 910, the Home cap is taller than the rest of the row, and there is no 1u Tab cap, nor a R1-height Fn cap. There's only one 1u blank keycap, which doesn't sit flush with the rest of the caps in its row. Minor gripes because I know my layout is particular.

But, again, there still is a great amount of keycaps so I'm sure most boards will be covered.

Now, as for the keycaps themselves. As I mentioned, I was very hesitant when the package arrived, but overall I'm pleasantly surprised. The keycaps are slightly thinner than enjoyPBT and BSP caps, and the stem can be a bit snug, but not too tight so that they don't come off easily. The sublimation is very good; I haven't noticed any that appear sloppy. Some num pad legends seem a bit thinner than others, but overall the legends are consistent and have that Cherry-legend appearance.

I wish there were more color options here, but for the price I can't complain. Truly, at $40, this set is an amazing bang for the buck.

title: Night Owl’s Rejoice! text: If you are someone who tends to stay up later than your partner watching TV but don’t want the volume to disturb them this is an excellent option.

I have tested this set on 3 TVs and my computer. This will work only if you have RCA audio outputs (red and white outputs), a headphone jack or an optical output. One thing to not on this, I’ve found the optical output tends to have a lag in sound while when hooked up through the other outputs there is not. Once plugged in you may have to search and adjust your TV’s audio output settings to find which one works for this set. I found depending on the TV they may be labeled differently.

Adjusting sound can be a bit tricky. Press the sound adjustment buttons on the headphones + or - wait a second then press again. If you just keep tapping or hold it down it will not change.

The battery life on these headphones is excellent and the charging base is small and convenient. I have this set up next to my bed so they are always ready to go.

In terms of sound quality, I would say they are a bit over average. While this would not be a pair I would use for listening to music if I wanted the experience of truest high definition it is definitely adequate for watching TV.

This is a solid pair of wireless headphones for watching TV. While they don’t have high definition sound quality they do sound good. Make sure you have the correct output ports available prior to ordering as not all TV’s have multiple sets of RCA output ports and if your’s are already occupied switching it every time you want to use these is a pain.

I’ve really enjoyed having this set and being able to enjoy watching TV at night without keeping anyone else awake.

Thanks for reading my review. I enjoy writing them as I value reading other’s reviews when I’m making a buying decision. I regularly update my reviews to reflect any changes I may discover and to include helpful tips you may need if you purchase the product. I will always make every effort to answer any questions I can as it is my pleasure to help.

title: Great Little Camera... text: I was concerned about some of the complaints regarding short battery life, noisy zoom lens and an overall cheap plastic feel of this camera, but it was a great value & I decided to give it a try.

Luckily, I havn't had any of those problems with the camera, and after several months, am perfectly happy with it. Yes, the camera has a plastic body, but it's been very durable while travelling and seems no flimsier than any other electronic device made today. The plastic body is one reason why the camera is so easy to take everywhere. It's light, compact & not a chore to haul around, which is nice.

Rather than a short battery life, I have been suprised at the long life of the battery that came in the camera. I bought an extra battery because I expected it to run out quickly, but I've never used it. I've never needed to. During a 4-day weekend in the mountains, I plugged the camera in at night, and was able to record any time and every time I wanted all day long each day.

The noisy zoom lens? I don't know. My model doesn't have a noisy zoom lens. I can barely hear it when I use it, and have never noticed the sound of the zoom during playback. Maybe it happens with some of them.

Granted, the built-in microphone doesn't produce the best sound, but it's been good enough for my casual use of video. The video has been clear, sharp & colorful. Would I use it to record a wedding? Probably not. To record my mother's belly-dancing recital? You bet!

title: Bass Boost that Can Be Turned Off! text: I am usually not a big fan of on-ear headphones. I have learned through experience that Philips makes good headphones, though, and based on the brand name I selected this set of headphones to try out. So far I am pleased with them.

As mentioned, these are on-ear phones. For me, I prefer over-the-ear phones which are more comfortable most of the time, and that is probably the only complaint I have with these. After wearing these for a while I need to take them off for a short time before I can put them back on and keep going. This is true with most on-ear phones I have tried. For on-ear phones, though, these aren't bad and the ear fatigue is less than many I have used.

This particular set boasts an on-demand bass boost, and for me that's a huge plus. Most headphones have the bass boost baked right in and there's no way to turn it off. I don't care for heavy-handed bass (gives me headaches), so for me it is a feature I will leave turned off most of the time. However, there are times when the bass needs some help, and these deliver. When activated, there is a very noticeable increase in bass response that will certainly make some people happy.

So, about the sound profile... A set of headphones isn't worth any amount of money if they sound bad. These are fairly balanced phones when the bass booster is turned off. The highs are bright and clear, the midrange is warm and the bass is present but not overwhelming. The bass becomes front and center when the boost is turned on.

These connect via Bluetooth and they pair and establish connection quickly. I have no complaints.

These are good on-ear phones that work well. They're reasonably comfortable, and they connect well. The most interesting feature, to me, is the on-demand bass booster which is better than having a continuous bass boost that's built in. For me, that's a major positive point and is the reason I will continue using these. These sound good.

title: For folks with USB C devices. Reliable file system and decent performance text: I received this as a free review sample. The reason for five stars is the design, which is convenient for folks who own USB Type C devices.

My acid test is to overfill a drive. On a poorly made thumb drive once the file is at capacity the files will become corrupted and are impossible to remove. In essence, the drive is useless. This one passed that test with no problems. I did not test the transfer rate because the only port I had open on my Thinkpad T61 was an ancient USB 1.1. It was slow (as expected), but the transfer was steady and error-free.

If there is a flaw, it's the loop for attaching this to a key ring is too small for one. Not a show stopper for me since I normally do not keep a thumb drive on my key ring, but if you do, this is NOT going to fit (and that I know of.)

This is definitely for folks who are now using USB C. I would have loved it even more had it come with a piggy back adapter on the C side for a USB micro adapter as well. Perhaps the next version will, but since USB C seems to be the coming thing, perhaps my personal wish is not practical in the long term.

title: My trusty sidekick
text: Whenever I need to capture some action footage and i'm worried I may damage my good camera, I use this little guy. You really have to kick it in the arse to get the white balance set. But once it's set, she's a beaut'. Don't recommend it at all for low light. The color reproduction is in par with its price range. Also, don't rely on the audio unless your in an acoustically treated environment. The mic is not true stereo. The manual zoom function (on the lcd screen) gets skiddish on high speed turns. It's still reliable for 720p HD footage and can make your action cut scenes look good when you push the camera to its limits. It'll always be my in the pocket action shooter.

title: Neat low profile mouse, works well! USB thing is a little too snug though... text: I'm using this with the Acer Vero laptop and it works perfectly. The track wheel works pretty well but it's kind of like driving an old truck with very loose-feeling steering. It works, it just spins fairly freely so it feels strange at first. I like it though! The optical on this works well, I'm using my laptop's sleeve as a mouse pad and it works great!

Taking away one star because the usb dongle on this has WAY too tight of a fit! I can't even get it into one of the laptop's usb ports and it's a matching branded Acer Vero laptop, same color and everything! But I put it in a port on the left side and had to nudge it in a bit harder than anything else and it went in. I tested it in various other usb ports around my house and in ALL of them it's a very snug fit and in some, it's hard to push it in. The dongle itself isn't bent or anything so the only thing I can think of is poor design.

Other than the dongle issue, this is one of my favorite wireless mice I've had! It has a low profile and feels very natural in my hand. I would just use the trackpad on the laptop but it doesn't have physical click buttons, you have to push the trackpad down in the corners to click- I really don't like that. So this mouse fixes that for me.

title: Incredibly easy to install and use text: When my review sample arrived I tested it on a few devices and it worked perfectly on each. The first device was my ancient ThinkPad T61 running Windows XP. I inserted the dongle (look in the battery compartment for it), and it was immediately recognized and activated. As soon as I turned on power to the keyboard I was able to navigate using the touchpad, bring up an editor and type.

The next tests were with my [[ASIN:B00JA5DCNS Keedox® Quad Core RK3188 Android 4.2 1080P 5G 2.4G HDMI Bluetooth 4.0 Smart TV BOX]], then using a [[ASIN:B00C7SK2J2 Micro USB OTG Host Cable to USB 2.0]] I connected the dongle to my Galaxy Note 3 phone and Tab 3 10.1 tablet respectively and was texting and performing other functions. This is truly a plug-and-play keyboard/touchpad.

One final thing I love is the battery is a standard BT51 that can be purchased just about anywhere if you are such a power user that you need a spare.

It's set up for thumb style texting, so most folks will be immediately comfortable with it. I love the tactile feedback from the keys, which were a pleasure to type with, as well as the array of function keys and buttons. If you spend a lot of time on smaller devices this is a dream come true. At about thirteen bucks at the time of this review it's a bargain for folks who are heavy texters.

title: Dead simple to setup if you have a compatible router! But decide if you need this... text: I happen to use a D-Link DIR 1360 as my internet router at home, and while it does a decent job broadcasting signal around me, it is located at one corner of our home which means the opposite corner of the house has too many barriers for a fast signal. And if I want to take my laptop out to the porch? No reliability at all!
But with this placed a few rooms over from the router, it has greatly extended my network and the speed of things nearby it. It was super simple to set up, too! I'm not sure if that's just because I happen to have a D-Link router, but all I had to do was press the setup button on the router and extender while plugged in next to it, then once setup I could unplug and move it wherever I wanted to extend to. No app or IT knowledge required! Literally press the button, wait a few minutes for the lights to turn green, and good to go! The access point matches the original name of my router, so it is all completely invisible to the user. The device picks whichever device is closer / stronger and automatically connects to it without any user intervention, much like a cell phone. Now, this is only possible because my router supports this mesh-style setup. Otherwise you'll have to do one of those alternative SSID things where the device sees two networks and has to decide which one to connect to. The first was is preferable obviously, and just works better in addition to being cleaner.

With my laptop in my living room (on the other side of the house from my router), I used to get somewhere between 20-40mbps in my speed tests downloading. That's not terrible, but I'm paying for 300mbps service! But with this plugged in the middle of my home, that jumped to 80-90mbps reliably! Still not the 200+ speeds I get if only a room or two away from the router, but definitely an improvement by almost 2x... and spots outside on the porch that rarely had coverage before now do.

HOWEVER, like any extender, this WILL introduce some lag to your network. This is the part I was warning about in the headline, as most people think extenders will improve your performance across the board, which isn't true. While my download and upload speed improved, my Ping time degraded from 8ms to 14 (lower is better). That extra hop from the extender back to the router has a cost. Now, that difference shouldn't make a huge difference in most things, 14ms is still pretty respectable, however a larger ping lag can effect real-time performance like lag in multiplayer games and video call performance. Arguably, in those cases, a lower ping is more important than higher speeds. So if I'm having trouble with gaming lag or video call echo, I'd probably unplug this and go with the original weaker signal to the router directly. But if I'm going outside, or just streaming Netflix etc, than the download performance is more important than the ping. So, make your decisions wisely... I've seen too many people running multiple zoom devices over lockdown and think a wireless extender is going to solve their problems, but in fact just made everyone's zoom calls worse! But this isn't the fault of the device, that's inherent of how all extenders work. So, I'm still giving this 5 stars for being an excellent instance of what it should be: a way to boost transfer speeds and extend range that's dead simple to set up.

title: Very Well-Made 3.5mm Audio Cable text: I wear headphones daily and I have had difficulties with the cables either failing or getting twisted and kinked. I looked to this cable to help resolve those issues. So far, it has definitely exceeded my expectations and has worked much better than I expected. Though it’s “just a cable” there is a good bit that can be said for it.

This is a 4' stereo audio cable with 3.5mm plugs on either end. Even while still in the package it’s clear that this cable is a bit more substantial and rugged compared to most other audio cables available. It is a heavy-gauge cable with woven nylon casing that is actually very difficult to twist though I suspect if one tried hard enough to kink the cable it could be done. The jacks are gold-plated and rather than just molded plastic they have a metal cap that screws down to make the jack much more sturdy and give it a much more sophisticated look. This is not a run-of-the-mill plastic-coated audio cable with cheap jacks on the end but rather it is a quality cable that’s worth buying.

I replaced the cable on a pair of headphones with this one and plugged into a music player and noticed no difference in the sound quality. The primary difference between this cable and the one it replaced is an integrated microphone on the cable which is not something I need anyway.

I am happy with this cable and am pleased to recommend it. It is very well made and it works well. It is a little more expensive than other audio cables available but you get what you pay for with this cable.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

title: Well designed and pro-level construction and features for transforming an iPhone 6 into a camera text: I received this as a free review sample. When I accepted this for testing and review I was a little skeptical. However, this has turned out to be a high-quality kit that will transform an iPhone 6 or 6s into a decent hand held camera, yet it will not interfere with other iPhone functions. With the case and attachments in place you can still make and receive calls, text, browse the web, etc.

This is actually the foundation for a more sophisticated set of lenses that will accept add-on lenses like the [[ASIN:B018TQUEYI 010 | bitplay Portable Add-on 3X Telephoto Glass Lens Compatible]]. As you can see from the product description this kit already comes with a basic wide angle/telephoto lens combination. It is not plastic junk, but a serious lens with a precision metal body that screws into this case. It has two parts - one lens screws into the other for combined or separate effects - and it is as good in quality and construction as the lenses that I used with a vintage Nikon SLR.

The case itself can be quickly removed to reconfigure your phone back into a ... phone. But while it is in camera configuration mode it feels just like a hand-held with a choice of grips, an integrated tripod adapter and even a leather strap. The case does not interfere with any phone function, and especially the iPhone's camera and flash. More importantly - for me - the case offers excellent protection. The lip that is slightly raised about the iPhone's screen is curved inward and adds protection for that critical area. The body of the case and two of the grips are textured so you can maintain a firm hold on the phone while shooting, even if your hands are wet.

Bottom line: this is not a gimmick or novelty - it is designed for folks who take photography seriously. I could not find a single flaw in the design from a photographer's perspective; nor could I find any faults from a build or design perspective. This is obviously not for casual users, but if photography is your passion and you own an iPhone 6 or 6s, this case merits serious consideration.

title: Great sunglasses; okay smartglasses. text: As sunglasses, they are phenomenal. They even fit my slightly narrow face. I own a pair of Gascans that I've had for almost eight years and they are my favorite pair of sunnies. Wanted something now that I'm starting to run more and the sun can sometimes cause a harsh glare.
So nice sunglasses with the ability to track my exercises? Sure; why not.

As sunglasses they fit a bit loose on my head, but with the same material that I used on my Gascans I was able to make them tighter by fitting some foam on the hinges; this way they wouldn't (and didn't) loosen while running.
They fit great and are an excellent addition to my running routine. The sun isn't as vibrant as of this writing, but I will continue to use these throughout the winter as the sun's glare on the snow will be an issue.

I tried these on without the smart devices enabled at first to get an idea as to how the sunglasses were by themselves. The box comes with all the electronics apart from the glasses, and the glasses come in a nice semi-hard shell with the additional lens inside. I then equipped everything in one bout.

The earphones fit okay, but they did tend to slide out at times during the few times I've used this so far while running. No issue in terms of when I'm in the gym, however. Syncing from my phone has never been an issue, though I hate carrying it with me.

As smartglasses, they're okay; nothing revolutionary, and it's up to you if you want to pay the premium price for something your phone already can do, provided you take it with you. As the coach doesn't do as much as I'd like as of this writing, as I already have most of my workouts set. I suppose it may not be entirely geared for me as the only exercise I do outdoors is running; the rest is all in the gym.

The music does tend to cut in and out, and I wound up just shutting it off completely after a while. I may look into more comfortable replacements, too.

As sunglasses, these are phenomenal. The perfect sunnies for triathlons, methinks (when they're not wet). But as for smartglasses, a novel idea but needs improvement.

The USB type C port did a great job delivering power to devices that support rapid QC charging, however when I plugged a second cable into the USB A port, the second phone did not use Quick Charge. title: A Great and Necessary Cover text: Since I wanted to protect my investment in a Kindle Touch, I ordered this cover. I am glad I did. It fits my Kindle Touch perfectly. The four corner straps secure it to the cover, and there is an elastic strap at the lower end that fits around the entire case, making the Kindle impervious to attack by foreign objects in your bag, backpack, what-have-you.

I agree with others who have said the cover is a bit pricey, but if you love your Kindle Touch as much as I love mine, you will want to protect it for many years to come with this sturdy jacket.

When I purchased the cover, I wondered if the flip design would get in my way. Not to worry. I find myself so focused on what I am reading that I don't even think about it being there.

Do not expect to stand the cover up with the Kindle in it. Despite the rubber strips on each end, the cover will slide. Not good.

All things said, I recommend this cover. The first (and I hope last) time your Kindle slips out of your hand, you will be glad you have a modicum of protection if the cover is open, and a lot of protection when it is closed and secured.

title: Must have for anyone smoking - best bang for the buck!! text: Awesome little product! I have an expensive smoker but I still use one or two of these smoker tubes. I have the 12" for quick cooks - 2 hours or less and the 18" for 6 hours or less. I use both when I want real extreme smoking! The trick is to fill the smoker tube with pellets and use a little torch with map gas to light the pellets, wait at least 5 minutes and blow out the flame and set in the smoker or barbeque. Remember to set the tube on some aluminum foil because the ashes will fall through the grates and make a mess. Note: if you light both ends of the tube, you get double the smoke but half of the time before it goes out. I have bought several of these for gifts for friends with smokers and they all say great things about this product.

Update: I have a RecTec smoker and I use their wood pellets because the burn so clean as compared to my old Traeger with Traiger pellets. I tried using the RecTec pellets in my smoke tube this past weekend and I didn't get as large of volume of smoke but they burned a lot longer than the Traeger pellets. I switched back to the cheaper Traeger pellets for my smoke tube because I like the larger volume of smoke and because I set the smoke tube on some aluminum foil, I don't get all of the ash in my smoker.

text: At first, I was disappointed in this camera because it didn't come with any software, but I quickly discovered that I don't need any.  First of all, Windows 10 comes with a camera application that this works good with.  Then I did a Facebook phone call with my sister, using the camera and it performed flawlessly.  The camera can either attach to the top of a computer screen or there is a nice tripod that comes with it that works well.  Just plug the camera into a USB port and you are ready to go.  Night lighting features for darker areas.  Bright white light that can be dimmed, a yellow softer light that can also be dimmed or if there is enough light, you don't need the light feature.  Even the USB cord was nice and long, so you can position it some distance from the computer.  I have no criticism of the camera at all, but the manual is in very tiny type, so a little hard to read for my old eyes.  Also, I could not figure out how to register the warranty.  They give you a card with a QR code to do the registration, but the QR code takes you to a Facebook Messenger page with a message that says: "Get started" and nothing else.  Very easy to use and no setup required.

title: Sturdy metal build, good read/write speeds and very versatile. text: This 5-in-1 card reader is exactly what I needed. It is fast, well-built, and connects to everything that I own.

Being USB type-c, this card reader will read and write to your microsd or SD card at the maximum speed that it is capable of. I found that the speed is in line with my previous reader as well as my laptop's built-in reader.

This reader has connectivity for Type-A, Micro-usb type-b, and USB type-c. It means that I can use this reader for my phones, including any older models that support USB host-mode and all of my PC's, including my Dell XPS that only has type-c ports.

Connected to the phone, I can back up my pixel phone, without having to upload all of the pictures to the cloud. Connected to my computer, I can quickly transfer files to and from my mirrorless camera.

This product does exactly what I need it to do and with its metal build and protective caps, this will be a product that I will carry in my tech bag.

title: Seems to Work Well; Bad Documentation text: I have been interested in a device that can find hidden cameras for a while as we do tend to travel periodically. This device seemed like a good one and I wanted to try it out before I travel again. It seems like a pretty neat device that works fairly well, but it is hamstrung by very poor documentation.

This does more than just find hidden cameras. It is able to pick up Wi-fi signals, wireless phone signals and more. The sensitivity is very much like working with a metal detector - turn it up too high and it becomes nothing more than a sight and sound show; turned too low and it hardly sees anything.

With the unit turned on and set to a reasonable initial detection level I set about looking for devices in my home office. I have several Wi-fi connected devices and I usually have my smartphone there too, and I messed with this detector until I found the level where it was able to find everything. I did not try going near the router which is in another room but I imagine that one would require another sensitivity adjustment.

Most of the functions are self-explanatory, but some took a little trial and error to figure out. This is where good documentation would come in handy, and unfortunately the documentation with this device is poor. It's sufficient to identify the different functions of the device and where to find different components, but the actual descriptions and explanations of the functions are written in very poorly translated English.

Aside from the documentation, it would have been nice to have a carrying case for this device for storage and travel. That's a minor gripe, though.

I am happy with this device, though better documentation would make it much easier to use right away. It has some useful functions that will appeal to wary travelers, and it seems to work well once you figure out the right adjustments.

title: Reliable personal tracker text: The ability to track all daily activities with one device is very convenient and beneficial. Great for tracking daily calorie intake & caloric burn, water consumption, various exercise activities, sleep and other valuable metrics.

title: The best low-priced led projector I've tried thus far. text: [[VIDEOID:6e49ad5f11d43ea1130e7014d1f00ce9]] I've always been interested in video projectors because I really wanted that theater experience at home. Previously, they have been out of reach because of the price of the devices as well as the price of the bulbs that required replacement.

In the last few years, LED projectors have really come down in price. When it became attainable for me, I started to try out various models and in the last two years, the prices have dropped to the $100-$200 range, even for native 1080p projectors.

As I've said, I have tried out various models and had problems with most of them, problems ranging from not being bright enough, 720p native, unable to fully focus the corners, or even that it needed to be very far from the screen to project a big picture.

The Vimgo Smart Projector is a stylish little projector that has a nice, vertical design that takes up less space than a normal projector. It has a good-sized speaker behind the cloth-covered side panels. The sound isn't high fidelity, but it can get pretty loud. Many other projectors barely comes with a 10w speaker or worse.

It is rated at 300 ANSI Lumen, which isn't going to work well in direct light but quite adequate when the lights are turned down. There are no dark corners and I find the picture to be evenly lit. The keystone functionality is great. You can adjust the "tilt" up and down as well as left and right. You can also zoom the picture out and if all else fails, each corner can be adjusted individually.

I really like that there is a motor that performs the focusing. With manual focus, I often get up and focus the projector, just to get back to my seat and figure out that the focus wasn't that great. With the focus controllable from the remote, I can sit close enough to really see if I got it just right.

The Android system works well for plex and jellyfin, which I have installed. Unfortunately, Netflix and Amazon Prime Video has DRM that prevents them from running on this projector, but that is easily remedied by projecting from your phone or with a FireTV connected to the HDMI (the USB port outputs enough amps to power the FireTV).

Here's a tip: Install the Android TV Launcher by downloading the APK file to a USB drive, then choose the USB app from the projector to install it. It is not only a better-looking launcher, it will also give you access to the full Android system settings. I wouldn't suggest setting it as the default launcher, though because I haven't found a way to launch the built-in launcher manually.

I also found that the Vimgo projector actually has a shorter throw distance than my previous projectors. I'm able to get a larger picture when set up at the same distance as my previous projectors. I actually had to zoom out to make the picture a little smaller to fit my projection screen.

So to conclude, the Vimgo projector does not have any of the problems that I found in my previous projectors. It is stylish and compact with a great picture and good-enough audio (for small gatherings, not for a home theater experience).

title: ABSURD PRIVACY AGREEMENT GIVES VICOO ALL RIGHTS TO YOUR RECORDINGS text: I have been working with security camera products for over 20 years - over that time I have installed systems for businesses, corporations and individuals - from enormous multimillion dollar systems to single camera nursery monitors. I’ve consulted on large projects and written about security vulnerabilities within networks for trade publications.

This is a field I know well. Over the years the technology has improved and become less and less expensive to produce. It is now practical to install security systems that would have only previously been used in commercial settings in residential.

As with all security systems my advice is never use cloud based recording - this opens your entire network to not only the company who you are giving blanket access too but also to hackers. The same is true for WiFi. Obviously WiFi is more convenient but if your privacy is a concern this really needs to be taken into account. Hackers have become quite adept at hacking into WiFi cameras and being able to not only watch your feed but control your cameras and access your entire network. If you choose to utilize WiFi cameras take the time to understand your router and employ proper VPN protocols.

In terms of this particular wireless WiFi camera by MYPIN it can accept up to a 128GB TF card. While this would provide plenty of space to record if only set to motion unless you subscribe it will only save the previous 7 days worth of data. This is ludicrous - this is the company manipulating users into having to subscribe.

The app “Vicoo” has the most absurd privacy terms you will see on any security camera app. To be clear, I tested this with a phone I do not use on a network I temporarily set up for only testing this and after testing I completely wiped the phone and removed the network.

To summarize the privacy terms YOU MUST AGREE TOO (the fine print most people skip to the bottom of and hit Agree) you MUST give this company COMPLETE ACESS TO ALL OF YOUR VIDEO CONTENT.

Here is the fine print for you to read:

“with respect to Content (including all related intellectual property rights) you submit or make available for the Vicoo Services, you grant Vicoo the following worldwide, royalty-free, nonexclusive, perpetual, irrevocable, sublicensable and transferable license(s), as applicable: the license to use, distribute, reproduce, modify, adapt, make derivative works of, publicly perform and publicly display such Content on the Vicoo Services solely in connection with providing you the Vicoo Services, as permitted through the functionality of the Vicoo Services and under these Terms. You grant Vicoo the right to maintain a copy of the Content (including all related intellectual property rights) for archival and legal purposes. You also hereby do and shall grant each user of the Vicoo Services a non-exclusive license to access and use your Content through the Vicoo Services, as solely permitted through the functionality of the Vicoo Services and directed by you and under these Terms.”

If this doesn’t give you enough of a reason to not purchase this product or anything that uses this app read on...

If you want to use any of the primary features of the app, AI, alerts, etc YOU MUST SUBSCRIBE.

In my tests battery life was subpar with similar cameras although video quality was adequate. Due to the nature of the security issues with the app I was unwilling to leave it hooked up long enough to do my full battery of tests which require over a month of use.

The app is not dependable nor is it user friendly. They force users into signing a completely unreasonable privacy agreement which forfeits any privacy you have - they own your footage and can distribute it HOWEVER THEY WISH. Beyond this ridiculous agreement the company forces users into using their paid services in order to use any of the semi advanced features.

I CAN NOT RECOMMEND ENOUGH THAT PEOPLE AVOID THIS PRODUCT AND ANY OTHER THAT USES THE VICOO APP. ALWAYS READ THE PRIVACY AGREEMENT PRIOR TO INSTALLATION - KEEP IN MIND WHAT YOU ARE ALLOWING OUTSIDERS ACCESS TOO.

title: Great power bank
text: I’ve owned this power bank for 2 years and it has been an exceptional and reliable source of power. I use it about once a month for a week at a time when I go RV camping to power my laptop. On its own, the laptop’s battery would only last at most 2 hours. But with the laptop plugged into the power bank, after I’ve used my laptop for 2-3 hours, the power bank charge has only dropped from 100% to as low as 77%--that extrapolates to 8-13 hours which is way more than I would usually need. So I no longer have to worry about my laptop running out of power. When I’m done, I plug the power bank into my RV’s 12V outlet and it recharges back to 100% in about 4-8 hours depending on how low its charge is. Between my monthly camping trips, when the power bank sits idle, it maintains its full charge without my having to recharge it.

title: Good IP Camera with a Couple of Minor Quirks text: An IP camera is an inexpensive and straightforward way to add a little extra security to your property, whether it is watching a door, monitoring a hallway or even just keeping an eye on the dog while you’re at work for the day. This is one such camera by Foscam, and it seems to work fairly well in my testing. There are a couple of minor issues I have seen, though nothing that I would consider a showstopper.

This is a small and lightweight camera, about the side of a baseball, and it is hinged such that it can be angled in a range of about 300 degrees of coverage if it is placed properly though in practical use (meaning, when it is placed on a wall and anchored to it) it is likely to be positioned more like 70-90 degrees. It also rotates on the base, so it can be configured to point to just about any target from where it is anchored.

The base itself is detachable and the whole camera can be popped off the base with no tools. To me this represents a concern. It means that someone can simply take the camera from the mounting place if it is low enough, using no tools. I like being able to rotate the camera on the base but I also like knowing the camera is not going to get taken easily.

Setup of this camera is very easy and I was able to get it connected to my network without too much effort. That said, I struggled a little bit with the Foscam software and it took me a little while to get the software talking to the camera. I have had this trouble with another Foscam camera, and the problem seems to be the software - very specifically the IP Camera Search Tool utility - and not the hardware or the network. I was able to find the camera in the monitoring client.

Once the camera is connected and available it can be logged into directly. There, the user has some control over a multitude of settings including firmware updates, login credentials and more. I like the interface even though it is somewhat basic as it is easy to navigate and is completely accessible from a web browser.

The monitoring client software allows for more control, which includes concentrating on a single camera if there are more than one connected, scheduling, playback and more. In addition to the software that runs on a computer, users can connect to it via smartphone if they have an iPhone or an Android. Windows phone users are unfortunately out of luck.

The camera resolution is very good and is detailed with fairly accurate colors. This certainly is not the same as a camcorder, of course, but it is sufficient to recognize faces even at a fair distance. The night vision (infrared) is excellent and is sufficient that I was able to read a sheet of instructions that was held in front of the camera.

I do not like the LEDs on the camera, though... It is very hard to place the camera inconspicuously and have it remain unseen in the dark when it lights up with a ring of LED lights. This is the one major issue I have with this camera that I think needs improvement. It’s not a complete deal-breaker, but consider the possibilities when an intruder sees the camera and knows he or she is being recorded. These can be turned off in the settings and I highly encourage doing so.

The camera has a micro SD slot near the hinge where storage can be inserted. It is unfortunate that there are no cards in the box though this is a minor gripe. I used an 8GB card for testing and the camera was able to record to it without trouble and I was able to control this from the monitoring client.

This is a decent little IR-capable security camera. So far I am pleased with it, though there are some minor quirks. It’s a relatively inexpensive camera and is an easy way to monitor areas of your house and record what is going on when you can’t be there.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

title: Design is more than just looks text: As 'cool' as the cloth covered outer jacket is, this retro look on this cable has a real purpose. Most cables use PVC for the jacket and the dielectric properties will cause some signal distortion when they go through their store/discharge cycle. Granted, the amount of charge a PVC jacket will store and eventually discharge is minute and also will not affect charging. However, many of us use our cables to sync to laptops and other devices and with the cloth jacket this effect is so minimized as to be nominal.

There are other reasons why I awarded the review sample I received five stars. At the top of the list is this cable not only supports charging my Note 3, but also is flawless when it comes to synching it. Not all cables I own will synch (sounds incredible, but unfortunately true), This one will and my guess why it's done so without errors so far is the gold plated connector that do aid in conductivity. Another reason for the five stars is the heavy duty housing for the connectors and how they manage to be both thin enough to be unobtrusive and substantial enough to assure a long service life. There are even strain reliefs on each end of the cable to minimize wear that can eventually cause diminished transmission at the weak points in any USB cable.

Finally, the ends mate perfectly with every device with which I've tried them. I have only tested the micro USB end on my Note 3, but have tested the USB A end on my laptop, various chargers and battery backups and the fits on all are precise.

title: Already Enjoying This! text: I thought long and hard about a tablet, knowing that for me it would basically be a toy. Plus I already had a Nook Color. When the iPad2 reduced in price, I thought about getting one of those, but decided against it for the following reasons: (1) no Flash--and yes, I know HTML5 is going to make that obsolete, but in the meantime many websites have a lot of money invested in Flash animation and even restaurants use the silly format to show you their menus (geez, just give us a LIST already--I don't need pretty pictures to find out if you serve something I can eat) and (2) I'm already invested in the Android market and would have to buy many iPad apps that I already have free from Android.

I have not even used it for a week yet, but this a preliminary review with some information I saw requested in other reviews (not necessarily here at Amazon).

UPS delivered this a little before 6:30 p.m. I immediately plugged it into the charger and left it alone. It was charged by 10 p.m. (it might have been earlier, but the unit was away from me and I heard no bleep or flash that might have have indicated the charge was finished). So it does not take six or eight or ten hours to charge as I have seen claimed on other sites. By midnight I was attached to wireless, had gotten into all my accounts and Android apps and was happily surfing and rearranging my home screen.

I used this over the weekend at a science fiction convention. I did not use it constantly, but turned the screen on and off all day for about a 12-hour period, reading Facebook and blogs, checking the news and weather, looking at the convention schedule online, playing short You Tube videos, etc. Nothing excessive, but sometimes did have it on for a half hour to 45-minutes at the time. I also do not have a lot of widgets going, like the Accu-Weather and news widgets that come pre-loaded on the home screen. (They delete easily.) In that 12-hour period it never got below 78% on the battery. It's very quick and fast and responds to a Targus stylus (rubber tipped) wonderfully, much better than my Nook color. The resolution of the screen is impressive. Maybe it's not the new iPad's "retinal display," but it's very, very sharp and bright, even though I keep my brightness turned down to save power. I downloaded the Nook app and the magazines I subscribe to look gorgeous and are simple to read; if not, a tap of the screen makes the text bigger. The unit also comes with Zinio preloaded, an app I plan to use to subscribe to non-US magazines. Kindle books look nice as well, but to me this is too large for marathon reading sessions. I prefer my Nook Color for that. Like my Android phone and my Nook Color, it connects to wireless like a dream, which is more than I can say for my laptop.

Things that might lead you to choose another tablet: (1) The camera is nothing special. It takes good close ups, but further away was problematic. However, I was in a low-light situation each time. Taking photos outside may be totally different. Why Samsung chose to remove the flash I have no idea. Silly, really. But who buys a tablet to take pictures with? (2) With a stylus I can tap to enlarge an image (like Google Maps), but not make it smaller and there is no plus or minus sign on the screen as on my Android phone. (3) Blogger doesn't work in the browser; you have to download the Blogger app, but that works well. iExit doesn't work on it, either. Rats. (4) As at least one other person mentioned, the screen cap button is right in a place where you can hit it easily. I thought of a good use for it this weekend (took a screen cap of the online schedule for the convention I was at, made a short-cut of it to the screen, then pulled up the screen cap for reference rather than going to the web page all the time). Very convenient! (5) Hate the pre-loaded websites in the browser, but I have seen this on other tablets. Apparently we the public are stupid (or lazy) and can't find our own favorite websites and bookmark them. [eyes roll], and (6) my Bluetooth keyboard won't work with it right now because there is as yet no driver for Android 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich).

I hope to check back with further comments.

[A few weeks later after I bought this, my husband found an Asus Transformer (TF300) at a good price. It appears to be just as good as this Samsung and the camera is better. It has a zoom and does take a better photo. So if you were looking for a tablet with a better camera the Asus Transformer may be for you. Note: It doesn't have a flash either.]

[Update July 31, 2012 to answer "How long does the battery last"?: I was sick and tired of not seeing any Olympic equestrian coverage except for a couple of hours in the wee hours of the morning, so downloaded the "Live Extra" Olympics app from the Android Market. This carries live streaming of events as well as archived events. This morning I watched about two hours of live streaming of the jumping finals. When that ended I watched six hours of cross-country eventing replay. Then about an hour and forty minutes of the replay of the jumping. I had my brightness at about 35%. This got me down to 10% of the battery from a full charge. Quite satisfactory.]
