title: Minor complaints, but generally a decent buy
text: I’m not a DIY kind of guy, so I went with the cheapest, simplest mount I could find. It’s okay, but be prepared for some minor adjustments. The Pros: price. It’s much less expensive than most of the others. It’s also quite minimalist - no thick bezels. It’s made of a flexible silicone material - that’s both a pro and a con - the pro - it’s soft on your tablet - no scratches. It’s also somewhat flexible - I installed mine vertically in a tight space and there’s no room to slide the tablet in from the side. Instead, I have to seat it in the bottom mount and sort of snap it into place in the top. Given the flexibility of the material, this works fine. The cons: included with the mount are 6 each screws and wall anchors - no spares and no washers. The anchors don’t have any lip on the end so a couple of mine dropped into the wall cavity, making it necessary to go buy some spares. Also, the screw heads easily pull through the holes in the mounts when tightened. I fixed that with a handful of small washers which should be included with the mount kit. Also, my tablet (an old iPad Air 2) Is quite slim and doesn’t fit snugly in the mount so I put a short strip of thin silicone insulation behind it to better hold it in place. There is a slot in the center of one mount to allow access For a charging cable. Thoughtfully, it appears to be even wide enough for the old style wide Apple connector. Included is also a paper template for various size devices and a stick on cable retainer. Aside from the minor complaints about washers and wall mounts, I’m satisfied with the kit.

title: Very Good Mid-Range Wireless Router text: I recently purchased one of these routers as a replacement for my Linksys WRT54GL, a stalwart in the realm of home networking. My Linksys router is healthy and it works but it does not allow me to set up DHCP reservations without a 3rd party firmware update, and it does not support Wireless-N. After searching for a good balance between functionality, quality and price I settled on this router by NetGear. So far I am very pleased with this unit, though I had some minor issues when setting it up.

Setup of NetGear routers (including this one) is simple and easy. There are two methods of setting it up, using the Wizard CD or going in manually. For users not too familiar with setting up wireless networks or routers, using the CD to get started is a good option. More seasoned users may prefer to work without the CD and work directly with the router. I chose the latter of the two. Even so, tapping in and finding any given setting is relatively easy, everything broken down into several pages. Because the router configuration is accessed through a browser, manipulating the router configuration is very much like accessing a web page and should feel familiar.

The factory-default username, password, and access address are printed right on the router itself so there is no risk of losing this information at any point.

I connected 3 laptops, one at a time, to the wireless network and encountered my only difficulty with moving to this router. Because I retained the network name and key I expected the swap to be seamless and mostly invisible, but my systems each complained when tried to connect, stating that the network configuration had changed even though I retained the settings, the type, key and everything else. To get each system working I had to delete the connection completely, then I allowed each to redetect wireless networks available. Two of them came up without any further incident, but one of the laptops required a reboot before it would properly connect.

Signal strength is important when it comes to wireless networks. My Linksys router gives me very strong signal strength, and I was fearful that this new NetGear router would lack the same power to broadcast. Happily, it broadcasts brightly enough that I have had no problems with connectivity due to losing signals. It is *at least* on par but seems to be stronger. My router lives on the second story of the house, while my personal laptop is in the basement.

As soon as the router was configured and provided a connection to the internet, I logged in ang got a surprise - it is configured by factory default to look for firmware updates every time I log in. This is fine as logging into the router becomes an infrequent activity after a while, though up front it can be annoying to have to wait for it to download and then update itself.

I have had no connectivity issues or drops since setting this router up.

The DHCP reservation and MAC filtering work well, which are the two advanced features about which I care most.

Something I have not seen in any other router up to this point is a USB port. According to the documentation, the router can be set up to provide persistent storage through the network by simply connecting a USB hard drive (or even a thumb drive) to it. I have not tried this but I absolutely plan to put this to work, which will make sharing files between the different computers simple without having to make several copies. It should be noted, though, that this could be a risky practice if using to access the same file frequently from multiple points.

Looking through the options that can be set up, I found a keyword-based page filter, QoS settings and a lot of other features I have not previously seen. For a mid-range wireless router this one has a generous set of features. Of course, the standard features are there - firewall, MAC filtering as mentioned above, different encryption key types and a lot more too.

This is a very nice router with a nice feature set. It is very easy to set up, easy to configure once it's running, and so far has proven to be stable. If you need more than a basic wireless router, consider this one as a good candidate.

===

UPDATE 12-01-2011: It has been over a year and a half and I still have not had any trouble with this router. I have seen some of the negative reviews and detailed reports of issues but I have not encountered any problems up to this point. It has been stable and reliable for me. I have noticed that the surface gets a little warm; I suspect if I kept it in an enclosed area that it could potentially be less cooperative but there's no reason for me to move it as such.

title: Does Not Retain DPI Setting Reliably; Slightly Smaller Than Average text: I selected this mouse to be a spare for when I am on the go. Amazon-branded things are often of good quality so I was hopeful for this mouse. I came away a bit disappointed due to a couple of issues I have had with it.

This is a basic wireless mouse, suitable for surfing the web, working on documents or similar tasks. It’s not particularly good for gaming as it is not designed for such. If the goal is to have something that will allow you to casually use the computer for basic tasks, this one will serve. If you need a heavy-duty mouse for frequent use or you need a gaming mouse, spend a little more and get a more solid mouse.

One of the issues I have with mice is that I have huge hands and finding a mouse that fits my hand properly is a challenge. This is a smaller than average mouse, so it really doesn’t work for me. That’s not a big deal; it was designed for the large majority of people with smaller hands, so I can’t criticize this mouse for its size. It’s in that weird in-between size - smaller than the average desktop mouse but larger than a travel mouse.

The real issue I have seen with this mouse, though, is with the DPI setting. After idling for a little while, the mouse has a very nasty and predictable habit of resetting the DPI mode automatically. This is the only mouse I have used that has exhibited the problem. This impacts me when I am doing photo editing or using a graphics program and I need fine control. Sure, I can hit the DPI setting and get it to where I need it to be easily enough, but I should not have to do this over and over, particularly when I need the same setting all the time.

Other than the DPI setting, this mouse works exactly as expected. It is a decent mouse if you do not need predictable DPI settings. If you need a mouse that retains your settings, or if you need a larger mouse, or if you need a heavy-duty device, this is not the right choice for you. It’s fine for travel or casual use.

title: Fits my iPad Pro 9.7 (A1674) perfectly ... text: An attractive case -- I tested the Rose Gold version -- nicely made with no obvious flaws. I've been trying various types of external keyboards as I like to use my iPad on trips and blog as I go. Having a full keyboard makes life a lot easier.

This is the first integrated case/keyboard I've tried, and so far, I like it. It's easy to set up -- charge it (a cable is provided), pop in the iPad, turn on, pair, and you're set to go.

The backlight is fully adjustable - brightness as well as color. That's a nice touch. Battery life seems to be excellent -- I've used it 2-3 hours every day for the past 10 days, and it's still going strong and it still hasn't indicated I need to recharge it. The keyboard size is a bit smaller than my MacBook Air laptop, but after a few minutes, I got used to the slightly tighter quarters and had no issues at all. Getting it into the case is easy; getting it out of the case takes a little more effort. When I take it along on my trips, I'll leave it in the case for the duration.

My only complaint is that it's quite heavy but given the battery capacity, that's probably not too surprising. So the trade-off is a slightly heavier case with LONG battery life, or a keyboard-only solution with much shorter battery life. I think in the end, I'll appreciate the longer battery life and fully integrated case/keyboard.

I'll continue to use this over the next few months, and plan to take it on my next couple of trips. If all goes well, it will come along on a 131-day world cruise early next year.

title: Love this case - exactly what I wanted. text: This case is exactly what I wanted: extremely durable shock-absorbing (read: drop-proof) protection without screen protection. Let me qualify that statement: I did *not* want screen protection. I love the pearl eink display on my graphite Kindle Keyboard, and it now has a big brother. I do not want a screen cover, as this would greatly reduce the screen's otherwise remarkable clarity, adding unwanted elements such as bubbles, surface scratches, and glare to the mix--no thank you. There is a reason I disliked reading on the iPad so much I gave it back (very reflective!). In fact, this OtterBox defender case came with a stick-on screen protector--no way. It would ruin that big, glorious pearl eink display.

A screen cover serves no purpose once you remove the device from your backpack/messenger/tote/briefcase for use. Assuming you transport your Kindle device safely in an appropriate sleeve (you put your other expensive electronic equipment--your laptop/tablet in one; your Kindle deserves the same amount of respect), the screen protector is completely unnecessary--the sleeve protects the screen during travel. THAT is when the screen needs protecting--when you are not using it, from the other goodies in your messenger bag/backpack (keys, pens, earbuds, and anything else rattling around in there). Yes, that's right--I'm talking about a Kindle in an Otterbox Inside a sleeve inside your briefcase. ...Inception-level protection. You got it. Better safe than sorry, right? What if they once again stop producing our beloved Kindle DX and something happens to yours? I do not want to have to replace my DX--especially if it has to be with a Fire device (5% the battery life, reflective, heavy, expensive--no thanks!). When you are holding your Kindle in your hand, reading, a screen cover only detracts from the experience.

What you see in my pictures is exactly what you get: a beefy, black rubber (not silicone--too easily torn; rubber is much stronger) form-fitting sleeve with an equally form-fitting outer plastic shell. Science geeks like me understand how this works, and just in case you are not one, here is the idea: if you drop your device onto the floor, the outer shell absorbs some of the impact energy generated by the device hitting the floor. It then disburses the remaining energy of the impact broadly into the rubber inner lining. The rubber lining then in turn disburses the now greatly-reduced impact energy into the device. In other words, by the time the force of the impact is filtered through two layers of protection, the second of which is very absorbent and resilient (rubber) the device inside absorbs little if anything of the original impact.

I feel very good about having my Kindle DX in an Otterbox Commuter. If I ever had one of those incredibly poorly-designed (read: seriously fragile) apple devices, such as an iPad or iPhone (which I do not, and am not ever likely to), it too would live in an OtterBox Commuter case. OtterBox = the best protection a device can get. I paid $18 including shipping for this. A great price, and worth much more in terms of peace of mind.

title: Nice feel in the hand, love the LED colors, but needs better directions for adjusting settings text: You cannot deny the great design in this mouse.
While my daughter thought it had a Star Wars feel, I just look at it as a circuit board design.
The LED colors cycle through several shades and looks nice. I thought it might bother me and be distracting
as I worked, seeing it out of my peripheral vision. However, it is mostly hidden by my hand anyway.

There are precious few directions included with the mouse, and what is included seems to be a loose translation from someone
who learned English on the internet. I have no idea how to set the side buttons or adjust the speed. My computer did recognize
it simply by plugging it in, but there were no driver updates or other information. I'd like to know how to adjust the DPI house settings, which are not an option in my control panel for mice.

The mouse is comfy for my hand - I like larger mice so my fingers don't cramp up - I am online for many hours a day.
This helps. I don't ever use the wheel, so won't comment on the wheel function.

Cons: This is something that definitely needs to be adjusted in the next "incarnation" of this mouse....
The bottom has very slightly raised areas on the bottom. The reason behind this isn't very clear, unless it covers up something
on the inside. However, as I mouse back and forth, these raised areas are not smooth, and they catch on my Belkin gel mouse pad.
I really don't like that at all. I am going to use it for a while longer before I decide whether to keep it or go back to my old mouse though.
(A Logitec that has served me well for many years.)

Not impressive in function, but the design is awesome. Overall, it is an okay mouse.
My daughter loved the design so much she had to buy one as well.

title: external hard drive
text: I purchased this to save my recorded programs/movies from my Dishnet Hopper 3.  Worked great.  I wasn't clear if it came with a usb or not, so I purchased one... DON'T.... It comes with one that works perfectly.  I keep it hooked up to the hopper, so the nice short cord is useful... (about 1 ft).  If you need a longer one, then perhaps you'll want to purchase one - but not necessary otherwise.  It was super easy - plugged it in, a box came up on my TV that asked if I wanted to update and format - I clicked yes and that was it.  It was ready for transfer of saved material. The drive itself is approx 5:x4"x 3/4".  It is black and has a little flashing light when it's being used.  I had things sorted on my Hopper in "files".  So far, I cannot figure out how to make folders on the hard drive, so everything is just mixed on the hard drive - that means looking thru about 200 titles - Eh - but the point of the hard drive for us is to save the content if we have to replace the Hopper at some point.  It is easy to move the files back and forth.. And you can play the movies from the hard drive.  It did take quite a while to transfer, we had about 50% of our Hopper memory - a number of hours.  But no biggee to me.  So far, I am happy with my purchase, however, time will tell.  Having said that, I never hesitate to update my reviews should new info seem useful.

title: Not top of the line, but excellent value! text: This is a great CHEAP sata solid state drive. I want to emphasize that this is CHEAP- it is not going to be a speed demon, and it's not large enough to be a main storage drive to house mission-critical data. But it seems to deliver consistently over 400mbps in benchmark tests, which is more than enough to get the benefits of it over a mechanical drive in a SATA setup.
I can't vouch for the longevity of a brand I've never heard of, but again... the value here is the insanely low price of entry. That makes it great for refurbishing an old laptop or perhaps turning older hardware into a chrome book or a closet file server at home. I like to use it in HDMI recording devices such as an Atmos Ninja, as I can edit footage directly off the drive (it's fast enough!) when plugged into my computer, and it's nice to have a backup from my camera's SD card slot when recording events. If the drive dies one day, nothing major will have been lost. For what it is, so far I am impressed, just have realistic expectations for what you can use it for. I probably would not use this for my main computer C drive if only because it is a laughably small amount of storage. But as a fast SSD that uses legacy SATA connections, it definitely has uses!

title: Good heavy duty zip ties!
text: These are good heavy duty zip ties! They are industrial strength and work perfect on securing my outdoor Halloween decorations. They are easy to use and extra strong. I love them!

title: Can take a thrashing!

Paired easily via bluetooth with iphone 7plus. So far, these have been very comfortable to wear and stay in my ears while I'm working. I ordered specifically because of the diamond coating. I work in an environment that has dust and particles flying around all the time and wanted something slightly more durable. Can take them out and put in pocket too without worries that they'll get tangled and thrashed. Well done, Anker.

title: Everything I wanted in a dash cam text: I've been wanting a dash cam for a long time but always put off buying one. This dash cam is excellent. It is super easy to set up in your car and just works. The largest time it took me for setup was to figure out where I wanted it on my windshield.

The video quality is good and I like that it also records audio inside of my car.

I had issues using the app with this camera. The app keeps losing connection to the camera and I'm not able to update the firmware with it. Luckily, there is a cable to connect it to your computer so you can update the firmware there.

Some cool features about this dash cam I didn't realize existed before it was installed and I was driving with it:
+ Has lane departure warning visually and with a beep noise
+ I think it's also alerting me whenever I'm being radar gunned or there's a speed camera nearby because there's a wifi symbol with a beeping warning that sometimes appears.
+ You can replace the included SD card with a larger one so it will hold on to more recordings before overwriting the older files

title: Almost plug and go text: I received this as a review sample and even though I am experienced with setting up and configuring networks, this was so easy that I honestly believe anyone can set it up with the scant instructions.

My initial set up was to connect it to my DSL modem just to check it out. Although the instructions are terse, you do need to read them regardless of level of experience. For one thing, it requires you to completely power off your broadband modem. For another, it takes a bit to boot up no matter how you intend to use it. Connecting to broadband was a snap.

What I really wanted was a range extender and this was as simple to configure for that as it was to configure for broadband. In that mode, when you first power it on and boot up it takes over a minute and you may be tempted to think it's broken. Don't. Once it is powered up, like the broadband set up (DSL or cable), the wizard makes it simple to discover your wireless router, connect to it and extend the range of your network. My wireless router turns in a weak -70dB from my master bedroom (measured with [[ASIN:B004EBZX6W Wi-Fi Analyzer]]) and once I installed this in the same room the signal dramatically improved to a strong -40dB. In the same room with my master wireless router this comes in at -47dB while the master router measures in at -56dB. That indicates that the signal of this router is exceptionally strong.

There are options for adding sensors for home control. I did not test that set of features because I did not receive sensors, but it is functionality that makes this router/extender a great choice if you do want to pursue home control too. There are IOS and Android apps that can be used in conjunction with the sensor features. Again, I did not explore those and probably will not since I am not interested in them. As a router alone I love this, and especially the overall signal strength and ease of setting up and configuring.

title: Nice watch text: This is my first running watch. Although this is listed as a "Smart Watch", it's only "Smart" when it's liked to your phone.
I use it as a running watch and a fitness tracker and it works great for a beginner like myself.

It has built in GPS which is great for tracking runs and walks. It gives you all the basics like pace, cadence, distance, and time. You can configure the data fields to your liking, change watch faces, and download other apps.

The GPS is very accurate, I compared the distance on the high school track and after 14 laps it was within a few feet of the track distance. An app using my phone's GPS was 1/2 mile off. (My guess is that measuring a distance from one point to another will be easier and more accurate than 14 laps around a 400 meter track.)

The watch screen is optimized for outdoor running and it works great in the sunlight. As it gets darker you need to tilt the watch at an angle to see the screen. I've run at sun up ad sun down without issue. The screen is backlit but you need to push a button. That's a little awkward when your running, but I rarely run in the dark. I have not had any problems seeing the screen indoors with normal lighting.

I picked this watch because of the low profile, large face, and relatively low price as it is an older model.

It has made collecting data easy, and I can compare my progress as I work to become a better runner.

Battery life is acceptable, I'm charging every 5 days while using GPS 30-45 minutes a day.

The Garmin Connect App works well. Link it to myfitnesspal and you have a fairly complete fitness tracking app.

Garmin also links with mapmyrun, Nike+, and Endomondo to name a few.

This watch also works with an Garmin hear rate monitor. (010-10997-00).

There are many great running watch choices available, so you will want to do your research.

Of course you can always just use you smart phone and any of several great free running apps.
A lot of those have voice feedback so you don't need to look at your phone.

title: The main laptop pocket is a major problem but... read full review text: This bag is WONDERFUL almost completely rounded for use. Great amount of space, love the charger pack accessory. My main and very serious issue is this, the main big laptop pocket WILL COME OPEN WHEN PICKED UP BY THE BLACK HANDLE!!!!.
please take serious heed to this issue. It will dump everything out and onto the floor or allow someone to very easily steal out of that pocket. I had to buy a small lock and lock the zippers together. That's the only way to avoid this other than using the big yellow handle to pick up bag.
I thought I lost all my electronics in the airport one day because my pocket was opened. Thank God some man was honest and stopped me to tell me about it. My heart dank for a sec when I realized what was going on.

The bag is great in every other way. Plenty of space. Plenty of durability, easy wash and clean. After 2 months of every day use there's no fraying no tears nothing to really complain about other than the laptop pocket opening and dumping. It can also hold alot of weight, with that weight it feels great on shoulders and your back. You really can't tell there 30-40 lbs of books and stuff inside.
I would for sure buy another one even with the pocket problem. 5$ for 2 small locks solve that problem and add extra security for your main use. Keeping your stuff safe.
The color is vibrant and even being little dirty still shines my beautiful yellow. I love this bag and it's perfect for the cost.

I have NOT been paid for this review nor any other review so far. (I wish I would though).
This is, as always, just and only my opinion thought my own eyes and felt with my own hands. I take reviews serious, as I rely on them to make my decisions before any and all my purchases. So if you have found my review helpful please vote and let the other Amazonian Browsers get a better judgment of what to expect and how the product works. Thank you for your time and happy buying

title: Flippin' easy to use text: This camcorder is a simple way for you to share videos with friends and family, make and share mini-movies, capture special moments, or film your next masterpiece for YouTube or Amazon.com.

Pros:
1. The "cool" factor is off the scale. Every time I showed it to somebody, they said "COOL!!!"

2. It uses two AA batteries that are easy to install. There's a latch at the bottom of the camera - one side has a picture of a closed lock, and the other has a picture of an open lock. It doesn't get simpler than that, does it? Push towards the open lock and slide off the panel on the front of the camera from just under the lens. After you put in the batteries, slide the panel back into place and push the latch back to the locked position. You're now ready to start filming.

3. There are very few buttons required to operate the camera. Turning it so that the side with the big red button is facing you, the on/off switch is on the right side of the camera. After powering up, the screen will light up with the Flip logo and then it will indicate that it's ready. At this stage you'll be looking at whatever's in front of you, with a time check at the bottom telling you how much video time you have left.

4. Filming is easy - just press the red button to start, and press it again to stop. The camera will save your creation, tell you how long it is and how much time you have left. You can zoom in and out by pressing the + and - signs on top of and below the red button. The microphone will pick up and record whatever's going on at the time.

5. Playback is a one button operation.

6. Deleting your mistakes is a one button operation.

7. You can scroll through your videos by using the arrow keys to the left and right of the red button.

8. Getting it on your computer is the easiest part. With the red button facing you, pull down on the latch on the left side, and - surprise!!! Out pops a USB arm which you then connect to your computer. Once you're linked up, the Flip Video software will show you the way home. (It takes a while to pop up) Choose the option to view your videos, and agree to the terms and conditions, and then the "Muvee Video Mixing Software" begins loading. This is a one time installation. From there you can easily play, name, edit and share your videos.

9. You can also capture still shots from your videos, but you can't use these when making your movies with the software provided.

10. There is an option for making a movie, where you can arrange your edited videos, choose from a selection of six movie styles and music, or even add your own music. Choose your style, click on the "Make Mix" button, and the computer does the rest. If you're happy with the results, you can save the file.

11. The camera comes with a wrist strap, a velvet drawstring case, and also the necessary cables to connect it to your television for a bigger view. There's also a place to connect a tripod.

12. There is a "Help" feature included with the software.

Cons:
1. Being a simple "point and shoot" camera, the resolution isn't fantastic, but quite good enough for action shots. Forget detail close-ups such as words and logos - zooming in and out will just get you various degrees of blurry.

2. You'll need to be careful with background noise, as the microphone will pick up the sound of your fan or your stomach growling.

3. The video editing capability is limited to the length of the video you want to save, and the order you want to save it. There are no options for titles, fade ins or outs or any bells and whistles. If you're filming yourself giving a speech, you'll pretty much have to get it right in one complete take.

4. As with all videos, if your hands shake, you'll need to get a tripod, or you may make a lot of people seasick.

5. If you have big fingers, you may have some problems with the red button. Once your finger covers the area around the button, you'll have trouble starting and stopping the video. If you can't get it to work, you may have to use just a fingernail, because if you press anywhere other than dead center of the red button it won't start or stop.

Overall, this is a very good camcorder if used for the purpose for which it is intended. It isn't going to make you the next Stanley Kubrick, but it's a good start.

Amanda Richards, October 9, 2007

title: Pleased With This Little Shelf text: I had an Echo Dot taking up room on top of a bookcase and I needed this space. The Dot is plugged into an outlet that sits between the bookcase and a bureau. Having tested the Dot and sure it would respond to voice commands even in that lower position, I ordered this set of shelves. It's a doddle to install: unscrew the switch plate. Click the shelf portion together with the outlet surround so that it forms an L-shape, line up the surround, with the shelf on top, around the outlet, then screw the switch plate back on until it holds the wall outlet shelf firmly and doesn't wobble. Plug in the power cord, run the other end through the cord hole, plug into your gadget, then set your gadget (Echo Dot, phone, etc.--it should not be something heavy) on top. That's it.

Works great.

However, if they bend at the plug part then it makes the cord pretty useless. I have my cats to thank for that. However, with these not being that expensive, being a great length, and come in cute colors I can keep replacing them when I need to.

title: Small Footprint, Large Capacity text: I have to confess, I have bought these small backup drives for years and never used the pre-programmed software that came with it. I just want to back up my files. This time I was determined to use it to see how it worked.

First: this is physically about the size of my hand (with fingers; I have small hands) and heavier than the 1TB drives I have bought previously. Nice and solid. The connecting cord is short as usual. It was immediately plug-and-play, and I registered it. Then I started the backup software. This worked okay, except it took forever. I usually back up my hard drive once a month, and via USB it takes two hours. This one went on for hours, to the point I had to stop it by shutting off the computer at bedtime; it continued backing up for an hour. It did back up my files on my separate D: drive, and also my entire e-mail folder. But it also backed up my C: drive with my Windows setup on it--what's with that? Anyone knows that if your computer crashes, it is better to just reformat and reload. That way you get junk and possible malicious software off as well. So maybe that's why it took so long to back up, it was copying all those Windows files.

Not interested in using the other software, but a small 5TB backup for this price is good bang for your buck! I remember years ago (late 90s) when hubby and I bought a 300MB hard drive for $300 and we thought that was a bargain!

title: Cute but you get what you pay for.

title: Solid tablet mount for a good price. text: The Arkon Tablet arm everything that you see in the pictures:
- Two clamps that secure tightly to the metal posts on a car's headrest.
- The arm is extendable and can be locked in to position.
- There are two sets of L brackets to allow for multiple configurations depending on the size of your tablet.
- The L brackets have rubber footing that securely hold the tablet.

My concerns:
- The screws that tighten the clamps to the headrest posts are very very thin. I can see them breaking if someone tightens them too much.
- The tablet mount is held to the extendable arm using a ball joint. While a ball joint works well for a cell phone, my concern is that tablets are much heavier and that the ball joint would slip -- especially with car vibrations. It is necessary to tighten the ball joint a lot in order for it to stay put.

I do not deduct any stars for these concerns because they have not happened to me, but potential design flaws should be pointed out.

For my iPad, I use two long and two short L brackets (exactly as you see in the sample picture). This is the perfect size for the ipad. The position that of the iPad at the center of the car means both kids are able to see the videos comfortably on long car trips.

title: These are perfect for an organization geek.. like me!! text: This is awesome!! I love these gadget containers so much.. it feeds my organization fix and need to have specific items stored in their perfect pouches! This is a protective case for any small electronic device and/or, cords and accessories. I've used Procase, Caseology, Bag-sport in the past and the AmazonBasics rivals then all- it does not disappoint!
-The integrity of the materials used to create the “outer shell“ is there.. This has a bendable stiffness (weird but, true!) and it keeps its shape for the protection of delicate items inclosed- Plus, the placement of the zipper running via the middle of this pouch itself- also helps give the outer edge added support. This has expected finishing details with the zippers edge so, it won’t cause issues zipping the lip of material into zipper when opening or, closing.. (you all know that stuck zipper crisis that happens on your favorite jacket..?!! Yep! The one that gets stuck when you’re usually in a hurry.. I’ve open and closed this x100 with no complaints!)

-The interior is made soft with a neon green felt so, it’s protective for enclosed items.. and I love the creature comforts! The bungee bands are perfect! Easy in/out and bands help keep items secure so, they won’t fall out while opening.. this case goes one step further and provides a buckle on the bungee itself- a new feature, even for me! But, my fav. feature is the interior ZIP UP POCKET!! With any gadget case this is my standard criteria.. they all must have an interior zip pocket. Simply put, it is a must have or, I won’t buy- TBH, these cases really need a secure pocket to keep all small objects, cords, SD cards, wall butts, extra batteries, etc.. from coming loose and falling out. I love that this interior pocket runs the length of the case and can fit all my small items securely.

I would definitely recommend- these are perfect for travel, anyone putting items in backpacks and wanting to protect expensive and delicate electronics… Or, those that continuously misplace necessary charging cords etc. for their various items- this is the perfect place to store such items.

I hope this info helps.. feel free to let me know!

title: Perfect--Give Me Sleep Tracking, Which Apple Does Not text: For what I wanted, this watch is perfect. I love that it tracks my sleep, which is desperately needed. I have fibromyalgia, so I find that deep sleep is hard to find. While the watch can't make my sleep better, it does track it in a way that helps me work on my sleep times and relaxation so I can get better sleep.

Although, like most fitbits, it doesn't perfectly track all types of exercise, I love how it combines with the heart rate to calculate calorie burn. For instance, I box and swim. I can leave after an hour and only have 3,000 steps. On the flip side, I can go for a lazy little walk and get 5,000 steps. I've learned that not all exercise is the same, and with the heart rate capabilities and calorie calculation, that this fitbit seems to get it a little better. I don't worry about the steps quite so much, as long as I can keep working on my heart health and calorie burn.

Overall, I really like this watch. It does show text messages I get and alerts me of phone calls. I'm pretty okay not being able to call from my watch--I don't want to be available every second of my life, but I do like being alerted to things. For what it can do, this is a great watch!

title: AWESOME STAND that is INCREDIBLY FUNCTIONAL text: I have thoroughly tested this stand with multiple devices over the last couple of months and I have been thoroughly impressed.

This innovative stand has a non slip base that allows it to hold fast to all sorts of surfaces. Not only can it suction with plenty of force to support even a heavy DSLR with a large telephoto lens but it will stay where you place it allowing for placement of equipment in places that are otherwise impossible.

I have had no issue with the 1/4” - 20 ball head adapter. I have used this with my DSLR, video camera, phone stand, LED lights and projector.

This stand allows for creative photography that with traditional tripods is just not possible. It is small enough to be easily carried whether out for a day or on vacation. It requires far less room than a traditional tripod yet is far more functional.

I have been thoroughly impressed again and again with this well built, expertly designed stand.

Thanks for reading my review. I enjoy writing them as I value reading other’s reviews when I’m making a buying decision. I regularly update my reviews to reflect any changes I may discover and to include helpful tips you may need if you purchase the product. I will always make every effort to answer any questions I can as it is my pleasure to help.

title: Great clarity & security text: Camera is a hardwire unit so installation takes a little longer over simple plug and play units. But installation outside took about 75 minutes and has performed great (one week so far). I am very impressed with the image quality and I can see two sides of my house (mounted on a shed 30 feet from the house). Connection to WiFi (Allo high speed) has been rock solid (even at 30 ft w/o a WiFi extender) with no issues. Outside durability is unknown, but in a week has withstood Nebraska winters. (I'll update if/when a weather issue occurs.) Use of the app has worked flawlessly.
Camera motion sensing is fairly sensitive so I get notices from large trucks that rumble by 25 yards away. Image quality at night is great. I have outdoor lights and so do not use night mode at all. With outside LED lights, image quality and colors at night are more than acceptable.
About the only complaint I have is that the alarm is not that loud but I hope to rarely use it. So impressed that I added two additional Geeni cameras (doorbell and second Sentry). I would highly recommend Geeni to anyone looking for easy to use cameras.

title: Great cameras and system text: Great cameras, clear vision and in color. Able to talk to somebody should they come up in view of the camera.

Also takes 10 seconds before camera starts to record and that’s to long. Sometimes what comes into view and leaves can be done in less than 10 seconds believe it or not or only see the person as they are leaving. I have seen others talk about this and hope Blink corrects this in the near future

title: This is FAST! If you have UHS-II cards, you NEED THIS!
text: If you don't know what UHS-II is, you probably don't understand what makes this reader special. But, if you've got one of these new UHS-II cards (you can tell by the extra set of pins, see photo), and you're using it in a regular SD card reader, you owe it yourself to get one of these! The price is right, as I've never seen a UHS-II reader this low, and the boost in speed is noticeable. I work in digital video, and coming back with tons of 4K content can sometimes take 6-10 minutes to load data for editing per card. With this reader and a compatible UHS-II card, I just managed the same task in 2 minutes. I performed a data speed benchmark (see attached screenshot), and you can see the read speeds are almost 2.5x what I get with my traditional standard SD reader! This thing reads faster than some internal HDDs! Super impressed, this will cut down on wait times dramatically.

title: Awesome Laptop for the Price text: I recently purchased one of these laptops when I stumbled on it here at Amazon. I was very much attracted by the price but was a little wary - this was one of very few laptops with an Intel Core i7 CPU in its price range so I was unsure what compromise might have been made to drive down the price. After working with it and really getting to know it, I can say there were few compromises made - this is an all-around awesome laptop at a really, really good price (as I write, $799). There are a couple of minor things I personally would change but these come down to preference.

I will start with something that no one else online seems to mention when describing this laptop - the screen. From reading the specifications to digging around on the manufacturer's website I could find precious little regarding the screen beyond the dimensions. It's the glossy type, so please keep this in mind when shopping for a laptop. Some people prefer a matte finish on the screen to cut down on reflections so if a glossy screen is a problem then this laptop might not work for you. Personally, I like the glossy type of screen as it's easy to clean and since I work in a darker room most of the time I do not have issues with reflections. This laptop's screen is also very bright and clear, brighter than that of my Sony Vaio.

Another very interesting feature of this laptop is the keyboard. It has a full number pad on the right side, slightly separated from the main keys. I like that. It also happens to be the chicklet-style keyboard which in my experience has been better at keeping stuff from getting in the keyboard.

I made one unfortunate discovery when setting up this laptop - the power plugs into the middle of the left side of the case. That's a very awkward place for the power to be plugged in. What makes this particularly unfortunate is that the plug sits directly next to the output air vent where heat from the CPU dissipates. When not relying exclusively on the battery, make sure you move the cord in such a way to avoid that vent.

This laptop has three USB ports, all of which are on the sides and close to the front. This may cause some issues, as both left- and right-handed users may struggle with external pointing devices when using this system. If using an external monitor this may be of no consequence but it's important to keep in mind.

To my great joy, it is possible to turn the touch pad off completely. I dislike touch pads and on the occasions where I have to use the built-in keyboard I don't want to accidentally click on something or move the mouse pointer.

One final thing I would have preferred to see when it comes to the hardware - a lid latch. I do move my laptop a lot and I would have liked a locking lid. That's purely a personal preference thing.

My very first exercise with this system was to make restore media. This process was lengthy, taking about 2 hours and resulting in 4 single-layer DVDs. I then made a second set of restore media - something that some manufacturers expressly prevent users from doing. Once that was done I took a little time to explore the OS.

The "Windows Experience" numbers reveal a lot about this system. As expected, the Aero graphics are the slow point, but still the number sits around 5.1. This is driven by the Intel graphics chipset and reflects the kind of usage that would occur under light-duty such as word processing or generating email. The gaming graphics, powered by the NVidia card posted much more respectable numbers. The second slowest number was for the hard drive, and considering that Asus puts a 5400rpm drive in these units this is not too shocking. It is easy enough to put a faster/bigger drive in, so I am not terribly concerned with this.

There's a fair amount of vendor add-on software, most of which I am not likely to use. I was especially dismayed to see Trend Micro's security solution on there, a packages I personally dislike and will not use. Fortunately, stripping off all of the unwanted fluff is easy enough, but it represents a minor inconvenience.

After contenting myself with the Windows side of things, I completely wiped the hard drive and loaded up Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6. RHEL 6 is what I planned to run when I purchased this laptop anyway and it is where I can truly explore the system in detail.

The Linux kernel reports eight cores as expected. Since the Core i7 is a hyperthreading quad-core, this is exactly what I hoped to see. It also reports the full 6GB of RAM.

Boot-up time from pressing the power button to getting the log-in screen (under Linux using GNOME as a window manager) is less than 30 seconds. This is by far the fastest machine with which I have ever worked. Times would be even faster if the hard drive was a 7200rpm or an SDD-type, but it's plenty fast enough to please me.

Overall, I am delighted with this laptop. It has a lot to offer for such a modest price and it definitely delivers on its promises. There are a few minor design issues that may or may not matter when using this system, but considering how much machine you get for the price it's hard to pass up in spite of a few minor complaints. This is a great system, worth more than the asking price.

title: Good durable storage, albeit USB2.0 read speeds text: This is exactly what it claims to be. It says very clearly that this is USB2.0 speed, so keep your expectations realistic. It seems like some people rated this poorly because it wasn't as fast as other USB devices, and that's not really fair if comparing to modern USB3 or Thunderbolt speed device made for data transferring regularly. This is more like a write-once-read-many distribution device.
I'm attaching speed benchmarks here, and this honestly seems pretty average for a USB2 connected device. I have many old USB2 sticks that are slower. A USB3 SSD connected to my USB2 port faired a little bit better. To be clear and give this a sense of scale:
An old 4GB USB stick connected to my USB2 port clocked in at 15-20MB/s.
An ultra fast USB3.1 SSD connected to the same USB2 port: 42.24MB/s (so one shouldn't be expecting to a USB2 to be faster than this or even reach this maximum on an average setup).
This device, at 30.59MB/s, seems pretty on par.
Where you will feel the sting, however, is in the slow 5.87MB/s write speed. That's also not uncommon for sticks like these- they are designed for durability and fast read times, to read data off quickly and conveniently. This is great for distributing finished media for a client to play on a projector, or have your resume / photo portfolio on your keychain. Reading more often than writing. A friend of mine who does wedding video would use a stick like this to distribute the finished event production to the client. It's perfect that for what it claims to be and do, a solid 5 stars.

title: These headphones have good sound when the buds are seated well in the ... text: These headphones have good sound when the buds are seated well in the ear, but they fall out a lot, and the gels fall off easily (I've lost one of each set that came with the packaging, so I'm looking for replacements. They are also not good for running or other vigorous exercise, but fine on the elliptical. They do not work well with a coat that has a collar. The battery life is great, as far as I can tell.

title: Amazing flexibility, serious value. text: I've got some experience with soundbars having been an early adopter in them along with the first generation plasma televisions. The thought then was to hide the wires and hang everything on the wall as if it were art - the modus operandi hasn't changed, it's just improved and become much more affordable.

First, the flexibility of this system makes it great for anyone. You can connect the speakers and create a large soundbar you can place on a shelf or hang up on the wall. This is ingenious - it looks great as one piece and you don't have to worry about multiple speakers. Or, you can keep the speakers separate and still either place them on a table or shelf or whatever, or hang them on the wall. So if you prefer the speakers vertical to the left and right of your TV, or if you prefer them horizontal under the TV, you have the freedom to do either with this system.

Next are the features. I found the Dialog settings to be superb. With my previous speaker setup I was always adjusting the volume between quiet monologue scenes and action scenes to hear what was being said. This system adjust everything on the fly automatically so you can hear the dialog without making any other changes.

I connected it right up to my cable box with HDMI and it was done. No complicated wires to hook up, one and done.
The subwoofer included is WIRELESS! That is terrific. I put it behind my seating and it was just perfect.

I tested the Bluetooth feature from my phone - I turned on Pandora and beautiful clear music came instantly through the speakers. Nothing to really setup, it was playing tunes in seconds.

All in all I'm really happy with this system. With the flexible speaker setup, the great features, and the price so low you can't even buy a subwoofer for that kind of money, it's a no brainer.

title: Great Microphone for Hobbyists, Gamers and Bloggers text: A warning to first time users, you may experience the microphone picking up background noise. It's very sensitive. Be prepared to set-up an area for recording if you are wanting to get clean audio. The VIMVIP USB Condenser Microphone came in a fairly plain box with a large hard foam protective insert. This microphone seems to be a great starting point for anyone interested in a higher quality microphone. I can whole heartedly recommend it.

The VIMVIP USB Condenser Microphone is a USB interface microphone that is a large step-up in quality to those used to the basic microphones that come with many web cameras. It provides a higher sensitivity to sounds; enabling both a greater ability to pick up lower volume noises and the ability to comprehend higher volume ones.

The lower volumes it was able to obtain included whispering, including the mouth noises associated with ASMR videos, and keystrokes from a non-mechanical keyboard roughly 6 feet away [With it's recording volume turned down to 50%]. On the higher end of volume it is able to accommodate singing, yelling, and screaming; by not topping out what it able to accommodate this allowed for wide arrays of vocals and would assist with those wanting to record instruments. I did many different experiments to test the range at home on different days.

The VIMVIP USB Condenser Microphone came with a short stand and pop filter that is attached to the stand by goose neck. The stand and metallic goose neck are both adjustable to assist with angling, but it is not vertically adjustable. The microphone, when pointing directly up, is about 26 cm / 10 in in height to the top of the microphone. It has a rubber ball footed desktop tripod for stability. The microphone can also detach from the included stand and be mounted to a standard size tripod or any other compatible stand, making the pop filter necessary depending on setup.

I had a great experience using VIMVIP USB Condenser Microphone to audition for a voice acting role organized by fellow fans of an animated series. The VIMVIP USB Condenser Microphone certainly made me sound much better than my webcam microphone is able to do. I have been using this for cooperative game-play online as well. This is a great value, especially at the price point.

Thank you for reading my review. I hope you have found it informative and helpful.

title: App is useless. Antenna barely brings in two local stations text: Well, I don't hate this antenna, but I sure don't like it either. It's bigger than other indoor antennas, but but not enormous - it's definitely uglier than others. The app for this is pretty useless and I just deleted it. It shows the towers nearest your location, but then freezes repeatedly.

Supposedly we have three towers with a total of 14 stations in two towns within 45 miles of us. I have a clean line of sight for two of them within 15 miles and should get at least 8 stations. After messing around with this antenna for four days and moving it eight times, we never pulled in more than two stations. One is the local ABC affiliate and the other is some Spanish only channel.

In comparison, I borrowed a different indoor antenna from our next door neighbor and within minutes of attaching it, we had 8 different stations without a bunch of position drama. It's also smaller and less intrusive visually than this one. I think I will just buy one like my neighbor has instead and put this one away as a last resort backup.

text: The corner holders will not hold the phone if you have a case on the phone.  I'm using a very slimline case, and it still will not fit.  There is no way to adjust for a phone's thickness.  I do not recommend this product if you have a case on your phone.

title: Works well
text: Works as expected.  Very easy to pair with your smartphone and listen to audio files through the car speakers.  Some of the buttons are small for large hands/fat fingers, but you do not have to change the settings frequently.  A great workaround if you have an old stereo system without any formal inputs.  Been reliable for several months of consistent use.

title: Must Have Item for College Kids! text: This is a great, sturdy lock/cable for laptops. The cable is thick enough to prevent standard scissors from cutting. It's over 6 feet long which allows plenty of length for wrapping around a desk leg, etc. My son will be heading to college next year & this will give us a little less to worry about. There were no instructions included, so I was a little clueless on how to use it, but my husband was familiar enough with this type of item that he was able to show me how it works without any difficulties. If someone was determined, they could most likely break the cable with right tool, but it would at least prevent an unplanned grab. Very pleased that it comes with an extra key. There's nothing like misplacing a lock key!

*I was provided with a Ruban Notebook lock directly from the company for the purpose of trying it out & reviewing. My thoughts & opinions are my own.

title: Excellent Tool for Unique Photos text: I have used similar crystal globes for unique photography opportunities for several years.

This is a particularly nice set as it comes with a unique tripod that can be used to hold the globe at different heights. This has come in handy for me as I have done several double globe series. When shooting through a single globe the image will be flipped - through 2, the image will be presented upright and allows for really unique light effects.

Besides this awesome large globe and tripod, the set comes with a hard, zippered carrying pod, a cleaning cloth and a base for the globe to rest.

I have thoroughly enjoyed this set and would certainly recommend it.

Thanks for reading my review. I enjoy writing them as I value reading other’s reviews when I’m making a buying decision. I regularly update my reviews to reflect any changes I may discover and to include helpful tips you may need if you purchase the product. I will always make every effort to answer any questions I can as it is my pleasure to help.

title: Beautiful retro design Bluetooth 5.0 speakers with a real wood cabinet... text: THE GOOD:
--------------
* Beautiful retro decor speaker. Well built with real wood, not lamination.
* Sound quality is super, though I'm not an audiophile.
* Dual 4 inch subwoofers, 50 watts.
* Bluetooth 5.0, lossless audio.
* Might be the best speaker you can find in this price range.
* Can link multiple Studiofinix speakers.

THE BAD:
-----------
* No remote control.
* No controls on the front, top, or sides. Everything is in the back, if you need to make adjustments, it is a hassle if this isn't hooked up in an open environment.
* The glossy lacquer makes it a fingerprint magnet.

Despite the few cons, I can't get myself to subtract any stars because this speaker is too cool. Me, being a retro guy, it is exactly my cup of tea. 5-Stars!

title: Just pass on this. WiFi is non functional and cords are exposed after installing text: I'm not impressed at all with this camera. That's my own fault for choosing a camera from a random company I've never heard of - generic soap is fine, but not for electronics. This is difficult to install and just badly designed. There are cords left dangling unless you create a space in the wall to hide them. A thief could easily cut these and kill the camera....sort of defeats the entire purpose of having it.

The biggest problem here is the so called wifi connection. It simply doesn't work once the camera is outside of the house. I tested a Canary unit camera outside and it had no problems connecting and staying connected to our WiFi, but this one was essentially dead. Inside and connected via Ethernet cable directly, it works fine - again essentially useless for the purpose of protecting our home.

I listened to disco, rap, rock, all sounded beautiful (haven't tried classical yet, lol). I would definitely buy them again if needed!

Its been working very well so far, running memory intensive applications (media editing) are more responsive and a pleasure to use now. Highly recommended if you have a Gateway or similar box.

title: Looses interface too frequently text: The DLINK COVR was setup to a replace an Apple AirPort Extreme. The setup was relatively simple via the iOS App. Each access point needs to be setup individually. This product is brand new for DLINK and the iOS app felt like a 1.0 product. The iOS app did get an update during my testing but it’s still a bit crashy and does not offer as many features as the web interface. Hopefully there will be more firmware updates.

Pros
- Units are small and unassuming
- Allow you to disable the bright white lights (warning lights will still function).
- Supports multiple connected devices (over 30 WiFi enabled devices) without issue.

Cons
- Primary access point needs to be rebooted (it seems like once a week) as it loses access to the Management interface (via the Web Page and App).
- Comes with different color faceplates for the access points (Metalic Blue and Copper) but it only comes with one of each color. If you want to change the color of the other access points you need to purchase two more faceplates.
- Product is still new. Other more refined products on the market from NetGear, Linksys and Eero.

I had never heard of this brand before, but it turns out they're legit. I'd pretty much do anything to get better quality internet, so I HIGHLY recommend this device.

Thanks so much for taking the time to read this review. I hope the information that I've provided helps make your decision a little easier.

title: Works as advertised text: I got this ram to double the amount of ram that I currently have. While I'm a power user, I'm not a performance snob. I don't care about benchmarks and gaining just that tiny bit of performance. What I needed was more ram space in order to do video editing and gaming. There was definitely a performance improvement simply by the fact that there is less necessity to cache to SSD.

The SABRENT ram have not introduced any instability to my system. No blue screen of death due to poor quality ram and no hiccups during use.

With 32gb of ram, you'll have enough for every day use and still have plenty of overhead for memory hogging activities such as photo and video editing (as long as you're not working with super high resolution or with too many files at a time).

title: Decent Speaker Set
text: This is a decent speaker set. I ordered it for my son who has been considering an expensive name brand system for his computer. The set looks nice. It was easy to set up. The sound quality is good, not great. For the price, it's really a good set. His main issue with this is that the cables are really short. His desk is one of those that quickly converts to a standing desk and when he does that, the cable length interferes and has pulled the speakers off the desk. Of course, we can order longer cables so that's not a problem, but until then, he's not able to use these as he intended.

title: I like this Blue- Black Ultra Metal drive's aesthetics, it is in short, gorgeous. text: I had a big clunky WD My Book Essential 1Tb USB 3.0 external drive and it was getting old and failing.
I received this Ultra Metal 2Tb model today.
I actually took the old My Book apart by prying the case off with a large screwdriver and removed the bare HDD from inside. There is a WD Green drive in there and I actually mounted it in my computer, wiped and formatted it and now it gives me 1Tb of extra storage, not bad.
So, the Ultra Metal external drive is so classy.
The only complaint I have is the included USB 3.0 cable, it is very short, maybe 12 inches long, not good, however, I had the other 3.0 cable from the old drive, it's about 1 meter long, and it of course works fine with the new drive, I have it plugged into a 1 meter USB 3.0 extension cable so now have about 6 feet of wiggle room from the computer to the external drive.
I like this Blue- Black Ultra Metal drive's aesthetics, it is, in short, gorgeous.
That big boxy My Book I had before was so clunky, big and ran hot all the time.
This device has no unnecessary power cable, just one USB port and nothing else.
I opened the file for this drive and saw about 5Mb of preinstalled apps installers including a PDF Users Manual and quite a few other apps in about 20 different languages.
WD has gone to a lot of effort to make this drive world class.
Except for that little 12 inch USB 3.0 cable. Get yourself an extension cable and this drive is the Cadillac of external drives. The included software is icing on the cake for you to choose how sweet you will make your drive.

title: Four Bays Are Convenient When Searching Drives From Retired PCs text: I have a collection of old SATA drives from retired (and now recycled) desktop PCs. I use this SABRENT USB 3.0 FOUR-BAY 2.5” HARD DRIVE DOCKING STATION WITH FAN (DS-4SSD) to see into the 2.5” (slender) drives, and to occasionally copy off a file that wasn’t transferred when I set up the replacement PCs. It’s convenient to have the four bays available when I’m not sure which drive contains the file I’m seeking. I can set up four drives at once to speed the process.

In my experience, Sabrent products always perform well, and they’re always reasonably priced. They deliver good value for the money.

title: Excellent product that delivers what it promises. text: Clear instructions. Do make sure you patiently work your way through the installation to avoid wrong assembly or damage.
I installed the antenna on the roof of my ranch-style house using the antenna mount purchased separately.

TV caught most of the channels within 75 miles at first scan :)
I get CBS, NBC, WKAR (MSU), FOX, ABC, ION.

Signal is strong and stable even in cloudy weather, rain and snow (I live in Michigan !). I installed the antenna in September 2015.
The only time the signal wavers is in strong winds that we had in fall. Not sure if this is due to antenna shake (I did fix it securely) or just an atmospheric phenomenon.

I have got rid of AT&T Uverse TV (which I was using mostly for network channels anyways).
I do watch MSU sports (go Sparty ! ), so I have internet Sling TV ($19.99 per month, no contract) to watch ESPN in the months I need it.
I need nothing else !!

In summary this product delivers what it promises.
I would recommend this product to anyone who wants to cut the cable/satellite.

As an extra bonus, the antenna looks really funky on my rooftop !

Very happy with this product :)

title: Flawless Bluetooth connectivity with Mac
text: My Logitech M310 (been using them for 10-15 years) could not connect properly with my USB-C/Thunderbolt MacBookPro, using their USB dongle, thru a USB adapter. Scroll wheel would NOT work, and Logitech tech support said they would not update drivers. 'Don't use an adapter.' But they aren't aware that new Macs don't have old-school USB ports? Anyone else have this problem?! Anyway... this Seenda connects directly with Bluetooth, and connects instantly. If it sleeps (after a few hours?) it wakes and re-connects with one click, in less than a second. I charged the battery when I bought it a few weeks ago, and forgot that I might need to charge it again one day. Still going. Downsides: it is much smaller and lighter than I am used to (the M310 is easily twice as thick/tall) so I am getting used to that. Took awhile to find the right DPI/resolution/speed (and the button to change that is in a precarious, easy-to-hit-by-mistake position. Overall a great recommend.

title: Very thin text: It is hard to have problems with zip ties, but I do have an issue with these. I had an entire bag of mystery cords that had entangled themselves like coat hangers do in dark closets. So, I sat myself down with the big bag, and a new plastic bin to bring some order to the chaos and bind up the cords. I had several sizes of zip ties with me to accomplish this task. The only black ties I had were these, so I know the issues I had were with these ties.

These are thinner than all the rest of my ties. Also, my others were made of nylon and were nice and strong. These black ties seemed to be more plastic than any nylon. They were a little harder to use, being a bit flimsy and much weaker than my other ties.

They did hold small cords together, but we're definitely cheaper and thinner. I would not buy these again.

title: Great sound that's wireless - Downgrade to 1 star text: Nothing about the original review is incorrect: they were great earbuds - while they lasted. I love these new earbuds. The BT is very easy to connect and has a been rock solid connection. Battery life seems very good, although I haven't needed to use it over an hour. title: Works flawlessly! Allows 2 unique displays with 2018 MacBook Pro (Intel) text: UPDATE (from 5 stars to 2 stars): JAN 2023: One of the HDMI ports stopped working, so now this thing has become pretty useless to me. If it had continued working, this would have been great. But unfortunately it randomly stopped working one day and it hasn't worked since.

This little thing has been wonderful. I have a 2018 MacBook Pro (Intel, not M1/M2) and I was looking for a dock that would allow me to use 2 separate monitors with the laptop lid closed, and this one is perfect.

It is pretty small (5" x 2" x 0.5", smaller than a Pro Max iPhone) and has a premium metal (?) feel to it (all I know is that it isn't plastic). All you need to do is plug it into the MBP and it works from there (side note: you need to install a quick driver before using the dock, but it's very simple)

I appreciate that it allows for pass through charging (which also ensures that high-energy USB devices receive ample power). Additionally, it is really nice that this has both DisplayPort AND HDMI, which is not common based on what I've seen.

My only gripe with this is that there are only 2x USB ports (which I knew when I bought it). If you're looking for an easy to use Thunderbolt dock for your MacBook Pro, get this one.

title: Affordable and effective
text: My husband and I bought two sets of these three years ago from Circuit City during their going out of business sale. We both travel quite a bit and were in need of decent headphones for longer flights (let's face it, the ear buds provided by the airlines just don't cut it). My husband accidentally left his set, in their pouch, in the seat back pocket on a flight last year and was in need of a replacement set for our trip to Germany last week. I was amazed by the price when I came onto Amazon to check - $29.99 was a steal compared to the $80 we spent a few years back! This headset is not the top of the line, but it is effective in canceling out the low aircraft drawl while in-flight. (They are also quite nice when you need to drown out the crying child in 23F. ;)) The battery life is remarkable. I have had to change the battery on my set only twice in the three years I've owned it. The only complaint that I have, which results in the four star rating instead of five, is that after wearing the set for a few hours (i.e., Amsterdam to Houston, TX), my ears begin to ache on the outside. It is almost like the headset becomes to tight over longer periods of time. I tend not to wear earrings on airplanes, so I can rule out the possibility of pinching. Other than that slight achy feeling, these are wonderful for the casual traveler and the price simply cannot be beat!

text: Great value for the money.  The buds go right up behind your tragus really blocking any extra sound.  For those of us with a tragus piercing, it does work fine, but my earring starts to ache after maybe 45 minutes.  But it does not slip out even with the tragus stud.  The wire seemed like poorer quality than I was anticipating--thicker and flat rather than thin and roundish like the more current models--but that is more of a style critique than one of functionality.  The headphones have worked well for the few weeks that I have been using it.  If you're looking for something that will stay in your ear and block out all other sound, producing high sound quality, this is a great model to get, especially for the price.

title: EXCELLENT 3.0 HUB!!! text: I am someone who truly puts data hubs to the test and I can say this is among the best that I have tested and reviewed.

I currently have twelve 10TB external hard drives plugged into mine allowing me to access and transfer large amounts of data between them, my computer and my NAS.

This hub has performed absolutely perfectly. There are several features that it has that others in the class do not but make a huge difference when using a hub effectively.

Each port has its own power button to the right of said port. This is important as powering on the port is the same as plugging that USB into the connected computer - in terms of external hard drives this lets them know that it’s time for them to work and they spin up. When not in use you can greatly extend the drives live by turning off the power to it and allowing it to be idle.

Transfer speeds are incredible with this hub. I have achieved the maximum transfer speed of each device run through this hub and know that it is my a limiting factor.

The hub comes with all the hardware you need should you want to mount this on a surface.

This is an outstanding hub that is made to last many years and perform at optimum efficiency without fail. This is the best hub I have owned.

title: Good Sound Quality and Lightweight text: I’m never been a huge fan of headphones. I recognize their value and necessity when you want to listen to something but no one around you does. The reason I don’t like headphones is the bulkiness and wires but Soundcore Anker Liberty Air True Wireless Earphones with Charging Case have eliminated these issues.

These earphones come in a small case and they are extremely lightweight. You simply remove them from the package, connect via Bluetooth, insert in the ears, and start listening to your favorite tunes. There are no wires so you can move around as you please and because they are so small, you don’t have the bulkiness. Many people, unless they take a close look at you, will not even know that you are using earphones.

Of course, what matters most with something like this is the sound quality and these earphones score above average marks for sound. The bass is especially good and I like that I can pause, skip music, take calls, etc with a simple push of the touchpads. And to charge, you just place them back into the case. They claim to last up to 20 hours on a charge, but I haven’t come even close to using them for that much time, so I cannot verify the claim.

Soundcore Amker Liberty True Wireless Earphones do not provide any way to control the volume using touch controls, so this is one issue I have with them. But other than that, these are very good earphones and certainly worth a try

title: 4.5 blue ribbon Romance Junkies review text: At the tender age of fourteen, Davie Adams's life is ripped apart. His mother's loose ways leads to a series of events that leave him homeless after his she dies in his arms. Grief-stricken, Davie makes the decision to leave Blackburn and go in search of his father.

Davie could have returned to his grandfather's house but he can't imagine remaining in Blackburn and having to endure the pitying looks and talk about his mother. After his mother's collapse, Davie runs for help and finds Tom Makepeace. They get his mother situated in the back of his wagon and are getting ready to head to the infirmary but she passes away moments later. Immediately afterward Davie jumps from the wagon and runs into the woods. Everyone assumes he'll return. Tom even yells into the woods for Davie to come to his home when he's ready that he's welcome there. Davie has other plans though.

He does go to the Makepeace's home but it's only to spend the night in their barn. He hadn't expected anyone to see him but Judy, Tom's daughter and Davie's longtime friend spots him from her window. She goes out to see him and reassures him that his mother's body is taken care of and his grandfather will be just fine. Judy realizes that Davie has to do what he feels is right for him but she also knows that her feelings for him have gone beyond friendship.

Davie leaves the following morning with nothing more than the desire to leave his memories behind him. Life on his own isn't everything he thought it would be and his search for his father proves fruitless. For years Davie travels and holds many different jobs but through it all Judy and his life in Blackburn remain firmly at the forefront of his mind.

THE LONER is sure to pull at readers' heartstring. Spanning over an eight year time period, you get a lot of insight into the characters' personalities and backgrounds. I love that Josephine Cox doesn't focus solely on Davie and Judy's story, there are many other characters who possess stories of their own which add a feeling of realism to this storyline. Davie's journey of self discovery is the main theme and it's a story you won't want to miss. Josephine Cox is a gifted storyteller who knows how to keep readers engrossed page after page so that the doldrums of winter just disappear.

Chrissy Dionne (courtesy of Romance Junkies)

title: A great value, love the SFF chassis, needs better packaging text: *UPDATED*

Update after living with this PC for half a year: Zero problems, fast, and works perfectly for my application (business use). And excellent value. VERY pleased with this purchase.
---

The PC itself seems to be a great value, and is working fine thus far. The system is plenty fast. The HDD is a bit busy/noisy, and spins a bit more than it should, as though the system is caching to disk constantly. I'm not doing anything demanding with it at all--just light MS Office use and surfing. That's it. No gaming, no video editing, nothing heavy. Note this system is intended for business use, and could not handle much in the way of gaming or video editing, as it has no video card. The on-board graphics use the system's RAM, so anything asking a lot from the system's limited graphics capabilities will slow the entire system down immensely. Luckily, I outgrew DOOM years ago.

The SFF case is heavy, but oddly a bit flimsy, with more flex than I had expected for the weight--especially the back panel--mine was oddly bent outward. I pushed it back in/straightened it (I had to in order to plug things in--the plugs were deeply recessed due to the bent real panel--very odd). The chassis itself is a joy to work with though, as the case pops open on hinges without turning a single screw--not even a thumbscrew, and everything is very accessible. The HDD's working vibrations and sounds are amplified by the plastic subframe the drive is mounted in, which acts like an amplifier for the vibrations. I worry a bit that the system's small case will have cooling issues. There just isn't much room in there, and there is only one small 3" system ventilation fan (+ the power supply's fan, and a fan over the CPU). There are vents on the front and rear of the system, but I would like a lot more ventilation--I would have appreciated a perforated lid. Heat is the enemy of all electronics, and my other systems all have more ventilation than this box. Of course, this is an off-lease corporate desktop workstation, and is not designed to have the long life of other systems. The components in the box are the cheapest possible variants thereof, and I do not expect this system to last more than 3-4 years at the most. That said, $269 for a branded Lenovo PC with a 3.2GHz Intel Core i5, 12GB of RAM and a 2TB HDD is a fantastic value. If it dies in 3 years, I will have gotten my money's worth.

Important note about the packaging: it simply was not enough protection. I guarantee the system took some hard knocks on its way to me. The UPS driver actually dropped it at my feet from a height of 1'--not kidding! The system is not packaged in an inner box within the shipping carton--the carton IS the box. The small Styrofoam corner blocks used to float the system inside the box are unusually rigid, so much so that they provide little in the way of cushioning, and one of them had cracked in half--meaning the PC wobbled around in the box during shipping. Also, the carton was sealed with "Microsoft Certified Refurbisher" packing tape, making it clear to all it contained a PC. They need to change the packaging--a desktop system simply needs more/better protection than this. I half expected it to be DOA due to the abuse it took on the way here from Arizona.
