title: OUTSTANDING QUALITY EXTERIOR GRADE ETHERNET Cat8 CABLE! text: I have used and tested more Ethernet cables than I can remember and there is no question, all Ethernet cables are not created equally.

Typically any device requiring an Ethernet cable will come with one in the packaging - it will work (usually). A good comparison is those cables are much like an old car - it should get you there, whereas this cable is like a high end sports car - it will get you there lightning fast, without failure.

This Cat8 is thicker than some due to the shielding within and additional insulation. This cable is made to withstand and holdup to exterior environments for the long term. The connector bases are reinforced at each end of the wire which really help hold all of the wires in place even if you have to bend and twist it to fit it within the plug. The connector plug itself is gold plated which is the ultimate standard in connectivity.

This Cat8 Ethernet Cable is 30’ long which makes it absolutely ideal for using it to directly plug your TV or gaming system into your router. So many of us stream programs and movies via our TV and there is no comparison in speed between a WiFi connection and a wired connection. For gamers, it is absolutely the way to go - do away with all lag caused by your WiFi by connecting directly to your router.

You will not find a better exterior grade Cat8 Ethernet Cable - this is really a top of the line cable that you’ll love.

This is a purchase that you’ll never regret.

title: Nice keyboard cover ... text: I'm very impressed with the quality of this keyboard cover. I honestly was not expecting to be as nice as it is.

I can speak from experience when I say that cats, coffee, and a MacBook are NOT a great combination. I lost an earlier MacBook Pro when cat and coffee collided over the keyboard, so when I purchased my new MacBook Air 13", I knew I wanted a keyboard cover.

This one has a lot going for it. It fits beautifully -- lays flat, the key covers are precisely where they should be, there's no slippage or any feeling of insecurity about the cover shifting position. It's transparent except for the colored key caps, so the underlighting of the MacBook Air keyboard shines through. It's quite thin so it doesn't add much in the way of bulk, either -- but the material feels like it will survive heavy use without tearing or puncturing.

I especially like having all the keyboard shortcuts printed right on the keys themselves. My version, the OX X shortcuts, is easy to read, and the colors actually mean somthing (blue = primary shortcuts, pink = finder, green = safari, orange = iWorks/Mail/MS Office). It's a nice touch that lends a bit of color to the rather drab aluminum face of the MacBook.

If you've never typed on a keyboard with a cover, it might take a little getting used to. It has a "softer" feel, but key action/etc. is not compromised at all.

Overall, I think this is a good product, a nice gift for someone with a new MacBook, with bult-in usefulness beyond protecting the keyboard from inadvertent spills and dust.

(Although a sample was supplied for review purposes, opinions expressed are based on my personal experience with this product.)

title: Dell Skimped on the RAM; Otherwise, a Decent Multimedia UltraBook text: I have worked with a large number of computers by various manufacturers, and I can say that each one has had its strengths and weaknesses. I was really intrigued by this one with the 8th generation i3 chip – I didn’t even realize that the i3 was still being developed or produced. My experience with this laptop (and its chip) has been a mix of positive and negative, though the positive does outweigh the negatives I see.

I will start by addressing the elephant in the room. This system comes with only 4GB of DDR4 RAM. Why? The standard anymore is 8GB unless all you’re doing is surfing the web and writing documents. I am not sure what possessed Dell to release a machine with that little RAM running Windows 10. So, my first order of business was popping the case open and expanding to 8GB, which was easy with a single 8GB stick. There are two slots in there, and 8GB works in one slot, so I am hopeful I can bump it to 16GB.

While I was in there, I was in for a surprise. There is a hard drive bay, and it’s empty. The system registers 256GB in a solid state flash, which is elsewhere (I did not see it but I know it's in there).

Oddly enough, the Dell software does not recognize the increased RAM though Windows and the system BIOS definitely see it. That’s a minor issue, not a real concern. It does need to be kept in mind though – it could be confusing for the unaware.

This is an UltraBook system, meaning that some shortcuts were taken to keep things light and small. The main thing missing is a CD/DVD drive which is hit or miss on UltraBooks. There is HDMI for video output but no other video output interfaces. Surprisingly, there is no USB type C port, but there are three type A ports. There is also an audio jack and an Ethernet port, as well as an SD card reader. The power button doubles as a fingerprint reader.

I booted the system, set it up and was on the network downloading updates within about 10 minutes. I was presented with a fairly clean desktop and not too much extra fluff n’ stuff. The system was a bit sluggish for the first hour as things were updated and cached, but it has settled down now and things are reasonably peppy. I have done little with the graphics beyond loading a video and looking at image files, though I expect it will handle light gaming and graphics work like photo editing, though the latter would definitely benefit from having 8GB instead of 4.

Windows did not activate automatically and I needed to run the troubleshooter before it activated. I am not sure what went wrong there, but it was a temporary issue and very quickly and easily resolved. I suspect there was a network issue.

The screen is slightly less bright than that of my Acer and Toshiba systems, though that’s not necessarily a bad thing. The screen is not as harsh to look at, and the resolution is good, so I would consider this a plus. Pictures and image files look clear and sharp with good color.

The real surprise is the sound, which is much better than I expected and is great for watching videos without requiring headphones or speakers. I will still use BT output when I want to listen to anything important (music or a movie), but the built-in speakers are more than adequate.

I like the keyboard, though I do not care for the touch pad. The pad is on par with most, neither better nor worse, and I am not a fan of touch pads. It’s nice that it can be turned off, and it is nice that it’s available if it’s needed.

The system comes pre-installed with McAfee which is unfortunate but not unexpected. I stripped that joker off in a hurry and installed something for which I already have a full license. There’s also the trial for Office 365 which I unceremoniously uninstalled. Other than those two, there isn’t much bloat on the system.

So, my main major complaint is that Dell went cheap and only put in 4GB of RAM instead of 8. Adding 4GB is very economical – less than $30 – so I fail to understand why that shortcut was taken. It’s easy enough to add after the fact, though, and the overall cost of the system is quite reasonable. This is not a heavy gaming rig by any stretch of the imagination, it’s instead a multimedia and light-duty graphics workstation which is what I need the majority of the time. I’m satisfied with this system in spite of the skimpy RAM (which can be fixed cheaply). If you need a system that isn’t for heavy graphics or gaming, this one is a reasonable choice.

title: Great product text: Most of us have a handful of usb charging devices that we take with us. A phone, earbuds, tablet, watch, whatever…. And swapping out the cords and plug adapters is a headache. Enter Apanage Powered USB 3.0 Hub and all its features for a really reasonable price tag.

1. On/off buttons. Don’t waste power on cables you aren’t using at the moment. The blue light indicates the plug is on. Otherwise push the button to turn on/off each port.

2. Charging port for specifically charging a phone, tablet, or whatever you need quickly charged up.

The Apanage Powered USB 3.0 Hub comes in several sizes. Shown in my pick is the 4 plug but I also have the 10 as well by the bedside. I have been super pleased with this device and have bought several for the house and office. Zero issues after 3-6 months of use. Great product.

title: Incredible Quality Camera at an Outstanding Price! text: I have run extensive tests on this camera over the last several months and I must say I’m very impressed with the performance.

Personally I have been working with security camera products for over 15 years - over that time I have installed systems for businesses, corporations and individuals - from large systems to single camera nursery monitors. I work with a group of security professionals and we regularly consult on large corporate projects and write about security vulnerabilities within networks for trade publications.

This is a field I know well - I understand what to look for in quality cameras and the places manufacturers tend to try to save money on which makes an inferior product.

Over the years the security camera technology has vastly improved becoming less and less expensive to produce. It is now practical to install residential security systems that would have only previously been used in commercial settings.

This is advice any professional security analyst will provide and what we tell everyone of our clients. If you are new to home security camera systems, we recommend going with wired (non-WiFi), NVR or computer based recorders run with systems such as Blue Iris. This type of system is infinitely more secure and stable. While initial setup costs are a bit more the security it affords is worth every penny. It always pays to research the products, discuss them with those in the field, understand vulnerabilities and PLAN YOUR SYSTEM PRIOR TO PURCHASING ANYTHING. If you are at all tech savvy at all you can do it. While there is a bit of a learning curve it is not awful and in the end you will be thankful for the time you spent in the beginning as it will save you time, money and endless frustration.

I have set up, tested and reviewed more security systems and individual products than I can possibly remember. Without question my go to solution for home security solutions is a computer based, Blue Iris system with PoE cameras run off of quality PoE switches. This type of system is not only easy to operate but is highly secure.

While this camera is not natively a PoE camera I’m happy to share the 5 Pairs Passive PoE Injector and PoE Splitter Kit with 5.5x2.1 mm DC Connector RJ45 Power Over Ethernet by Exgoofit ( https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07F82YK6P/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 ) allow for this camera to operate almost identical to a PoE camera. The power adapter must be plugged in where the Ethernet cable is plugged in with the first pigtail adapter while the second adapter plugs onto the cameras power port and Ethernet jack. By utilizing this you can avoid the security concerns associated with WiFi cameras and still only have minimal wires run to the camera.

As with any component there are a host of factors to consider. In terms of cameras more megapixels is not always better. For instance 2MP cameras often perform better in low light while 5MP will allow for more detail when lighting is good. This camera is 2MP which is ideal for the vast majority of installation situations.

Highlights of this camera include:

Awesome Pan Tilt Zoom - Utilizing a 110° wide-angle varifocal lens and the head rotating 355° horizontally and 90° vertically, a 360° view is easily obtained. This makes this camera an outstanding choice to be placed on a corner of an eave where it can constantly monitor the largest possible area.

3.6mm Board lens - in my tests over the last couple of months I have been fairly impressed with the performance of this Fixed Focus 6mm lens coupled with the 1/2.8" Sony IMX307 CMOS with ICR image sensor. While this will not allow for near as clear zooming as a varifocal lens it is adequate in most circumstances.

Low Light Capability - this lens is decent in low light. Images are ok at low light, far better than the vast majority of similar cameras in this price range. IR lighting is dependable and nighttime / low light images are better than expected. My tests showed accurate images within 75’ of the IR lighting. By using both 4 IR lights and 4 bright LED lights this allows the camera to capture more details than many of the others on the market.

ONVIF Compatibility - critical for using with software such as Blue Iris. I have set it up with advanced features such as Patrol and Watchdog utilizing multiple detection zones.

2 Way Audio - I have had no issues utilizing the 2 way audio through Blue Iris - sound is accurate, clear and minimal lag.

Video Compression - This camera utilizes Smart 265/Smart 264/M-JPEG compression allowing for the smallest file sizes while maintaining the highest quality.

Great build quality - this camera is well built and will hold up outside in all conditions. That being said this is not a small camera in any way.

Over the course of my testing this product for the last several months I’ve been thoroughly impressed. It loads into Blue Iris without any issue and advanced features work without any trouble. By using the PoE splitter kit (referenced above) you can easily make this a secure camera by avoiding the use of WiFi. Build quality is excellent - this is made to last and hold up even in severe conditions.

This is a product I would definitely recommend. While this is the first ENSTER camera I have reviewed I look forward to seeing other cameras they create. All indications point to this being a manufacturer that builds high quality security cameras that are dependable and made to last.

I collect vintage tvs, and wanted to attach a few of these sticks to old tvs for fun. So these LITEs without the 4k is the best bang for the buck, since old tvs can't do 4k anyway. But I noticed something peculiar about the remotes. I made two separate orders and didn't pay attention that the listings were actually different. This listing with over 16,000 reviews gives you a newer remote WITH shortcut buttons for Hulu, Disney, Netflix and Prime. If this matters to you, then you're in the right listing! For some reason, if you prefer the remote without these buttons, then you'll want to order from the listing with over 245,000 reviews. Here is the link to that listing:
https://www.amazon.com/fire-tv-stick-lite/dp/B07YNLBS7R/ref=cm_cr_srp_d_product_top?ie=UTF8&th=1

As for the Fire TV sticks themselves, they remain the same. It does not matter to me. I use Plex for my purposes. 5-Stars!

title: You might find a camera with better recording. text: I wished this camera did not pushed the envelope in the 30x optical zoom. We tested this and on play back the picture was very granular and shaky. I mean really shaky. You will need a tripod to reduce the shaking effect. We compared the output with one of panasonic camera that also had a movie function and we found that was better than this HD camcorder (for about the same price).

However, the zoom button was not hyper sensitive and hence you could zoom in and out without the picture looking like you were traveling through the stargate (sorry, for the syfy fans). It was a very easy and light camera to use and the menu was not overtly complicated in that within one choice you do not have to go into many steps to get what you are looking for - in fact there are only 6 menu options and within each one there is up to 6 choices. Great ones that we found actually worked included the face chaser (useful for filming moving objects coming towards you!) and the noise reduction (reduced the wind muffles). The camera is on as soon as you open the side wing with the view - there is no longer a viewer for the eye (thank goodness).

Works great with good lighting - natural and artificial. But does not work too well with dimly lit rooms. We noticed that it really picks up the sound real well so try not to talk as you are filming as we found we ended up being more focused on that than watching the movie. The down side on this camera was that you needed to buy a memory card and a big one at that as there is no hard drive with this camcorder; what is available only allows no more than 5 minutes of movies.

The camera is okay, not great as you can get better pictures on a stand alone camera. There is flash light, which some camcorders do not have. More useful as a camcorder than a camera - so a tad expense for just a camcorder without a hard drive.

title: A year of use and I'm still happy. Solid WiFi reception, strong battery, great for email text: I purchased my Fire 10" almost a year ago after having used my Fire 8" for 18 months previously. This tablet is surprisingly light considering the large size and it is thinner than my Fire Fire tablet.

I am really happy with the larger screen. Watching a movie or even just shopping and surfing websites is a nice experience. Better than lugging my laptop from room to room. My only real complaint is that the screen definition on my old Fire Hd was significantly better than this one.

I can use my tablet outside on the back deck because the WiFi reception on this tablet is stronger than my older Fire. I have also been really pleased with the battery life. I use this tablet daily throughout the day for email, surfing, games, record keeping for various projects, review writing, and of course, videos from time to time. I charge it over night and it rarely drops below 30%. I do have a memory card and back up my photos from both tablet and cell phone to the cloud with no problems. Bottom line is this is a nice tablet for basic use and it also travels well.

title: Works perfectly for me and no issues as others have reported text: I purchased this to transform a [[ASIN:B0002E38EE Monster Keyboard Cable - Straight to Straight 1/4" plugs]] to right angle at one end. The female connection mated perfectly with the Monster cable. Note that that cable is relatively high end with beefy plugs, so I did not expect problems with this adapter and have not experienced any.

Since my instrument is a keyboard there is practically zero movement or opportunities for the connections to jiggle. In addition to no issues or complaints about the female end, I am as happy with the male plug, which has firmly mated with a few amps and a PA.

If there is any issue, it's the fact that this adapter adds a lot of bulk to the end into which you plug a cable. On my keyboard it does protrude, especially with the cable I cited above. But the sound quality is noise free with my arrangement, and as I said, the connections at each end are firm and solid.

It may just come down to the quality of cable that you intend to use with this adapter. For the Monster model I am using this is a perfect way to change one straight end to angled.

title: A great option for behind my night stand text: Recently I found a need for me to have multiple devices hooked up at my nightstand. (Remember the days when it used to be just a lamp and a clock?)

With this unit I have the choice of three USB ports and four sockets. I wanted something with the USB ports on the top so I could easily reach them, as well as keep the cord length closer to me. This power “strip” has met that need and has certainly come in handy.

Instead of attaching it permanently to the wall or nightstand with screws, I used Command tape for a more temporary solution. Two Command strips have held it up with no problem. It has never fallen off, even when I plug items in and out.

I have my google home hub plugged into one of the sockets. I also have my Bose sleep bud charging case and iPhone charging stand plugged in. All things I want close to me when I’m in or on the bed.

Recently my eye doctor said I should be using warm compresses on my eyes, so I bought an eye mask with a USB cable. I leave the USB cord plugged in and just attach the other end to my eye mask when I’m using it. So convenient and really speeds up the process. When I’m done, I disconnect the cord from the mask and tuck the cord back behind my night stand. So easy to pull out and tuck back away.

Sometimes I need to plug in a heating pad and this is the only convenient place to plug it in while I use it from the bed. Since I don’t use the heating pad all the time, it’s easy enough to just plug it in when I need it.

I like that it’s low-profile enough to allow my nightstand to stay somewhat close to the wall. You wouldn’t even know it’s back there without leaning over and looking down.

I found this to be a good value and I would purchase again.

title: This is a PRO light! text: I work in photo/video for a living, and I can tell you that good LEDs aren't cheap. I have worked with hot tungsten lamps for high output and smaller LEDs for lightweight smaller setups, but LED lights that can compete with the output of Tungstens are pricey.
That being said, this is a FANTASTIC light. It has high output yet has the pros of LED panels such as lower power consumption and heat, as well as being dimmable and color adjustable from the panel or remote control. I had the opportunity to use this for a job yesterday setting up an interview in an office setting. My tungsten bulbs would have been too bright and need gels to match the rest of the office. My other smaller LEDs would have cast smaller spots and we all know a larger light source casts a more pleasing glow. It seemed effortless to get the amount of light we needed in a short time.
HOWEVER, I did find that the mounting point was a little bit difficult to use. There are two bolts to secure it to the stand, and both need to be loosened to mount it properly. It took me a few attempts to get it on the stand, one side felt like I was screwing the bolt the wrong direction most of the time. Meanwhile, the light is large and kept wobbling during this overly complicated procedure. It didn't feel like a premium product during that, which I found odd considering the price point. I have lights that cost about half of this one that felt more premium during mounting. But, that being said, once the lights are up it works a treat!
So, a solid 4 stars from me. Almost 5 if the mounting were easier or the price lower to make up for that. But as a light, it does what it should do and well.

title: Much More than Your Standard Power Strip text: Electronics have become a regular part of life. There is really no sense in resisting- electronics are here to stay and most would agree, even if they have slight reservations, that electronics have improved our lives overall. These electronic devices need to be continuously recharged and an excellent tool for the job is this Kasa Smart Wifi Power Strip.

This power strip is intended to charge lots of electronics at once. It has six standard outlets and three USB outlets. That means you can charge up to nine devices at once, making this a very useful and popular item to take with you at your next conference. You will find that people around you will ask to plug themselves in and you will have no trouble obliging. It has surge protection, too, so that your electronics stay safe.

What sets this power strip apart, however, is its high tech personality. It can be controlled remotely using the Kasa app and you can see exactly how much power each item is using, then shut off individual outlets if you like, all from the app! And if you have Google Assistant, Alexa, or Microsoft Cortana, you can use voice commands to control the outlets. That means being able to turn on and off, say, a light that is plugged into the strip with a simple utterance. It’s a geek’s power strip dream come true. I plan to use it on my holiday lights when the season comes around- it will be much easier then climbing behind the tree to manually turn the lights on and off.

Kasa Smart Wifi Power Strip is a heavy- duty power strip that seems like it was made to last. The plug on the strip does require a three prong outlet to plug it in, so make sure you can accommodate before you buy. It has all of the things you would want in an app controlled, voice activated power strip and it receives my highest recommendation.

title: Great for music AND calls! text: I have been on the search for wireless earbuds that sound ok and can handle calls, yet don't cost as much as Apple's... and I think this is IT! I had tried cheap brands, and wasn't surprised that the sound wasn't good. I tried expensive brands (even those costing almost the same as airpods) and while they had some excellent sound quality and noise cancellation, the callers couldn't hear me! I sounded under water and very compressed.
I kept having to resort to an old-school wired headset for calls, or bigger over-the-ear headphones with a good mic. But this set is that perfect blend! Decent sound quality, pretty intuitive to use, and the mic actually works for calls! And on top of all that, they are pretty affordable and from a name brand I recognize!
My daughter isn't into the look of the hoop-over-ear design, but honestly they are comfortable to wear and work exactly as expected so I can't help recommending these and singing their praises. Well done Skullcandy!

title: Fast, Responsive Memory Cards text: I haven’t used these PNY 16GB ELITE CLASS10 U1 FLASH MEMORY CARDS (2-Pack, up to 85MB/s Read Speed) for long enough to know how reliable they are over time. (Some reviews of other PNY memory cards say that the cards stopped working after a few months.)

However, the memory cards are fine for my purposes, because I only use them to transfer scanned files from my all-in-one wireless printer to my desktop PC. (For some reason, the wireless printer won’t connect wirelessly to the PC, and it’s easier to transfer files via a memory card than to troubleshoot the connection.) Should the memory cards fail unexpectedly--and they haven’t, in my experience--there will be no significant loss of files because I’ll know immediately if my PC can’t read the scanned files.

These memory cards have the advantage of being quite inexpensive (about $10 for two cards on Amazon). They also write very fast, and respond very quickly to file requests.

text: If your getting this, make sure you MB can take it for one, and secondly, make sure you can use a 3pin cpu fan header or get an adaptor for it. Fan control isnt and option at 3pin, so if you dont mind just use the first three pin of the 4 pin cpu header. What this will do is power your cpu fan but at full throttle, the 4th pin is there for auto fan control so if your a perfectionist make sure to get the adapter. Personally, it makes no difference to me.

title: Sturdy and electrically well constructed. text: I am totally impressed with the cable. The outer jacket appears to be tough, but the best thing is both ends are precise fits. I am using a pair of these to extend the distance between powered speakers and surge protector strips on stage.

These can take some abuse being dragged across less than smooth surfaces (although I am not sure about rough-finished concrete or brick). The key, though, is the 25 footers that I purchased do not get hot during prolonged use, and are rated at 125 VAC at 10 Amps. For me the safety factor is important, and I am one hundred percent confident that these are safe in indoors environments.

I am so impressed that I plan to order a pair of 10 and 15 foot cables for times when 25 feet is a bit much.

title: No Setup Required - It Just Works text: I recently purchased a new [Windows] laptop that has a Type C connector, and I selected this unit to get more USB ports as well as the card reader. So far it has worked out well for me and it seems to work as designed, and with no tweaks or software installation required.

This little unit is small and it easily fits in a shirt pocket though the cord does impact the way it fits in said pocket. It’s a little bigger than a comb but smaller than a candy bar. It feels solid and well-made and so far has shown no signs of fatigue or weakness.

I plugged it in and the fit was very snug so I had to work with it to get it plugged in properly. That’s actually a positive – it should not come unplugged unexpectedly when I move my laptop or plug something else into it, a problem I have had on occasion with MicroUSB devices.

Windows recognized it immediately and it didn’t seem to need any extra device drivers or anything to make it work. It picked up the Ethernet interface as well as the USB hub, and that’s really all I would expect before plugging in anything else. The card reader works and I was able to read images off of the card I use in my camera through this device.

I have not yet tried it under Linux but that’s coming shortly. I also have an Android tablet with a Type C port with which I will try this device as well.

I have not yet tried the HDMI adapter. I have a use for it as my laptop actually does not have an HDMI port on-board and I’d like to attach it to my television to stream video.

Would I add anything? I would have liked to see an integrated wireless adapter or a Bluetooth receiver built in, though I have those built in to my system and adding those to this unit would drive up the cost a bit. I would probably make the unit slightly larger too.

So far, this device has been solid for me. It works right out of the box without any setup required – plug it in and you’re ready to go.

title: Solid, Well Made and Very Smooth text: Fishing is one of the activities I have loved ever since I was very young and able to hold a fishing rod. Though I have used several types of fishing reels my personal preference is spinning reels. There are a number of reputable brands available and I have tried several - Lew’s, Quantum, Daiwa, Mitchell’s, Shakespeare and more. Until recently I was unfamiliar with KastKing as a brand and had no experience with their fishing tackle, and in a short time I have come to realize I have been missing something important. I received a Triton 3000 spinning reel for test and evaluation and have been thoroughly pleased with it.

This reel has some heft to it, very solid and tight. It’s more substantial than many reels I have used but it’s also not the largest or heaviest either. In terms of size and weight, it falls in the middle of the pack of reels I have used for freshwater fishing and it’s a bit on the small size compared to many saltwater reels I have used. I have larger hands and the size it about right, but someone with smaller hands might find a smaller size (like the Triton 2000 or 2500) a better match. In terms of assembly, there is nothing loose or flimsy on this reel at all and there is nothing that required tightening or adjustment right out of the box (which has been a problem with some others I have used in the past). Overall, this is a solid and well-assembled reel.

Appearance-wise, this reel is absolutely gorgeous. It is a deep shade of purple, almost black, with chrome and nickel colors on the spool, bail and handle. Appearance is not really all that important but it certainly does add to the package, and this is a reel that you won’t be embarrassed to break out in front of others. It relies on simple elegance, not bright flashy colors to make its statement.

This reel has a good-sized spindle on it and it can hold a good amount of line. I put at least 150 yards of 8-lb test on this reel and there’s a lot of room for more. The spindle is tall, not deep.

Ok, on to the really important stuff - how does this reel perform?

This reel has 10 ball-bearings for forward reeling and the reel is about as smooth and quiet when retrieving as could be. Cheaper reels (cheaper meaning lower quality) tend to grind a little bit when retrieving or they make substantial amounts of noise, and some reels even have a clicker in them to mask the sound when retrieving. Some also feel hollow when retrieving, but the Triton feels solid and smooth without a hint of inferior build quality. As nice as the reeling forward is, one of the most important features in a good reel to me is a zero-reverse clutch and this reel has it down. When engaged, the reel will not reverse even a little and to me this is worth its weight in gold.

One very real issue I have seen with some spinning reels is a poorly shaped bail that interferes with the distance when casting. If the bail is too shallow and does not allow enough clearance to allow the line to fly freely off the spindle, it can seriously impact casting distance. Fortunately, this reel has a very wide bail that has plenty of clearance around the spindle and it does not impact the cast at all. I get very good distance when casting as a result. Instead of concentrating on distance, the angler can instead concentrate on accuracy (and after years of practice I am still working on improving my accuracy).

I tested the drag and am pleased with it as well. When tightening the drag the dial does not get more difficult to turn like on some other reels and the drag gradually makes the spindle harder and harder to turn. It is not a graduated turn, meaning it does not increase in steps so there is essentially a limitless variance in how tight the drag can be adjusted. The dial remains easy to turn all the way through the turning range until it is tightened completely, at which point it just stops.

When reeling, either forward or backward, this reel remains balanced and does not wobble much at all. It is hard to notice wobble when the reel is attached to a rod so I tried something when I had not yet attached the reel to a rod. Holding the reel in one hand by the assembly and giving the handle a good spin, I was able to feel the reel gyrating very slightly but not appreciably. I tried the same with another high-quality reel and it was similar. This is not the case with cheaper reels which may or may not balance.

I love the fact that the reel is mounted on an arm long enough to prevent the bail from whacking me on the knuckles when I retrieve. A reel mounted too close to the rod due to a short arm can have this unpleasant effect and I look for this problem specifically so I can avoid it. I also appreciate that the handle is far enough from the reel body to avoid hitting my hand.

In the box with the reel is a velvety microfiber cloth bag for storage and transport when the reel is not in use. This is the only reel I have ever had that has come with such and it’s a nice touch. The bag is useful for keeping the reel clean and also for keeping supplies with it, like a small container of lubricating oil, an extra spool of line or even an extra lure or two (though this is no substitute for a tackle box).

I am very hard-pressed to find anything to criticize about this reel. It is a solid and well-made, looks great and works like a dream. I believe I have found my new primary reel.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

title: Nice camera but way overpriced
text: Let me start by stating that I received this camera as part of the Vine program. I have used it for almost 2 months now exclusively and this review is based on this. I also own a Canon Rebel (which I used for real photographic ventures like special events, concerts and travel) and a Sony Cyber-shot (which I had be using for more 'quickie' picture taking as it is smaller and I can fit it in my pocket).  Although I found the picture quality far superior with the Fujifilm XF1 than the Sony, the complexity of the Fujifilm along with the high price tag, make it seem like it should be comparable to what I paid for the Rebel. To be honest, the picture quality and the flexibility/lenses of the Rebel far outweigh the Fujifilm XF1. The way I look at it, the XF1 is a really nice point and shoot. If you are looking for a quality, sleek, stylish camera which is a step above the other pocket sized cameras (especially when it comes to low-light picture capability), and you have several $100 to spend, then the investment may be worth it for you. I just think that if you are a true photographer and want to take quality pictures in the $500 price range, then go for an entry level DSLR which will give you the flexibility of interchanging lenses. I am rating this as a 4 star because, honestly, it's a great camera. It's the price, and what you get for it, that has me shaving one star off the rating.

title: 5amp total to share between 5 USB ports text: This is a fairly standard surge protector with 12 outlets with only two of those set apart for the larger adapters. The selling point that it attempts to sell consumers on is the usb ports, including one type-c so this review will concentrate mostly on those ports.

As far as the surge protector portion of this product, the face outward, which means that the longer style chargers that comes with some electronics will not plug in without taking up an extra socket. With only two set farther apart for power adapters, this power strip will not work well for a location with routers, modem, and NAS.

Now on to the USB ports. Five USB ports share a total of Five amps. It means that is the power strip is completely filled, it will only deliver one amp to each port. The type-c port is only useful if that is the only cable you can find because it does not support any fancy features such as quick charging or type-c pd, although it does support up to 3A so some phones may actually consider this "fast charging". Do not expect to replace a true 5-port usb charger with this power strip.

title: A bit of Advice text: The other reviews and the description seem to properly describe this camera. I am writing this review to give you the perspective of someone who started out with film SLR cameras in school, then got a digital 5MP camera and have used that for years and am now finally getting into Digital SLR photography. This is a big step back into the professional circle for me, and I'm anxious to get out to the zoo or to some vacation spot in the mountains to do my professional photography once again. I purchased this camera almost a month ago and my opinion is that it is the best camera ever made under $2,000. This camera has everything you can need.

I want to warn you, get the full set with the lense. This lense sells for almost $400 and is about the best all around lense you can find. Don't go for the cheap models. I wrote a list about this camera that may appear on this page for you to look at, but be sure that you get the ML-L3 wireless remote (for $20, how can you go wrong) and a spare battery (2,000 pictures sounds like a lot, and I haven't needed to recharge in this month that I've had the camera, but remember that when you go on a trip you may forget to recharge and you don't want to get stuck). Also, get a tripod (try the Slik Tripods U9000, I wrote a review of it and I find it to be the best buy around for a light-weight tripod that acts like a much heavier one) and get a carrying case (the jury is still out, I haven't found one that I like, I want one that will hold two cameras, 4 lenses, a large flash and a bunch of accessories).

If you aren't sure if the D70s is worth the money over the D50 or the D70, it is. The improved autofocusing system is much better than the others and the larger LCD is worth all the tea in China! I leave the LCD protector that came with it on and have no problem seeing my pictures, even outside. Although this is a larger camera than the D50, it isn't much of a difference and you will regret going with the cheaper camera.

If your budget was lower, save up and buy this camera. I bought a CoolPix 5000 a few years back and always kicked myself for not going with the D100. Now I've gone with the best camera on the market and I'm perfectly happy. Plus, I have the satisfaction of knowing that none of my friends can show me a better camera (unless they spent $4,000 or more on a D2X or D2H, and none of my friends can afford to do that)!!!

title: Superior Night Vision text: Let's face it. Most crimes happen under the cover of darkness. If your camera doesn't have good night vision, you're wasting your money. This camera does a fantastic job giving you clear and crisp video in low light situations. You'll see every detail and not just shades of grey blobs. With an almost 200ft distance, you'll get the coverage you need to feel safe. This is an important feature if you live on a large lot. Overall, I think this is a great camera. I highly recommend it.

Thanks so much for taking the time to read this review. I hope the information that I've provided helps make your decision a little easier.

title: Installation of the Corsair H80i V2 wasn't easy in this smallish case but the radiator sandwiched between ... text: I received this cooler today and installed it along with two new 140mm front panel case fans.
I have an AMD based system running stock cooling that came with the case and hardware components.
My system temps running stock cooling were way to high, idyling at temps around 45c to 50c and when running
demanding applications temps would shoot way up into the 80's and 90's sometimes causing shutdowns.
I kept remembering statements from AMD advising consumers to keep the down blowing fans installed but I decided
to try a liquid cooling solution out of desperation.

My case is a Corsair Spec 02.
My motherboard is a Asus Sabertooth 990FX R2.0.
The processor is a AMD FX-8320.
The graphics processor is a Sapphire Radeon R9 380.
That AMD FX 8320 runs hot, extremely hot also the NB and SB components on the Asus MB run very hot.
My system temps were way to high, I had to do something.

Installation of the Corsair H80i V2 wasn't easy in this smallish case but the radiator sandwiched between
the two 120mm fans does fit in this case. I followed the manufacturer recommendation and configured both
fans to push air inward into the case. This case has perforated holes in the roof for ventilation and this
allows used air to evacuate out of the case assuming the fans are configured to blow inward which will push
air out those top vents.
The two big 140mm red LED fans I installed in the front panel are configured to pull air inward and I set them
to run at 100% speed (1000 RPM), they are Cougar Red LED's, very high quality fans that move a lot of air
silently.

This Corsair H80i V2 has got to be the best liquid cooler available for smaller cases like mine, it has dropped
my system temps by 20 to 30 degrees C instantly. I am seeing system temps lower than I've ever seen them since
I built the system back in December 2015.

This fridge is rocking my system. Cool is good, the cooler the better when it comes to computer systems. I have
Core Temp 1.0 RC6 installed and it is showing my CPU temps idling at 13C - 15C... That is chill.

Chill is good.

Thanks Corsair, this liquid cooler system is awesome.
Thanks Amazon for the excellent service and thanks UPS for being the most dependable carrier on earth.
My system purrs away at 15C, OMG this is awesome.

title: NOT FOR GAMING!!! text: Initially, I liked the ergonomic design. It put much less pressure on my wrist than the Logitech trackball I've been using for many years. Unfortunately, when I started up World of Warcraft, I noticed the Kensington trackball button mapping software disabled the ability to use more than one button at once. I found the same detriment in Overwatch where multiple buttons often need to be pressed simultaneously. When I contacted the company, they sent me an email. The following is a direct quote from their email:
"Thank you for contacting Kensington Technical Support.

We would like to inform you that these trackballs are designed for basic office use and will not work on gaming applications.

We appreciate your time and patience."

To me, this came across as rather rude. This, coupled with the fact that this very mouse shows up in searches for gaming trackball mouse made me extremely disappointed and, in fact, somewhat angry. I feel Kensington needs to do any or all of the following. 1. Fix the software to make their hardware gaming inclusive. 2. Stop advertising their non-gaming devices as gaming devices (I feel this is blatant false advertising.) 3. Ask customers how they could fix issues rather than giving them a short, curt email to inform us that we, apparently, are idiots for expecting their devices to work as advertised.

Bottom line: I do not recommend buying this product unless all you intend to use it for is emails and youtube.

title: Worked ok for 1 1/2 years, then died text: We bought this Netgear WGR614 router back in March 2006. It installed somewhat easily and except for a little problem with the wireless PC card for the laptop (wouldn't be recognized at first but easily corrected) we had pretty stable use for about a year. Then we began to have connection problems. The connection would get slower and slower until internet pages would just not load, resulting in repeated "page cannot be displayed" errors. Powering down and restarting the router, modem and computer seemed to correct the issue. But as of this morning the router appears to have completely died. Powering down and restarting does nothing, the internet connection cannot be re-established. We can connect the desktop directly to the cable modem but for now the laptop is without connection, making for some unhappy family members here.

As of right now I don't know if we'll be buying another Netgear router & wireless PC card. The life expectancy of Netgear products does not appear to be all that great. Looking at some of the reviews we appear to be quite lucky that we got as much time out of the router as we did. Still I'm not in the mood to be shopping for a new router every 1.5 years or less. Hopefully there is a good router out there that can last at least two years.

title: Works with Linux; Small and Fast text: Crucial is one of the first names that comes to mind when I have needed reliable RAM for my systems in the past. I have a Crucial 500MB SSD in one of my systems and it has served me well over the years so I was interested in this SSD as a back-up option for pictures and data. It has proven to be a fine solution for my needs.

Right up front – yes, it works with Linux right out of the box. I plugged it into my Peppermint Linux system and the kernel immediately recognized the drive and made it available. It was on me to mount the drive, but this was a simple matter and I was able to access the file system and see drive statistics. Obviously it works with Windows so I won’t go into that.

This is a physically small device, slightly less than half the size of a cell phone (iPhone 6s is what I used for comparison). It will easily fit inside the change pocket in my jeans and can tuck just about anywhere. This is a double-edged sword. On one hand it is convenient to have something this small and easy to store, but it is also easy to misplace or even lose. If this stays in your laptop bag or briefcase it should be secure, but if you are in a habit of keeping things in your pockets instead be cautious.

Transfer speeds are good. I have not done benchmarks on this drive but I copied thousands of pictures (average size about 8mb per file, some more and some less) and it was significantly faster than the USB drive I have been using for a while and faster than many of the thumb drives I have been using for backups. I have no complaints.

This is a small and fast drive that just works. It works with Linux which for me is important, and it is small enough to tuck in my camera bag for making backups in the field.

title: Excellent protection, but ... text: I received this as a free review sample. As advertised the protection is excellent. The construction is as well, and you actually can turn it inside out to change the color scheme.

Here is the 'but': this case literally fits the Sound Blaster Roar 2 like a glove (and it is only for the Roar 2 model.) The stretching and pulling required is a bit onerous. I thought it would be a learning curve issue, but each time I use this bag it is as difficult as the last time. Difficult, but not impossible. On the other hand, had this been designed for an easier fit I am not sure the same level of protection would be there.

Also note that this is strictly for transporting the Roar 2. Once it is inserted in this case you cannot access controls. I kind of like that because I do carry my Roar 2 around and appreciate the fact that this will keep it from getting dinged.

One final thing: the top cover does not completely close. There is a gap and there is no zipper. That is why you can turn this inside out.

Bottom line: this provides excellent protection and is well made. On the other hand, there are challenges as I noted above and you will need to weight those into a purchase decision. I do use mine a lot and have a love/hate relationship with it.

title: Fast data storage that's water and magnet proof text: I got this to backup my photos and two movies from a Dell Latitude E6430 running Windows 7 with Service Pack 1.

I did not even have to format the drive. I just inserted it into the SD card reader and began copying. In total I transferred over 7.4 GBs in pictures and movies. On the first transfer, I copied 1.35GB in 1 minute and 42 seconds, which I felt was incredibly fast. The additional transfers were just as fast.

The package says this has a read speed of up to 90MB/s and write speed up to 80MB/s; is water proof, shock proof, magnet proof, temperature proof, and X-ray proof; and comes with a 10-year limited warranty.

For fun, I subjected this memory card to two strong magnets (one magnet is used to find wall studs). I then verified that the data was still there. I also dropped this into a full glass of water, fished it out, dried it off, and then verified that the data was still there. I also played a movie directly from the card and it loaded instantaneously.

It backs up my pictures and movies extremely fast and did not require I format the card and for that I love it.

title: Lightweight and Powerful Tablet
text: This is a very nice little tablet. The touch screen is highly responsive and easy to operate. It comes with a type C charger and cable. I took it out of the box, signed in with my email, and was ready to go in only a few minutes. It's easy to change the settings for things like the volume of notifications, brightness level, and font size. It also features good video reproduction. I'm mainly going to use this as a digital reader and it works perfectly for that purpose. This is a good quality, affordable tablet.

title: Powered by Android!! NOTE: This model did NOT come with browser and FM radio text: Ok, first of all, I want to say I LOVE this player much more than others I've used. My kids are not allowed cell phones in school, but they are allowed music players- however most players that aren't smart devices are really janky with buggy/slow UIs and lots of impairments (I tried encoding a video for one and it wouldn't work unless I used a very archaic codec that required a suspicious Chinese desktop app). This, however, actually runs a stripped down version of Android under the hood. This is a GOOD thing! The UI is very polished and smooth thanks to open source mature OS, and features like video playback are much more robust with a wider variety of formats supported and compatible as a result as well!
The hardware is smooth and the menus are intuitive thanks to being familiar with the Android OS already. It's a very cute device!
So why only 3 stars? Well, the listing claims it has a web browser and FM radio. Both of those things are missing on this model. The truth is, I don't need my kids to have that anyway, but it feels weird that the listing advertises features which aren't there. I think I may have gotten a different model than the one advertised.
I considered side-loading a browser apk since it DOES run android, but the truth is this isn't designed for that sort of use and wouldn't make a difference for the purpose of this review. I'd imagine that there are a lot of possible hacks and modifications possible thanks to the operating system inside if someone wanted to tinker.

title: AWESOME USB to ETHERNET Adapter text: Due to internal components within my laptop I was not achieving the internet speeds I should have been and I finally realized it was due to the Ethernet card built built into my computer. I plugged this device in and I immediately started reaching speeds of 200Mb/s+.

This is a great little device. You simply plug it into a USB 3.0 port, my computer recognized it immediately, plug in your Ethernet cable and watch the lights illuminate to indicate data transfer.

A really nice feature of this device is while you are using one of your computer’s USB 3.0 ports it provides 3 more.

It comes with a nice carrying bag for when you travel.

While many similar devices are constructed of plastic this is made of aluminum and nylon braided cable - this is a device that is made to hold up.

This is an awesome product that I definitely recommend.

title: Good Monitor at a Great Price
text: I purchased this monitor to replace a 19" Gateway HD monitor and I have no regrets. The Gateway didn't have built-in speakers and costed me more than this Viewsonic. I had a Viewsonic several years ago and it was a nice monitor. Sold it to a co-worker when I got the Gateway and she's still using it today. Just sold her the Gateway monitor too when I got my 23" Viewsonic. The speakers aren't the greatest quality, but I don't use my computer to listen to music or watch DVD's. title: Astounding powers........ text: Install this on your compatible motherboard and you will think you have installed the heart of Superman in your computer.
I am in awe of this prodigy of modern computer technology.
Edit:
I've had this processor running in my new build for about a month now. I was being annoyed by the stock cooler fan buzzing at very high rpm whenever the heat rose to moderate levels like 52C. The fan was really buzzing like a little aircraft prop at full throttle for takeoff. It would crank up to 6600 rpm at the slightest provocation like CPU temp hitting 50C.
I decided to take everything apart down to the motherboard coming out and all components attached to it.
When I pulled the cooler off the CPU and looked at the thermal paste situation, OMG what a mess. The stock thermal paste was not covering the whole area, it was reduced to a gummy, sticky glue. I had to pull very hard to get the cooler off the CPU.
I cleaned the cooler base and the CPU thoroughly and applied a pea sized spot of Arctic Silver 5 then reassembled everything.
Instant cure. Instant quieter fan. Instant low CPU temps andQUIET!AMD needs to stop using whatever they're putting on the coolers and just include a syringe of a high quality thermal paste for customers to apply themselves because whatever they're using is junk.
The stock cooler and fan they include with the fx 8320 are very high quality but the pre applied thermal paste is garbage.
Just apply new first quality thermal paste, you don't need to spend big dollars on third party hardware and I suspect those of you who have installed new coolers and seen great results is because of the new thermal paste used during installation.
The fx 8320 is a very powerful processor don't smoke it because of 10 cents worth of cheap thermal paste, use the best for your investment and this hot CPU will give many years of great performance.

title: works mostly as intended, inc 4 aa batt, 2 cords (car and home), details in review text: This charger works. It comes down to preference in style, and perhaps the going price at the time you are shopping around.

Upon arrival, I immediately unpacked this ACDelco battery charger. It comes with 4 AA batteries, and since I didn't see anything on the package about them being precharged, I went ahead and plugged them into my truck adapter. I was curious how well it would do in my truck (with the included car adapter) and since I knew I was running an errand that would take no more than two hours, I figured it was a good time to try it out.

I plugged them in at 2:10 pm, and saw that the batteries were charging as indicated by the red light. When I got back into my truck (I remembered to look!), the time was 3:05, and the battery indicator light was green, telling me that the batteries were fully charged. So this 55 minute charge time (likely less, since I wasn't in the truck whole time) tells me that it charged faster than anticipated, or the batteries had a little bit of charge on them to begin with, which is more apt the case--which is nice when they can be used right out of the package. Either way, it clearly charges and works fine.

(edit to add..) I see in the lower product description that the batteries come charged. Mine weren't fully charged, but I assume half charge (or more), and my charge time just topped them off. So to test this product further, I grabbed a set of drained rechargeable batteries from another brand that I hadn't gotten around to re-charging yet. I mean, I used them but drained them. I hadn't charged them again yet because I don't care for the charger it came with, so I just keep putting it off. I LIKE THIS CHARGING UNIT, and I will explain after details..

DETAILS!
--This charger charges AA and AAA batteries. It comes with 4 AA batteries and two styles of cords 110-volt wall adapter and 12-volt car adapter

-- The cord measurement for each is as follows:
74" wall charger cord
41" car adapter cord

--Charging Time Per Battery Capacity:
AA 1400mAh - 1800mAh: 1.5 - 2 hours
AA 1800mAh - 2300mAh: 2-2.5 hours
AAA 600mAh - 750mAh: 1.5 - 2 hours
AAA 750mAh - 1000mAh: 2-2.5 hours

--So, on the face of the charger on the left hand side, there are two indicator lights: one that glows red as the batteries charge, and one that glows green when charged and ready for use. Easy peasy.

--On the right hand side, there is a switch. It is to be set to either 2 batteries, or 4 batteries (+2, +4). Among the rebels among us, I have no idea what happens if we tried charging three batteries! :O

--Within the battery placement area, the slots are numbered. 1 through 4. I wish there were more clarification on this on the product page because I can no longer find the directions it came with. I am thinking that if just two batteries are being used, and they were placed in #1, #2 slots (or #3,#4) AND the indicator switched was in place for 2 batteries, does the charging juice primarily go to those spot (so as to keep with the quick charge ability)?. I think if just two batteries are being charged, then they go in the center, in the #1 and #2 spots-- so that's my plan going forward. I imagine this information is in the little pamphlet that came with the package. I'll be back if I find it and learn anything.

--The charging batteries at no point has gotten too warm my Energizer one gets pretty warm).

MY THOUGHTS:
--I LOVE that it has the TWO charging cords, with LONG cords. First, I like that it even has a cord, period. I have the Energiizer one that is just plugged into the wall. It seems like it would take up less space, but it doesn't. I find it harder to use as I need perfect clearance to plug that thing in. With this, I just need to find an outlet, then I can have it placed further away, making it easier to see and access. With the addition of the car charger, it just adds another option. Nice for camping (flashlights, radio, etc), or if you still use non cellphone cameras that eat batteries like crazy (this is what originally got me into rechargeable batteries almost 20 years ago, the digital cameras- ugh, I'm old). I sometimes bring a speaker with me for use with smartphone. It takes AA batteries. If I think to actually carry this unit around with me, I can charge my speaker batteries on the go if need be. But I think I will use this primarily in my home. I go through batteries with use of a couple of lighted mirrors. I have one that takes 4AAA and one that takes 4AA. The lights are bright, and I tend to go through batteries- so I make sure to have rechargeables on hand. As mentioned before, I like this unit because it is easier for me to find a place to put it to plug in AND have resting nearby. I had been in need of recharging a set of batteries and just hadn't gotten around to it because I don't care for the inconvenient (to me) charging unit of the other one. It works great, but I just found I prefer to have a cord. This has a cord.

PICTURES include another brand of (depleted) rechargeable AA battery (2000mah) with start time of being placed in charging unit. Product info says AA batteries between 1800mah and 2300mah will take 2-2.5 hours to charge. I put in the batteries at 11:42 am, and at 2:18 pm they were still charging. This would be just over 2.5 hours. I got up to take my dogs outside, and when I came back an hour later, the batteries were fully charged. So, I would plan on anywhere between 2.5-3.5 for a full charge on a depleted set of batteries (from another brand). Since I have yet to fully deplete the ACDelco batteries, I can't test those out until I do.

In summation.. I find nothing wrong with it, it works mostly intended.. If I figure anything else out as I continue to use these, I will be back to update.

title: Turn Your iPhone Into a Natural Point-and-Shoot Camera text: The cameras built into smart phones are getting more and more capable and they have impacted sales of point-and-shoot cameras significantly. I still prefer using a dedicated camera instead of using my phone, and part of the reason is that using my phone doesn't feel the least bit like using a camera. This case changes that and converts your iPhone 6/6s into a camera that actually looks and feels like a dedicated camera in your hands. This is not just a cheap plastic shell with a lens port on it; it actually provides some good protection for the phone.

I will start with the shell case itself. The case is a hard plastic shell, providing back and bumper protection for the phone. It snaps over the phone and holds well. It is not so tight that it is near impossible to remove, nor is it so loose that it runs a risk of letting the phone slip. Overall, it is snug and holds well. The shell itself is a hard, semi-rigid plastic that has a small amount of flex but very little. The bumper guard is a softer material though still quite stiff and it has added material at the corners to give it some extra shock absorption. This is better than the majority of shell cases I have seen and used, and on the shell itself this is a good case.

In the package is everything you need to turn your phone into a point-and-shoot camera: the shell case itself, two grip bases (one hard plastic, one wood), a carry strap, a lanyard, a lens kit and a thumb rest for when you are holding the phone. There is even a small screwdriver so you can change the grips. It requires no other equipment or tools.

I did not understand the purpose of the grips right away, until I removed the base plate from the shell and attached one. It made sense then – the case actually looks and feels like a camera, with a natural groove for your middle finger when holding the phone like a dedicated camera. I of course prefer the wood one, but the black plastic one better matches the shell.

I also was puzzled by the thumb rest (wasn't even sure what it was) until I attached it to the case and held it up. My thumb rested on it naturally and it was actually a little more comfortable than my regular camera.

The case comes with a small lens kit which is made up of a wide angle lens and a macro lens for close-up shots. I experimented with the lenses and took a picture of the field behind my house after a recent snowstorm and it definitely captured a wider view than without the lens in place. I then removed the wide angle lens and used the macro lens to take a picture of a fiber on a blanket, and it did a better job than my dedicated camera with a close-up lens. I have attached both of these pictures with my review.

The one thing this kit does not include is a screen protector. A lot of cases do not have screen protectors and you have to buy them separately anymore. I would suggest using a tempered glass screen protector to get the best possible protection to go along with this case.

This case is enough to make me seriously think about using my phone's camera a lot more. It makes the phone feel like a dedicated camera, it has some thoughtful features and it provides very good bumper, corner and back protection for the phone. Also available for this case are separate add-on lenses like telephoto and fisheye lenses so you can expand the capabilities even more. If you have an iPhone 6/6s, consider getting this case before you buy a separate camera.

Disclosure: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no/minimal cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

title: Never Lose Your Connection with the Ourside World text: This great radio picks up AM and FM stations with clear bright sound. There is a separate National Weather Service station. It runs on regular AA batteries or you can generate power for it by turning a crank. It doesn't take many turns to make it work.

There is a flashlight with bright steady light, or several flashing patterns to summon help. A metal loop on the side allows you to attach it to a belt or backpack with a carabiner or strap. It's made of lightweight but sturdy plastic. There's a power output and a socket for a headphone.

In an emergency, batteries may well run down. Electricity may fail, but you will usually be able to turn a simple crank to keep in touch with news and weather.

title: Much worse performance than the last generation. text: First, I want to say that I am an Amazon fanatic; I am an Amazon Prime member; I have over 4000 Kindle books that I started collecting with the very first Kindle tablet ever put out. I buy everything that I can from Amazon. This is my fourth Kindle tablet.

Let's start from the beginning. It is not thin and light. When you compare this to the Ipad, it does not even come close to being thin and light.

Second, even though I paid for no ads, I am constantly bombarded with ads. It tells me all of the things that I SHOULD LIKE TO BUY. If I wanted to buy the damned things, I would have bought them.

Third, it is incredibly slow. Much slower than the last generation Kindle. It is slow initially loading programs. It is slow going from one program to the next. IT IS JUST BORINGLY SLOW.

There is not enough memory associated with the processor. When I go from one program to the next, even though I can see the program by using the box at the bottom, it still needs to reload the program. When I switch loaded programs with either my Ipad or my Windows 8 HP tablet, it is instantaneous. I can not believe that is this way. Did no one test this?

I think the problem is with the new OS. It is horrible. If I could go back to the old OS. I would do it. If I could just use my old Kindle, dropped for the fourth time, I would.

This is the fourth kindle tablet that I have purchased. It is probably the last. I expect I will be buying Apple products in the future. In fact, I bought an Ipad this morning for my birthday.

I will continue to be an Amazon fanatic. I will never purchase another Kindle tablet.

title: No bubbles BUT lost sensitivity text: I purchased this protector due to the overwhelming positive reports from other verified buyers. I do not like my cell phone's screen being unprotected and now with my first Kindle I feel the same way. The HDX screen is gorgeous and I want a way to keep it as such. This screen protector seemed the answer to my predicament.

This protector is, indeed, extremely simple to 'install'. It takes more time to remove it from its packaging and throw the trash away afterwards than it does to apply the protector itself. Simply line up the cutouts on the protector film with the camera and flash at the top and center of your Kindle and you are done. I found it helpful to guide the film into place by kind of rolling the sides down, guiding them to ensure proper placement. Then just apply a little pressure (basically, run your hand around the edges) to activate the adhesive.

Only the outer black margin of the protector has adhesive to stick it to the border and outer edges of your Kindle, thus leaving the clear center which covers your Kindle's screen loose, or non-sticky. This manufacturing and design approach has both pros and one con I have noticed so far.

Pros:

It allows for lightning fast and super easy installation.

Because of the solid black border, you can accidentally touch the sticky side while installing and lining it up without any fingerprints showing through as with a normal screen protector. This was a bonus to me as these things are always so difficult to install without this happening.

The clear center portion that covers the screen is completely 100% bubble free.

Due to some micro hairs/fibers being on the screen despite having wiped it down prior to installing the protector, I learned that I could remove the protector (lifted up one corner and peeled it halfway back to do a quick swipe with the MF cloth again) and it would re-adhere to the Kindle's surface just as well as it did the first time.

The company claims that, if it should lose its stickiness, the protector can be rinsed/washed and used again. I have yet to need to go this far so I cannot comment on the credit-worthiness of this claim, however from my experiences so far, I can see the possibility of this claim holding up.

I have not noticed any blurring or the rainbow affect the company mentions on its packaging. The screen is crystal clear and appears to not even have a screen protector on it.

Con:

Since the clear center portion does not adhere to the screen, it is allowed to float just above the screen thus reducing the screen sensitivity and requiring more force from either your fingertip or your stylus.

After using my Kindle for a few hours after installation of this screen protector, I have come to the above conclusions. As bad as the con is for me and my preferences, I will leave it on for a few days to give myself a little more time and to see if anything changes. This screen protector ranks very high on my list of desirable protectors (I even searched to see if they make a version for my Droid cell phone) so I am really hoping that the sensitivity issue works itself out soon.

title: NOT suitable for Raspberry Pi text: I have a couple of Raspberry Pi zeros that use the mini HDMI sized plugs. I needed an adapter, so I searched Amazon for a 2 pack, and these even say compatible with Raspberry Pi in the title / description.
I can assure you THEY ARE NOT COMPATIBLE WITH THE RASPBERRY PI. As far as I know, the Pi Zero is the only board that uses this sort of HDMI plug (the others use full sized HDMI), and the angle of this adapter makes it IMPOSSIBLE to connect the DC power input at the same time. You can clearly see in the attached image, the HDMI cable blocks access to the input. If it was angled the other direction, it would work fine but in its current design, it DOES NOT work with any Pi board that I'm aware of.
It does work as an adapter for different hardware - my laptop for example has mini HDMI and my cameras use micro. So maybe I'll keep them around for that, but I'm only giving it 2 stars because I bought it based on the claim it would work for a specific product mentioned in the description, and it most certainly does not.

title: Had to return it due to connectivity issues text: I got this internet radio and tried it for a few weeks. At first I was happy with it - the sound quality is quite good, it seemed pretty easy to set up, and I was able to find my favorite NPR station streams as well as connect to my Pandora stations. But after the first two weeks or so, I started having problems with connectivity.

- I'd come home from work and the thing would be on, not playing, with "error connecting to network" or some similar message flashing on the screen. The best way to solve this seemed to be to turn it off, then turn it back on, and then it would work (for a while).

- While listening, it frequently stops playing in the middle of a song. Then the display says either "Buffering" for a few minutes, or more frequently, will actually say "Connecting" for up to five minutes at a time! This happens, on average, every 4-6 minutes. The thing is, I have a wireless router upstairs on the same floor as the radio (Apple Time Capsule) and the wireless signal is quite strong. The other devices that connect to this router never have a problem with connectivity - devices that include a Roku box, a Chumby, my iPhone, my HP netbook, my Macbook, etc.

The problem with losing connectivity started infrequently but got worse and worse over the past two weeks or so, to the point where I can't really listen to music on it at all anymore. So I'm returning it. Too bad, because in terms of looks, sound, and basic functionality, it had everything I wanted.

I still haven't figured out some of the features of the watch, as they are not obvious.  I got it because it monitors blood pressure and heart rate.  Those functions work well so it serves my purpose.  This is my first smart watch, so I have nothing to compare it to, but I assume there may be better smart watches that are easier to figure out.  Once I learn how to fully use it, I may like it a lot better.  I just think the user interface could have been better and you shouldn't need a cell phone application to do basic time and day settings.  Perhaps you don't, but there is no obvious way to do it directly on the watch.  The free cell phone application that you have to install from the internet also doesn't seem that straightforward to use and I struggled a little with it also.  Watch is lightweight and charges up reasonably fast.  Available in several colors too.

title: GREAT SOLUTION for 2 COMPUTERS SHARING A MONITOR / KEYBOARD / MOUSE text: I added a dedicated desktop as a hub for my security system though I did not want to have to have an entire separate computer station set up - this switch was the perfect answer!

By plugging the HDMI cables from both computers into the corresponding PC 1 and 2 sides (this requires HDMI - one of my computers only had DP so I required an adapter) and running the included USB cables to the same computers I’m able to share the peripheral devices plugged into the front of the switch. All that is required is a simple press of the button on the front.

In addition to sharing a keyboard and mouse there is an additional port that would allow sharing of a USB hub, printer, external hard drive or the like.

The plug requires no external power supply but is powered solely from your computer.

This is an excellent solution that allowed me to avoid duplication of peripheral devices which not only saved me money but also space. This is a great product that I highly recommend.

Thanks for reading my review. I enjoy writing them as I value reading other’s reviews when I’m making a buying decision. I regularly update my reviews to reflect any changes I may discover and to include helpful tips you may need if you purchase the product. I will always make every effort to answer any questions I can as it is my pleasure to help.

title: Inexpensive DAC that is easy to install and performs nicely text: I received this as a free review sample. I actually had a need for one of these because I wanted to run an audio signal out of my Yamaha receiver to an older analog reel-to-reel recorder. The receiver had a toslink out, and the recorder had RCA in. This box was the perfect DAC.

My signals were noise free, but understand that I was not running the analog cable more than a meter. So in that respect I did not have an adequate test of noise characteristics for longer cable runs. Moreover, I did not really use the volume feature. I set it mid way and used controls on the recorder for volume level. However, for my needs this worked perfectly.

The instructions are a little weak, but anyone who knows what a DAC is should be able to connect and use this without them. The power supply is a standard 5V DC at 1 Amp with a center positive connector. I ran it for an extended length of time and it did not overheat (I have learned from experience to test power supplies because of occasional failures and issues.)

Overall, this is a reasonably priced DAC that I found to be easy to use. The performance was what I had hoped, so am pleased with it.

title: Small, Unobtrusive, Motion Sensor text: I have been using SmartHome devices for over 10 years and have watched this category grow and change in incredible ways over that time. Many of the changes have been consumer driven while some have been manufacturer driven.

Consumers have been wanting a reliable outdoor motion sensor for a long time. The design of this motion detector is the most compact and resilient, where it can hold up under covered outdoor conditions. I have had this set up on my covered front porch for the last several weeks without any issue.

While the Amazon listing reads that it detects temperature, luminosity and motion thus far I’ve only been able to get my unit to read luminosity and motion - temperature is not showing whatsoever.

I was able to pair the unit with my SmartThings 3rd Generation Hub immediately with no problems. I opened the original app and went to add a device, as soon as I pulled the plastic battery protector the detector was recognized.

In regards to operating, other than not showing temperature, it is working flawlessly. I have used it as a trigger to turn on my front porch light from dusk till dawn. It easily detects motion from appropriately 20-25 feet away.

I read that there was a better custom handler for this device that could be added to SmartThings but I was unable to locate it. I wish the manufacturer would have either added it to SmartThings or had the handler text within the manual.

Even without the temperature capabilities this is among the best motion detectors I have used. It is a product I would recommend.
