title: Swell briefcase. Works fine with my 13" MBP. text: Now that I'm transitioning to a more corporate world I figured it's about time I get a more "professional"-looking carrying satchel than my Osprey backpack. The only laptops I possess range around thirteen inches, as I find carrying anything heavier than that is far too large to be considered portable.

This briefcase has it all. There are pockets galore; at times I feel there are too many as I keep unzipping the wrong pocket or can't remember in which pocket I put something, so I wish the tags would've been different somehow. Maybe have some lanyards on some or another.

But inside the pockets you get even more pockets and sashes to separate compartments. The material is sturdy and has held up just fine in this insane Chicago spring weather. We've had temperatures ranging from 40-80 in just two weeks, as well as rainy and dry weathers. Chicago, I tell ya!
My 2010 13" MBP fits fine in the main laptop sleeve without sliding around much, and I'm not able to feel much wait on my shoulder from carrying it around all day, along with a couple of books, a Hobonichi planner, and my pencil case.

The main flaw I will say this has is the shoulder strap. It's not easily adjustable, and I still haven't fully figured it out. There is a buckle in the middle on either side--one static, and the other adjustable. But the adjustable buckle doesn't allow the strap easy give, and so I can't for the life of me get it to a comfortable length.
The removable strap is sturdy otherwise.

The other issue is the clasp holding the two handles together. It's not long enough, so instead of closing it with one hand I'm having to use both hands to squeeze the handles together before being able to snap the button together.

All in all, it's a great briefcase usable even with 13" laptops, but the shoulder strap and the handle clasp need better, user-friendly improvements.

title: A Few Wipes and the Dirt is GONE! Amazing!
text: Well, it finally happened. Thanks to 'having some birthdays '(my optometrist's polite way of saying  I'm getting older), two months ago I officially joined millions all over the world and became a wearer of eye glasses!  First time ever for me.  I was shocked how quickly the lenses get dirty!  The first time I went to clean them I was about to use a wet paper towel on them when my husband walked into the room, saw what I was doing and screamed, "NO!!!" before grabbing the towel out of my hand.  lol.  (My poor heart...scared the daylights out of me!)  I then had to listen to a lecture about what to use to clean my glasses, along with a demonstration showing me how to clean them! lolol.  He gets a box of eye glass wipes at the store for $5. and they do work well. But they left kind of a sticky residue on my fingers that I didn't care for. I did a quick check online and learned microfiber cloths do a fantastic job of cleaning glasses and do so without the use of glass cleaner (liquid) or water. I immediately ordered Fiber Promot microfiber cloths and was (still am) amazed and impressed how well they clean my glasses!  And how easy are they to use? Simply wipe the lenses a few times and PRESTO! Clean glasses! That's it. That's all it takes to wipe the dirt away!  But I didn't stop with my glasses....I then wiped down the TVs, my laptop, my Kindle and my cell phone all with the same fabulous results as my glasses!  These cloths do an amazing job and best of all, they do not scratch items they are used on!  I got the 6x7 cloth size (6 cloths included) and they're the perfect size to clean everything I listed above. I put one in my purse as well. They work great, do not cause damage and leave no sticky residue as the other wipes I previously used did.  And they're cheap! Incredibly cheap! You'd think something that works as well as these cloths work and require next to no work to use them would cost  far more than these cost!  These are incredible and do a fantastic job. There is even a 1 year money back guarantee on them, though I doubt the company gets many returns because these are fabulous!  If you wear glasses, you're going to want these cloths. And don't forget, they clean other items as well!

title: Good tablet but not for everyone text: I will preface this review by stating that I am not a graphic artist and I did not buy this tablet for graphic work. I use tablets as an alternative to keyboards and mice as I find them more comfortable.

I am relatively new to working with tablets but I have quickly become very dependent on my Intuos4. I like being able to write instead of type, which is in many ways easier on my hands. When I saw the Bamboo Fun [Pen and Touch], I had to try it. What better way to work with the computer than to use a touch pad and still write like I am holding a pen and writing on paper? I researched it out, watched any demo I could find and made the decision to commit. Though it's a fine tablet and it works as advertised, it does not suit my needs. There are some things I would change with the design, too, which I will discuss below.

The Bamboo Fun [Pen and Touch] is a pleasant-looking device, very thin and taking up a modest amount of desk space. It follows a design look-and-feel of Apple devices, very smooth, simplistic and masking its real potential.

My first observation - the USB cable is a permanently attached cord, which is a design decision that really should be changed. If the cable fails, the tablet fails. Most USB devices have a detachable cable, so I am not sure why Wacom elected to make this device with a permanent cable. I suspect (rather, I hope) that this will change down the road on future versions, but for now it is what it is.

The install did not go well, and I realize I am the exception to the rule. Because I had previously attached and installed drivers for the Intuos4, I uninstalled the drivers before trying to attach the Bamboo. The uninstall did not work as I expected, as Windows loaded up drivers without hitting the installation media when I plugged it in. As a result, the touch portion of the pad allowed me to move the cursor but tapping and dragging did not work at all. I ended up uninstalling and reinstalling the tablet, and on the second attempt it installed properly. The tutorial loaded and I was able to practice some of the new hand gestures available to me.

Most intriguing of the features available is the ability to use two fingers on the pad simultaneously to zoom in and out and to rotate images, but there is a catch - it is application-dependent and does not work the same with different applications. Also, at one point I tried to scroll and I got a zoom action instead.

Digging deeper, I discovered that the device simply maps the hand gestures to the same events that would be associated with a good mouse and in fact the documentation suggests making sure the actions that would be associated with mice should be mapped the same as if using a mouse instead of the tablet. In a nutshell, this tablet is a glorified laptop touchpad with scroll wheel events mapped in. Properly mapped, this tablet performs very well.

As I worked with the touch portion of the Bamboo, I had some trouble with the two-finger gestures. I closed a lot of Windows inadvertently and the events were not mapped uniformly (as mentioned above). However, the most frustration came because of the way I rest my hands on the desk (which affects the way I rest my hands on the tablet). I found I frequently would have more than two fingers on the tablet simultaneously just because of the way I rest my hands, and as a result I was working against myself with this tablet. Also, because I would hold the pen while trying to use the touch features, the pen would disable touch and I would get nothing.

Using the pen with this tablet worked as expected. It has 1024 pressure levels, which is fine for the average user like me or someone who is a little more creative. Wacom offers more sensitive tablets with more pressure sensitivity which is more in line with professional artists' needs. That said, I can see the difference when doodling with the pressure levels. Some upgrading from a simpler tablet will be thrilled; someone downgrading from a more sensitive tablet will be unhappy.

I uninstalled the Bamboo and went back to the Intuos. Most of the problems I had with the Bamboo are personal preference, though some of the issues are design related.

This really is a good tablet and I can recommend it to people who want to completely get rid of mice and other pointing devices. There are a lot of good features in this tablet and it works as advertised. Unfortunately in my case, it did not suit my needs.

title: Does what it says, as long as you understand this is a USB2.0 cable text: This is not a fast cable. But it tells you that right away, so anyone expecting a USB 3.0 speed adapter should have read the description and gone elsewhere.

I have some older things that rely on standard USB-A charging cables, so I needed one of these to supplement the available ports. It works perfectly, and delivers the standard USB port power I needed. It can also plug into your phone or tablet to give you a standard USB host port, but just understand you will be limited to the older (but still very good) USB 2.0 standard. That's fine for most things, but if you're copying files from USB storage to your Macbook's thunderbolt port, you might want to get at least a USB3 speed adapter.

title: Works like it should, quality product, 3 gripes text: So the range works, very few false alarms.

Receiver unit doesn't have a rechargeable battery backup. This would have been nice to carry it to the gate for testing so that you can hear it go off when the sensor is tripped. Also if power goes out, you can still hear the chime. I have a plug in outlet in my truck as well as an inverter and a portable electric battery with 110v capability, just would have been nice for those without.
Programming the transmitter/receiver with dipswitches is a bit of headache especially getting the cover off the reciever. Should have just been exposed on the underside rather than have to pull apart the plastic housing. Maybe some sort of phillips head rotatable dipswitch settings. I do like the versitility of the current setup thought to prevent collisions with other systems.

Like the mounts, especially the swivel mount for gate post adjustments so that windy day swinging gates don't trip the sensor.

title: Well designed and easy to install and configure text: Through no fault of this excellent product I was only able to use it for a week - I inherited an old Lexmark Z11 inkjet that I wanted to share between two laptops in my corporate apartment, but wound up replacing the Lexmark with an USB-only printer.
What makes this such an excellent product is the ease of installation and the fact that it flawlessly works. Installing it consisted of attaching the device directly to the printer's parallel interface, connecting an Ethernet cable to the RJ-45 port on the other side of the print server, running the CD ROM installation and being able to immediately print to a shared printer.
One of the things I most like is the installation and configuration utility that ships with this device. You get an administration program (you can also access and administer the print server through a browser or through a telnet session), and an "add printer" wizard that makes configuring other computers on your network easy. In fact, the "add printer" wizard is a quantum improvement over D-Link's earlier Pocket Print Server products - I own an older model and set-up and configuration was somewhat confusing, which is no longer the case with their newer software. I also link the small power supply, which takes up little space in a power strip or on an UPS.
Overall, this is a high quality product that has a plethora of features (it supports Windows networking, AppleTalk and TCP/IP, and it can be managed via browser of by using TCP/IP telnet), and can be installed and configured by a novice.

title: New sheriff in town text: Prior to Alesis coming up with this and its larger sibling, the [[ASIN:B005NIVLX4 Alesis Mic Tube Duo Stereo Tube Microphone Preamplifier]], I was sold on the venerable [[ASIN:B0002D0KG4 PreSonus Tubepre Single-Channel Vacuum Tube Mic Pre]] as the "gold standard" in lower end tube microphone tube amps. I personally think this and the 2-channel model that Alesis offers are game changers, mainly because the features and reliability are on par with the PreSonus competing products, and the price point is significantly less. In other words, bang for your buck.

Before rushing out and getting one of these (or its larger sibling - or even the competing PreSonus), make sure you need it. I have found that on a reasonably decent PA system this product makes a dramatic difference with the older technology mics like [[ASIN:B000CZ0R3S Shure SM57 Microphone]] and the [[ASIN:B000CZ0R42 Shure SM58-LC Cardioid Vocal Microphone without Cable]], or the lower end SM58 clones that are bundled with PA systems and otherwise flood the market (the [[ASIN:B00009W40D NADY SP-4C Dynamic Microphone]] comes to mind). On the other hand, not only have I found that these tube pre-amps not very useful with more modern design microphones like the [[ASIN:B002SQJL9U Blue Microphones enCORE 100 Studio-Grade Dynamic Performance Microphone]], the [[ASIN:B00006I5R7 Sennheiser E835 Dynamic Cardioid Microphone]], etc. In fact, with the more modern designed microphones, which run much hotter in signal, a pre-amp in a live PA needs to have the gain turned to the lowest level in many cases or feedback becomes a problem.

If you do need one of these devices, I recommend - unless your budget is severely limited - that you consider the [[ASIN:B005NIVLX4 Alesis Mic Tube Duo Stereo Tube Microphone Preamplifier]] instead. The reason is for a slight increase in price you get an extra channel that you may not need now, but may find to be a requirement in the future.

title: solar charge actually works, good assortment of features, text: [[VIDEOID:17a58332b933800fe99b76e58398768d]] We have a few of these emergency radios. I am the main prepper in the household, but even my husband bought one at random recently. He showed me his, then I showed him mine. Then I got this one to add to the collection. Different brands, all very similar. The one feature that STANDS OUT to me on this FORTECLEAR is that there is a light that indicates that it is being charged. I can see it glow brighter when using the hand crank, as well as when I have it sitting in a ray of sunshine. If in the sun with the light glowing, once I cover the solar panel with my hand, the indicator turns off. Really nice to see that working. Like others, there is also an indicator that shows about what percent of power is has (25%, 50%, 75%, 100%) which will light up when it is being actively used. Really nice to be able to see this important info. For that I recommend this as an emergency item (or even casual use, why not?)

Has typical features such as flashlight (low beam, high beam, and flashing), has a flip up "reading" light, and radio bands such as alert, WB, FM, and AM. Nice long antennae, knob tuning, knob volume control. USB port, USB C port, comes with a cord & instructions, wrist strap, has SOS alarm- which requires pressing for a couple of seconds to activate, SO much better than another where I have accidentally triggered it by a simple short press. Scared myself. LOL. SO LOUD.

When looking for weather band, you may need to walk around to get a signal. I find this true of all emergency radios, or any radio with WB/NOLA option. As with most all other radios, FM comes in the best, the easiest.

I am a big fan of having multiple options for lighting- whether it be solar, battery operated, internal battery that can be charged, etc. This has the ability to be charged, to be hand cranked, and to be solar charged. Nice to have a few options in one device. I also keep regular flashlights, rechargeable flashlights, battery powered radios, etc on hand. Multiple options for when it is needed. But this will be one I will rely on. I would get it again, and I would get this for someone else. I tend to give functional gifts, stuff that most folks dont want to buy for themselves (preps, fire extinguishers, smoke alarms, car care kits, etc), and this would be a good one to give. Really pleased that it works so well because it happens to be a few bucks more than most options out there.

I will continue to play around with this. If I think of anything else, or experience anything else (good or bad) I will be sure to come back to update. So far so good!

title: If you need to connect HDMI to AV composite or expand AV composite to HDMI this is a good solution text: I received this as a free review sample. Note that this only accepts HDMI as an input and converts that signal composite RCA out. It cannot go in the opposite direction (connecting composite RCA devices to HDMI).

For me this is a great way to add an additional HDMI port to a monitor I own that has a single HDMI and a single set of AV composite ports. I can also use this on an older TV that has HDMI and a dual set of AV composite ports. I did test this using a Blu-Ray player on the HDMI and to the TV and it worked beautifully as long as you do not set your video resolution to be higher than 1080p for Blu-Ray, but will support ancient 640x480 all the way up to 1920x1080.It also supports 480i or 480p up to the 1080p I mentioned above. Of course, if you are using this to add HDMI to older display devices you are probably going to be limited in resolution anyway.

Then converter itself is small, hassle-free and does not require any external power. For expanding to an additional HDMI port on a TV or monitor with a spare set of AV composite ports, or connecting HDMI devices to legacy equipment that only has AV composite input this is an inexpensive solution.

title: A Heftier, More "Substantial" Stylus text: Capacitive styluses are not all alike. Besides color, there are subtle differences in sensitivity, length, barrel size, weight, and attachment clips or lanyards. This Targus stylus, which is 4.75" long (exclusive of the capacitive tip) is quite a good one, in terms of sensitivity. Screens slide with minimal pressure, and selections register with only a light touch or tap.

Compared to other styluses that I tested, the Targus stylus is the longest, has the widest barrel, and is the heaviest. The weight makes it tiring for me to use, but some individuals (men, perhaps?) may prefer a heftier, more "substantial" stylus like this one. Because of the wider barrel, the tip is also wider, which makes it slightly less accurate for selecting small targets (e.g., links displayed in web browsers in tiny fonts). The extra length is a plus, if you hold a stylus like a pointer (away from the tip), rather than like a pencil (close to the tip).

This stylus has both a pocket clip and a metal attachment "loop" (for attaching to a lanyard or keychain). I purchased mine at a local office supplies store. Besides this stylus, I tested the [[ASIN:B005O2URES MiniSuit Universal Capacitive Stylus Pen]], the [[ASIN:B0008G3ID2 BoxWave Capacitive Kindle Fire Stylus]], and the [[ASIN:B004GCJEZU AmazonBasics Stylus for Touchscreen Devices]]. My favorite is the AmazonBasics Stylus, because of its 4.25 " length, slim barrel, light weight, and excellent sensitivity. I rate this stylus at 4 stars ("I like it") rather than 5 stars ("I love it"), because I like the AmazonBasics stylus slightly better.

In case you're wondering, as I was, what a "capacitive" stylus is, it is a human interface device (e.g., a mouse) that uses "capacitive sensing" to measure changes of position on a touchscreen. It works just like a human finger on a touchscreen device, and you can often get more accurate navigation using a stylus. Wikipedia has good articles on capacitive sensing and capacitive devices.

When plugged in it did receive power, but repeatedly tried and failed to recognize the disc. It was not recognized on my laptop, and all of the suggested troubleshooting methods yielded no results. title: Sleek, stylish, and incredible sound! text: My first Bluetooth speaker was the Bose Soundlink; I then transitioned to a smaller, more portable Braven LUX. As an audiophile, when I was offered the opportunity to test drive the RIVA Turbo X, I jumped at it. The first thing I noticed right off the bat is the WEIGHT; the speaker clocks in at nearly 6 pounds (compared to the lightweight Braven, or the slightly heftier Soundlink). It's also designed like a sportscar, with a glossy black finish with red rubber accents covering access ports. The top contains streamlined buttons for Power, Surround, Bluetooth pairing, mute, up and down volume, and Turbo mode. There's also an iOS app that allows you to control the surround and turbo settings directly from your phone.

I appreciated the quick start guide handily attached to the top of the speaker; it recommends that you play the speaker at 50% volume for several hours to break them in. It comes out of the box partially charged (around 40%) meaning you can start using it immediately (which I did using David Garret's new "Explosive" album). The sound balance is fantastic; as I live in an apartment, unfortunately I'm not able to really take advantage of the Turbo mode (which boosts to over 100dB). Pairing was a snap and I was off and running. As soon as I synched with my iPad, I was prompted to download the "Ground Control" app (which as previously mentioned, gives you battery life stats, volume, and the ability to turn on surround and Turbo modes).

It also comes loaded with extras in the form of RCA cables, male-to-male audio cables, and it's also capable of charging other devices. The battery is recharged via AC (the life is around 26 hours); no USB option here. The touch buttons on top illuminate when you hold your hand over it, which is a fantastic feature in a dark room or if you're using this outside.

The sound is fantastic with just about every genre I threw at it, from Baroque opera vocals to instrumentals to EDM.

This is a serious investment that not only looks fantastic, but sounds absolutely fantastic...and my Bose Soundlink is going in the closet. If you're looking for maximum power with no trade in sound quality (especially at higher volume levels), the Riva TurboX is the way to go.

title: Pretty slow, even for USB2 text: I wasn't expecting this to be a speed demon, it says right on the box USB2 so I knew I wasn't going to get the 150+MB/s level speeds I get with some of my thumb drives. But even for USB2, this is on the slow side. Plugging in a standard sandisk drive to my USB2 port, I'm able to pull over 40MB/s without breaking a sweat. This one? Even on a USB3 port, I'm only able to pull a bit over 18MB/s in read, and the writing is even more abysmal. That's less than half of what USB2 can pull.
For the money, this is a decent delivery platform for you to hand off large files to someone, or perhaps to play media on a USB TV or something like that. But for regular daily transfer of data, you might find this painfully slow. As you can see in the benchmark screenshot attached, it timed out for the last two write tests and never even finished.

title: Great for adapting HDMI out for professional runs text: This is a great tool for those who need to use prosumer equipment in more professional environments. HDMI is great at what it does, but it has limitations. Long cable runs and many professional live hubs and recorders require the more robust SDI cable format. I've found myself working live camera feeds, etc, more than once with prosumer grade cameras and laptops that needed to interface with our SDI equipment. Having these available means I can use SDI outputs even if my source doesn't have an SDI port. And while at first I wanted to remove a star for the lack of a proper power adapter (it just comes with a USB plug), I realize now this is a blessing. If I want to run it off a laptop, I have a power supply immediately available without another wall plug. If I need a wall plug, any standard USB charger will do, and those are plentiful.
Solid metal body seems durable, kudos to Amazon Basics for offering a good alternative for such a useful tool.

Also, there are lines in the whiteboard where it fits together (it's not a mat that rolls out or a solid board, it's several solid boards that fit together).  So overall, it didn't work for my purposes and I got a different brand. title: Sleek design, nifty tech, and terrific sound quality... text: Replacing my altec lansing speakers from the early 2000's. Honestly, I'm not an audiophile. My altec speakers were pretty good speakers too, and I can't tell the difference. My upgrade is simply cosmetics. This logitech set is black and sleek, looks more modern. My altec speakers were grayish, very early 2000's design.

I like the nifty wireless controller that looks like a little echo dot, but it's smaller. So coming from speakers in the early 2000's, my first question was.. Can this function like old school speakers if I don't care for all the tech? So I simply used the 3.5mm connection method from my dell to the logitech, but there was NO SOUND. So you have to at least power up the wireless controller for the first time. Because under the controller is a button to switch from bluetooth to wired. Press the WIRE option, and you will then get audio. After this, if you remove the batteries and take away the wireless controller, the speakers will continue to work as 3.5mm connected speaker. You just have to turn on the wireless controller on the initial set-up. So this is good. My concern was what if the wireless controller is lost or damaged? If that happens, then you would like the speakers to go on like old school speakers connected simply by 3.5mm. So I'm happy to report, this will function without the wireless controller module. I'm not even sure turning on the wireless controller in the initial set-up is absolutely required. Your PC my pick-up sound the moment you plug in the 3.5mm jack. For me, I had to turn on the wireless controller during the initial set-up.

Another thing I wondered is if I connect a bluetooth device, say my smartphone, to these speakers, then disconnect, will the speakers automatically revert back to wired? The answer is no. To connect to a bluetooth device, you have to press the bluetooth pairing button under the wireless controller, and it will stay in this mode even after you disconnect. You have to press the "wire" button to get back to 3.5mm.

One more thing, the left and right speakers have 2 slots in the back to insert the stand. So you can configure it to stand vertically or horizontally. Conclusion... I love the sound, the sleek design and the technology. 5-Stars.

title: Well-Balanced System for Business and Gaming Use text: The majority of Ultrabook computers on the market right now are ill-suited for the gamer, concentrating very heavily instead on the business user. With this particular Ultrabook, Dell has found a balance between the two groups and has produced a system that does well both as a business workhorse and a middle-of-the-pack gaming rig, at a very reasonable price point. I can think of a few relatively minor changes I would make to this system to make it even more attractive but that would mean increasing the cost.

Right out of the box, this computer feels very well constructed. The lid is brushed aluminum and does not flex like that of some other systems I have used in the past and that's reassurance that the screen will face less stress from being flexed. The hinge is nice and tight too, and from what I can ascertain so far it should hold up for a very long time. The overall system has a little bit of heft to it as well, feeling quite solid. I personally prefer a system that feels rugged, even if it weighs just a little more.

At its thickest this system is roughly an inch. This is great - it fits beautifully in my computer bag and leaves room for papers and folders with it in the same bag. This is a minor point, particularly if the user is going to leave this system on the desk all the time, but I find it to be a positive trait. Other systems I have used have been a snug fit in the bag and require a little more planning when packing for use on the go.

When first powered on the system walks the user through the setup process, eventually landing at the Windows 8.1 Metro interface. A quick check confirmed that Windows 8.1 Update is *not* installed by default, and this actually came as a surprise. Microsoft has made it clear that the update will be required in order to get any further updates, so I would have thought it would have been part of the configuration already as this system has very recently come to market). I pulled it down from Windows Update and it installed without a hitch.

One of the first things I did with this system was to build recovery media. Dell won big points with me on this - while most (if not all) other manufacturers seem to be going towards creating USB-based recovery images (and many rely on the built-in Windows 8 recovery media creation tool), Dell still allows the user to create DVD recovery media. I made two sets. The utility that Dell provides is just as simple and smooth as can be, was easy to find and worked without a problem. This is exactly the kind of experience most users should expect, regardless of manufacturer.

This is an Ultrabook-class system and as such there are certain things to keep in mind. First and foremost, this system has no CD/DVD/Blu-Ray drive of any kind. Having an optical media drive on an Ultrabook is rare so this is not a shortcoming per se, but it does mean that users need to have an external DVD drive in order to work with any platters in this system. This is inconvenient but it's the norm for Ultrabooks. Also, this system has only three USB ports, a HDMI out port, an SD card reader and no VGA out (which isn't any surprise actually). Some Ultrabooks do not have an Ethernet port and rely solely on the wireless network adapter, but this one does include an Ethernet port.

Dell makes a point to extol the virtues of their touch screen, and so far I have found the screen to be above average. The resolution is 1920x1080 which makes for very clear, crisp images but it also means that print is very small at maximum resolution. I will likely lower the resolution slightly which will make everything a little bigger and easier to see, but some people likely will especially like the ability to cram so much more on the screen. The screen is very bright, too, and my particular screen has absolutely no dead pixels. The important feature of this screen is the ability of it to receive and process touch and gesture events. It is very responsive and so far has given me no difficulties except that my fingers are a bit large and sometimes I touch something next to what I want on the screen.

Typical notebooks and Ultrabooks available come with 8GB of RAM. This one comes with 16GB which is great for those running multiple applications simultaneously or are running virtual machines. I was a little puzzled, though, by the "DDR3L" type which I had not seen prior. It turns out that DDR3L is a low-voltage variant of DDR3.

The hard drive in this system is a generous 1TB hybrid drive, which means it is partially SSD and partially traditional platter-based. The idea behind this type of drive is to put the bootable OS on the SSD portion and everything else on the platters. I see some advantage to this and the system boots up in a reasonable amount of time but I don't see this system coming to a ready state nearly as fast as systems with a straight SSD. Also, this drive is a 5400-RPM drive which is slow by today's measure. I personally would prefer to have less space and have a purely SSD in the system, but that would drive up the cost a bit.

There are two graphics controllers in this system. One of them is the Intel HD4000 controller which is part of the Core i7 chipset. The other is an ATi Radeon R7 M265, sporting 2GB of display RAM. This second adapter is what allows this system to run more graphically intensive games, though it is not a high-end controller and struggles to render the top new titles at maximum resolution. As a test I had my teenage son load up a 1st-person shooter he likes and he was favorably impressed with the ability of the system to keep up with it. I also loaded up a drawing application with complex artistic brushes and tried to overwhelm the system. While the system lagged behind when I pushed hard enough, it kept up admirably well.

One of the features generally pushed with Ultrabooks is battery life - lower power consumption and only necessary components should extend the run time on battery power. I have found the run time to be roughly 3 to 3.5 hours which is a little low. There are a few contributing factors to this that I think can be partially overcome. First, the system has a backlit keyboard that is on by default. This lighting can be turned off and this will help. Also, the default power scheme has the screen brightness up a little higher than expected in energy conservation settings, so lowering the screen brightness is a good option as well. However, the hard drive is a traditional platter-based drive. If replaced with a SSD instead the power consumption could be improved even more.

Dell touts their sound system on this Ultrabook as being something special. Using just the speakers this is not obvious as the speakers are only average. However, when the system is used with headphones the difference becomes very apparent and it is clear that Dell put some thought and effort into the sound system. The default sound profile is good - very crisp highs, warm midrange and full bass, all suitable for gaming. The sound profile can be changed to another pre-defined selection by selecting a menu option on a Dell-supplied utility, making the sound system very flexible. This is a bit unusual for a system - I am used to this for individual applications. With such effort put into the sound system in this computer it is puzzling that Dell chose mediocre speakers.

This particular system comes with facial recognition software that is supposed to make logging in easier. I did not like it one bit - the software seemed to have trouble recognizing my face and would not allow me to log in, even with the correct password. I uninstalled it when I finally got logged in.

As I write this, this computer retails for about $1,150 (though is a hair less expensive here on Amazon). Considering the feature set, this is a very reasonable asking price. I can think of a few improvements to the system, such as better speakers and a SSD instead of a traditional hard drive but adding these in would increase the cost of manufacture and would therefore increase the end-user cost as well.

Dell has put together a nice system that finds a good balance between business uses and gaming. There are systems better suited to gaming available but these typically come at a higher cost. It has a nice touchscreen, good sound and generous storage. The ATi graphics adapter makes the gaming experience not only possible but pleasant. Other than a few smaller point this is a solid and well-designed system that is worth a look if you want a system that can handle most functions without argument, all worth its asking price.

He's very pleased and eager to complete some projects with it. There are many different parts inside, all are labeled. As it's been mentioned, more comprehensive information is available by sending an e-mail. This is all fine by me, as I'm really looking for some supplemental educational materials since we have no choice currently than to home-school. I suppose if we must home-school, we can make it as fun as possible and do some projects that are more true to real life and sourcing material and information just as any adult must do to learn a new skill on their own.

As there are a variety of components, I can easily imagine this would be great for modifications or repairs as well. It's a good value for the price as far as I can determine doing comparisons, so I would certainly repeat the order if more of the same components are needed in the future.

Thanks for reading my review. I hope you found it helpful.

title: Good product, on the small side text: I got this for my teenaged son to use on his gaming PC. He had actually broken his previous gaming headphones and this seemed like a no-frills decent replacement for him to try.
The sound quality is actually quite good. Both the ear pieces and the microphone are crisp and clear, so no complaints there. However my son found it a little uncomfortable to wear compared to his larger over-the-ear style headphones before. The actual ear parts on this are smaller, which means they don't fully envelop your ears the way other ones do. On the plus side, this means it doesn't block as much external noise, which I like for him in our household (no more calling his name when he can't us!), but others may want more noise isolation. Also, the smaller ear pieces aren't as comfortable when worn as the larger ones.
I also didn't like that it didn't come with an adapter to break out for mic and speakers like other headsets do. I thought it would come with that as an option, as I've never gotten a PC headset that didn't offer either a splitter or TRRS combo adapter so you can use it with both a laptop that has mic/headphone combos as well as separate mic and headphone jacks commonly found on a desktop.
Thankfully I had an extra one lying around for him to use, so that wasn't an issue. But something to take into consideration. Others, I've got to give it at least 4 stars for working well and doing what it should. But there might be other options for the price worth considering as well if you want larger earphones or a breakout cable included.

title: Amazing little card
text: I bought this card for use with my new Canon ([[ASIN:B005MTMFHU Canon SX40 HS 12.1MP Digital Camera with 35x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 2.7-Inch Vari-Angle Wide LCD]]). I traveled to Germany and Amsterdam August 17-26 and wanted to ensure I had enough space for any pictures I wanted to take. I took my laptop along to transfer pictures over for safe keeping in case I accidentally deleted while learning to use the new camera. Turned out that this card was more than enough storage! Over the course of my ten day trip, I took over 2000 pictures and the display on the camera today says I have room for 7056 more pictures still. Simply amazing. AT the time of my purchase, the item title stated that this card was a 30MB/s speed and the description stated that it was 45MB/s. I wanted the 45MB/s so I contacted live chat and the representative confirmed that the title needed to be updated to reflect the correct specifications for the item. I am glad to see that Amazon is on their game as the title has now been updated less than two weeks later. I highly recommend this card to anyone who needs a SDHC card for everyday/travel photography needs!

title: Stand Holds iPad Securely at Many Comfortable Viewing Angles text: This BEANPAD FOR iPAD is an absolutely great iPad 2 stand (and I've tested several). First, it's nearly impossible to knock over or drop. Second, it can be set to almost any comfortable viewing angle. And third, it securely supports your iPad pretty much anywhere you can set it down.

To use this stand, you insert your iPad (2 or 3) into the black, hard plastic holder. The holder grips firmly but gently, and easily releases the iPad whenever you like. With the iPad in the holder, the beanbag conforms to any surface (a knee, a table, a desktop, a chair arm), and makes a secure base so that the stand cannot suddenly collapse. The black beanbag is about the size of a large cantaloupe, and is just heavy enough that it cannot be easily knocked over or knocked off a table.

The stand's viewing angle can be adjusted to an almost limitless number of positions. The holder itself can be rotated so that the iPad is held in a vertical or horizontal position. Then the actual viewing angle can be adjusted by squishing the beanbag to find the most comfortable viewing position.

I purchased my first BEANPAD FOR iPAD from Woot! for the bargain price of $25 (including shipping). But when my husband needed an iPad, too, I purchased a second BEANPAD FOR iPAD (this one) for him at full price, because it allows the iPad to be used comfortably just about anywhere in the house.

title: If you live in a valley surrounded by mountains where at best you have a fuzzy cell phone use text: We bought two of these in December 2015. Hooked each camera up. Downloaded the online app. Put in a memory card. Turned on our iPads, Phones, and Apples. Presto we could see every point inside our home should our exterior camera system connected to the home security device ever fail.

We travel 140 miles West to our 2nd home and watch inside our home, while driving whoever is not at the wheel will pull up the home-cam so we can see what is happening on our cell phones. We went to Vegas, a few months ago and hired a dog sitter to stay with our beloved pet at our home. We were able to check-in & from our hotel room, Freemont Street or the Strip and check on our home without any problems.

Unless you are still operating in the AOL age or have so many firewalls up the smoke detectors keep going off inside your home; I can't see why the product would not work for a person needing a quick install. The type of one they control that is portable enough to move from room to room, (even a window seal).

If you live in a valley surrounded by mountains where at best you have a fuzzy cell phone use, you may want to get the kind of cams able to be through DSL if possible. Personally, if you are using the most current technologies, keep you system updates performed and no longer have to type www after the dial tone stops screeching, can read and follow directions; then you should be able to follow the instructions and if necessary work with a customer service technician associated with this item.

By the way, it is not just your computer that needs updates if you no longer use brick phones. If you have advanced enough to be no longer paying for minutes, but rather have plans permitting you unlimited use of services through "unlimited data" plans (this includes calls too,) within the lower 48 and depending how fast you can drive into and out of Mexico, you will have excellent service.

title: Convenient, but needs careful handling text: We bought this as a gift for our son, to keep him occupied on long car trips, and while traveling. It is compact and light enough to tote around without breaking your shoulder, and comes with accessories for playing in the car, an AC cable, and also has a rechargeable battery for wireless viewing anywhere. It even comes with a remote (but not a pretty one)

For adults this is a great little gadget - it never gets into a snit over bumpy roads or potholes, and with your headphones on, it can give you hours of viewing when you’d rather be alone. The screen even swivels around for the best possible picture in cramped situations.

For kids however, there are some things you should note:

1. The silver finish gets scratched and dirty quickly

2. The power is controlled by a slider button which doesn’t feel as sturdy as it should – ditto the button to open the section where the DVD goes

3. The button to open the player is right in front where little hands can accidentally press it while in use.

4. On the right hand side, there’s a button to choose the DVD format. This often slides to the other side when taking it out of the case, and fools you into thinking that the player isn’t working.

5. Our video display stopped working on Day 2, until we reset it by unplugging the player without turning it off and then plugging it in again.

6. The control buttons on the player itself are not very user friendly, and I still have no idea what some of them do, but I haven’t needed to use them so far anyway.

7. You can’t play old or scratched discs, as these will damage the player. (I don’t know about you, but most of my kid’s DVDs are scratched and battered)

Picture quality and sound are good, as is portability. Overall, this is a very convenient DVD player for traveling or commuting, but one that requires care and attention to work properly.

Amanda Richards, March 1, 2006

title: Great bluetooth headphones, poor fit text: These headphones are great in every aspect except for comfort. They're the behind-the-head style that's oh-so-popular these days, but the fit is far worse than the comfortable (but breakage-prone) Logitech Wireless Headphones for iPod that I had before. These pair easily with my bluetooth-enabled Thinkpad, which is nice, and also with my phone (at the same time) so I can take calls and it will switch from the music, then switch back when my call is over. The built-in mic works surprisingly well, for a really hassle-free bluetooth experience.

Now for the bad: I feel like these headphones were designed for kids. They're so small (I was really shocked when I opened the packaging at how small they are) that they pinch my ears hard. The headband just simply isn't big enough for a normal-sized head. Another minor thing is that they have a mind of their own when you put them down. If you sit them down with the earpieces facing up (which you invariably will when you have to take your hourly break from the pain they cause), they "walk" themselves off of the desk if you put them down the wrong way.

title: Acceptable for portable storage, will probably not cut it for PS5. text: The Centon Premium SSD at 1TB is priced higher than even the WD_Black while claiming faster speeds. Before I get into my conclusions, I need to say that I'm only testing this drive through a USB enclosure so the conditions aren't optimal, but my conclusion about this drive is in comparison to another drive that I test through the same enclosure, meaning all conditions are the same between the three drives.

I had two other drives that I was able to performance test against this Centon drive. The first is a [[ASIN:B09575SWX5 Pioneer NVMe]] drive at 256GB and the second is a [[ASIN:‎B08695D3VW Klevv NVMe]] drive at 512GB. All three drives were placed inside a USB drive enclosure and connected via a Type-C cable capable of video transfer (meaning it's made for data transfer, not just charging).

Because I'm only testing through USB 3.1, I'm not expecting to reach advertised speeds but using the relative performance between the three drives under the same conditions, I can make some conclusions. The Pioneer drive is advertised at speeds of up to 2,100/1,600 MB/s and in my setup, I was able to reach 1,041/937 MB/s which is quite impressive. On to the Klevv drive: it is advertised at speeds of up to 2,050/1,650 MB/s and my results for this drive was 915/922 MB/s. Both drives are quite affordable and for use as a fast, portable storage, they work well.

Now, the Centon makes big claims. It is advertised at 5,500/1,800 MB/s. That's faster than WD_Black's advertised speed of 3,600 MB/s read! This is obviously aimed at those who are looking to upgrade a PS5 with more storage, but my results can be see in the screenshot. Under the same conditions, it only meets the performance of the Klevv and is slower than the Pioneer. I don't have high confidence for this actually being great for a PS5.

In addition, just as a previous review stated: I received this drive in an electrostatic bag inside an Amazon Prime envelope. I was lucky that the drive was still functional when it got to me.

Not impressed.

The devices that work with the hub are more expensive than the knock off ones that work through their individual apps but in my opinion it’s worth the extra money to have one central app where you can controll everything.

The apps have a bit of a learning curve but not terrible for people who are familiar with smart home devices and how they work.

I’d recommend this hub to integrate multiple smart home devices together and to simplify your life.

title: An AMAZING Shower Speaker text: This shower speaker has far exceeded my expectations, after a very thorough evaluation I can completely say this is an outstanding product - in fact, the best shower speaker I have reviewed.

First of all, this item arrived quickly and is exactly as described.

After following the instructions and fully charging using the USB cable, I paired it with my iPhone with no issue.

All of the control buttons are on the front of the speaker while the charging port is on the lower side. Every opening is sealed very well and withstands the moisture of the shower without an issue.

The sound is rich and clear. It is clear in the full range of sound from the deep bass notes to the clear high pitches.

Calls are clear and can be received without any issue. Microphone volume is a bit low when speaking - the person calling may have some trouble hearing the person speaking in the shower. Part of that is the ambient noise generated by the shower, which is to be expected. Most people won't make a habit of talking on the phone while showering, so I really don't see this as an issue.

The super powerful 1800mAh internal battery will last and last. After the initial charge, I was able to use the speaker daily while in the shower and then getting ready for well over a month before recharging and probably could have gone longer. I used the speaker not only while showering but also while getting ready.

In conclusion, as far as listening to music or audiobooks while in the shower and getting ready this speaker is excellent. The speaker produces a rich sound quality with more than enough volume. The battery is excellent, providing plenty of power requiring less time charging and delivering more time enjoying the music.

If you are looking for a great speaker for in your shower or other moist environments - look no further. This is definitely a Bluetooth speaker I highly recommend.

title: I tried to love this model...but ends in divorce :( text: I've been an avid Olympus camera enthusiast for quite some time. I've had all TG-830 to the TG-860 haven't tried the TG-870 as of yet. I wanted to try Olympus newest camera the TG-4. Big disappointment :(
Since day of purchase 06-2015 video stabilizer wasn't working properly, the audio when you zoom in or out muffles out and you lose audio.
Auto focus on photo & video is just crap...I can be in the most well lit areas and 80% of the time I have to power down and power back on and hope the auto focus adjusts accordingly.
When video shooting/recording the working mechanism can be heard throughout the video shoot and usually happens 75% of the time. With all this said....Mine was repaired 3 x's for these issues....
When the camera works it works great, but I do a lot of YouTube and all you hear is the clicking noise from the mechanism inside and camera has been since replaced and replacement one is just as bad :( 1 star folk's sad to say ;(
I understand there are very sensitive working parts and the audio can pic them up....but it's not OK when you make videos and you friends and fans ask? What is that clicking noise in your videos? I tried to ignore it...but it's just so loud and annoying.
The video stabilizer just straight up a joke in the model....I can get a old flip phone camera and get better results. Remember folk's these were all supposed to have been repaired many times.
On the bright side.....when the camera works it take absolutely amazing photos. But video is very weak in this model....Customer service was fair....and did replace the camera, but the replacement was just the same....as for the extended warranty those folk's were a joke.
I'll leave it as that cause then this review would be a book/novel. On the flip side....I see and this can possibly only be coincidence....but I feel it really is mostly with the "Red" model....seems the black has it's own special issues. I really tried to love this camera...but the camera is my job and this is just a no go....I'll just have to say this was a waste of $400.00 bucks I may try the TG-870 but now I'm studying up and leaning towards Canon line of cameras :(

title: Works just fine. Don't see any big difference from my 50-mile antenna text: I didn't want to review this until I'd had a chance to use it for a while.

We cut the cord on cable a few years ago, and went to antenna and a smart tv. The antenna I was using had a 50-mile radius. This one makes claims of 180 miles.

I placed it next to my other antenna. I have a very large tree fairly close to the bedroom window, so I do have some difficulty with reception here. We are near the STL broadcast area, so no mountains or forests in our way.

I first tried just switching the antenna connection without a new channel scan. Everything looked exactly the same as with my old antenna. No biggie. It has a nice, long cord, which helps for placement.

The next day, I ran a scan for new channels. I really expected to see some new channels pop up with the additional 130 mile radius. Nope. I have exactly the same channels.

Of course, your experience could vary greatly, depending on your location, topography, big buildings, etc. But I have to say that this 180-mike-radius antenna does nothing at all different from my 50-mile-radius antenna. So, not really better, and definitely not worse.

title: INCREDIBLY HANDLY AMPLIFIER! text: This amplifier is so nice to have when you need to boost volume without losing sound quality.

If you have ever turned the volume all the way up and still not been satisfied with how loud the volume emitted from the speaker your plugged into is, this amplifier is exactly what you need.

I have a set of high quality Bose speakers on my deck that I occasionally plug my iPhone into, if it’s only a couple people out there the volume is adequate but if we are hosting a party it’s not. By running this amplifier between my iPhone and the receiver volume is not an issue - without losing a bit of sound quality.

I love that this amplifier has an internal 2,000mAh battery so there is no searching for the correct sized batteries when you need it. All I do is keep it charged up and ready to rock.

This is an outstanding product that I definitely recommend.

⭐️As with all Drew’s Reviews, if I discover something new about this product - good or bad - I will UPDATE my review. I believe in creating detailed, unbiased, complete reviews because, like you, I depend on reviews when I am shopping. If you found this review HELPFUL - please click ⬇️ below, to let me know!⭐️

title: Garbage. text: Don't even bother with these unless you're ONLY using them for a lens protector.
That's about all they do.

As for the description:

"CPL: Polarizers let you acheive vibrant color saturation, reduce or eliminate glare from non-metallic object.
F-DL: Fluorescent light correction filter gives true-to-life color rendition. Fluorescent filter dramatically increases color saturation"

They don't do any of that. They actually ruined my photos rather than enhancing them.

Go buy a REAL filter from B&W. I got one there after ordering these and they are 10,000% better, but also more pricey.

My guess is these cheap ones were built in China/India from scrap class/plastic while B&W uses high quality metals and glasses for their filters.

Anyway that's all I have to say, don't be disappointed and just skip these altogether.

Best part of all is that the letters and numbers are laser engraved, so they will not fade over time. It's difficult to find a nice retro beige mouse to go with this though. LOL! 5-Stars!

title: Quick & dirty text: This is going to be quick--I only have a minute. However, as an avid point & shoot hobbyist, I wanted to contribute my $0.02 worth in on this magnificent little gem. Small, simple, and almost goof-proof, this is an ideal inexpensive camera for anyone just getting started. No optical viewfinder, managable file sizes, and the typical unbeatable Nikon lens mean you get serious bang for your buck with this camera. Full auto works well, and easy access to simple manual control over the basic parameters of the capture process mean it is easy for anyone to make minor adjustments. Also, there are (I think) 16 or 20 custom auto modes, including fireworks, black & white, etc.

HUGE plus: this camera runs on AA batteries. Spend about $25 once on a charger and two sets of high-capacity rechargables (2600miAh), and you will be all set. Regular Energizers are good for 100+ shots with the flash. The rechargables I bought are good for easily 250+ on a charge. MOney VERY well spent.

For your dollar, this is a hard camera to beat--and what makes it great is that it's a Nikon--these people know lenses... and TRUST ME, it's all about the optics. Nikon simply rules in that dept, IMHO.

title: It's not slow, but it's not magical
text: I'm currently transferring about 1 TB of video files from this drive to an internal drive. The speed is ranging from 50 MB/s to 105 MB/s using the USB 3.0 cable that came with the drive on a USB 3.0 hub which is plugged into a USB 3.0 port on my desktop running Windows 10 Pro. This is about the same speed I get transferring similar files from one internal 4 TB WD Red drive to another via SATA III. From what I've read from actual experts in the field, this is slightly above average for a typical external USB 3.0 drive. It's not an SSD, and there are no physical drives that come close to SSD speeds, or close to the theoretical maximum throughput of USB 3.0. Ignore anyone who says it's too slow. It's not the drive. It's them.

title: Superior quality text: This is one of my favorite patch cables, and I especially love the fact that they come in a variety of them to color-code by function. I received mine as a review sample and it is one of the best constructed patch cables that I have used.

Since I am using them is my music studio the best thing is they are low noise. Actually this is about noise-free as you can get. Part of the reason is the double shielding, but part is the overall construction.

I also love the precision fit. I use these to patch bluetooth receivers in some of my amps and PA mixers for backing tracks. Lesser cables that I have used had a sloppy fit, These have a firm feel inserting and removing.

Construction is top notch. Everything from the heavy duty strain reliefs to the plated tip, ring and sleeve are well made. I also love the flexibility of the cable itself.

If you are looking for high grade patch cable for 3.5mm male-to-male, this is it in my opinion.

title: A good-enough camera for the price text: The NexHT 1080P Pan Digital Tilt / 8X Zoom Indoor Smart Camera has all of the features that one would want from a wifi camera. Panning, recording, remote viewing, infrared night vision and two-way audio. It is also very small. Designed to look like the Wyze cam, it is actually much smaller at 1.5" wide and 3" tall. While cloud storage services are available, there is a microsd port for local recording.

If one just needs a basic camera at a low price to monitor the home, this camera will serve well. To compare to products such as Wyze, this camera comes up a little bit short. The title of the product is carefully worded to show that the tilt function is "digital", which really means that the camera records with a wide-angled lens and when the phone is held in landscape mode, one can drag the image up and down. When held in portrait mode, the entire height of the image can be seen and there is actually no tilt function. Even so, in both modes, the camera image is squeezed together and not at the correct aspect ratio (I guess this depends on your phone's aspect ratio because the programmers chose not to maintain aspect ratio of the picture).

The recording function is fairly basic. It works like a dashcam in that the camera is always recording and will loop back over itself once the storage is filled.

As with any other wifi home automation product, a separate account needs to be created to log in to the app -- an app one must trust to not send any sensitive information back to the mothership. Personally, I plug this camera into a smart switch that I can turn on only when I'm out so that at least the camera isn't on when I'm at home.

So this camera will do what it advertises but it there really isn't anything that sets it apart from the large number of products out there. Wyze, while being a little bit bigger, costs only $30 and has actual tilt function.

title: Micro end not for all android devices
text: The micro prong was too long for my Samsung Galaxy 5 phone and my Samsung Tab A tablet. Therefore, the cable does not sit snuggly into my devices. The one that I have been using is bent already, so I don't expect these cables to last too long. Disappointed.

title: I forgot how slow and tedious buttons are...
text: When society was transitioning from keyboard phones to touch phones, I held out as long as I could. I just thought touching letters was weird, and not accurate. After converting to touchscreen for several years, I tried to go back to a Blackberry with buttons and man, it's not like riding a bike at all. You simply cannot go back to buttons. Everything just seem so slow with buttons. That's because your brain has conditioned your fingers to touch. Pressing buttons will now feel extremely slow, we've lost that finger pressing muscle memory. Which brings me to my point, this is a slow and tedious way to save your credentials/passwords. LOL! The onboard software, if you can even call it that, doesn't help you differentiate password vs username vs websites. It would be nice to have folder levels where you can then drill in. For example, create a folder call Amazon, tap it to go inside and see the username and password. There is no such organization. You need to input the name of the website, your username, your password all on one string. So when you turn on the Pinmaster, you'll immediately see the first string you created. On the back of the retail box, it says ILLUMINATED DISPLAY as a feature. I take that to mean the screen has a backlit, but there is no such backlit. I don't think they claim backlit on the amazon product listing, so it's probably just an error in packaging design, a feature they decided to scrap or something. Lastly, you should know that all the special characters are in the 1 and 0 buttons. That's where you can find the @,&,%,^, etc. Maybe I'll entertain this thing when I have spare time, watching a movie, and this thing is in my hands like a fidget device. LOL! Other than that, I don't think I'll be putting any effort into this. I'll go 3-Stars!

title: Great for splitting a source to two monitors text: I'm occasionally asked to set up 2 projectors at small events (engagement parties, bar mitzvahs, guest speaker lectures, etc). This is a great and inexpensive little tool to take my media and duplicate it to two identical HDMI signals. The only issue is then that HDMI doesn't travel well beyond 25-50', but that's a limitation of the standard and cable, and not this adapter. If you're looking to use this for something like I describe, it definitely works and will do the trick, but do yourself a favor and also get either an HDMI-to-SDI adapter or HDMI-to-CAT5/6 adapter, as those will both allow much longer runs of cable without signal degradation.
If you just want to split into two signals in the same room (such as, projector and TV), this should work a treat.

title: Runs a little warm, but works with Amazon Basics batteries text: Runs a little warm, but works as well as my three year old [[ASIN:B00MPWFO3O Knox 16-Bay Rapid Ni-MH AA/AAA Battery Charger]]. In fact, this and the Knox look similar (except for color and logo).

I charged a batch of [[ASIN:B007B9NV8Q AmazonBasics AA Rechargeable Batteries]] with no issues, so this charger and those batteries are compatible. I also charged four Knox AAA batteries after the Amazon ones finished. No issues other than the batteries from the AA batch were warm when I removed them.

This (like the Knox unit that I also own) comes with both a wall and a car charger. For me that is a major selling point because I use AA batteries in some wireless microphones my band uses for some gigs. I can keep standby batteries charging in my vehicle in case some need to be swapped out of the mics during intermissions.

Bottom line, I am not sure what the heat does to my battery life, but I do love the convenience of this charger.

title: Gorgeous picture, full rich sound, easy to set up text: After almost 3 weeks with this television, I am amazed and very, very happy with it. There's a lot to like here and a couple of things that I wasn't expecting from any television.

First is the ease of set up. Our previous smart tv was a ROKU and reasonably simple to set up as well. The Google connection here means just signing in with your existing Google info and the tv uploads your existing apps. Just like moving to your new Android phone or tablet. All of our streaming apps populated and we were able to sign in without drama - HBOMAX, Prime, Paramount Plus, HULU and Netflix. We only stream and haven't used cable or satellite in 5 years, so easy app access with a new tv is important.

The 4K picture is outstanding. There's no distortion in picture quality or digital noise even from old 1940s movies. The colors are rich and full and the tv settings let you adjust to your preference as well. We've watched a lot, A LOT of tv recently and every show on all platforms has been gorgeous. Frankly, we probably watch way too much tv as a rule and that's not going to change. I've been amazed at the picture quality difference between our year old HD tv and this one.

We've connected Alexa to this tv and the voice controls work...most of the time. Using the voice control via the remote control renders better responses for sure. The tv has recognized a Fire stick, Roku Express stick, and a portable DVD player for us without any drama. We don't have a gaming system, though.... I'm considering buying one for this giant screen.

But my final show stopper moment with this television has been the sound quality. We've never had a tv that didn't require a sound bar. Until now. Despite the tv being quite thin and lightweight, the speakers still produce a deep sound quality without any tinny undertones. The settings have a calibration option for the speakers that you definitely need to do for the best sound - it works. I truly believe this is the best television we've ever owned.

title: Perfect for my application; battery life is less than advertised text: I use this to illuminate objects that I am photographing (mainly small items that I sell on various sites), but also to provide extra light for smaller rooms when I am making videos of my band at rehearsal and/or on gigs.

The battery life is touted to be 90-110 minutes under maximum illumination power, but I have gotten around 75 minutes. For me, this is still pretty good I especially like the fact that the battery is integrated, so there is no need to purchase extra batteries and chargers like the other lights that I investigated before purchasing this one. Moreover, this will work with the same external batteries that I use for my tablets and phones, as well as the wall chargers and cables for those devices.

Illumination is soft and can go from warm to cold, depending on your shooting environment. Since I am by no means a professional (or even an advanced) photographer, I found this light to be all that I need for easy to shoot videos and stills.

One thing that I am on the fence about is the mount. It is a little shaky in that it tends to not firmly hold the light steady when installed in my camera's hot shoe. I can live with it since I keep my rig stationary, but if you are on the move that mount is going to be the weak spot.

Despite my dislikes I intend to purchase one more of these as both a spare and as a second light source for some shots that will benefit from the added illumination.

title: Comfortable Handles are a plus. Vertical Side-Pockets are a minus. text: I have been trying to find a Neoprene case, with Handles, for a large (17") laptop and was so happy to find this on Amazon.

1. The handle is pliable and comfortable. The material is strong and sewn in tightly. It does not feel as though it will tear out. Please note, the handles are not immediate apparent - they are tucked down into the side pockets (When this arrived, I thought they had sent the wrong item. I had to fish around in the pockets to find the handles)
2. The zipper works but is not as sturdy as I would like for such a large case. The zipper pulls are also a bit small. The zipper is sewn in evenly. I think with careful use, the zipper will stand up to time.
3. There is NOT any additional lining inside this bag, so no added protection. Just the Neoprene.
4. There are outer D-rings for a shoulder strap, but a shoulder strap is not included. I am not sure why they give you the hardware, but not the strap.
5. The reason I cannot give this 5 stars is the pockets. There is a deep, vertical pocket on each side, that is only as wide as the handle. Very difficult to get your items out of these pockets. A horizontal pocket would be more useful and user friendly. I personally find I cannot use these pockets.

title: BEST KEYBOARD EVER MADE (IMHO) BUT HAS SOME SMALL ISSUES
text: Have used this keyboard for many years at work and home and I wouldn't use any other keyboard.  It is that comfortable.  I would hate to pay the price they are asking for these now.  Hate to say this for those of you who want one, but I just bought one for $2.99 from Goodwill.  It is well worth it to have a spare on hand; actually have 2 spares, as obviously these are expensive to replace if you buy new. These keyboards have both USB and PS/2 type connectors and two USB ports in the back of the keyboard which I have never used.  I tried out the USB ports in the back and they do not work.  There could be a couple of reasons for this.  One might be that in order for them to function, you might have to use the USB connector for the keyboard, rather than the round PS/2 connector.  Another reason is that my keyboard does not connect directly to the computer, but goes through a KVM switch.  Through the switch, the keyboard may not receive enough power to power the USB ports.  I don't have a USB connector on my KVM switch, so I have to use the PS/2 round connector.  The only problem that I have encountered with this keyboard is the feet that elevate the back of the keyboard to a comfortable angle, tend to fall off.  I have lost a couple and cannot find replacements.  If you are used to a flat keyboard, the tilted ergo keyboard does take some getting used to, but once you have used it for a while, you will never go back to a flat keyboard again.  Microsoft has some newer versions of this keyboard, but I don't think they are an improvement and they are expensive.

title: Perfect for on-the-go journaling/blogging ... lightweight and portable, it travels well! text: I purchased this to take along on vacations so I could journal (and ultimately blog) about my journeys. The first test was just completed: a 2-week cruise around Alaska (Ketchikan, Endicott Arm, Juneau, Hoonah, Anchorage, Kodiak, Homer, and Sitka). I wanted a full-sized keyboard, portable, and easy to manage that would work with my iPad Pro.

I chose this for the size, the fact that it is powered via my iPad (rather than needing to be charged), and the fact that it's a wired connection via the lightning cable rather than Bluetooth. Nothing against Bluetooth, but not having to deal with pairing simplifies things a lot.

This performed beautifully! Connected easily, and no problems at all with performance. It has some nifty shortcuts, many I didn't use, but at least they're available. Despite being a full-size keyboard, the small size means I can tuck this into my carryon along with other necessities and it doesn't take up much space at all. It's durable, too -- the wire connector appears to be sturdy. I used this a couple of times per day to record events and activities, so it was in and out of my bag often. No problems at all.

It's coming along on my next adventure: a cruise around the North Atlantic (including Greenland, Iceland, and Norway) for 6 weeks.

title: Great!

title: What I was looking for text: I picked up a factory refurbished unit and I'm satisfied. I was looking for a point and shoot camera that didn't have an extending lens. I wanted something that I could stick in the pocket of my bicycle jersey and pull out without having to worry about destroying the camera. I did wreck one of my old cell phones by sticking it in my jersey pocket, so the waterproof component of this camera was ideal.

I paid approximately $100 for this, and it takes decent pictures. Like I mentioned before, the lens doesn't extend, so you have to be pretty close to your subject, but the images are good enough that you can use enhancement software to create the image you want from the raw material. It's not a DSLR, but this is a good accessory camera to bring along. It slips easily into your pocket and can take a bit of a beating.

I don't intend to use this for underwater shooting, so I haven't tested it for that. If it rains on me while cycling, I'm confident the camera can take it. I'm satisfied.

title: Works as expected
text: My 16yo daughter was putting her iPhone into a ceramic mug to try to "amplify" the music from her phone (fyi: it works in a pinch!), so I gave this to her to try. She took it upstairs, and in just minutes I could hear music coming from her room! It was quick and easy enough for her to pair without instructions, and the sound was good and robust (not "canny," as I feared). She also has good range on it, meaning she can walk in and out of her room with the phone - away from the speaker - and the music continues to play, uninterrupted. But the speaker is also unobtrusive enough to port around to the yard, the car, and more, and since it can run on batteries, that's more than possible. Altogether, we're quite pleased!

title: fitbit flex 2 sleeve text: Oh boy. I can I just say this is the BEST fitbit Flex 2 accessory so far. It's really really cool. and fits on all your basic rubber like bands. I purchased the silver... but there is a yellow gold color and and rose gold color too. I really, really love it. I have included some pics. It slides right on. You position it over the light dots and VIOLE! Your plain, boring band is beautiful! The piece is metal. It is very smooth... no sharp edges. There are points at the top and bottom tips but it fits so perfectly on the band that I have not had any issues with snagging or catching. It's rich looking.. not cheap. It's not really heavy... but I think it weighs a reasonable amount. Honestly, I've purchased a lot of different "enhancements" and accessories for my flex 2 and this one is really my fav. In fact, I think I will go back and purchase a couple more. I never hesitate to update my reviews should new info seem useful and I really hope this review was helpful to you.
UPDATE: 3/10/2018... I went back and ordered 2 of the 3 piece sets and an extra silver to travel with. Honestly, these appear to be really well made and a really lovey, EASY to use accessory. Of course I will update if new new info would be useful.

title: Handy for small peripherals and charging text: Stephen M. Charme's incredibly helpful June 19, 2014 review covers this device in exhaustive detail. I'll attempt to not repeat him, so will confine my review to why I awarded my review sample five stars.

Foremost, I love the convenience of having an all-in-one power and charging station for my phone, tablet and a few smaller electronic items. It takes up one full two outlet wall connectors in my music studio where I am using it. One of the plugs is a dummy that does not draw electricity. This ensures that you do not overload a circuit as well as providing stability to the rather large unit.

At 15 Amps (1675 Watts) this is more than sufficient for the small amperage devices I am using (although I do have a 5 Watt RMS output tube amp plugged into it as well.) Where I live the power fluctuates too wildly to plug anything of value directly into a wall outlet, so this is essential.

It's also a convenience with respect to the swivel. Most of the devices I am powering with this use wall warts, and even with the swivel I can only plug four in at any given time. While that blocks two of the outlets, had it not swiveled I would have probably lost one more outlet.

I have found this so useful that I intend to order another to place in my gig bag for playing out. There is always a dearth of outlets on most of the small venue stages where I play, and the power in most of those places is usually abysmal. One of these for a small PA and keyboard will afford adequate protection as well as being conveniently small.

title: Not just for Brainwavz products text: This case came bundled with my [[ASIN:B009UNZ5WQ Brainwavz R1 In Ear Noise Isolating Earphones]] and I was struck by how nicely made and perfect it is. I will not parrot the other excellent reviews on this page with regard to physical characteristics, but will confirm that they are spot on.

Although these are bundled with a Brainwavz product do not let that deter you if you have invested in another brand because these will work with most of them. I tested the fit with the following phones and they are a perfect match:

[[ASIN:B001EZYMF4 Sennheiser CX 300 II Precision Enhanced Bass Earbuds]]
[[ASIN:B004PO10E2 Shure SE215-CL Sound Isolating Earphones]]
[[ASIN:B000XPG2QI Etymotic Research HF5 Portable In-Ear Earphones]]

Of course I also tested them with the [[ASIN:B00G4UQ6U8 Brainwavz S1 In Ear Headphones]] which I expected to fit and they did. Although many of the phones with which I tested these come with their own case, none of them are are as sturdy or as protective as this one. For low-end phones this will probably outlast the phones themselves, and will be ready their their replacement. For the higher end phones this is an investment - and an inexpensive one at they - for protecting the instrument from damage.
