title: Sturdy, great sound, worth the price
text: We recently bought this for my husband to use in his garage workshop. He previously had a portable Memorex CD player/stereo that fell apart and wanted a replacement. We tried to with the inexpensive portable stereos you can find at Walmart, an RCA unit, but it was broken right out of the box. The CD player wouldn't even play. Because of of all the sawdust, grime, debris that comes with my husband's projects, I encouraged him to spend more for something that will do what he wants while lasting through the messes. The Sony ZSH10CP Heavy Duty CD Radio Boombox fits the bill. It's rugged and well made. The CD player doesn't skip if the boombox is bumped. He likes the rubber operating buttons and the sturdy latch for the CD player. The sound is excellent. He's really happy with it and so am I.

title: Excellent Mini Desktop PC text: This is an excellent mini desktop PC that is perfect for home, school, or work. You have to purchase your monitor, mouse, keyboard, and other accessories separately. The unit is 5.1" by 5.1" and is 1.8" tall which means it will fit easily in a briefcase or handbag. It comes with an HDMI cable, a VESA mount, and a power adapter. The VESA mount is nice because you can conveniently hang this computer off the back of your monitor.

The computer has two HDMI ports and a VGA port which makes this a nice option for giving presentations. It also has an ethernet port and multiple USB ports.

I plugged mine in, turned it on, navigated the Windows setup, and was ready to go. This is a fast and powerful mini desktop PC.

title: A Major Disappointment
text: This product was designed for portability - it's small and takes up little space in a traveler's bag.  The compactness is what also contributes to its uselessness.  Most devices come with cube shaped plugs or three prong plugs that will overlap the neighboring socket, so instead of having three sockets, you're lucky if you get two.  The holes are also so small and tight that it's difficult to insert and remove a plug, especially if you have arthritis as I do.  Pulling at a plug on this device will loosen the surge suppressor from the host socket and I fear that I might accidentally electrocute myself.  Final analysis: Poorly designed unit that's unfriendly to large or broad adapter plugs.

title: petite, light, digital display, front controls, remote w/ batteries, plug n play text: I'm very happy with this blu ray player. I was so pleased with an Arufuna DVD player, that when it came time to look for a BluRay player, I was very open to trying it from this brand again. I could get a brand name for same price or cheaper, but what drew me to this one is that (besides being very happy with their DVD player) is that this is smaller than many others on the market. I already have a huge, heavy blu-ray player, and I wanted something smaller, lighter, and easier to move around. The small size of this is perfect. It is bigger than their mini DVD player, but smaller than nearly any other blu-ray player. It also has similar features that made me first select their DVD player (still small, but still has remote and front display).

This Blu-ray disc player is petite but still has full functionality- ie; remote, front digital display, and controls. It works. It comes with HDMI cable as well as an RCA cable, and coaxial cable. I dont need the latter two. Good size remote comes with batteries. Easy for me to set up-- I just plugged the HDMI cable into the port on the player, and one into the back of my TV. Then plugged the player into the wall. ALL WORKS WELL. I popped in a variety of movies, and had no issue having them play.

I dont often watch DVDs or Blu-ray discs, but I want the option. We have a few smart tvs, and our main already has an old Blu-ray player, but I wanted something for our other tvs. I put a DVD player (by arufuna) in my spare room, and am using this in our smaller den. Now I feel like I can grab a DVD off the shelf and not have to always stream something.

10.2" x 7.7" x 1.3"

title: I'm happy with this reader so far text: I purchased this reader because the [[ASIN:B002P5KOXG Kodak A250 50-in-1 Card Reader 83037]] reader only worked once and the replacement Kodak sent me [[ASIN:B0026H5DFM Vivitar 72-in1 Memory Card and Sim Card Reader/Writer VIV-RW-ALL]] wouldn't fit my card because the card reader housing was too slender.

This Kingston worked great the first time. All I had to do is open the box, press down and push forward the sliver slider on the top of the unit (this slides the slots forward), insert either my IBM microdrive or CompactFlash card, and then connect it to the USB port on my computer (running Windows Vista). Almost immediately I could access the photos I needed. Copying the photos to my hard drive was also quick and easy.

This is the best reader out of the three I tried! I'm very satisfied.

title: Nice Deal but Firmware is Clunky text: This player is well worth the asking price, and I've not come accross any feature that doesn't work. Streaming, DVD, Network, USB all 'just work,' though I've not tested some features like 3D, Blu-Ray, and Wireless. The USB input sees my self-powered USB Pocketec hard drive as a media, and will play from it whatever formats the player supports. You just click your way to the directory on the drive that contains your media files. There is one issue: jpg thumbnails take 'forever' to load, much slower than a computer. If you have several hundred jpgs, it could take 5 or 10 minutes just for all the thumbnails to be displayed. There doesn't appear to be a cache either, so each time you load the directory anew, you have to wait.

The streaming video (I've only tested Netflix thus far) works pretty good. Also, DVD's play nicely and load quickly. However, the LG Apps are pretty lame - mostly stupid games you will not likely be using. :) Also, the interface is slow, so you have to wait a few seconds - 30 seconds for the main menu system to load when first turning on the device. However, the connection is pretty robust. I've only experienced very brief 'dropouts,' when the connection is lost, so far.

Overall I would say I am quite pleased with what I bought for the money. This was a replacement for my satellite service which I dropped for lack of use. Now for a nominal fee to netflix or Amazon (Pandora is, I think totally free), I have a wide assortment of home entertainment on demand. That is worth the 169.00 I paid for the unit. I recommend this model for anyone looking for a full-featured, internet ready, blu-ray/media player on a budget.

Terry

title: Well.....it makes noise. text: Bought this to replace a dead shop stereo.
The Good:
Knobs and buttons are higher quality than I thought they'd be. It has plenty of power. USB input is kinda neat. GREAT PRICE!

The Bad:
"A/B" outputs are not true, switched A/B outputs. They are simultaneous outputs that are wired together. All on, all the time. The remote has no "power off" button. REALLY stupid. Sound quality is pretty crappy. Its good for making a lot of noise, but that's about it. If you fancy yourself any kind of audiophile, than move along. The manual is a joke. EXTREMELY uninformative.

So there ya go.

If I weren't just using this as a "background noise" shop stereo, it would be on its way back to Amazon. Would probably make a good stereo for a kid also. Definitely not for real music lovers.

title: Perfect! text: I am very pleased with this purchase and I wanted to write a review on things start to finish.
Packaging
-Fantastic overall look and also care in terms of making sure the watch face was protected and sitting in its' own section of the box. The bands were not attached but were easy to slip on (there's a small little nub on the band end that attaches to the watch, color side will face down). There is also a screen protector to peel off the watch face. The charger is magnetic and the charging process may have taken an hour (I just plugged into my computer).

Directions
-These were really fantastic. They lay things out in detail but also keep it brief for the many different options available. Turn on the bluetooth mode on your phone. I found the app "Da Fit App" from the product description, though the directions only show a QR code. From there it was opening the app and doing a quick profile setup (Sex, Height, Weight, Birth Year). It automatically scanned for the phone and the letters displayed on the screen and it was the only one shown so that was quick. I do wish it would pop up a notification that the pairing was successful but there is a watch icon in the app at the bottom. If you click that it displays "Connected" right at the top and shows your exact watch. It also let's you customize the "face" of the watch from within the app. I like Dial 3.

The App
-Very well laid out and some details were provided earlier but you can adjust the notifications you receive and it all pairs through Bluetooth so as long as they are on (and you accept push notifications on the phone) you'll receive the notifications on the phone. You can make a lot of the adjustments you want through the watch, but the app can allow for a faster level to set all at once.

The Modes
Phone calls, sleep (need to leave on during sleep), heart rate test, steps, training (stopwatch), blood pressure, SpO2 Test, Weather, Reminders, Shutter (photos/video), start/stop songs, Alarms, Timer, Stopwatch, Theater Mode (turns off vibrating and brightness), Move reminders, Drink reminders (stay healthy), Health reminders (menstrual, pregnancy, gender health).

The watch will sync to your timezone once the app is set and you can also get weather notifications which I set inside the app.

I am really thrilled to use the watch and was able to even deny a call earlier without having to grab my phone (unwanted caller). Excellent product and totally worth it!

title: Amazing Keyboard Cover text: This is the best keyboard I have found for the iPad, and I've used a lot of them. In terms of the usability and comfort of the keyboard itself, the quality is simply unmatched. My last keyboard had flimsy keys and would sometimes type 2 or 3 letters with one keystroke, while other keys didn't seem to work at all. This one is exactly the opposite - it feels great to type on even if it's a little undersized, and all the keys are exactly where you'd expect them to be. Having two shift keys is also quite nice, that's one of my main gripes with every other iPad keyboard.

The cover feature is also very good, though the hinge magnet does seem a little bit less "snappy" than the smart cover. It works fine, but it just seems a little bit lower quality. When closed, it blends perfectly with the iPad itself and creates a seamless brushed metal case all the way around, aside from the two ends of the slot that the iPad fits into during use. It is slightly thicker than the iPad 2. One thing this product has over many other keyboard covers is that you can use portrait mode, though as stated in other reviews, that position is not quite as steady as the magnet in the holding slot does not work in portrait orientation.

The battery life is also quite impressive. The manual claims 6 months (2 hrs/day usage) on a single charge. I can attest to that since I've had it for several months and have yet to charge it a second time (although I use it probably an hour a day, if that).

The last point is the price. Having used it, I'm confident it's a good buy. Might be a bit on the expensive side, but you're getting your money's worth - it does not seem rinky-dink like a lot of these other keyboards. This is clearly a professional, high-quality product.

For me it's turned typing on the iPad from a headache/nightmare into, basically, using a normal keyboard. I've seen a couple other reviews that complained about the protective edges getting in the way, but I keep my wrists up when I type so it's not a problem for me. The only thing I miss from a normal keyboard is a delete button (the 'delete' on this keyboard is backspace) and the home/end keys. There may be a way to do those, but I haven't used it long enough to find out.

I'm a software developer with roughly 10 years of solid typing experience, and this is not just a great iPad keyboard, but in itself a very nice keyboard, period. I wouldn't mind having to use it on a normal computer. Overall, it's simply amazing. I typed this entire review with it and had no problems whatsoever. I highly recommend it.

title: Great features and sound quality! Some caveats text: I've been a fan of Panasonic's consumer electronics since their camcorder days, so I was excited to try these! I've owned many of the cheap Chinese wireless earbuds, and generally sound is good enough for music or listening to videos but I've never found one with a microphone decent enough for sound quality outside of the major brands (Apple, Samsung, etc).
Well, I'm happy to say these Panasonic 'buds don't skimp! They don't cost as much as the big players but the sound quality both for listening and microphone use is head and shoulders over the cheap knock offs. The noice cancelling feature is pretty amazing as well, and overall I'm very pleased with the feature set and quality of those features. But here's the caveat:
The ergonomics aren't great. Touch sensitive buds are difficult for me because I'm the kind of person who moves around a lot and needs to adjust my earbuds to keep them from falling out. But touch sensitivity means sometimes I'm accidentally activating things when I don't want to. I also didn't find some of the features intuitive and had to learn how to use them properly (changing noise cancelling modes for example). They also have rather bright blinking LEDs but you'll only notice that in a dark room. All in all, this is a good product that could be made better in a second edition. For the price, I think it fits squarely between the polished big name brands and the cheap knock offs. This is a good product, it works and doesn't exactly what it says. But it isn't perfect.

title: Resolved: Issues with wireless performance only with keyboard text: Updated 6/5/2021
After having problems with the keyboard's wireless signal registering with the PC, I took another reviewer's suggestion and purchased a 6 foot USB extension cord, attached the wireless receiver to it, and mounted it to the top of my large screen display. This resolved the line-of-sight issues and now both the keyboard and the mouse function well.

I would have given 5 stars but...
I have purchased quite a few Logitech wireless keyboards/mouses/combos over the years and have been satisfied. With this purchase, I constantly have problems with the keyboard signals being received by the PC (never a problem with the mouse though!). The PC either does not receive the signal at all, or it takes a quite a few persistent attempts (usually by adjusting line-of-sight) for it to function. Doesn't make sense. If the mouse is completely unaffected, why would the keyboard if they are right next to each other?
Never had this problem with the other Logitech keyboard/mouse combo and it is the same model #.
Granted, I have a large 55" display between my desk and the PC, but still...
Going to try what another reviewer suggested and get a USB extension cable and attach the the receiver to it and tape it the top of the screen.
I definitely like the size and overall performance of this model, that's why I have ordered it twice.

title: The keyboard is premium, the mouse is lacking, overall pretty nice... text: THE GOOD:
---------------
* The keyboard feels very premium, like an aluminum slab.
* Works on iOS, Windows, Android and even though they don't mention it in the manual, it works with Raspberry Pis too. I'm very happy about that because that's what I got this set for, to troubleshoot Raspberry pis.
* USB-Charging for both keyboard and mouse. This is what I look for now. I'm tired of changing alkaline batteries. I will no longer buy accessories that require traditional batteries.
* Can be connected by Bluetooth or 2.4G usb receiver, which is located under the mouse.
* Read the operating instructions on the Amazon listing page itself.

THE BAD:
------------
* Quality of mouse is not up to par with the keyboard. Mouse feels light & cheap compared to the keyboard, which is dense and high quality.
* Text on the manual is so tiny, so I read the instructions on the back of the packaging instead. This caused some headache because on the back of the packaging, it says to press FN + C to connect the Bluetooth. This does not work at all As it turns out, all the proper instructions are on the Amazon listing page. It's the same instructions as the included printed manual, except the text is big and readable on the web page. So you'll see the proper way to connect to Bluetooth is FN + "1" or "2." They need to remove the incorrect instructions from the back of their box to avoid confusion.

Overall, we'll go 4-Stars!

title: Can be a little intimidating… Follow instructions! text: This must be assembled from a handful of smaller pieces.. reviewing instructions and using common sense will help a lot. I DO suggest the buddy system when setting up for sure- it makes the process so much easier! It also ensures being careful not to crease the screen.. Just note- sizes may not sound big when ordering but, I was surprised just how big 120 size screen really was!!! (Maths never been my strong point- so maybe this was just me.. but a quick size reference before ordering will give you some real time idea!)

Used indoors- we didn’t need water weights.. but have if/when necessary. Not sure how easy they’ll be to use if using on a camp out… Water can be sparse- I’d probably weight down with sandbag or cinder block?

If following instructions it’s a bit contradicting to state… “Do not fold or roll screen.” To store in the provided carry bag- The only way to fit the screen in is to roll..?? Carefully doing so, we blindly followed and hoping it won’t cause any issues- I wish it provided more clarity in this department!

As for screen itself.. just be sure to eliminate any light source from behind it since it can offset the picture from projector light on front side. Doing this gives a solid image… It’s awesome! Used at our teen sons bday party with group of friends- we set up big screen in our game room and all had a solid view of movie marathon- zero complaints.. a huge node from a picky crowd!

Overall, as our 1st screen purchase.. it was so much better then using the wall or a sheet tacked up like we have! You cant believe how much it enhances the picture. I do wish screen protection was better and a few less pieces to build (capable for younger crowd to set up..) Otherwise, it’s ideal. Wouldn’t hesitate to recommend- hoping info can help your decision.. stay safe everyone.

title: Great watch, much better than my old "smart" watch text: I got Moto 360 several years ago when smart watches first came out and it was nice, but annoying. It was tied into everything and kept giving me alerts and so eventually I got tired of it. My wife also had a first generation Samsung Gear watch and that was about the same as the Moto.
Well, fast forward a few years and now my wife, daughter, son and daughter-in-law all have newer smart watches (Apple Watches and Fitbit) and they all love them. It was time to get a new phone, so I got a Samsung S20 FE and then decided to get the Samsung watch. I saw on the reviews that it really works well with Samsung phones and so I decided to get the Watch 3. I was looking at the Watch 2, which had a few less features and then I found the Watch 3 in the 41mm size and then found a refurbished one so I ended up paying about the same for the Watch 3 as I would have for the Watch 2.
I'm very impressed with the watch and really love it. I didn't get the one with a cell phone, it just connects to my phone with bluetooth and/or wifi, but it's really amazing. I get my messages, and can turn off the ones that I don't want and then I also get all the health apps. So, now it tells me to get off my chair and walk around and does EKG and stress tesing and Oxygen levels..
I was concerned that the 41 mm might be too small, but it is a great size for me as you can see from the pic. I have had a Citizen Echo Drive for more than 10 years and it is a little larger, but I like the size of the Watch 3 better.
If you are thinking about getting a watch, this one is a good deal right now and I believe it does work best if you use it with a Samsung phone.

title: So easy to use. text: We have a TP-Link router, so getting an extender of the same brand seemed to fit the bill in extending our Wi-Fi issues. We live in a 150-year-old apartment building with very thick walls. The cable for the TV and Internet is located in the living room, whereas my office is on the completely opposite side of the building. There are about three walls in between, so my Internet was shoddy at best. I have an iPhone, MacBook Pro, a Toshiba PC, and some handheld gaming consoles, and the only one to get decent service in my office was the MBP.

I ordered the signal extender and stuck it into our bedroom, which is the halfway point from the router to my office. Setting up the device was extremely easy, and took all of a couple minutes (half of which was me making sure I did it right). At first, I noticed no boost in Wi-Fi to my office. Before, the strength of signal reaching back there was about two or three bars on my Toshiba PC, and the first or no arc on my iPhone. However, after going about my business, I found that my Toshiba PC only once has dropped under three bars, and sometimes even reaches its full signal strength--but that's happened once. My iPhone is about the same, but sometimes it does show full signal strength as well.

I never get any more disconnected webpages in my office, and I can go about my work and non-work without having to worry about taking the power off my PC and dashing to the living room.

Only once in the past month or so has it lost signal, but it picked up right away. It also acts as a nice nightlight with its warm blue glow, illuminating the path to the door so I can get out for a quick midnight getaway to the throne room and back.

title: High-end quality without the high price text: What an amazing router at such a great price! I did a lot of research before I bought this. Because my previous router was a TP-Link router also, I was skeptical about this one at first. I was actually leaning towards a $300 Asus gaming router (I don’t game that much, I just wanted something powerful). But truth is, my previous TP-Link was just end of life—almost five years old. I’m pretty certain that WiFi tech was going out. I found an article titled something like “Best 2020 Routers” by Tom’s Guide and this was his #1 ranked router out of 10! After reading some other reviews and resources about it, I pulled the trigger. This router quadrupled my speeds (which wasn’t hard to do I suppose since my previous internet speed was so intermittent and slow).

I am extremely satisfied with this router. I’m a lv 4 IT engineer for a big company, and I can tell you that this is a quality product. You are getting the quality of these expensive gaming routers for half or quarter the cost. And the newer admin interface is very easy and simple. The setup for this router was easier than I’ve ever experienced. I have 25-30 wireless connections by the way and this thing is handling it like a champ. My other router really struggled with that.

I highly recommend this whether you’re technical or not, and whether you’re needing lots of bandwidth or just for basic internet usage.

title: Very good 5 inch display with all the bells and whistles... text: THE GOOD:
--------------
* They provide you with both external and internal accessories to connect a raspberry pi.
* Once up and running, 800x400 pixels is very adequate for a 5 inch screen.
* 10-point capacitive touch.
* Built in dual speakers.
* Monitor has onboard control as well with display menu.
* I tested it with a PI running RasPlex. It ran with no issues.

THE BAD:
------------
* The bezel for this 5 inch is bigger than others on the market, and that's due to having the internal speakers. This is not necessarily a bad.
* No fan. You might want to buy a fan for the cpu.
* Manual only shows you the easy set-up, which will have you running cables all over the place, and it looks messy.
* They do include accessories that will eliminate the external HDMI cable, eliminate touch usb cable, as well as eliminate the need for the monitor to power itself. But they don't explain or teach you how to do it. I didn't make a video for this review, but you can watch my review for the 7 inch version for an idea.
* However, for some reason, the internal touch cable did not work for me in this package. The external micro usb version worked fine. But every time I hooked up the internal cable, it killed the display, it just won't turn on. But once I unhook it, and I use the external cable, the display is back.
* Lastly, not a pro or con, just a FYI.. the packaging and instructions are from USPARKLE.

I'll go 4-Stars overall.

title: BEST. THING. EVER. text: My 'kid' is 24 (cognitively he's about 2) and takes his iPad with him to bed. Doesn't use it, just that's where he puts it when he goes to sleep. Between his pillow and the wall. And every night the iPad was sliding off the bed (even though it is in a silicone case) and I was having to dig it out in the mornings for him. Not once have I had to do this.

I had contemplated a few Pinterest 'hacks' that suggested (for example) using Command Hooks attached to the wall and then sitting the iPad down into those (the big 5# ones) hooks. Problem for us is my kid has seizures that are not well controlled by meds, so all I could 'see' in my mind's eye was him seizing and in the convulsing or 'rooting' he does with most of his seizures (or unconsciously standing up then falling back down) one of those seemingly harmless plastic Command hooks gouging his eyeball out or ripping a nostril open. (If you knew all the off the wall sh** that can and does go wrong with seizures, you'd get why all the one-in-a-billions go through my head!)

Anyway, this was the best $ I've spent in a long time. It holds the iPad without any sliding or moving (the device or the pillow) and it came in his favorite color. He loved it. I love it.

title: Great for holding diffuser on your lights.
text: If you have a flash or constant light on a stand and it doesn't support its own diffusion holder, this is the piece you need. I was working with hot tungsten lamps for a video job in a semi-permanent studio by one of my clients, and it was basically a 500 Watt bulb in a dish, which obviously casts a very harsh bright light with lots of shadow. I picked out some shoot-through umbrellas to get some basic diffusion of the light, and added this piece to go in between the light fixture and the stand to hold the umbrella rod. If you have worked with light setups like this before, you should be familiar as it is pretty standard/basic. Like other adapters of this sort, there is a hinge that lets you tilt the light to get a little extra control over where you are aiming. If you are using this with off camera flashes that use a shoe mount, it already comes with that preinstalled.  In my case, I didn't need the cold shoe mount (the video lights screw into a 1/4" 20 threaded bolt), so I just removed the shoe mount which revealed exactly the connection I needed underneath.  Very useful piece of kit for a simple setup.

title: A little intimidating, but works!
text: We got a reviewer sample of this a while ago and got intimidated as soon as we opened the box.  We were not ready to see so many wires and it looked like a pretty big project.  Before we knew it, winter had come and we lost our motivation to get this installed.  It took until the spring thaw to get into this project again and while it was not quick, the install turned out to not be so bad. I am actually pretty happy with the outdoor night shots and we have captured lots of rabbits in the yard.  It is decent quality, perhaps not razor sharp, but pretty good.  We found a good location off our garage for the device itself which allowed up pretty open lines to run the wires, only once having to really fish it above the ceiling.  Now that it is all set, we have been happy knowing that it is running.  Decent system, but it does take a bit to get into place.

title: Finally someone is mass producing this! text: I've been doing this for years with a DIY rig made out of an interchangeable-plate battery charger. I've even got a video on youtube with over 5k views demonstrating how it works on my A7S and a dummy battery. It is such a simple concept, since most of these smaller cameras have the same voltage requirements as the big NPF batteries, I couldn't believe the market hadn't embraced mass producing the concept.
I was so glad to see devices like this have hit the market, I had to try it! I'm happy to say, it not only works just as I expected it to (provided you have the right size dummy battery adapter), but they improved upon the design by adding USB ports and even USB charging! So now if I don't want to use my dummy battery on, say, my A7Rii, I can use this as a charger to top off the internal battery while recording speeches, AND top off my phone and/or power a recorder or monitor while I'm at it!
These guys thought of everything, even offering USB C or micro USB charging so that you can use whatever cables you happen to have around. So hats off to Power Junkie, for not only mass producing something we no longer have to DIY, but adding enough functionality on top of it to be so worth it.

title: Great companion to my Kamvas 13 text: I'm no artist in any way but I do want to try getting into digital art. As a present to myself, I purchased the [[ASIN:B083W88L5H Huion Kamvas 13]] to get started. Huion is known for providing great quality in their products while keeping the prices affordable.

As anyone who has used a drawing tablet can attest, with the tablet taking up the main desk space, it's difficult to access the keyboard for all the shortcut keys that help to make the job easier. One option is to use an under-the-desk keyboard tray, but I really don't like doing that as I tend to kick the tray when I get in and out of my chair. Others purchase more expensive hotkey devices such as this one.

While the HUION Mini KeyDial KD100 does not have fancy led lights or e-ink display on the keys, it does have the basics of what one would need. The keys are laid out like the number pad on a full 101-key keyboard and the dial can be used to adjust anything that needs a kind of analog input (volume, zoom, brush size, etc). The keys are preconfigured for the most common shortcuts but each key can be customized.

The Mini KeyDial came in an oddly plain white box with the name Huion printed on top. It's almost like this is a rebranded white-box device but that really isn't a problem. It simply means that the unboxing experience isn't as satisfying as the drawing tablet itself. Once connected to the Huion drivers, the device feels fully integrated to Huion's ecosystem.

It is managed in the same driver/software that Huion uses for its tablets so that once you'll be able to get up and running customizing the buttons immediately.

Last thing to point out is that the dial on this device can support Microsoft's own RaDial drivers to emulate the dial that Microsoft introduced a few years ago for the Surface Studio, allowing it to interact natively with built-in Windows utilities.

title: Nice Camera! text: We've set up and used security cameras before in our home, but this is the first pan and tilt one that we have used. Set up took about five minutes. We plugged it into our router with the cable that was provided. We installed software that located the camera and now we can view the camera through the web browser. We plan to install the app to our phones eventually. The camera is easy to control. We have used it primarily for spying on the cats so far, but I'm sure we'll come up with other occasions. The infrared camera works well even in low lighting or darkness and the images are pretty clear. You can set it up to detect motion and then email you when it detects movement. We're having fun playing around with it right now, but there are a lot of real-life applications where this will be handy to have.

*I received this for free in exchange for my honest & unbiased review. My thoughts & opinions are my own.

title: Very good value for Active Noise Cancelling headphones. text: I don't know how it happens but I somehow ended up buying over 20 pairs of bluetooth headphones over the course of my life. I'm also finding that I can't pass up a good pair of bluetooth headphones.

So of the over-head style bluetooth headphones, I've run across problems with short battery life (had one pair that lasts only 3 hours), too tight against the head, presses on the ear (supra-aural) and gets sweaty, active noise cancelling that can't turn on independently of the bluetooth function, and no carrying case.

This pair of RCA Active noise cancelling headphones don't have any of those problems. I sit at my desk all day with an air outlet behind me that is constantly blowing. I'm able to use them the entire day with music playing without the batteries running down. I don't keep the noise cancelling on the entire time but when I do, the fan noise is completely blocked out. Being circumaural headphones, the ear cups completely surround my ears and do not press on them. In addition, the spring isn't too tight to make me feel like my head is being squeezed in a vice.

As far as sound quality, because the speakers are not pressing against the ear, the sound seems to have a wider-room feel, making me feel even more like I don't have headphones on.

Overall, I'm quite satisfied with this purchase and don't feel the need to splurge and buy the much more expensive Sony and Bose products.

title: Cable Connects iPad, iPhone to New, Fast USB-C With PD Charger text: This AMAZONBASICS NYLON BRAIDED USB-C TO LIGHTNING CABLE (MFi Certified iPhone Charger; Silver, 3-Foot) lets me use an 18W USB-C with PD fast charger to charge my new iPad Air (3d gen). (The tablet comes with an old-style 12W USB charger that is pathetically slow.)

USB-C PD (for “Power Delivery”) is a new power standard that increases power levels--up to 100W--so that mobile devices charge much faster. PD determines how much power each device needs, and ensures that it is NOT overcharged.

PD chargers have USB-C ports, so you need a cable with an oval USB-C plug (rather than the familiar flat USB plug) to connect your tablet, cellphone, etc. to the charger. This cable with one lightning cable plug and one USB-C plug is exactly what you need for an Apple tablet or phone that uses a lightning cable. It’s amazing how much faster my iPad Air charges when I use the 18W charger with this cable!

The cable’s braided cover is long-lasting. The 3-foot length is ideal--the cable is long enough to reach from a table to an outlet, but short enough to fit into a purse or backpack for travel.

title: Every pair of earbuds need skinz!
text: Finally, a solution that really stops your headphone cord from tangling up but also protects the wires from becoming detached sooner from the earbuds and connector. I can tell you that I have ruined many earbuds because of tangled cords but no more. Cordskinz is the best solution and works amazingly well. Plus they are super easy to put on and it comes with a skinning tool to help you put them on your earbuds. Now, they don't work on the flat cabled earbuds but they work perfect on the round ones, which these are made for. Maybe they will expand their skinz and make them for the flat cables one day but for now what they have is amazing and if you have earbuds you need these for them to keep them safe. Plus, they look awesome and because they are so easy to switch out you can have a new color for your buds to match your every outfit.

title: Fun Speaker text: This is a neat little speaker. It claims to be waterproof, and I think it would handle a brief rain shower, but I doubt you'd want to throw it into a swimming pool. Still, for poolside entertainment this thing is great. The ports are covered up by a rubber cover, so I think it's about as water resistant as a speaker can be. Beneath the cover is also an on/off switch. It's a tactile switch, not a button so you don't have to sit there pressing it while counting to five or anything ridiculous.

The sound of the speaker is very good for such a little item. The speaker itself is about as wide as an old VHS tape just to give you an idea of scale. There's also a flashlight on one end, which makes this a nice camping item.

Recommended!

I received a free sample in exchange for an honest review.

title: Good, inexpensive alternative to an expensive camera
text: I ordered it with the mindset that it was worth a try.  I have more expensive cameras around the house but I wanted a less expensive camera so that I could check in on my dog when I'm not home.  It's worked well.  The picture quality and the night vision are adequate, the motion sensor works well, it can record and the set up and app are easy.  The features of being able to talk through it and being able to move the camera through the app are fantastic.  I especially love being able to move the camera remotely so that I can see different rooms  I wish my other cameras did that.  Overall, a good choice for a basic camera that you want to use for checking in on your pet.  It's also very discreet so it can be used as a nanny cam to monitor a babysitter or pet sitter.  I'm happy with it.

title: Very happy with the Canon ELPH 100 HS (Grey)! text: The Canon ELPH 100 HS is beautiful, and the Smart Auto feature takes great, no-stress photos for the user who has little or no experience with camera equipment.

Before buying the Canon ELPH 100, I read reviews and did a lot of research online to find a point-and-shoot camera that I would enjoy within the under-$200 price range. There are a lot of good products from which to choose.

I next went to Best Buy, Office Depot, and Sears to hold different point-and-shoot cameras made by the major producers: Canon, Nikon, Sony, Olympus, etc. For me, these visits to different retailers is an important part of the process of buying a point-and-shoot digital camera for the first time.

Another important step is to learn whether or not the camera's software is compatible with your desktop computer. Because my computer is old (2006), I had to research compatibility with the different cameras that I liked. You can find the information at the product websites.

Canon has a very user-friendly website that influenced my purchase considerably.

I had XP Service Pack 2 on an older Dell Dimension E310. For the Canon, I had to download XP Service Pack 3.

I ordered the camera from Amazon.com. From the moment I opened the box of the Canon ELPH 100 HS, I liked everything that I saw. The instructions are clear and organized well.

Finally, I love the pictures that I am taking. No, they are not the same quality as those taken by friends and family members who own thousands of dollars worth of camera equipment. However, these photos are beautiful and fun to take.

I am practicing now so that I will be ready to take photos at baby showers and graduations in the next couple of weeks.

Is it easy to learn how to use the Canon ELPH 100 HS? It is VERY easy to learn how to use Smart AUTO. The sliding Smart AUTO button is on the top of the camera: you slide the latch to Smart AUTO, and you are finished. The camera "decides" whether or not to activate flash and also determines other settings.

To learn to use all of the optional features (P mode) is fun but not essential to photographing great photos right away.

Another reason that I bought the Canon ELPH 100 is that it is considered to be among the best in its price range -- and possibly THE BEST -- in low-light conditions. The only time the colors seemed to be distorted somewhat was when I took photos of pets sitting in a semi-darkened room while they were directly under the strong light of a table lamp. I found that the bright light from the lamp washed over all objects close to the lamp; the objects outside of the lamplight were fainter in color. Since then, I've taken the precaution of composing photos more carefully so that I am not creating a spotlight effect.

I read that the ELPH 300 could be a better choice if you plan to use the video features a lot. For me, the video features on the ELPH 100 are fine.

While in Playback (viewing photos that I have taken), I am learning how to use the displayed menus to select options such as Slideshow and Erase -- so far, so good. While not as easy as Smart Auto, the menus are fairly intuitive.

I have been very pleased. The sheen of the dog's coat, the warm expression in her eyes, and the mysterious, bold gaze of the cat -- all captured beautifully.

title: A Fantastic, Well thought out Tripod text: I have three main uses for tripods, food photography, nature photography and to hold up a spotting scope. This tripod succeeds wonderfully at two of those. It is great for nature photography and supporting the spotting scope. I am 6' 3" and I love that height of this tripod. even without extending the center post, I can comfortably use the tripod when standing.

This is a fantastic birdwatching tripod for my spotting scope. The carbon fiber material is light and rugid. Vanguard has remembered the little things, for example, the upper legs are padded which is huge in when trying to spot an owl in Minnesota at twenty below. The insulation makes the tripod much more comfortable to handle, equally when shooting images of Northern lights.

The legs are fairly sturdy although I feel that here is a little more play in the carbon fiber over my older aluminum, Bogen tripod. I was a little disappointed that there are just a few angle settings for the legs. They click into 30 and about 60 degrees. It would be nice to have more granular settings, so I find myself altering leg lengths more than my other tripod. The feet are well designed with hard steel spikes with nice rubber feet for indoor uses. Both options allow for good stable footings.

Also there are some great other details like leveling bubbles on the top of the tripod and ball head. Also, I like that they though to include a hook at the bottom of the center post for adding stability weights. The leg releases are easy to use and have held tight during all my time in the field with the tripod.

Where I wish they had put more into this tripod is the ball head. It doesn't seem to live up to the tripod body. I miss a pan handle and while I appreciate the feel and functionality of the locking knobs, it just seems like it is not the pro quality of the rest of the tripod. There is a second leveling bubble on the head itself which is fantastic. But probably the biggest drawback is the quick release plate. It is not quick at all, it requires quite a bit of screwing with thumbscrew to attach. Also there is not set screw on the "quick" release plate.

Pros
+ Height
+ padded legs for comfort in cold weather
+ Light Weight
+ Great feet, both the grippy robber shoes and the steel spikes
+ built in leveling bubbles
+ Functional and strong leg locks
+ built in hook on bottom of center post
+ Second leveling bubble on the head

Cons
- No built in strap
- Carrying case is ok (this is more a neutral than a con)
- the head is not great
- limited leg angles
- Head could be better
- Somewhat awkward and slow quick release plates
- Lacks a panning arm.

In General, this is an awesome tripod, but for the money I would have expected a little more, especially a strap and a better head unit. But I have to admit I love this tripod. I would have put 4.5 stars if possible, but for $500 my expectation for a "Professional" tripod head is a little higher. But for my uses it's awesome, it holds the Spotting Scope will but again, lack of a panning arm hinders it. From the shoulders down, the best I've seen.

title: Does the trick text: These are the large F960/970 size batteries, the biggest standard Sony NP sized batteries you can get them in. I use these extensively to power lights, recorders, monitors... they are the single most versatile sized battery a video freelancer can have on them.
I've used many brands of this battery, from Neewer, Wasabi, Power2000, Great Video Maker, etc, and they all seem pretty competitive to each other. Ironically, the only brand I HAVEN'T used is the authentic Sony batteries. This brand seems right up there with them so far. The batteries last a long time and are very large physically. On the flip side, they come with only a very basic charger, which anyone using these probably has plenty of already. So it shouldn't be any surprise that it takes hours to fully charge one of these (I usually leave them overnight, I don't know how long they actually take but it definitely seems to be more than a few). This is not the fault of the charger, this is normal for a battery this size.

title: This keyboard is comfortable to use thanks to the fabric
text: This keyboard is comfortable to use thanks to the fabric, and doesn't feel cramped despite the 12" size.  Keys feel solid and type well, with medium-high resistance, and are somewhere in the middle between quiet and noisy.  The keyboard isn't as noisy as most mechanical keyboards (like a Cherry blue/green) but it's still noisy enough to bother my wife if I'm using it in bed when she wants to sleep.  The backlighting is well-balanced, enough to make keys clear and easy to read but not so much that it looks freaky at night.  The magnetic attachment to the surface pro works like a charm, and is so easy it's almost fool-proof.  It still feels expensive (compared to similarly priced mechanical gaming keyboards) but does its job well.

title: A Good DVD Player for Those With Limited Needs text: Portable DVD players have their use and the Verezano Portable DVD Player is a decent one for general needs. With a nine inch screen area, stereo speakers, and a swivel screen, it’s a good DVD player for children and others and it’s nice to have when on vacation or in other situations when the kids need some electronic entertainment.

We use portable DVD players in my household mostly for child entertainment so I often base buying decisions and reviews from that perspective. This portable DVD player does seem to have the minimum requirements to keep the kids happy and occupied. It is made mostly from plastic and is lightweight. And kids love the swivel screen. I have had to step in a few times and calm them down, as they love grabbing the screen and twisting it back and forth.

I find the functions on this portable DVD player simple to use and my kids had no trouble picking up on the operations. I did notice, however, that the remote control does not always make the unit respond. I often have to grab it and point more directly at the unit to get it to accept my command and even then, it takes a couple of pushes before anything happens. It isn’t a battery issue, as it does this even when the batteries are fresh.

Speaking of batteries, probably my greatest problem with this Verezano DVD player is the battery life in the unit itself. A charge is good for only about 2 hours, and that means it will die out after a one full movie is watched and sometimes even sooner. This means a long road trip in the car or flight on a plane will be too much. The unit will die out and have to be recharged long before your destination is reached.

So, judging this product from different angles, it seems to have the adequate properties to make it a worthwhile purchase for those with limited needs. My kids really like the swivel screen and they quickly figured out how to make it the player operate. But the battery life and issues with the remote control convince me to lower my rating to 3 stars. You basically get what you pay for, and that means a very average product.

title: Creates Mixed Feelings
text: The iHOMX 360 Degree Rotating Long Arm Adjustable Tablet Stand Holder was packaged well, easy to assemble and holds my iPad securely. The one issue I quickly found is that the counter balanced weight of the base is not even. This is disappointing as the goose-neck arm allows for a great variety of positions, but due to the non-centered base, it will easily tip over unless the weight of the tablet is directed in the same direction as the bulk of the base. This can be corrected with placing more weight, like books, over the base. However, this requires extra clutter in my work area. I'm using the tablet holder beside my work area to follow video tutorials, it does keep my tablet safe from my messy products and supplies, but the base isn't centered so it requires one extra step on my part to use it easily. I find the price fair, but the balance of weight on the base is disappointing.  Thanks for reading, if this was Helpful to you, please click the button below.

title: I bought it for the gimmick and I was still disappointed text: Don't get me wrong, it's a mouse. It functions like a mouse should and nothing else.

Pros:
-The tank-track scroll wheel is a neat gimmick to show your friends once. Whole reason I bought it basically.
-projected logo is cool, albeit blurry
-Feels ok in the hand, and the clicking action is satisfying (should expect as much from cherry)

Cons:
-Horrible, and I mean Horrible side button placement. They are way too far back, feel cheap and squishy, and hitting the back button requires you to be a hand gymnast. Either they tested this with child hands or didn't test it at all.
-Useless RGB. Seriously, it's nearly invisible, why even include it? I had it for a week before I realized it had RGB lighting
-sensitivity controls are a goldilocks game. Low is incredibly low, high makes your mouse a crackhead, and medium is manageable.
-super cheap packaging.

If you want to try a neat gimmick mouse, give it a shot. Don't expect it to be a great mouse though

title: Great padded case for carrying your gear text: This is my second Condition 1 case that I've tried out for my photo/video gear. The last one was beige colored, but otherwise pretty much identical to this one. So my review of it should be the same- the foam cut outs are easy to tear and conform to things like cameras, lenses, microphones, and other goodies you want to keep safe. It is tough and rugged feeling, however I hope I never have to test the water proof part.
While this one came fine, the other Condition 1 case I got had a loose rubber lining that wasn't in the groove etched along the cover. I was able to push it back in and it's been fine there ever since, but I don't know how waterproof that really is if it ever gets dislodged again in the future. So, don't take these swimming with you, however I'd personally trust it to the elements like rain.
A good case otherwise. I'm going to check if they have a deeper one to accommodate my Phantom drone, as this is slightly too short for it.

A layered design doubles internal space to hold ample items. We packed: wall butts, iPhone cords, x1 AirPod, x2 headphones, x2 battery boosts, speaker for x4 kiddos and myself!!!

Best yet, with roomy space the size is quite small and unpretentious, easy to slip into carry-on and TSA check no prob! The bonus.. as one’s batteries run low I’ve got whatever needed at arms reach- in x1 place.. AmAziNg!! Interior elastic straps, pockets/pouches + movable walls hold content secure- keeping a “jack in the box” of tangle from popping out when opened! Reinforced handle lets you carry with confidence.. A total solution I’d recommend without hesitation. Hoping info helps decision- stay safe everyone.

title: A No Frills, High Quality Organizer for My Action Cam text: This is not the most gorgeous, whistles and bells laden case out there, but what it lacks in aesthetic glitz it makes up for in utilty and ruggedness. For me, I was looking for a way to organize a Sony HDR-AS100VR POV Action Video Camera with a couple of mounts and their tiny remote monitor. So I did not need a lot of space, just a protective, organizing case. This is not the biggest case in the world so if you are running multiple GoPros with a ton of mounts, it's not for you. It will work fine for my single cam needs. Personally I love that I can pack this in my luggage.

As for organization... There is a nice side pocket for cables, three bays for storing the components, including one Velcro adjustable bay so your can customize two of the bays a little. Internally, there is another side pocket, two multiuse but smallish mesh pockets and three elastic bays to store SD cards. So you have enough room for everything you would need for a personal Action Cam and perfect for what I was looking for.

The case is lightly padded, but offers ok protection for traveling in a backpack etc. Not waterproof but probably somewhat water resistant for rain and light splashing The zippers are reinforced at the ends to avoid fraying as are handles and zipper pulls. It really seems to be designed with long lifespan in mind. The looks are understated but classy. All in all, perfect for what I was looking for.

Pros
+ Rugged Design
+ Small for a single camera set up
+ Will pack well into luggage
+ Good organizational pockets inside and out
+ Well manufactured and reinforced

Cons
- Not very big so might be to small if you have multiple mounts
- Not the most beautiful bag on the market, but very functional

Bulk aside- the sound quality is great. Cancellation of background noise works really well! Battery life is great. It's an amazing Bluetooth piece if you can get past the humongous size!

title: Great tablet for the price. text: For $80, this tablet is actually pretty good. It's about the same height as my Note8, but almost double the width. Still, the tablet-exclusive apps on the Google Play Store work without issue on it, though of course you're going to sacrifice some viewing due to the smaller scale.

When I got the tablet I knew it wasn't going to be anything spectacular. At $80, I knew it wasn't going to compete with the devices I was used to, but it still was nice to have to act as a tablet to play my tablet-exclusive games on and for the kids to use to play their games. The screen of course isn't the sharpest, and out of the box it isn't as sensitive in all areas. Two of the first games I installed were a couple of pinball apps, and the screen had a hard time detecting my presses on the left side.

The screen is quite sharp considering it's a "low-end" tablet, and the feel is very solid. Has a nice textured back to it which makes me reconsider if I'll get a case. The screen does retain fingerprints easily but a quick wipe on a shirt resolves all issues.

There is a microSD slot which is a nice addition; I can transfer any transferable games to that since this tablet has only 16 GB (less considering there's only 14.-something and some of that is taken up by the OS).

Operating the OS is super sluggish. Takes four times as long to do something as it would on a beefier device. But actual in-app operations aren't as bad. A little more sluggish than on a beefier device, but not enough to notice that much.

Since this tablet doesn't have a phone speaker at the top, the actual main speaker is located in its stead. As a result, you get a nice, loud, crisp sound whenever you watch a movie or play a game.

All in all, a fantastic little tablet for the price; I hope the missing sensitivity spots are temporary. The screen isn't as smooth as others, but I'm willing to forgive that for the price.

title: Superb Tablet Stand, Suitable for Industrial Use text: I have a 10" tablet and it primarily gets used as an e-reader and as a music streaming device. It's a great device and I love it, but I do get frustrated with figuring out where to put it when I am streaming music through it. Although it is a relatively small device it does take up some room on the desk when in a stand case. I have tried suction mounts to attach it to a window and that works fine but the window cannot move and when the window is cold the suction mount lets go. This flexible mount for tablets is a very good solution for my needs and is far better constructed than suggested by the product description.

This is a simple mount in concept and design. It is flexible coil tube with a screw-on vice clamp attached on one end and an adjustable frame-style bracket attached via a ball joint to the other. In the box the unit comes unassembled and requires less than two minutes to put together. When finished, the whole thing is approximately 3' long.

Everything about this mounting stand suggests that it is built to last and is designed to hold up under heavy use. The coil tube is about the heaviest I have ever seen: it is roughly a half inch in diameter and is exceptionally stiff which makes it well suited for supporting the weight of the tablet. The item description here says it will support 2.2 pounds but it will support a little more than that (though I would not try to put much extra on there, particularly if the coil is horizontal).

The coil attaches to the vice clamp via a threaded machine screw assembly and it has enough threading to allow the coil to turn 360 degrees without becoming detached. This allows the tablet to be swung around a work area in an arch without having to really do anything that requires any effort. While this is great, what really caught my attention is that the clamp itself can be screwed to the coil in two ways at 90-degree angles (top or side) so that the clamp can be attached to an anchored surface that is either horizontal or vertical. This is one of those design decisions that just makes sense but I have seen very few manufacturers make this kind of effort.

The coil is covered by a very heavy plastic sleeve which protects the tube and makes flexing the tube easier on the hands.

The mounting bracket is connected to the top of the flexible tube by a ball joint, similar to the kind of joints many GPS navigators use in cars to attach to the suction base. When I first attached the bracket to the coil I put it on upside down, which is not a big deal except that the weight of the tablet worked against the joint and it tilted downward slightly. The bracket itself is a standard slider with a lever that presses against the slider which then catches on teeth on the frame to lock it in place. There's a fair bit of padding on the bracket to protect the tablet when it's being clamped in and when the position is being adjusted.

This mounting stand is of such heavy construction that it suggests the stand was designed for industrial use. While it is just fine for home use and is not out of place in a professional office, it is a good for a manufacturing assembly line or even a busy retail location.

This is a great mounting stand for tablets in 7"-11" range. The whole stand is very sturdy and solid and is build to last. Based on my experience with it I can heartily recommend it to any one who needs a mounting solution for a tablet.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

title: Solid Sound Profile text: The current trend with ear buds is to boost the bass to the point of overpowering the rest of the sound profile. I don’t particularly like bass that is too heavy because it can give me awful headaches. These buds have the bass boosted but it is not over the top.

These ear buds are very lightweight and low profile. Smaller than many ear buds I have used they fit in my ears very comfortably. The silicone inserts are soft and do not cause any discomfort, but just as important they create a good seal in the ear canal and as a result they have good passive noise canceling (sound isolation). This is a good sign right out of the package - many ear buds I have tried do not seal properly.

The sound profile is the most important aspect of any earphones or ear buds. There are really three areas in the sound profile that merit mention - the highs, the mids and the bass. This set of buds is marketed as heavy bass and that is not completely true. Yes, they do have good bass, but it is not heavily overdriven like most. The bass is a little more front-and-center, not in-your-face, if that makes some sense. The mids are good and the music sounds full as a result, not hollow and depthless. The highs are very bright and clear which is a slight surprise - most ear buds that enhance the bass do so at the expense of the highs, so having a set that had strong bass and highs together is a very nice change of pace.

These buds come with a very small carrying case. It is a pinch case and has enough room for just the buds and the replacement silicone inserts. It is a soft plastic case and provides protection only from dirt and moisture (though by no means waterproof) so this is not a case that will help when the buds are crammed in a pocket or backpack.

This is a very nice set of ear buds at a very nice asking price. They have a very good sound profile and they are comfortable to wear. Keep these in mind when looking for inexpensive buds and good sound.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

title: More dust blowing than for vacuuming...

title: Nice sport watch, but not sure about blood pressure accuracy.
text: The Pard Health Sport Watch has a pedometer (steps taken, distance and calories burned), heart rate monitor (beats per minute), O2 monitor (amount of oxygen in your blood), weather (current temp, high and low temp), messages (must be synced with your smart phone), stopwatch, find feature (locates your phone, in app on phone will locate watch), a blood pressure monitor and an exercise monitor.  The exercise monitor tracks running, cycling, jump roping, table tennis, badminton, tennis and swimming.  The watch is comfortable to wear and looks nice, it has five different watch faces you can choose as your display. I chose this watch because of the blood pressure (bp) monitor, I have high blood pressure and I take medication to keep it normal.  I own two electronic high blood pressure test cuffs and I tested my blood pressure with both of them and the watch and the two cuffs were +/- a point or two apart, but the watch was reading a lot higher than the other monitors.  Throughout the day I repeated the test and the watch was constantly reading that my blood pressure was high, even after I had taken my medication and I know the readings should have changed.  I will have to get with my doctor/nurse and have them do a manual test and see if the watch is showing the same results.  If the watch bp monitor is not accurate, I have not been able to find any way to recalibrate the watch to input the correct bp reading.  That is the only problem I have with this watch.  I like all the features the watch has along with the phone app too.  It doesn't take long to learn all the functions of the watch as well as the app.  If you have high blood pressure, I wouldn't rely on just the watch to monitor your blood pressure because I don't believe it is accurate enough.  Maybe in time there will be an upgrade in the software to fix that. Other than that it is a great sport watch and I am happy with it overall.

title: Decent Entry-Level Bluetooth-Only Headphones text: I have worked with a lot of different headphones, mostly active noise canceling (ANC) phones but also more traditional phones. Over the years I have had several Sennheiser phones and they typically have balanced sound and good build quality. This set is a step down from many of the others with which I have worked, though they’re still decent.

My preference on headphones is over-the-ear phones which for me are more comfortable. These particular phones are on-ear, and these pinch a little after extended wear. They’re better than some of the other on-ear phones with which I have worked, but I still prefer over-the-ear phones. One preference I have is a headphone that clamps down fairly tightly when worn so they’re less likely to slip off when I tilt my head down; these are a lighter fit.

These are Bluetooth-only phones and as such cannot be used with non-BT devices. This is unfortunate but isn’t a deal-breaker. These connect easily and quickly.

These are not ANC phones, but they have excellent passive noise canceling which is quite surprising for on-ear phones. They reduce ambient noise in my office considerably, which us especially noticeable when running a large fan that I use to generate white noise. I am pleased with that aspect of these phones. These are still not as effective as a set of ANC phones.

The sound profile is fairly typical of Sennheiser phones, though the bass is mildly beefed up.. The trend with phones these days is overdriven bass, and these do increase the bass response a little bit but not to a headache-inducing level. The midrange is full and warm, and that’s a good thing as many times the increased bass comes at the expense of the midrange. The highs are bright and clear without being piercing. Overall, the sound is reasonably balanced, but certainly not audiophile quality.

Build-wise, these actually feel a bit on the cheaper side which is surprising. These aren’t exactly fragile, but they are definitely not of the same build quality as other Sennheisers I have used in the past.

These are probably best described as entry-level headphones. They’re not the highest quality, and they are not the most sturdy, but the sound quality is fine and the cost is right. The main thing I would change is the addition of an audio port so they could be used as wired phones.

title: A pleased long-time user text: Although this review may seem to be "a little late", I do think that my experience with the earlier model of this Sony is appropriate. I bought a KDS-60A2000 in January of 2007 so I've had it for a few months over a year. As most of you will recognize, my unit is a 60" SXRT from the previous model year.

Like many of you, I did a lot of Internet research before settling on the Sony - it was very highly rated by a number of sites. The final straw was live viewing many sets side-by-side on the same program from the same source - it was a no-brainer - the Sony had at least as good a picture as any Plasma in the store and the price couldn't be beat.

I use Verizon's FIOS fiber optic service and have the unit hooked up through my home theater audio. The picture - indeed the HD experience - is simply awesome - especially live sports - like ice hockey.

I did "tune" the picture using the DVE (Digital Video Essentials) HD optimization DVD and it remains the sharpest, most accurate picture that I have personally seen (including the high-bucks plasma sets). I've had absolutely no problems of any kind and there have been no regrets on purchasing this set.

Another tidbit: I also purchased a Logitech Harmony 880 remote control and am able to control the Sony, the Verizon HD receiver, a Yamaha home theater receiver and a Sony upscaling DVD with a single click. It's programmed via the Logitech Internet site (using a USB connection) and can handle about any peripheral you might have. I've got a bowlful of unused remotes now. It's a little pricey at $150 but it has contributed to my HD enjoyment by simplifying the mechanics.

title: AMAZING QUALITY EXTERIOR GRADE ETHERNET Cat8 CABLE! text: I have used and tested more Ethernet cables than I can remember and there is no question, all Ethernet cables are not created equally.

Typically any device requiring an Ethernet cable will come with one in the packaging - it will work (usually). A good comparison is those cables are much like an old car - it should get you there, whereas this cable is like a high end sports car - it will get you there lightning fast, without failure.

This Cat8 is thicker than some due to the shielding within and additional insulation. This cable is made to withstand and holdup to exterior environments for the long term. The connector bases are reinforced at each end of the wire which really help hold all of the wires in place even if you have to bend and twist it to fit it within the plug. The connector plug itself is gold plated which is the ultimate standard in connectivity.

This Cat8 Ethernet Cable is 75’ long which makes it absolutely ideal for using it to directly plug your TV or gaming system into your router - even if located in a different room. So many of us stream programs and movies via our TV and there is no comparison in speed between a WiFi connection and a wired connection. For gamers, it is absolutely the way to go - do away with all lag caused by your WiFi by connecting directly to your router.

You will not find a better exterior grade Cat8 Ethernet Cable - this is really a top of the line cable that you’ll love.

This is a purchase that you’ll never regret.

title: Works Great for Me text: I selected this audio extension cable for the office, where I need to use headphones to listen to content but am unable to move the source. A 6' audio cable is often too short, and having an extension cable instead of a full audio cable enables me to use different headphone sets. So far, this cable has worked out for me.

This is a nylon-wrapped cable which I prefer to plastic-insulated cables for durability. Unlike many other nylon cables, though, this one has some flex to it and it is not stiff and prone to knotting or kinking like others I have used. The end connectors are attached with a plastic sleeve that is stiff enough to keep the cable from getting bent at the connector without some effort, and this should greatly help in making this cable last longer since the point of connection is usually the failure point for me with audio cables.

The main concern I had when adding this cable to my configuration is if it would work seamlessly or would it introduce static or a hum to output. While this might not be a huge concern in this case it was still something I made a point to check. The sound was identical with this cable in place as it is without it. Even when turning the connector on either end, there was no static. That's all I can really ask of it.

This cable meets a need I had and it works very well. It's made nicely and it doesn't impact sound quality, good or bad (unless replacing a bad extension cable). Based on my working with it I am happy to recommend it.

title: Really useful (even WITHOUT the subscription!) text: Ok, I have to admit I'm pretty impressed with this little camera. At first I thought I had to use the Haven subscription, especially after reading the reviews here which said it is necessary. I was kind of bummed about that at first but it turns out this is really useful even without! Sure, being able to record videos and store them in the cloud require a subscription as well as many of the advanced features, but you can still "arm" the camera to snap a photo and alert your phone when it detects motion, which it does splendidly even without a sub. The way I currently use it, it alerts my phone and I can then go to the live view and see and even interact with who is there (talk feature is really cool!).
On top of that, I set ours up with Amazon's Alexa voice service and it is EXTREMELY COOL! I think the speaker seems a bit louder than an Echo Dot, which surprised me. I'm mounting ours by the front porch so we can see people come to the door and interact with them, but we can also use it to play music via Amazon's Alexa when just sitting on the porch drinking coffee. That's an amazing perk that I wasn't expecting before we got it!
I do wish you could combine it with device music groups in Alexa (so I could say, for example, play this song on the everywhere group and it will play inside on our Echo and out on the porch with the Ecobee), but sadly only echo devices can be grouped. That's OK, I knew that before getting this as other devices in our home can't be grouped either (Facebook Portal or Kindles, for example).
If you want to spring for the subscription service, there's a TON of goodies and advanced features beyond even the cloud storage things. But even without that, the live view and photo motion alerts combined with the voice assistant / Alexa integration makes it worth it even just for the hardware alone!

title: No tension adjustment for rotation text: Like most of these stands with monitor rotation that I have been thru, this has no adjustable tension on the rotation mechanism. This means the weight of the monitor will make it lean to one side or the other, especially when you have it in portrait orientation. There are tension adjustments on every other part of the arm... I have no idea why they choose to make the rotation non-adjustable, but with the monitor leaning from side to side it makes the arm basically worthless. This will become worse over time as you adjust the rotation and tension continues to weaken.

If anyone has a recommendation for one of these adjustable arms that DOES include a tension adjustment for the rotation, I would appreciate it.

title: Nearly indestructible, nice length ... text: I was actually looking for a longer sturdier lightning cable when this showed up. I've been using it for a couple of weeks now, and I'm definitely a fan.

First, it's very solid with reinforced plugs (both ends). I've worn out many lightning cables, and the place where they wear out first is where the cord connects to the plug (especially on the lightning end). That shouldn't be a problem here.

The cord has a round braided nylon cover that helps prevent tangling. Yes, it takes up more room than either a flat cable or a smaller cord, but I think the durability outweighs that.

Finally, the length is great. I use a shorter cable for my bedside recharging station, but when I travel (especially when I travel), I'm never sure where the outlet will be, and I like to have my phone handy on the nightstand just in case. A longer cable gives me more options and some reassurance that at least ONE of the outlets will be close enough with this longer cable to allow me to have the phone handy.

Charging speed is just fine, too - comparable to my Apple-original cables.

Basically, I have no complaints at all. With the quality and durability, this should last a long time. Solid 5 stars from me.

title: Cheap Junk! text: I have only used this drive a few times - to rip some CD's and burn ISO. I always suspected the speed was more USB 2 than USB 3. It is very, very SLOW.

Tonight, I tried to eject a CD that I had in the drive and there was no response - when I looked at the 'USB 3 ' connector, I noticed it was just flopping around and not making contact.
It seems the connector on the drive is too weak to support the weight of the heavy USB cable.
Anyway it is being returned - but thankfully AMAZON will handle the defective return.
So ZERO stars for this 'Pawtec' drive, AKA 'Poor-Tech", and 5 stars for AMAZON!
