title: They have software called Sentinel you install on your PC and this is your gateway to all updates and firmware and it can contro text: This review is for the Uniden BCD436HP I see reviews here for other radios, so not to be confused.
I used Amazon Prime Now to get the radio to me, in less than 1 hour (about 45 minutes) the delivery person was knocking on my door with my new receiver, wow, I was highly impressed and I will always check to see if Prime Now is available for all my deliveries from now on.....
So, the radio....
This receiver has a 4 gig SD card preloaded with every known frequency with text for the entire US and Canada. They have software called Sentinel you install on your PC and this is your gateway to all updates and firmware and it can control your radios SD card any way you like. Sentinel has an extensive database of all frequencies and let me say this again, all frequencies have text description included which is the most highly advanced scanner database system I have ever seen and I have owned scanner receivers most of my adult life, (long time)..
This is a digital receiver using the latest technology available. It can monitor any analog or digital TX (with some exceptions, like encrypted signals) and gives you extensive control over what you're listening to. There are FCC laws regarding what is legal and not legal to monitor and Uniden has got us right up to the maximum legally allowed to be monitored by civilians. If you are law enforcement persons you will have much more powerful receivers available to you capable of Cell phone conversation monitoring etc., things no civilian should even be interested in.
There is another version of this Uniden radio, the BCD536 which is a tabletop version. If you have large powerful outdoor weatherproof antennas the BCD536 is a good option and it is completely transferable to vehicle dash mount and back from your work desk to your vehicle.
I like this handheld BCD436 best personally for my purposes.
This is basically a plug and play receiver. It comes with 3 2300 milliamp rechargeable batteries, load those, charge them or just leave radio plugged in, enter your zip and you're in. Well theoretically that's how it works, in the real world? No.
When you first receive the radio I would suggest positioning yourself in front of your PC. Have the paper manual, the radio, you and your PC right there in front of you. Get ready to read and learn your radios keyboard layout and what these great, well thought out keys can do for you. You will learn, trust me, you will quickly come to love this radio.
Some cons:
No wall charger adopter included. You can charge from your PC's USB ports but you will need a wall charger with USB port. Most of us have several of these around the house from old cell phones etc. They work fine.
This unit should come with a nice wall charger adopter. That's really the only con, not to bad really.
Antennas:
Your ability to scan and receive signals on any scanner is proportionate to your antennas. The more robust and correct (correct meaning size, materials used etc).. You will need some nice antennas for this nice radio to increase your scanning powers. Amazon has some nice antennas, scannermaster.com has some also. Your local radio shop retailer will have some also. The included rubber ducky antenna is garbage, toss it from across the room to your garbage can, see if you can make a rim shot. Like I said, I have been playing with scanners for many years so I have many antennas to pick from.
Verdict:
This is without a doubt, the most powerful handheld scanning receiver available from any manufacturer. It is the luxury sedan of the scanning receiver world. It is easy and robust. It is backed up by Uniden's Sentinel software which will future proof your radio for many years to come.
I give Uniden 5 stars for this winner.
I give Amazon 5 stars for Prime Now 1 hour shipping, also a winner.

Edit:
Okay some people are wondering what the best accessories are for this receiver.
Go to scannermaster.com and look for the Austin Condor All-Band Portable BNC Antenna and the SpectrumForce Desk Mount for One Portable Scanner.
The Condor all band antenna is unsurpassed.
The desktop stand holds your handheld at the perfect viewing angle, you can listen and see all text clearly right beside your computer.
See my photos. The photos ended up sideways.... trying to fix this..... Amazon, can you turn my photos upright?

Also, the blue tooth connectivity seems weaker than my PCX 310's. I get a lot of dropouts and 15 foot range from my laptop. I have found that I only use these patched into my work computer with the included cord. I have not been overly impressed with the bluetooth sound quality on these headphones, but they are pretty sleek and comfortable. The bluetooth set up and quick and easy and I have no troubles getting connected to my laptop. I just have issues when I move away from my laptop.

Corded, the sound is fairly good, but does not live up to the sticker price. For $300 dollars I expect stellar sound quality and I'm not getting that from these.

title: DO NOT BUY
text: PLEASE PLEASE, do not buy these cameras and the doorbell. I did not listen. Now I am not going to use a lot of big words to describe the problem. I am just going to tell you the truth. I am 70 years old and I purchased these cameras because I live alone and I wanted security. I am not secure and I do not feel secure. I purchased due to all the advertisements and because Shaq endorsed them. They do not work and the customer service really sucks. One day I was put on hold for 45 minutes then hung up on. The supervisors are no help at all. I purchased 3 floodlight cameras and 1 doorbell camera. They all are malfunctioning. The doorbell does not alert until the person is long gone. What is the purpose if the incident is over before you can even see it. Then you cannot even pull the incident up for about 4-5 minutes! You have to wait to see who was at your door and that's not safe. in 4-5 minutes someone could already be in your house!! I have horrible neighbors who are interfering with one of the floodlight cameras and literally making it go off every 1-3 minutes. I've called ring over 52 times since October of 2019. They cannot or will not resolve the issue, other than tell me the camera cannot be tampered with. I KNOW THAT IS NOT CORRECT! If you buy these cameras buy at your own risk. I am here to tell you that they do not work and customer service will not help you when they fail and they will fail!!!! Shame on you Shaq O' Neal. Shame on you Amazon for buying and selling this mess !!!!!!!  On my last recent call to Ring I was told that the cameras do not work in real time. The representatives say whatever they want to try and get you to hang up. I'm 70 not senile. Someone named Richmond told me that! The commercials show the people walking up, you activating the sound and talking to the person. One of My problems is the people are already gone before the camera actually activates. I would look into buying something else if I could afford it. You have a choice. DO NOT BUY RING. Do not be tricked like I was.

title: I am amazed at the sound that these small speakers produce text: Looks like I have the privilege of being the first person to review the BA M25 speakers. I picked up a pair of these on Christmas Eve and have been playing them constantly over the past 2 weeks. My focus has been on 2 channel stereo recordings instead of movies. My set up is through an older Denon AVR 610 receiver that I have had for almost 20 years. I was initially impressed with the smooth, balanced feel of these speakers. Good mid range, nice high end, but not too bright, and a very strong bass response. The M25s defy their size in producing bass tones. Give them some break in time before making a final assessment. These speakers excel at producing music performed on real instruments. The do a great job on jazz, blues and acoustic folk styles of music. Vocals come across nicely as well.
Boz Scaggs "But Beautiful" CD of standards sounds great. Upright bass, piano and vocals make you feel like you are in a small jazz club. Diana Krall "Live in Paris" also plays very well. Nice piano, guitar & vocal reproduction. Jorma Kaukonen's "Blue Country Heart" CD showcases some great finger style acoustic guitar. Very natural acoustic guitar tones. Linda Ronstadt's "Winter Light" CD has some of the most powerful vocals you will ever hear and the M25s reproduce Linda's voice and backing instrumentation extremely well. The sound is never strained or harsh. Initially, I was a bit more apprehensive on some CDs with lots of bass. They sounded like they were trying to overcompensate on bass, but this has evened out over the past week. Eric Clapton's "Pilgrim" CD has come serious bottom end and the M25s produce very deep, tight bass response. Peter Gabriel "So" is a similar story. Deep, tight bass response that does not bottom out. Paul Rogers "Muddy Waters Blues" is a treat on the M25s. The opening track features some acoustic delta blues guitar, followed by a chorus of female backup singers and later some nice Strat blues guitar tones. It all sounds great on these speakers.
The look and finish on the speakers is impressive also. They are finished in a polished black exterior with a leatherette finish on the top, back & bottom. They look like a piece of fine furniture that would fit into a modern style of home décor. These speakers are very expensive though. I got a demo pair at less than half of the $399 per speaker list price. I don't think I would have bought them at full price. I have been listening to Boston Acoustics speakers for over 20 years. I still own a pair of A60s and a pair of A120s that have served me well over the years. The M25s have replaced the A120s as my primary speakers in my living room due to their sonic capabilities and their stylistic good looks.

Update 6/24/14 - After listening to these speakers for 6 months, I continue to be even more impressed by the Boston M25s. I bought these thinking they will do until I can find better. While there are better speakers out there, I have concluded, after many demo sessions, that I would need to spend at least $1500-$1800 or more to get some form of improvement over the M25s. Short of stepping up to KEF R300 @ $1800, B&W CM5 @ $1500 or Aperion Verus Towers, the M25s deliver the goods with very balanced & neutral sound, great detail in the upper register and sold bass. Highly recommended.

title: MOVE THE CHANNEL GUIDE AMAZON!!!
text: The GOOD:  1.  Set up was pretty easy and the Recast actually pulled in about 6 channels I never received before--even using the same antenna! 😊 2.  The ability to use Alexa to navigate is nice (although I don't use it) - - especially since the user interface is awful (see below) .  The BAD:  1.  The absolute WORST thing about this is that the Channel Guide is buried and you have to scroll through several menus to actually find it.  AMAZON, IF YOU'RE LISTENING :  MOVE THE CHANNEL GUIDE!  It should be the first thing you see on the home page, or at least put a link up in the top bar where you put everything else (Home, Live, DVR, etc.)  2.  The user interface needs to be streamlined--it is way too busy.  3.  Along those lines, there is no way to delete the apps you don't want on there, so we're stuck navigating through a bunch of stuff we are not interested in and will never watch.  4.  A minor issue probably,  but the channels are listed by name and not number in the Channel Guide, so if you're  used to punching in numbers on a remote, this takes getting used to.  I would prefer it if there was a number pad on the remote to punch in the channel number, but there isn't.  You can tel Alexa to "tune to channel #___, but I prefer to do this the old-fashioned way.  5.  Even though there are 4 tuners, you can only WATCH on 2 devices at a time.  If Amazon would make the channel guide more accessible, this could be a 5 Star review!

title: Stylish, flexible and total protection text: It may be a bit pricey, but is definitely at home in a conference room and does make an impression. However, the key is the protection it provides and the folio's flexibility in accommodating right- or left-handed folks.

You can change the orientation of the sketch pad and tablet by simply turning the folio upside down, reinserting the sketch pad from that direction, and doing the same with the tablet holder, which is held in place by a magnet. In addition, this offers two different viewing angles as well as a typing angle when the folio is configured as a stand. See my customer-supplied images for details.

I love the absolute protection that this folio/tablet holder provides. The holder into which the iPad snaps in is tough and shock resistant, and the folio itself is equally so. This comes with a screen protector to add yet another layer of protection. Of course, with the paper sketch pad covering the face of the iPad when this is closed gives maximum protection to the screen should you accidentally drop it.

While the functionality and protective features are outstanding, this folio has looks too. If you like understated elegance this has it. Or it does in my opinion. I love the feel of the exterior, which is akin to a fine suede, but is truly tough.

The pad itself can be replaced with 6x9 inch refills. The actual size of the one that ships with the case is slightly undersized, but I did test a standard 6x9 and it fit.

title: This capture device came with a HDMI cable, it's a lot of bang for your buck, and works great... text: [[VIDEOID:6fbb7930c23f2b3918bfee62b7dbdebc]] THE GOOD:
---------------
* Price. Wow, less than $20. I just reviewed another usb capture device for $60. I'm not sure it does anything better than this one, except in the looks department. This $20 version even came with a HDMI cable. What? Compared to the other, this is a crazy deal.
* Plug and Play for people familiar with these devices. If not, you'll need to learn about capture software. If using this at the PC, then a popular software people use is OBS.
* However, there are higher quality capture devices for your desktop. These little usb versions are better fro DSLR camera users who want to create a second monitor screen with their smartphones.
* Personally, a fun use case scenario for me, is turning spare phones into mini tvs.

USING YOUR SMARTPHONE TIPS:
----------------------------------------
* The type of USB adapter you use will matter. If your phone has a USB-C port, then you'll need a female USB A to USB-C adapter. If it has a micro usb port, you'll need a female USB-A to micro usb adapter. I found that the ones with a little cord are finicky. A solid one piece, cordless usb to usb-c adapter solved the issue for me. Watch my video to understand what I'm saying.
* Many USB Camera Viewer apps won't work. It's not an exact science because you're dealing with so many variables such as app version, phone brand, android version, not to mention your hardware. Some apps gave me video, but no audio, some slam you with so many ads, it's annoying unless you pay. The best paid app is USB CAMERA PRO by Shen Yao, their free version is good too, but has ads. The best free app that virtually has no ads is USB CAMERA VIEWER by Homesoft, LLC. This is the app you see in my video demo. I'm using a Pixel 6 Pro.
* If connecting a media device such as fire stick, roku, etc., you will need to bypass HDCP, and you'll have to trial and error with the different types of splitters on the market. The GOXMGO splitter in my video demo worked nicely.

THE BAD:
------------
* Well, as mentioned above. I had reviewed another usb capture device that cost $60. The only advantage it has is that there is no dangling cord, and it's a colorful red. In terms of function, I don't see an advantage. At $20, you get the usb capture device and a HDMI cable. This is an amazing deal compared to the other. This product is 5-Stars!

title: Very nice tempered glass screen protector complete with installation frame... text: THE GOOD:
--------------
* It's tempered glass with "silkfeel." This screen protector works perfectly with both official and 3rd party pens.
* The guard frame is a must have tool! I don't buy screen protectors without guard frames now. They make installation so much easier.
* Complete package with micro fiber cloth and dust absorbers.
* Easy to follow instructions.

THE BAD:
------------
* This is not a bad, but a FYI... I got two of these screen protectors with similar packaging, just different brand names. This review is for the HOCENTS brand. I'm guessing they are white label products coming from the same factory. So don't dwell on the brand too much. It doesn't matter, they both worked perfect for us. 5-Stars!

title: Superior to iPod text: I bought a ZuneHD 32GB as a replacement for my iPod Video. I still have the iPod but I don't particularly care for it (never really did) so I decided to search for a better MP3 player. After digging online for a while I decided on the ZuneHD which has proven to be far and away better. It is not a perfect device but it's excellent for my needs.

Looking a lot like a small smart phone, the ZuneHD is a sleek and attractive device with a nice touch screen and a brushed metal back. Having never before used one of these I was a little confused at first on how it worked but the learning curve is easy and it took little time to get used to it. It works a lot like a tablet, actually. The screen is very responsive and navigation is simple.

I confess that I never used the ear buds. Instead, I use a set of really nice noise-canceling head phones and the sound coming out of the Zune is excellent. My music of choice is usually techno-trance stuff so there is a lot of base and a lot of synthesizer, and by default the sound is well-balanced and clear.

So, my main use for an MP3 player is to connect it to my car. My car has voice-controlled everything and I wanted to be able to listen to my music collection in the car without fiddling with the player directly. When I used the iPod I found that the system frequently got confused and the player would often select the wrong song. If it got confused enough, it would hang the voice activation for controlling the MP3 player for weeks at a time, so I gave up and put my Zune in the car instead. So far, the Zune and the car work together nearly flawlessly. As a bonus, the car keeps the Zune charged up.

The only drawback I have found with the Zune is that there is no way to expand the storage capacity. It would be nice to have the ability to add a MicroSD card in to expand the capacity.

I am exceptionally satisfied with my Zune. I likely will never buy another iPod again, now that I know how much better an MP3 player can be.

title: Plug n play, very easy to use for a first timer! text: The price of these seems bloated and seems like these should be a bit less but other than that, I love these! If one was on a budget then I suppose VR goggles you just slide your phone into would give you the same effect as these. These don't take up much space though and would be great for something like an airplane instead of having to have a giant laptop out the whole time and your neighbor judging you for watching a horror movie on the plane. I get bored easily and even a 2 or 3 hour flight could be made so much better by watching a movie so these little glasses are my best friend! You can plug the usb c into your phone and into these and you get instant mirroring without any apps even! I went to some VR videos and you can look up and down and turn around in a room and see all around it- it's really neat!

Honestly I don't know the full potential to use these for gaming or whatever but for streaming video, they work great and have a great picture! I've even used them in bed and they light up the room a little less than my phone screen so don't disturb my boyfriend as much.

If you're worried about someone seeing what you're watching from the front (they used see thru lenses for some reason)- I suppose you could put some sort of darkening tent or something on the outside and it'd keep people from seeing what you are watching.

I was truly blown away at how quickly I got these up and going without having read any instructions or having ever had anything like this previously. I do absolutely love them but again- the price point for what they are seems a bit insane.

title: More Comfortable Than It Looks text: I selected this mouse as much for the cool factor as for the function. I needed a wireless mouse to use with a laptop and this one looked like a good fit. So far I have no complaints, but I do offer one word of caution with it.

The most obvious thing about this mouse is the strange appearance. It doesn't resemble any other mouse I have used and at first it looks like it might be uncomfortable on the hands. On the contrary, though, it is quite comfortable and I have had no issues with it being too small for my hands even though it is a typical-sized mouse.

I used with with my Windows 10 system and it works just fine. I have not tested it against my Linux system though I have no reason to believe it won't work - every other wireless mouse I have tried has worked without any trouble at all so I expect this one to be no different. If it proves otherwise I will return here and update.

I ran into an immediate issue with this mouse - I could not find the receiver and as such I was unable to get it to connect to the system. It does not have any Bluetooth capability so that is not an option. As it turns out, the receiver was packaged in the box but was in a small plastic baggie separate from the mouse and when the box was opened to remove the mouse the receiver fell out, unnoticed. I thought I had been sent a mouse without the receiver until I finally realized what had happened and located the receiver. So, use some caution when taking this mouse out of the box.

Overall, I am pleased with this mouse. It works as expected and is more comfortable than it looks.

title: Wow! Excellent TV Mount! text: I have used a plethora of mounts to hang TVs and this is among the most stable I have found for mid to large screen size that still allows for full motion.

Typically when hanging TVs over 65” the mounts are limited to only minimal tilt adjustments. While this works in some settings it is simply not ideal in others. This mount is outstanding in those situations where you want full motion, including awesome tilt capabilities allowing for elimination of screen glare.

We really have put this mount to the test of the limits holding our 75” Sony TV and it has worked perfectly!

This is really a well thought out mount. I had no problem attaching this to my Sony 75” TV and hanging it on our block walls with 16” stud spacing. As with all TV mounts it is important that you anchor into studs whenever possible or use heavy duty anchoring systems. Due to using this on a block wall with fur strip studs I utilized a combination of anchors in order to achieve the security I required.

This mount not only holds our 75” TV securely but we are able to pull it away from the wall and swivel it so we can see it while working in the kitchen - absolutely incredible!

This mount is worth every penny and every second you’ll spend insuring a solid install.

This is an outstanding TV mount that I highly recommend.

He pulled his car over to check his map & some up to no good folks tried to box him in! That was it! I ordered this gear in, he can use his phone hands free and before he leaves each week he programs addresses and no more maps no more looking the vulnerable tourist. An added benefit, first time he used it back in DC it shaved 20 min off his drive time from the route plotted by mapquest. Truly this is worth it's weight in gold. I worry so much less when he's driving those strange cities in the late hours knowing he has his Garmin. Of course you can get a navigation system w/ most rental cars but, you pay extra each time and you have to program it in the lot, so you need to keep all addresses handy. It is cheaper and more efficient that he has his own.

title: Interesting Gadget, Works as Advertised, But Tied to Smartphone text: This SAMSUNG GEAR S2 SMARTWATCH (Dark Gray) is an interesting gadget, and works as advertised. It's kind of fun to make and receive telephone calls from your wristwatch (just like Dick Tracy did in the comic strips with his 2-way wrist radio). However, to be able to make calls, you need to register it with your cellphone network (on Verizon, this entails a $30 activation fee, plus $5 a month thereafter).

You can use the Gear S2 for lots of things without activating the phone, of course. There is a fitness tracker app, and there are interactive watch faces that can keep you abreast of your favorite teams' real-time game scores, the current stock market numbers, and other things. However, I like my [[ASIN:B00N2BW2PK Fitbit-Charge-Wireless-Activity-Wristband]] much better for telling time and for activity tracking--the Fitbit is easier to use, and does more things reliably.

The biggest drawback regarding the apps, is that they are tied to your smartphone. All of the Gear S2 apps use Bluetooth for running the app from your phone. This means your smartphone has to be turned on, within the Bluetooth range, and charged, for the apps to work. One problem that I never solved with the NBA watch face, was that the real-time scoring updates would stop when my Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge went into sleep or dormant mode after about an hour.

Finally, the Gear needs frequent charging--every day or two. This means you can't really treat it like a watch that you leave on your wrist 24/7. You have to treat it like a cellphone, and take it off for charging every night.

A negative about activating the phone--boo to Verizon!--is that my assigned phone line had been previously assigned to someone who had a lot of people still looking for him/her. Thus I got a lot of unwanted calls from the moment the Gear S2 was fully activated.

My Gear S2 was free (from a Samsung/Verizon deal with my preorder of the Galaxy S7 Edge). I'm very glad that I didn't pay a couple of hundred dollars for mine, as it turned out that I have no need for a smartwatch.

title: just ok text: I had the very first kindle...with a red leather first gen case. I was really excited to get the new hdx 8.9" kindle and a new red leather case. These origami cases seem like a good idea. But if you have them sitting on any kind of slightly slick surface or slightly inclined surface, it won't stand up. The function of the "origami" part is a little complicated, but the pictures help. Initially it is it very stiff and hard to "fold". After a few uses it loosens up which makes setting up the "standing" position a little easier, but it still resists the action and as I mentioned, slips. I was thinking a little rubber edge all around the case edge would help some. The case "attaches" to the kindle via magnets and turns your kindle on automatically when you open the case, off when up close it. On the up side, I definitely prefer the feel of the leather case as opposed to the plastic one. Sadly neither case really functions as it should for standing. However it will provide some protection for the glass which is a pretty good size now. In addition to the magnet set in, there is are outer power and volume buttons. They are in good locations and I have not hit them accidently. In fact those buttons are quite handy.
I just wish they'd put more thought into actual function and less into "wow this looks cool" on the stand part.
Hope this helps some. I have not found a great alternative yet, but I will keep looking and update this review if I find one.

title: Cable too short! text: These are really, really high quality earbuds, especially for the price. The sound quality is actually pretty amazing. I had a middling-quality pair of those "Inked" earbuds attached to my laptop at work. The sound quality was always disappointing, but I had sort of assumed that it was probably due to the laptop sound card, etc. Then today I attached my new Sony Fontopias and wow...what a difference! Yes, they have bass boost, but not so much that it overwhelms the music.

These headphones are also surprisingly comfortable. They aren't the typical in-ear shape that gets jammed all the way into your ear, but there's a little more to them than the default "sort of hang in the outer part of your ear" that you get with the default iPod earbuds, for example. I like the hybrid, in-between quality and they fit me pretty well. They're not noise-cancelling, but the sound is so good that I really don't notice other office sounds (not even my disgusting cubicle neighbor who eats cookies like the Cookie Monster and sounds completely disgusting - now you know why I need to listen to music at work!). I'm so happy with the sound quality and comfort of these headphones, I'm willing to give then four stars in spite of one very major drawback:

THE CORD IS RIDICULOUSLY SHORT.

I have NEVER seen such a short cord on any pair of headphones, earbuds, headset, etc. that I have owned. I measured the cord from the jack to the point where the "Y" that goes to each individual bud starts, and it is barely 2 feet. TWO FEET! People, that is SHORT. So I'm going to go to Radio Shack at lunch today and buy an extension cord/adapter. So unless you're going to sit right next to the source you are connecting the headphones to, whether it's a computer or MP3 player or stereo, you'll need to add the cost of an extension cable to the price. Trust me - it's way too short as sold, like it wouldn't even stretch from my iPod in a backpack to my ears if I was walking around.

Otherwise, awesome headphones.

title: Cool Product. Literally. text: So far so good! My emachines E525 (stop laughing) has a known issue that I didn't know about that makes the computer overheat after about 20-30 minutes of viewing video or listening to streaming music.

Easy to use, didn't have to read the directions, just pressed a button to release the fan from where it was and reposition it, then use the usb to power the fans and we were off. The black "headband" was a little confusing, but the 2 year old likes it. Don't think I'll use it to join the pad and the laptop together.

I know I need to get another laptop but this will extend the life of mine for a little while longer.

title: Universal Router extender - however it won't help in a motel/hotel text: My first question was "What is 802.11ac?" - In December 2011 "802.11ac" was the next evolution of WiFi & enabled wireless speeds over a gigabit per second.

"b" was the first there was (802.11b) which provided up to 11 mbps data rates per radio in the 2.4 GHz spectrum.
"a" was the next evolution (802.11a) which provided up to 54 mbps data rates per radio in the 5 GHz spectrum.
"g"came out shortly after enabling 54 mbps per radio in the 2.4 GHz spectrum.
"n" was ratified in 2009 (802.11n) allows for data rates up to 600 mbps per radio.
"ac" builds on 802.11n.

setup took 2 minutes; I plugged the TP Extender into a wall plug outside the room the router was in. Wait until the `power' and `wi-fi' LEDs light up; then press the WPS button on the router (this is the reason it isn't going to work at a motel/hotel). Then I pressed the Range Extender button on the TP Extender the lowest on the front of the device (must do it within 2 minutes). The LED on the TP Extender should go from flashing to solid, showing that WPS connection has succeeded. Done.

tips:

there are 6 lights on the TP Extender the top two should be green, if they are RED your extender is too far from the router. If it is no color it means you need to reconnect the router and the extender by repeating the steps above.

> to minimize wireless interference keep the Range Extender away from cordless phones, Bluetooth devices and Microwave Ovens.

> If possible place the TP Extender in open corridors or spacious locations rather than a crowded room.

Frankly I have not noticed any difference in our wi-fi but we have a smaller home (1700 sq feet) the router we have is 2 years old and is in one room in the house while I use my 3 year old laptop (Sony Viao series E) in the livingroom 2 rooms away and 2 walls away. I do plan on bringing it with us on vacation where I am hoping that where we do get poor reception (where we have access to a router), we will get a noticeable improvement.

The device has a reset option (if the TP Extender doesn't seem to be working): While the Range Extender is plugged into a power outlet, press the RESET button (located next to the ethernet port underneath the TP Extender) with a pen for 1 second. Wait 2 seconds until all the LEDs flash once.

*Bonus - The Range Extender's ETHERNET port allows it to function as a wireless adapter for a wired devices (Blu-ray players, game consoles, DVRs and smart TVs) allowing the device to share the wireless network.

title: "Getting Started in Under 5 Minutes" Is No Lie! text: The JABRA STEALTH BLUETOOTH HEADSET guide is titled "Getting Started in Under 5 Minutes"--and the guide does not lie. The basic setup took me less than 5 minutes, even though I had zero prior experience using a Bluetooth headset paired with a cellphone. And in under 15 minutes, I had voice dialing activated (a feature that depends on your phone), so that I could use the headset to place and end calls with voice commands transmitted to my phone (a Samsung Galaxy S4).

My Jabra Stealth headset seemed to need a brief charge (a USB/MicroB cable is included) prior to accomplishing a Bluetooth pairing. However, I may not have been pressing the Answer/End phone call button correctly at first, to activate pairing--the "button" is actually a long silver piece with mic holes, that moves up and down when you press the "Jabra" marking. Once the flashing Bluetooth indicator light appeared, my phone found the Jabra headset immediately, paired with it, and connected. I can also use NFC to quickly connect my phone with the headset.

The headset charges completely in about two hours, which gives you about six hours of talk time. Once it's even partially charged, a pleasant female voice announces how much talk time is available when you turn the headset on. The headset is so lightweight, it's barely noticeable when you're wearing it. You do want to experiment a little with the included selection of ear gels and ear hooks, to find the one that fits your ear most comfortably. You can wear this headset in either the right or left ear.

I would recommend visiting the Jabra Stealth web site, to watch a short instructional video, look over the FAQs, and download the Jabra Stealth User Manual (a .pdf file). The .pdf manual is slightly more complete than the Getting Started guide, and has an additional section on "Handling Multiple Calls" (you can place a call on hold). The FAQs tell you how to set up the Jabra Stealth headset to work with two different mobile devices (but only one device will be able to use voice-activated dialing).

I like this headset a lot, and plan to use it for answering calls handsfree when I'm driving. The sound quality is very good. You have to use the volume controls on your mobile phone, because there are none on the headset itself, but I'm happy enough with that tradeoff in return for such a small, lightweight headset.

title: Inexpensive Way To Extend the Capabilities of a Samsung Camera text: I ordered this lens and filter kit to go with my Samsung NX300 with the intent of expanding the capabilities of the camera without spending a fortune. I looked at several different kits before settling on this one, based on the price. I will admit to being a bit apprehensive about the cost in relation to the number of lenses and filters in the kit (presently this kit sells for less than $35 on Amazon as I write this) but my concern was ill-placed - this is a good kit.

I will start off by saying that I am not a professional photographer by any stretch of the imagination. I could be best described as an enthusiast who is trying to learn as I go.

I have experimented and played with many of the various components with this kit, starting with the 2.2x telephoto lens. This is a chunky item, which should be expected as it is a glass lens. It attached without issue to my 18mm-55mm OIS lens and I was able to use it almost immediately out of the box. It took me a little fiddling at first to get the focus just right as I am still learning with the camera but once I figured out the manual focus I was able to improve the zoom range with the telephoto lens in place. This, to me, is worth the cost of the kit. One thing I did notice, however, is that when the telescoping zoom is not fully extended on the regular lens, this lens adds a shadowy blackout area around the perimeter of the image that fades when the zoom is telescoped out.

My favorite component of this kit is the .43x wide-angle lens which works surprisingly well with the camera's included lens. It is another chunky item like the telephoto lens and it attaches easily as well. Even at closer ranges (15 feet or so) it allows the camera to capture appreciably more than the regular lens, without distortion. This is probably the one component I will use more than the others, and again this is an accessory that is worth the cost of the kit. This lens is not going to give the same quality result as a dedicated wide-angle lens but the price/quality tradeoff is worth it.

There are four close-up lenses in this kit that vary in strength. These are fun to play with though I did start to get a lot of edge distortion when using the strongest lens. This is not a problem as there are times when this kind of distortion is a good thing. I was able to get similar close-up shots - without distortion - with the Samsung lens but it required a lot more effort. Interestingly, one of these lenses had a smudge on it when I removed it from it's cellophane envelope. A quick wipe with a microfiber cloth did a fine job of cleaning the lens but this puzzled me - why was it smudged?

The wide-angle lens comes coupled with a macro lens that is absolutely astounding for close-up shots. I use this lens for taking pictures of pattern weaves, close-ups of surfaces, animal fur and other interesting subjects (the knee of my denim jeans makes a really interesting background shot). It works even a little better than the close-up lenses and is likely going to be the only lens I use for when I need a really detailed close-in shot of something. Though this lens outperforms the close-up magnifying lenses it requires decoupling from the wide-angle lens before it can be used and this is a minor hassle.

The kit includes a UV filter, a CPL filter and a FL-D filter. I used the CPL filter while experimenting and the result was minorly disappointing but I figured that was due to unrealistic expectations. It did tweak the color profile just a little but not dramatically like I had hoped. The FL-D filter was another story and gave the whole picture a completely different color profile. It is designed for use with fluorescent lighting (which means it should be used a lot when indoors) so when it is used with incandescent lighting it give a very eerie and unusual hue to pictures. With my lens I can adjust for fluorescent lighting electronically so this isn't a lens I necessarily need but I still like to mess with it. I have not tried the UV filter.

The cleaning kit is an important item in the kit, for removing dirt and smudges from the various lenses without using a harsh cloth. It's very basic but is a fine start - cleaning spray, cotton swabs, a microfiber cloth and a squeeze duster for puffing away particles when a full cleaning is not needed.

This kit includes a couple of other miscellaneous items as well, including a miniature tripod for a desk mount and a 6-compartment memory card storage case. These are nice-to-have extras, though I confess I am thoroughly unimpressed with the tripod which is a flexible bendy-leg tripod that does not retain the position in which it is set when supporting the camera, so it really is of little use. I continue to mess with the tripod, though, as I am sure I can get it to work in certain scenarios.

The main negative I encountered so far was actually the manner in which the kit was packaged and shipped to me. Everything was in a large plastic envelope bag with no padding at all. What would prevent the items in the kit from being crushed in such a shipment? Fortunately, all items were individually wrapped in small and sturdy cardboard boxes and one of those boxes was actually slightly crushed though there was no damage to the merchandise inside. Something like this should be shipped in a larger corrugated box, to better protect everything.

If you have a Samsung camera for which this kit is compatible, this is a very good kit to extend the capability of the camera without breaking the bank. The various lenses add range and effects, the filters are nice to have on hand and the extras are icing on the cake. At the current pricing, this is a very good deal.

title: It is an OK value for the price, but there are much better text: I'm going to be 100% honest here: This is not a great tablet. I'm awarding it 4 out of 5 stars because of the value for the money, but as a Tablet alone I'd only give it 3 out of 5.
With a 10" display, Android 12 and a kid friendly case, you'd be hard pressed to find anything better for the money- especially with the current promotional discount being offered. But understand that for a little bit more, you can get something more brand-name, like a Lenovo M10 or TCL tab, and the performance and build quality of those will be better in my experience.
Granted, you also get the kid-proof case here, which is great, but other kid-friendly offerings come with things like CLAP software suite, which my daughter was hoping this had (her old one broke, and we've had two previous no-name tablets before which both had that software installed with no subscription needed). Otherwise, it gets the job done, works with Google services, and is powerful enough to get through basic tasks.

After 3 weeks of daily use, I have not experienced anything that seems like an improvement. I develop websites using Adobe Dreamweaver and MS Expression Web with lots a graphic content and have managed fine (OK) on my previous system except that it wore out. (I guess, hard drive failure, DVD drive failure, motherboard, one after another.) This system also comes with Windows 10, which I hate a lot. A joke! Maybe that's a contributing factor to my totally unimpressive more expensive, less capable new computer. Bottom line, the fastest processor and faster DDS RAM and solid state drives don't seem to add any power or performance so save your money and look for a Windows 7, Intel i5 if you can find one. Sometimes, you don't get what you pay for.. I wish I could have a 'do-over' but I have work to do with my so, so OK new computer.

title: Nice Monitor text: There is a lot to like about this monitor. It's easily height adjustable, it can pivot, the angle can be tilted up and down, it has built-in speakers (I am using a Bose Solo 5 soundbar instead of the built-in speakers), the side and top bezels are not too wide, and the picture quality is very good, with a lot of picture configuration options. (I plugged a 3.5mm stereo patch cable from the back of the monitor into the soundbar.)

I watch TV broadcast and cable channels, movies, and TV shows via my computer, so I wanted a larger high quality-picture monitor with a higher DPI capability. I did not want to spend so much and buy one of the many monitors above $500, but I did not want one of the cheaper 32-inchers that had less DPI capability.

This LG has so far satisfied what I want. I have settled on the "HDR Effect" Picture Setting for most use, and it is quite nice. There is also a "Custom" picture setting that allows for a lot of configuration. (I could never have just settled for LG's factory default picture settings.)

The monitor is very heavy...much heavier in weight than I expected. Attaching the stand is really easy. Detaching the stand is also very easy. Build quality of this monitor seems good. Assuming this just-released monitor stays working perfectly for a long time, LG did an excellent job and I am glad I bought it.

title: Installation is easy; sound is crisp, headset is adjustable; ear muffs are cushiony but are tight around the head text: I ordered this as a replacement for the Plantronics headsets that my company provides. I assume the firm I work for buys a cheaper version of Plantronics because they are always breaking after a couple of weeks or months of daily use. Usually, the problem I have with them is that the left earpiece no longer works.

Therefore, I decided to try this one. I've only been using this a week on a Dell Latitude E7470 Ultrabook and I really like them. Installation was easy. All I had to do was plug it into the USB port and the system (Windows 7 Enterprise edition) recognized it. I didn't need to follow the instructions provided. The sound is crisp, the ear muff portion keeps external noise to a minimum, and people hear me well on it. I only received two comments. One morning my boyfriend said he heard a slight echo in the background. At one meeting, the attendees said my voice blanked out for a few seconds. However, I don't believe it is the headset because since I got a new computer I was having this same problem with the Plantronics and that problem was worse. With the Plantronics headset, the voice would blank out entirely and would not come back. I actually had to disconnect the headset, reconnect it, and re-dial my call. With this headset, I did not have to do that. I've since moved the headset to another USB port on the same computer and have not been having any problems. Only time will tell how well this headset holds up. Right now I'm using it all day long over 8 hours a day.

I would have rated this five stars except that it is a bit tight. That takes some getting use to. If I had a larger head I would get a headache. The headset is adjustable up and down but that did nothing to loose the grip the ear muffs have around the head.

So far I love the performance of this unit. Since it takes a while before problems develop with USB headsets, I will update this review if I have any issues. If I get a full year's use out of these without a problem, then I feel it's worth it. At the listed price of $21.95, I would buy this at its current performance level.

UPDATE Feb 25, 2017 - I've been using this headset about 8-10 hours per day and it's performing wonderfully. They are so much better than the Plantronics headsets I was using previously.

UPDATE August 8, 2017 - This headset is still going strong at 8-10 hours per day. The headset no longer feels tight on as it did in the beginning. This will be my last post unless the headset breaks.

UPDATE October 20, 2017- This headset has finally failed with colleagues telling me my voice is spotty. I can still hear others beautifully but cannot carry on a conversation because they cannot hear me. This is now headed for the garbage. It lasted eight months, which is longer than any other headset I have had.

title: Wall cord cover D Line
text: If I could rate this 10 stars, I probably would... of course, time will be the true test!  I had some really ugly black cable cords just sitting along the floor.  Ugly to say the least.  So, I thought I would try these.  I just installed this along my base board (looks like quarter round) and it PERFECTLY holds and hides the cords.  I have two cable lines and a very small, flat land line cord in it... plenty of room for another cable if necessary.  There are no instructions.. but it's pretty easy.  There is a clear film on the outside/front - the back is a the self stick.  I was placing it on a painted, non textured wall - so it's very flat and the perfect material for this use.  A couple of things I learned as I was placing it... it worked best for me to cord up the holder before sticking to the wall - IMPORTANT - the sticky back is SOLID - NO repositioning at all. You want to make sure you have shoved up against the last one you placed as tightly as possible - you will still see the seam between each length - but less so if you carefully, firmly place each piece. Before removing the sticky back I "placed" it in position to see if I liked it and it would work.  Good thing, because once you remove the sticky back, it is NOT coming off without the sheet rock in torn pieces... just fyi.  I chose to position the opening part of the D tube facing up to make it easier to put another cord in or take one out... personal choice.  The ad says it is paintable and that is what I will try next.  Having said that, I never hesitate to update my reviews should new info seem useful - and I am eager to see if this will stand the test of time and use.. meaning.. cords pulled, etc.  I see no reason why you couldn't use this going up a wall (thinking of TV that has been hung on wall, etc - personal taste - but remember, the sticky tape is solid and won't be removed without tearing/damaging paint.  As for textured surfaces - like wall texture, I am thinking that as positive as this sticky tape is, as long as it's not too textured, it should work - but to be honest, I have not tried it on a textured surface.  As with most things that use a form of sticky tape, the smoother the surface, the better it will stick.)  I hope this info was helpful to you!

title: slim profile, smooth tracking, plug & play connection, can charge & use at same time text: Slick, small. The main aspect that I like about this is not having to change the batteries. It seems to hold a charge for quite some time (I have been using it nightly for a couple of weeks straight out from box; have yet to actually charge it). I use it entirely with my lap top because I can't stand using the touch pad. So I always use a corded mouse or a cordless mouse. Usually the batteries last a good while, but it is extra nice to not even have to worry about them. When it comes time to charge I can still use it AND charge it by using the USB charging cable.

When not in use, the dongle is stored on bottom of mouse. It has a little magnetic port that it slides into.

Overall, it works perfectly fine. Smooth-- I use a colorful mouse pad most of the time, but sometimes solid black.
Can change DPI, so that will make a difference in smoothness and tracking. "Featuring 5 adjustable DPI (2400/2000/1600/1200/800)"

What I don't care for, and this is entirely a personal preference, is that it is very sleek and flat. I am used to a beefier mouse-- both a cordless for my lap top as well as a corded for my desktop. I am used to that hump in the middle, and this is rather flat. I don't have huge hands, but I have wide hands. So for short term use it is fine. For longer term use, it could be tiring on the hand. Since I use it with my laptop, and I usually only use it for a little while before bed to check out the internet or play a silly game, it is ok. But for more intensive activities, especially gaming- I need a mouse that fits MY hand better.

I do like it though for my short term use. Again, I really like that it is a rechargeable mouse. That is the selling point for me. So if you are ok with a slim profile mouse, this should be just fine for your needs. If you are used to a beefier mouse with that hump in the middle, you may not care for this for long term use.

title: EXCELLENT VALUE PRICED OUTDOOR WiFi CAMERA text: I have been testing and reviewing WiFi cameras for the last five years. Over that time the industry has seen major advances which has led to incredible availability of high quality cameras at very reasonable costs.

I had no problem setting this camera up on my network. I set it up vis Ethernet cable and WiFi and each time it connected without any issue.

Due to security precautions I never use cloud based storage in relation to WiFi cameras because that amount of constant data transfer opens your network to unnecessary hacking. The only cameras that I employ in my home allow for local storage - whether to a dedicated hard drive / served or individual micro SD held within each camera. This camera can hold up to a 128 Gb micro SD card. The card will over write the oldest data first - how much the card holds is dictated by the settings you select.

It’s important to know that by default the camera is set to record and save to the cloud. That can easily be reset in preference settings.

The camera provides a crystal clear 1080p image. I found little to no lag with my mesh WiFi network - typically camera lag has to do with individual network properties rather than the camera itself. As with the vast majority of outdoor cameras pan and tilt controls are not possible with this camera as it has a fixed lens.

This camera has a built in microphone and speaker allowing for 2 way communication making it ideal for placement at home entrances. In addition it has motion detection and an alarm function that can be set when you are away. If motion is detected you can have it set to alert your phone, record and / or record the action.

I found all of the controls intuitive and easy to control. The app is well designed allowing for the installation of multiple cameras and easy switching between multiple camera views.

In my tests I found this to be an excellent budget friendly WiFi camera that as long as you utilize the micro SD card feature is quite secure.

This is a camera I would recommend.

title: Voice calling is bordering on unsuable text: I'm very conflicted writing this review. As music listening and noise cancellation devices, they are wonderful! You can wear this in a noisy environment and get lost in your own tunes or just hear yourself think. Also, it has a similar functional design as Air Pods that allows air in to make it comfortable to wear without the vacuum "under water" seal effect that other ear buds have. So out of the box, color me impressed- comfortable and sounds great, what could be better, right?
Well, the reason I wanted to try Jabra over other brands is their commitment to call quality. Back in the early days of Bluetooth, Jabra was one of the kings if you wanted to ensure a clear 2-way conversation on a call. A lot of portable audio devices these days overlook mic quality and put all their effort into music / playback, with Apple, Sony, and some other big brands being the exception.
Sadly, these Jabras don't seem to deliver in that regard. People we call constantly complain they can't hear us, that we sound far away, under water or over-compressed / missing parts of our voice. In quiet environments it seems to work ok, but maybe the noise cancellation bit is working overtime? I don't know. All I know is I'm so disappointed with the call quality, I can't rely on these if I want the other party to hear me clearly. Yes, the ANC is awesome. Yes, the music sounds good. Yes they are comfortable. But if you need to switch to another headset to make a phone call, these are silly. I really wish it wasn't so.

title: AWESOME SURGE PROTECTOR text: After using surge protection for audio, video and computer equipment for more than 30 years I can definitely say not all of these products are created equally.

While surge protectors will often boast of great protection, more often than not they are more multi outlet plugs rather than actual protection.

I have thoroughly tested this surge protector and it has passed all of my testing. This will definitely protect your important investments.

The only thing I wish was different was the outlets should be spaced a bit further apart to allow for larger power blocks - the top 2 outlets are separated though the others are not. So many plugs are nonstandard and end up blocking surrounding outlets. The only thing that would make this product better would be if the outlets rotated which would make them far more adaptable to oddly sized plugs.

The 4 USB ports are definitely a nice addition as this helps avoid having to use plugs for USB powered devices. What is even better about this particular surge protector is 3 of the USB-A ports are 3.0 (which charge far faster than previous versions) and the 4th port is a USB-C (the fastest of them all).

This is an outstanding surge protector that has proven itself through my extensive use and testing.

This is definitely a surge protector I recommend.

title: Recordings Are Stored in Canary Cloud; Full Replay Access Requires Paid Membership text: When I ordered this CANARY VIEW INDOOR 1080p HD SECURITY CAMERA (with Wide-Angle Lens, Motion/Person Alerts, Works with Alexa, Pets/Elder/Baby Monitoring), there was one very important thing that I didn’t understand. To wit, the camera has zero internal storage--everything is uploaded to Canary Cloud, which costs $89 a year for full-featured camera access and video replays.

It is possible to set up the camera without signing up for a free 30-day trial membership (which requires entering a credit card that will automatically be charged after 30 days unless you cancel the membership). You do this by accepting the $0.00 monthly charge option, and scrolling on down past the place where you enter the credit card info.

However, most of the playback and customizing features in the Canary app (the only way to access the camera) are inoperable without a membership. When you’re at home, you can “Watch Live” if you tinker with the available settings. However, you can’t play back motion events without a membership unless they happen while you’re away--and you can’t trick the camera into thinking you’re away, because the app determines your location by the location of your tablet or smartphone. (And you can’t turn the phone off, because you need the app to access the camera.)

The camera sells for about $80 on Amazon, and that’s a lot to pay for a device that’s almost useless unless you add a “membership” that costs another $89 a year. Should the company go out of business, your device will, too. Also, all of your recordings are stored in Canary Cloud, so you need to trust the company to keep the site secure and private.

As for the camera itself, it’s fairly low resolution, but reasonably wide-angle. Without the membership, the camera will works as a real-time spy camera for the room it’s in (it does resemble an Amazon Echo). The camera is fixed in one position, and only records what is directly in front, so you need to place it in a spot where it will cover as much area as possible.

When I think about it, I don’t really need an indoor security camera, because my Comcast home security system monitors all the doors and windows of my condo. Given that this device costs $89 a year, it makes more sense for me to add another camera to my existing system ($95) and then accept the extra Comcast monthly charge, so that I don’t have to fool with the awkward Canary app settings.

title: Superior Cleaning Cloth for Touchscreen Devices text: The large size (5"x7") and extra thickness of this TODDY GEAR MICRO FIBER SMART CLOTH are what make it a superior cleaning cloth for large touchscreen devices (in my case, an iPad2, a Kindle Fire HD 8.9" tablet, and a Nexus 7 tablet). The "plush" side (loopy, like a washcloth) removes greasy fingerprints quickly, and the "silk" (microfiber) side polishes to finish the job.

The Smart Cloth works fine with screen protector film (all my touchscreen devices have film). It is much easier to handle than a thin, slippery, microfiber square. Also, the cloth's plush side does an excellent job of absorbing skin oil (unlike my microfiber cloths for cleaning eyeglasses that quickly acquire an oily coating and need frequent washing).

Additional nice features are: (1) the Aegis Microbe Shield® protection, which helps protect the cloth against mold and mildew; and (2) the fact that the cloth is stain and wrinkle resistant and machine washable. The cloth comes in a clear plastic storage bag that has a nice zipper closure.

The microfiber side of the Smart Cloth comes in a wide assortment of prints: flags, bubble dots, stripes, jacquards, flowers, etc. This beautiful design, Aizuri, is my personal favorite, but there are quite a few other prints that I like almost as well.

title: A pocketful of everything text: Pros:

1. A bag big enough to carry all your camera bits and pieces. There's a padded lower compartment with customizable Velcro edged dividers for camera and lenses, a drawstring upper compartment for your what-nots that can be converted to one big compartment with the lower one; five smaller external zippered or Velcro-closing compartments; two pull-out side pouches for water bottles or tripod; a rain cover, and a lot of hooks, straps and loops for attaching gear outside of the bag.

2. The bottom compartment can easily hold a DSLR camera with two or three lenses, or one lens and a flash, or a combination thereof.

3. Smaller pockets have zips &/or Velcro closures for securing lens cleaners, filters, diffusers, spare batteries, chargers, memory cards, remotes or shutter cables etc.

4. Sturdy construction and nicely padded adjustable straps.

5. Cool National Geographic logo to give the impression that you may actually have something to do with the magazine.

Cons:

1. It's a big bag to lug around, especially if you're not built like a rugby player.

2. Even though it's a big bag, and has many pockets, it's still not ideal as a carry-on travel bag, as the upper drawstring compartment is too small to hold a change of clothes and toiletries, and the sideways slit pocket is awkwardly designed to fit a full-sized laptop.

3. It's not possible (or very difficult) to whip out the camera at short notice without taking off the backpack.

4. Too many external loops and fasteners add to the weight.

5. You may have a hard time remembering which pocket you put specific items in.

I use this bag for events or outdoor shoots where I may need more than the basic equipment. For daily use, the [[ASIN:B000YIWNUS Lowepro Fastpack 100 (Red)]]is much more convenient to fetch around.

Amanda Richards, December 28, 2011

title: Protect Your Electronics from Harm text: When you own and use many electronics, you need a place to plug them in- something that goes far beyond the standard 2 plug wall socket. A surge strip is ideal because it not only serves as an extension cord, it also helps protect valuable electronics from harm. And a good tool for the task is Tripp Lite 6 Outlet Desk Clamp Surge Protector Power Strip.

With this power strip, you get six traditional style outlets and two USB ports, perfect for charging your cell phones. There is an on/off switch and an indicator light that confirms the surge protection is working. This latter feature is one you don’t normally see with other power strips and it provides added peace of mind.

This power strip is u- shaped and comes with a clamp so it can be attached to a desk. The clamp won’t work on just any desk, as I learned, because some desks are too thin. You need a thick spot to clamp. And keep in mind that the clamp isn’t super strong. It can still slip a little but this shouldn’t be an issue in most instances.

UL listed and with a long cord, the Tripp Lite 6 Outlet Desk Clamp Surge Protector Power Strip is practical and useful for most home office needs. Mine has already been put to use in my office, as you can see in the picture, providing a place for my wife to plug in all of her electronics and keep them safe from surges. It’s a useful device that makes a good addition to any home.

title: Great Crisp Sound, a little less so with Blue Tooth text: I truly love these headphones for style. They are a little bulky but you can tell that style was high on the designer's list. I have been using a pair of Sennheiser headphones exclusively and I feel that the sound on these are a little crisper and the sound canceling is comparable. I have no complaints at all on the corded sound these produce. I'm a little less happy with the Bluetooth which works well when close to the bluetooth source and have a line of sight between the two. These work beautifully when listening to books on tape on walks - perhaps a little too well and cutting me off from the environment.

I do wish they would fold up a little smaller, so Sennheiser will continue to be my traveling headphones, but these have found a place wired to my computer for late night music and video enjoyment. The price is a little high for dedicated wired headphones though.

title: Pack It Along in Style text: I love this bag. The canvas, I chose the brown color, is very heavy duty and has a retro look and feel. There is a large zipper compartment with a soft nylon lining which is quite big enough for any 15" laptop. My Asus X533M fit with room to spare. Zipping the bag closed with my laptop which is no lightweight by any means was not a problem. I ,carefully of course, held and shook the bag by the carry handle, the shoulder straps and the even side pockets with my laptop onboard and all the seams held nicely.
Other pockets for accessories, gear, cables, etc. on the pack a small zipper pocket inside the main laptop compartment as well as another half compartment pocket in the laptop area. Under the large flap that covers the back of the pack and is held down by two magnetic snaps are two generous snap closured pockets. On the sides are two pockets suitable for water bottles or other beverages. These pockets are resizable with a strap and two snaps which are set a few inches apart.
The brown canvas is so very attractive with darker brown strapping and brown contrast edging on the shoulder straps. There are also dark leather pulls on the laptop compartment and a decorative leather patch with the slogan "Taste Emoton On One's Way" Really, I checked twice, I don't get it but it's enigmatic enough to be clever. I'm guessing they mean 'Emotion.'
One small note about the shoulder straps. The pack continues its retro styling on the pack using an old style double chrome ring strapping system to adjust the shoulder strap length. Make sure these are taunt when you use the shoulder straps. This isn't anything against the pack. I was actually pleased to see them stay with the retro styling all around.
I received this item in exchange for my review.

title: More security than I probably even need! text: I have had many Kingston drives and computer parts, and the quality continues to be excellent. I have never had to worry about them being cheaply made or breaking down. This drive continues that tradition.
It is ruggedly made, with a great looking case, as far as external drives go. The touchscreen that you use to access the drive is large and accurate to the touch. The USB acts as the power source, so you don't see anything on the screen until it is plugged in.
Setup was easy: Plug it in and let the drivers load, set a 6 digit PIN. You can setup additional passwords and security features, or emergency wipe protocol!
Security is 256bit, which is the limit you'd need to combat brute force attacks. I don't foresee having anything that someone is going to want to hack, but I am very glad that my documents and pictures are secure, just in case. I am sure there are more features on this device that I will never even use, but they are there if you have a need for even more security than I do.

title: As good as the OEM cable that shipped with my Note 3 text: I wanted a spare charging cable for my Samsung Galaxy Note 3 phone and took a chance on this one. By that I mean that that other USB 3.0 cables that I have tried with the phone would charge it, but would not support full speed data transfers and synching. This one performed without issues and identically to my OEM Samsung cable that came with my phone.

The blue outer jacket is much thicker than the Samsung cable. Although it is slightly stiffer it's also pliable and easy to bend and coil. Part of the reason for the extra thickness is probably from the the foil and braid shielding. In fact, the shielding is one factor in this cable's ability to transmit data at such high speeds without error. Another factor is the gold plated connectors.

The bottom line is this cable seems to be the equal of the more expensive Samsung OEM cable. In my experience anyway. I have owned it for three months and it has been problem free in every respect.

title: A bit inconvenient if you're buying this for kids under 10... text: This is pretty nifty, but it's not as convenient as they make it sound. Here are some things to consider...

1. You can't be handsfree like a microscope, unless you set up your phone with a mini tripod and stuff.
2. It's advertised for kids, but I don't think so, not if they're under 10. My children were very interested, but I had to do all the holding and focusing.
3. Most likely you'll need to take off your phone case for the lens to stick to your camera lens, especially if the case rises above the phone lens. With the case I'm using, there is a very slight rise, almost imperceptible, yet the microscope lens won't stick to my phone because it's sitting on top of part of the case.
4. The lens stick to your phone via some sort of suction/sticky pad. After awhile, it will no longer stick. However, the manual has a solution that did work. You simply use clear tape to clean the dirt off the lens as well as the lens on your phone. It's like when you're putting on a screen protector for you phone, and they provide you with stickers to pick up the dust. Same thing here.. you're using tape to pick up the dust. It actually works. My lens was able to stick again to my phone.

All in all, it's nifty, it's something you're curious about, but after going through with it. I'm 100% sure we won't be using it much. We have a dedicated microscope at home for the kids, and to me, that's still much more convenient. I don't want to take off my phone case, focus the camera for the kids, etc. If you're buying this for yourself.. go for it! If you're buying this, thinking you'll be using it a lot to keep your kids busy, think again. Because it'll end up keeping you busy. LOL!

I'll rate this 4-Stars.

title: easy to install- buy an SD card to go with it text: It took me a little while to get around to writing the review. I hadn't hooked up anything like this before, so it was an entirely new experience for me. In short, I was able to figure it out, with the rear cam being the more complicated of the two in my SUV.

It doesn't come with an SD card, so I bought an SD card and waited for that to arrive before installing the unit/s.

Pros/Cons/Thoughts
The front facing camera looks best. The rear facing cam could have better image.
The field of view on both is impressive; I can tell that I am seeing a lot of my surroundings.
I don't do a lot of night time driving, so at this time I can't give specifics on my experience with that.
I like that camera slides over existing rear view mirror. The mirror isn't as clear as original mirror, but it makes due.

I have seen a lot of dash cam review videos, and while this is still a very new concept to me to put into use, I think it is good to have one. I've seen some that are real grainy, and some that are incredibly clear. I think for the purpose of recording incidents or suspicious activity, that this one would absolutely do a fine job (as well as for backing up purpose). This particular one seems to do the job- you will have decent imaging, ease of use, and installation.

title: Zosi is an excellent company with excellent products. Plugs work great text: They work really well. Zosi is a GREAT security camera company with EVEN GREATER PRICES. I have an 8 cam, 4k system w/2GB HDD and it was barely over 400$. Compared systems were 800+. Their products are made really well to be from China. They also DO NOT have a security problem like 100s of other cams manufactured in china has. (PLEASE DO YOUR RESEARCH BEFORE BUY NEW CAMs OR DVRs, THERE IS ALOT OF BAD COMPANIES WITH SERIOUS FLAWS, ALLOWING YOU TO BE HACKED VERY EASILY)...
These plugs were needed for my audio add-on to my Zosi DVR. They fit tight with zero wiggles, and for the price I was amazed 4$ for 10 plugs. (Cant buy just 2). My old non DVR cams work great with the DVR using these plugs no video loss over 100' distance and once I find an audio device that's worth a damn I'm sure the audio will be top notch. title: Received used item instead. Stopped working in three weeks. Replacement Stopped Working. text: Took a coffee break and left the computer idle. When I returned fifteen minutes later, the monitor no longer worked. It's been in use for about three weeks, and now reports that it has no signal. Windows can see when the monitor is plugged in, but the monitor still reports no signal. Plugging in other monitors which continue to work proves that the problem is not the graphics card or ports.

To say I'm disappointed is a massive understatement.

I'll be asking for a refund as soon as I finish posting this review :-(

[Edited to add] I've received a replacement for the broken monitor, and it was immediately obvious that the monitor they sent me the first time had been used and returned. The tape on this box was new, the interior packaging was different, and there were items in the replacement such as decals and the like that were not present in the first one.

Shame on you for selling me used equipment as new :-(

[SECOND EDIT] The replacement stopped working three months to the day after I started using it. It would appear that the problem wasn't one bad used device, as I'm fairly confident the replacement was new. It seems like this line of monitors is just garbage unfortunately, and that malfunctions are common.

I'm so extremely disappointed.

title: Good Camera With Lots of Accessories text: I am very impressed with this camera. It is a lightweight, easy to use unit that comes with a ton of great accessories. The camera has a fold out screen that you can use for viewing while filming. The hand strap makes it easy to hold the camera while you are creating video. This is a very intuitive camera to operate right out of the box.

The package comes with two batteries that slide into a compartment on the side of the camera. A 16 GB memory card is also included which allows you plenty of memory space for your first videos. There are also two batteries so you can bring a fully charged replacement battery when you're filming on the go.

I like that they also included a slot reader so you can easily take the card from your camera and insert it into a USB port on your computer. This allows you to shoot videos and quickly upload them to the internet. This camera offers a lot of good video recording features at a very economical price.

title: Good picture if set up correctly & in a dim room. I couldn't get all of the inputs to work. text: The biggest difference between this projector & the much more expensive projectors in professional settings is the bulb. This one does a fine job in low light or with back light but will completely wash out with light around or over the screen. I ordered this primarily to do presentations & show videos at my club meetings. It performed well but we did have to fiddle a bit with the lights in the room & the position of the projector.

The usefulness of this projector is its portability & low cost. It is lightweight & compact & fairly easy to set up. I would have appreciated a padded carry case for the projector but the box it comes in works pretty well. It has foam that surrounds the projector, it holds all the cords, it has a handle & it is easily sturdy enough to set the projector on for more height.

It helps a lot with the focus & clarity if the projector is nearly horizontal. That means that if the projection screen is to be 4' over the ground then the projector also needs to be 4' off the ground which is generally going to be much higher than a table. The focus ring around the lens works very well to dial in the clarity. There is a foot that unscrews from the bottom front to angle the projector up. I tried propping something under the front to angle it higher but the image distorts & loses clarity the more it is tilted.

The biggest issue I have had with the projector is the image source. I can't get either of my laptop computers to recognize the projector as an external screen with the HDMI cable but the HDMI works on a DVD player. The IOS control works pretty well with my iPad. My Pixel phone doesn't support the built-in Miracast. The Bluetooth only recognizes my Samsung TV & none of my phones, computers or tablets sees the projector's Bluetooth signal. It has a YouTube app built into the device software but it is un-useable due to a cumbersome search process that doesn't return any results. I ended up using it with a USB thumb drive which works well & the menu is easy enough to navigate but takes some learning. I did not try the AV cable inputs or the SD memory slot.
